headline: Fruit Flies Are Invading Los Angeles. The Solution? More Fruit Flies.
abstract: The Mediterranean fruit fly lays eggs that hatch into maggots inside fruit. Officials plan to halt population growth by dropping millions of sterile male flies over the affected region.
lead_paragraph: The winged creatures were squat, striped and just a quarter-inch in size. But the three Mediterranean fruit flies prompted officials to quarantine the produce of an entire Los Angeles neighborhood. They had a plan to stop the spread: more fruit flies — millions of them.

headline: The fate of many Gazans lies with the Rafah crossing, and Egypt.
abstract: A gateway to the Gaza Strip has allowed some vital aid in but has yet to let anyone get out.
lead_paragraph: On the far side of the Sinai Peninsula, about a six-hour drive from Cairo through a largely empty Egyptian desert, the Rafah crossing is a dun-colored expanse of sand, concrete and not much else. Isolated from the rest of the Egypt by not only distance but also heavy military restriction, Rafah can feel as distant from world events as any place on the planet.

headline: For Europe’s Jews, a World of Fear
abstract: The Oct. 7 Hamas assault on Israel and a surge in acts of antisemitism have awakened a repressed horror in Jewish populations across the continent.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps not since the Holocaust, which saw the annihilation of about two-thirds of Europe’s Jewish community, have the Jews of Europe lived in an atmosphere of fear so acute that it feels like a fundamental shift in the terms of their existence.

headline: Woman Is Accused of Fatally Poisoning Boyfriend With Antifreeze for Inheritance
abstract: Ina Kenoyer, of Minot, N.D., killed her boyfriend with antifreeze after learning he was set to inherit $30 million and planned to leave her, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A North Dakota woman has been accused of fatally poisoning her boyfriend with antifreeze in what the authorities say may have been a plot to claim part of his $30 million inheritance.

headline: Tyler Christopher, Actor Best Known for ‘General Hospital,’ Dies at 50
abstract: His performance as a character sometimes called “the dark prince” won him a Daytime Emmy Award in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Christopher, an actor best known for his long-running role as Nikolas Cassadine on the soap opera “General Hospital,” died on Tuesday in San Diego. He was 50.

headline: Sites of Some Docs
abstract: Steve Weyer makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: Nov. 1, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An Inside the Times article on Oct. 19 about street parking in New York City misstated the number of people who flow through the southern half of Manhattan each weekday. Before the pandemic, 7.7 million people flowed through the area on weekdays; not all of them were commuters.

headline: It’s a Bird. It’s a Dame. It’s Heidi Klum’s Halloween Costume.
abstract: The model and television host dressed as a giant peacock with some help from Cirque du Soleil.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Klum spread her wings this Halloween. Well, technically, several Cirque du Soleil acrobats spread them for her.

headline: They Propelled China’s Rise. Now They Have Nothing to Fall Back On.
abstract: Migrant workers, who moved from China’s villages to its big cities, were a secret weapon building the economy. Now many see few options.
lead_paragraph: When Zhang left his village in northeastern China a decade ago to work as a welder in a big city, jobs were plentiful. He earned about $50 a day and managed to save most of it.

headline: How Germany’s Greens Lost Their Luster
abstract: The party was riding high when it entered the government two years ago. Now it is stumbling, blamed for driving voters to the far right.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s Green Party entered the government in 2021 with the best election showing of its history, establishing itself for the first time as a true mainstream party with the potential of one day even yielding a chancellor.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Israel strikes a crowded area in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes hit a densely populated district in Gaza, leaving behind a massive crater and widespread damage. Israel said the targets were Hamas militants, including a commander who helped plan the Oct. 7 surprise attack on Israel that killed 1,400 people.

headline: Italy’s Prime Minister Broke Up With Her Boyfriend. It’s Actually Quite a Big Deal.
abstract: Giorgia Meloni’s breakup offers a window onto the nature of power in Italy today.
lead_paragraph: Giorgia Meloni broke the glass ceiling again. After becoming the first woman and the first post-fascist leader to be prime minister of Italy, she recently became the first head of government to announce on social media that she had dumped her boyfriend.

headline: Tropical Storm Pilar Kills at Least 1 in El Salvador
abstract: The storm was drifting north toward the Central American country early Wednesday. It was forecast to begin moving west, farther into the Pacific Ocean, later in the day.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains linked to Tropical Storm Pilar have killed at least one person in El Salvador, an official there said early Wednesday, as parts of Central America faced heavy flooding.

headline: Word of the Day: stilted
abstract: This word has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word stilted has appeared in 59 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 11 in “The Radical Act of Eating With Strangers” by Setareh Baig:

headline: Harris Warns That the ‘Existential Threats’ of A.I. Are Already Here
abstract: In London for an artificial intelligence summit, Vice President Kamala Harris urged global leaders to address the technology’s effect on vulnerable groups.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris called on world leaders to tackle threats that artificial intelligence poses to human rights and democratic values in a speech in London on Wednesday. She also announced new measures the Biden administration would take to manage the risks and regulatory challenges of the emerging technology.

headline: Charlamagne Tha God Gets Short With Ron DeSantis on ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: “You know your campaign is going terribly wrong when people only want to talk about your shoes,” the guest host said of rumors that DeSantis wears lifts to appear taller.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Your Guide to the 2023 New York City Marathon
abstract: Everything you need to know about Sunday’s five-borough race.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from the 2023 New York City Marathon.

headline: The Best Places to Watch the New York City Marathon
abstract: It has become the city’s biggest block party. Here are the best spots in each borough to cheer for the race’s 50,000 runners.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Marathon is a big race for more than 50,000 runners each year, but it is also a community celebration for the New Yorkers who line up along the five-borough course to cheer for the participants.

headline: Pay Gap for Women in New York City Is Unchanged Since 2007, Study Says
abstract: A new study finds that women’s pay in the city has declined slightly in the past 25 years, even as it has increased nationally.
lead_paragraph: Progress toward closing the pay gap between men and women in New York City has stalled, even as there has been improvement nationally, according to a new study.

headline: Tammy Murphy, N.J. Governor’s Wife, Prepares to Run for Menendez’s Seat
abstract: Ms. Murphy has never held or sought elected office but is in a strong position to take advantage of the scandal swirling around Senator Robert Menendez.
lead_paragraph: Walled off and under renovation for nearly six years, the governor’s wing in New Jersey’s 231-year-old State House reopened in April after a gut rehab that was years overdue.

headline: Pink Jersey
abstract: Lionel Messi’s eye-catching new jersey is the hottest piece of sports merchandise on the planet. Would you want to wear one?
lead_paragraph: Since Lionel Messi, considered by many to be the greatest soccer player ever, signed with Inter Miami this July, he has made a big splash for his new team — on and off the field.

headline: How a Blind Runner Trains for the New York City Marathon
abstract: Francesco Magisano intends to run the New York City Marathon on Sunday. But first, he is breaking in a new guide.
lead_paragraph: Two men were running side by side in Central Park on a recent morning when one of them bumped into a woman as they passed her. The woman was briefly furious, but her face softened once she saw the tether connecting the men by the waist.

headline: A Story Revealed in Data, Dining and Dosas
abstract: Two designers and graphics editors teamed up with a Food reporter to answer a question that has haunted New Yorkers: How can you snag a hard-to-get restaurant reservation?
lead_paragraph: The two of us have been working together for over four years. We sit face to face at opposite desks in the office. But for one Thursday night in September, we were total strangers.

headline: Trump’s Sons Set to Take Stand at Fraud Trial
abstract: Donald J. Trump, Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump played different roles in the family business. The New York attorney accused them all of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the civil fraud trial against Donald Trump.

headline: Global Leaders Warn A.I. Could Cause ‘Catastrophic’ Harm
abstract: At a U.K. summit, 28 governments, including China and the U.S., signed a declaration agreeing to cooperate on evaluating the risks of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: In 1950, Alan Turing, the gifted British mathematician and code-breaker, published an academic paper. His aim, he wrote, was to consider the question, “Can machines think?”

headline: Neighbour Abdi
abstract: Through reconstructions in a special effects studio, “Neighbour Abdi” embarks on a candid journey through Abdiwahab Ali’s personal history scarred by war.
lead_paragraph: Through reconstructions in a special effects studio, “Neighbour Abdi” embarks on a candid journey through Abdiwahab Ali’s personal history scarred by war.

headline: What Happens When You Reach Out to Your Neighbor?
abstract: Through reconstructions in a special effects studio, “Neighbour Abdi” embarks on a candid journey through Abdiwahab Ali’s personal history scarred by war.
lead_paragraph: After working on several projects that took me far from home — literally and thematically — I felt a strong need to create closer to home. Across the hall, in the building where I rent my studio, Abdiwahab (Abdi) Ali, a furniture designer and social worker, set up shop.

headline: Taking Off From School to Take In the World
abstract: Vacationing during the off-season has long been considered a cost-saving boon. But can families with school-aged children take advantage? Should they?
lead_paragraph: For her family vacation next year, Liz Thimm has booked a 10-day trip to Bocas del Toro, Panama, in February. She requested time off from her pharmacist job a year in advance, checked out guidebooks from the library and has shared itinerary ideas with her daughter and son — who are 11 and 9 — to involve them in the planning process. One thing she has not and will not do? Schedule the trip around a school vacation.

headline: Read Your Way Through Lima
abstract: Lima is a city of contrasts and contradictions — gray and tropical, dense and isolated. Augusto Higa Oshiro, one of its writers, recommended books and authors that have captured its complexity.
lead_paragraph: When I was born, in 1946, Lima was home to 640,000 people. Now, as I’m about to turn 77 in the year 2023, Lima is a city of 10 million. The population has grown more than 15-fold. In some ways, you could say that I’ve survived alongside the city. I’ve gotten to know all 43 of its districts and municipalities, and I can say with true pride that I’ve suffered but also delighted in this gray, sleepy city. As Herman Melville describes it, in “Moby Dick”:

headline: Israel Is in Crisis. These Authors See Reason for Hope.
abstract: In “The Genius of Israel,” Dan Senor and Saul Singer take a look at the economic strength and high quality of life for some of the people who live in a troubled country.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 of its citizens, mostly civilians, were slaughtered in a matter of hours by a militant group thought to be ragtag and toothless. The country’s security services were nowhere to be found. The citizens’ faith in their political leader, a prime minister charged with bribery and fraud, was plummeting even before the attack. For the previous nine months, tens of thousands of protesters had held weekly demonstrations asserting that their beloved nation was being dragged by its populist government into authoritarian penury. Eventually, 360,000 reservists rushed into uniforms to fight the militants, only to find substandard equipment that had to be upgraded with private funds raised by volunteers.

headline: For China’s Jobless Young People, Hostels Are the Place to Be
abstract: Chinese backpacker hostels offering bunk beds for a few dollars a night have become hubs for the anxiety and ambitions of job-seeking youth.
lead_paragraph: In a youth hostel in downtown Shanghai, amid the dull roar of a hair dryer, the shriek of a blender and the lingering aroma of spicy instant noodles, Ethan Yi, 23, was pondering the state of the world.

headline: Grief, Community and Boat Building in a Moving New Novel
abstract: In Elaine Feeney’s latest book, a child’s grief-driven engineering dream connects a handful of isolated citizens in a small Irish town.
lead_paragraph: The Irish writer Elaine Feeney’s atmospheric second novel, “How to Build a Boat,” is set in the small fictional town of Emory, home to 13-year-old Jamie O’Neill and his father, Eoin. Perched on the west coast of Ireland, the town is defined by the River Brú, “an infinite and uninhabitable space” that flows into the Atlantic and holds the characters together in a desperate, watery grasp.

headline: The Republicans Who Want to Invade Mexico
abstract: Hitting fentanyl labs could further destabilize northern Mexico and the borderlands, worsening the migrant refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: As president, Donald Trump reportedly floated the idea of shooting “missiles into Mexico to destroy the drug labs.” When his defense secretary, Mark Esper, raised various objections, he recalls that Mr. Trump responded by saying the bombing could be done “quietly”: “No one would know it was us.”

headline: How Does the World’s Largest Hedge Fund Really Make Its Money?
abstract: Ray Dalio’s investing tactics have always been a closely kept secret, even inside Bridgewater Associates. Several years ago, some of Wall Street’s biggest names set out to discover his edge.
lead_paragraph: For years, the whispered questions have passed from one Wall Street trading floor to the next.

headline: ‘We’re Making Progress’: How the Rock Hall of Fame Is Trying to Evolve
abstract: John Sykes, the chairman of the organization behind the hall, talks about the ouster of Jann Wenner, the need to diversify inductees and surprises at this year’s ceremony.
lead_paragraph: The 38th annual Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony will take place at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Friday, bringing Kate Bush, Willie Nelson, George Michael, Sheryl Crow, Missy Elliott, Rage Against the Machine and the Spinners into pop music’s leading pantheon.

headline: Drought Saps the Panama Canal, Disrupting Global Trade
abstract: The number of ships that can travel through the vital route has fallen sharply this year because of a lack of water for the locks, raising costs and slowing deliveries.
lead_paragraph: For over a century, the Panama Canal has provided a convenient way for ships to move between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, helping to speed up international trade.

headline: One of the Touchiest Housing Decisions: Do We Stay or Do We Go?
abstract: Often, one half of a senior couple wants to remain in the house they long loved, while the other half sees their future unfolding in a continuing care community.
lead_paragraph: There are 39 steps from the spot Gerry Goldsholle and his wife, Myra Levenson, park the car at their four-level wood frame house in Mill Valley, Calif., to where, at the end of each evening, they park themselves.

headline: After Pandemic Rush, South Florida Office Market Sees Steady Demand
abstract: Developers are adding amenities like wellness rooms and restaurants as competition for top buildings remains strong in Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties.
lead_paragraph: For years, Angelo Bianco, a Florida developer, drove past the enormous, wooded IBM corporate campus off Interstate 95 in Boca Raton, Fla., without paying it much heed. But his interest was piqued when a broker informed him that the property was for sale.

headline: Searching for Brian Friel, and His Mythical Ballybeg
abstract: Irish Repertory Theater’s season-long survey of the playwright’s work prompted our reporter to seek out the Irish town that inspired the imaginary site of so many of his plays.
lead_paragraph: Up a steep and grassy windblown hill, in the top row of what’s known as the new graveyard, the playwright Brian Friel lies buried under a dark, glossy slab etched with an image of a St. Brigid’s cross, a traditional Irish symbol woven from rushes.

headline: $1 Million Homes in Delaware, Idaho and North Carolina
abstract: An 1824 townhouse in New Castle, a Tudor Revival home in Boise and a Colonial Revival house in Swansboro.
lead_paragraph: This brick rowhouse is near the waterfront, with views of the Delaware River from the deck and backyard. It is within walking distance of a number of historic sites, including First State National Historical Park; Bull Hill, a park on the site of an old Dutch fort; and New Castle Battery Park, which has a walking path that winds along the riverfront. Nearby Delaware Street is lined with stores and restaurants, including an ice cream shop and a tavern in a circa 1724 building.

headline: If Palestinian Freedom Makes You Uneasy, Ask Yourself Why
abstract: ‘I am undone by empathy’: A Palestinian poet on the fight to exist.
lead_paragraph: “Every time I was told I’d humanized the Palestinians, I would have to suppress the question it invoked: What had they been before?” says the poet, psychologist and professor Hala Alyan, reflecting on her experiences as a Palestinian American. In this audio essay, Dr. Alyan documents how being Palestinian in America is an exercise in auditioning for empathy.

headline: An Orange Cake From a Revolutionary Chef
abstract: Lisa Donovan weaves her own story into this recipe from Paul Bertolli’s “Cooking by Hand.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a corner in most professional kitchens, a small peek into the core of how cooks are all mostly just a bunch of nostalgia queens and hero worshipers, where the books of our revered chefs and mentors reside. In my first kitchen as a professional, we kept all these textbooks by the cereal — usually Cap’n Crunch and Cocoa Pebbles.

headline: The Eternal Life of the ’90s Supermodel
abstract: How did a small group of models manage to stay on top for so long?
lead_paragraph: Bluejeans and little black dresses may be forever, but fashion’s essential promise is change and reinvention. In the same way that clothing styles evolve season after season, the models wearing those looks are in constant flux, articulating whom we consider beautiful, cool and powerful at any given moment. Modeling careers generally aren’t long, though, and depending on how you look at it, the industry’s churn can be thrilling or unnerving. It’s fun to talk about trends in makeup and shoes; it’s horrible to think about trends in people.

headline: If Trump Wins, His Allies Want Lawyers Who Will Bless a More Radical Agenda
abstract: Politically appointed lawyers sometimes frustrated Donald J. Trump’s ambitions. His allies are planning to install more aggressive legal gatekeepers if he regains the White House.
lead_paragraph: Close allies of Donald J. Trump are preparing to populate a new administration with a more aggressive breed of right-wing lawyer, dispensing with traditional conservatives who they believe stymied his agenda in his first term.

headline: The Secret Power of Swearing
abstract: The linguist Geoff Nunberg wrote that “dirty words are magic spells that conjure up their references.”
lead_paragraph: Swearing can be so satisfying that it can help us withstand pain. It can shock, offend and entertain. It can release tension or increase it. It can foster intimacy.

headline: Planting a Field of Lights Where a Developer Hopes to Raise a Casino
abstract: Is an immersive piece featuring 17,000 illuminated, flowerlike stems a precursor to a huge gambling hall along the East River?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out when a field of lights is coming to a vacant lot near the United Nations. We’ll also meet a pianist who has celebrated the Day of the Dead onstage five times a week for the past couple of weeks.

headline: Five Minutes That Will Make You Love Thelonious Monk
abstract: We asked Jon Batiste, Arooj Aftab, Mary Halvorson and others to share their favorites.
lead_paragraph: For over a year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz. Now we’re focusing on Thelonious Monk, the innovative pianist and bandleader whose angular melodies and dissonant chords made him stand out among his peers in the bebop era.

headline: My Sweaty Revenge
abstract: As Christi Clancy was about to teach a spin class, her best friend’s ex-husband walked in. She decided to let him have it.
lead_paragraph: Christi Clancy had been avoiding her best friend’s ex-husband. He’d unexpectedly left her friend for another woman. After supporting her friend through the pain and heartbreak, Christi couldn’t help but resent the ex-husband for all the damage he’d done.

headline: Some of the Lawyers Who May Fill a Second Trump Administration
abstract: Donald Trump’s allies are hoping to install a different species of legal gatekeeper throughout the federal government. Here are some of the potential prospects.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is a year away, but key allies of former President Donald J. Trump are already thinking about staffing a potential administration, including by filling White House and agency legal positions with aggressive and ideologically like-minded lawyers.

headline: How Did Democrats Lose Control of State Agriculture Policy?
abstract: Democrats once dominated statewide elections for the influential post of agriculture commissioner. Now they’re hoping to win just one.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Robertson was preparing to start the workday on his family cattle farm when a campaign ad in the race for agriculture commissioner of Kentucky flashed across his television.

headline: Some Ukrainians Helped the Russians. Their Neighbors Sought Revenge.
abstract: For people in Bilozerka, the invasion began a cat-and-mouse game of collaboration and resistance.
lead_paragraph: Andriy Koshelev steered his car into the driveway of his home on Pushkin Street in Bilozerka, a lakeside town in Ukraine’s Kherson region. Leaving the car on, Koshelev got out and walked to the entrance gate. He reached down to loosen the latch. When he pulled it, the gate exploded. Koshelev’s parents, who lived on the same property, rushed outside as acrid smoke filled their driveway and the street. The explosion resounded across town.

headline: House Blocks Censure of Tlaib on Charge of Antisemitism
abstract: A solid bloc of Republicans joined Democrats in refusing to back a move to formally rebuke Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, a far-left Democrat, for her harsh criticism of Israel.
lead_paragraph: The House on Wednesday turned aside a Republican effort to formally reprimand Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, for her participation in a recent pro-Palestinian protest in which she accused Israel of genocide, as a solid bloc of Republicans joined Democrats to reject the move.

headline: Clash Over ‘Fossil Fuels’ Pits U.A.E. Against Public Health Experts
abstract: A declaration on the public health impacts of climate change may lack two words: fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: Can you talk about the health impacts of climate change without mentioning the burning of fossil fuels, its leading cause?

headline: After Years of Vowing to Destroy Israel, Iran Faces a Dilemma
abstract: With Israel bent on crushing Iran’s ally Hamas, Tehran must decide whether it and the proxy militias it arms and trains will live up to its fiery rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, Iran’s rulers have pledged to destroy Israel. The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, rarely appears in public without wearing a black-and-white checkered Palestinian kaffiyeh.

headline: Does a 2-State Solution, Long Discounted, Still Have a Future?
abstract: As President Biden and other Western leaders promote the idea, some diplomats and analysts say the Hamas-Israel war may breathe new life into it.
lead_paragraph: “There has to be a vision of what comes next,” President Biden said last week of the war between Israel and Hamas. “In our view, it has to be a two-state solution.” The surest path to peace, said Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain, is a two-state solution, a sentiment echoed by President Emmanuel Macron of France.

headline: The Israel-Hamas War Will Reshape Western Politics
abstract: Some ideological trends and tendencies worth watching.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long time since the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians occupied such a central place in Western political attention and debate — certainly not since the Israeli invasion of Gaza in 2009, arguably not since the second intifada ended in 2005.

headline: Biden Travels to Minnesota to Highlight Rural Investments
abstract: The president’s push to focus attention on the domestic economy comes as his administration has been dealing with events overseas after the terrorist attacks in Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Wednesday began a tour of rural communities at a Minnesota hog farm where he lamented the loss of family farms, attacked the corporate consolidation of agriculture and pledged to oversee a renaissance of the American heartland.

headline: Mike Johnson Just Confirmed How Unserious He Is
abstract: The new speaker is playing a game with the world when the world needs American leadership.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for the new House speaker, Mike Johnson, to demonstrate to the world that he will not be a serious partner for American allies or for those who still believe that governing is not a petty little game.

headline: ‘The Embodiment of White Christian Nationalism in a Tailored Suit’
abstract: Mike Johnson’s ascension reflects the strength of white evangelical voters’ influence on the House Republican caucus.
lead_paragraph: Mike Johnson is the first person to become speaker of the House who can be fairly described as a Christian nationalist, a major development in American history in and of itself. Equally important, however, his ascension reflects the strength of white evangelical voters’ influence in the House Republican caucus, voters who are determined to use the power of government to roll back the civil rights, women’s rights and sexual revolutions.

headline: She Wasn’t There to Make Friends
abstract: As recounted in Jennet Conant’s biography, Marguerite Higgins played the high-stakes game of journalism in a man’s world.
lead_paragraph: From the cover of the journalist and best-selling writer Jennet Conant’s biography of the superstar war reporter Marguerite “Maggie” Higgins, its subject beams at the camera. Dressed in army fatigues, pockets stuffed with notebooks and pens, wisps of blond hair escaping from a cap, she looks delighted to be where she is and delighted to see you, too.

headline: Why Pharmacy Workers at CVS and Walgreens Are Protesting
abstract: The actions coincided with a period of increasing labor activism by workers in other sectors, including the auto industry and Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Some pharmacy workers are calling in sick or walking off the job this week to protest what they call inadequate staffing and increasing work requirements, according to protest organizers, and say it’s harder to do their jobs safely.

headline: Lessons From an Unending Conflict
abstract: After three decades of wars and stalemates, Azerbaijan seized Nagorno-Karabakh from ethnic Armenian control seemingly overnight.
lead_paragraph: In late September, one of the world’s most intractable conflicts ended suddenly and brutally when Azerbaijan seized the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh and tens of thousands of ethnic Armenians fled their homes.

headline: A Record 119,300 New York City Students Were Homeless Last Year
abstract: Tens of thousands of migrant children have enrolled in public schools, but many of them do not have a consistent place to live.
lead_paragraph: The number of homeless public school students in New York City reached an all-time high of 119,320 last school year, according to new data released Wednesday, as migrants crossing the southern border continued to flock to the city.

headline: ‘Vague’ iPhone Alert Triggers Serious Accusations of Spying in India
abstract: The notifications suggested that many opposition figures could be under “state-sponsored” surveillance, but even Apple said the warning could have been a false alarm.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen iPhones across India buzzed with the same message earlier this week. Each notification sounded its own little alarm, but was amplified many times over when the targets identified themselves publicly. Most were prominent political opponents of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party.

headline: A Drop in American Gun Violence
abstract: Some progress has been made on firearm violence in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: American gun violence can feel like an unsolvable problem, with every mass shooting, like last week’s killings in Maine, affirming that the situation is getting worse. But the U.S. has in fact made some progress over the past few decades, enacting policies that have saved lives.

headline: An Old Fashioned With … Brandy? This Must Be Wisconsin.
abstract: Two state legislators want to declare this the state cocktail. “I’ve had a couple of calls from people: ‘Don’t you have more important work to do?’” one said.
lead_paragraph: So you’re at a classy party and you approach the bartender. You adjust your tie and ask for an old-fashioned. The charismatic bartender smiles knowingly and reaches for his finest bourbon. But no, you interrupt. You’d like it with brandy.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in November
abstract: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out Keltie Ferris’s  body prints in Chelsea; “Wild Style” memorabilia in SoHo; Joseph J. Greer’s steel sculptures in Chinatown; and Qualeasha Wood’s Jacquard tapestries on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out Keltie Ferris’s scintillating body prints in Chelsea; “Wild Style” memorabilia in SoHo; Joseph J. Greer’s laser-cut steel sculptures in Chinatown; and Qualeasha Wood’s Jacquard tapestries on the Lower East Side.

headline: First Group Has Left Gaza Since the War Began
abstract: Thousands of foreign passport holders and people affiliated with international organizations are set to evacuate from Gaza to Egypt starting on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of thwarted hopes and intensive diplomatic negotiations, the first group of people to evacuate Gaza since the war between Israel and Hamas began on Oct. 7 was beginning to arrive in Egypt.

headline: Investors on Edge as They Await the Fed’s Decision on Rates
abstract: The central bank is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, but Wall Street is growing increasingly anxious over its next move.
lead_paragraph: The Fed hasn’t budged on interest rates since July, and it’s expected to stand pat again today. Still, an anxious Wall Street will be closely watching for any change in the central bank’s higher-for-longer strategy on rates, including the possibility of a new increase as soon as next month.

headline: Why We Need to Talk More Openly About Birth Control Side Effects
abstract: If medical experts don’t address them, snake oil salesmen on social media — and conservative anti-contraception influencers — will.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Axios reported that OB-GYNs “have seen a wave of patients quitting hormonal birth control.” According to Tina Reed, the author of the Axios Vitals newsletter, there’s a small surge of patients who are opting for “natural” birth control. Some may be making this shift because they’re getting health information from social media.

headline: First Group of People Leave Gaza Through Rafah Crossing
abstract: For the first time since Oct. 7, civilians entered Egypt through its border crossing with Gaza.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since Oct. 7, civilians entered Egypt through its border crossing with Gaza.

headline: Offshore Wind Firm Cancels N.J. Projects, as Industry’s Prospects Dim
abstract: Denmark’s Orsted said it would be forced to write off as much as $5.6 billion as wind developers in the U.S. faced wrenching financing costs.
lead_paragraph: Plans to build two wind farms off the coast of New Jersey were scrapped, the company behind them said on Wednesday, a blow to the state’s efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and the latest shakeout in the U.S. wind industry.

headline: Why Wall Street Is So Worried About ‘Refunding’
abstract: A routine announcement by the Treasury Department about its borrowing plans has attracted more attention than usual because of the rapid rise in interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Investors have fixated this week on a routine quarterly announcement of how the government plans to finance itself, a sign of how sensitive Wall Street has become to a rapid run-up in interest rates.

headline: We Don’t Want Kids at Our Dinner Parties. Do We Have to Include Them Anyway?
abstract: A couple is eager to be closer with their new friends, but they worry that insisting that guests arrange for child care will start the relationships off on the wrong foot.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are happily child-free, though most of our new colleagues and friends have young children. Now that the worst of the pandemic seems to be behind us, we are eager to entertain at home and connect with our new friends. The problem: One of us would prefer to invite couples over without their children, so the adults can have a conversation. The other worries about the impression this might create, asking new friends and colleagues to assume the expense and complication of arranging child care. Any thoughts on this?

headline: As Climate Shocks Grow, Lawmakers Investigate Insurers Fleeing Risky Areas
abstract: Insurers are already pulling back from California, Florida and Louisiana. Senate Democrats are trying to find out which states could be next.
lead_paragraph: Faced with growing losses from hurricanes, floods and wildfires, major insurance companies are pulling out of California, Florida and Louisiana — a shift that threatens to undermine the economies of those states.

headline: Those Promotions Promising a ‘Free’ iPhone? It Isn’t Free.
abstract: The so-called iPhone giveaways marketed by Verizon, T-Mobile and AT&T can make customers spend more on perks they don’t need.
lead_paragraph: There’s no such thing as a free iPhone.

headline: Condé Nast, Publisher of Vogue, Will Cut 5% of Its Work Force
abstract: Roger Lynch, the chief executive, said the company was grappling with digital advertising pressures, a decline in social media traffic and shifting audience behaviors.
lead_paragraph: The magazine giant Condé Nast will cut about 5 percent of its work force, backtracking on a much-ballyhooed plan to build up an in-house video studio to tap into Hollywood’s demand for film and TV ideas.

headline: Birds in the Americas Will No Longer Be Named After People
abstract: The American Ornithological Society has committed to replacing all bird names derived from people so as not to honor figures with racist pasts.
lead_paragraph: The American Ornithological Society, the organization responsible for standardizing English bird names across the Americas, announced on Wednesday that it would rename all species honoring people. Bird names derived from people, the society said in a statement, can be harmful, exclusive and detract from “the focus, appreciation or consideration of the birds themselves.”

headline: San Francisco Wants to Eliminate Illegal License Plate Covers
abstract: The city attorney plans to order four websites to stop selling gadgets used to evade the police, tolls and tickets, calling them “like something out of Gotham City.”
lead_paragraph: A suspect speeds through city streets while trying to evade the police and, with the push of a button next to the driver’s seat, lowers an opaque screen over the car’s license plate.

headline: A 500-Year-Old Inca Mummy in Peru Now Has a Face
abstract: A team of scientists worked with an archaeologist who specializes in facial reconstructions to create the silicone likeness of a girl whose remains were found on a volcano in 1995.
lead_paragraph: A famous mummy of a young Inca girl who was sacrificed in a religious ritual more than 500 years ago on a mountaintop in Peru now has a face.

headline: Portland Teachers Are on Strike, Closing Schools in Oregon’s Largest District
abstract: There will be no in person school or online instruction for about 45,000 students in Portland Public Schools.
lead_paragraph: Teachers and other school employees in Portland, Ore., are on strike Wednesday, canceling school for tens of thousands of children in Oregon’s largest school district.

headline: Pilot Accused of Threatening to Shoot Captain Over Potential Diversion
abstract: The pilot, Jonathan J. Dunn, was indicted by a grand jury and accused of interfering with the performance of a crew member by using a dangerous weapon, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A pilot was indicted last month for allegedly threatening to shoot his captain if the flight they were piloting was diverted for a passenger’s medical needs, U.S. officials and court documents said.

headline: Setting a Table at the Whitney With Art
abstract: The Whitney museum commissioned Rashid Johnson and Dyani White Hawk to make works for its cafe spaces, in a partnership with Frenchette Bakery.
lead_paragraph: Culinary passion and art-making can flourish together in the right hands, such as those of Rirkrit Tiravanija, who has explored meals-as-art-medium, and the artist-founded restaurant Food, started in SoHo in the early 1970s by Gordon Matta-Clark and others.

headline: Two More Arrests Made Over Destruction of Sycamore Gap Tree
abstract: More than a month after the tree was mysteriously cut down, the police in Britain said they had arrested two men in their 30s on suspicion of criminal damage.
lead_paragraph: Two men in their 30s were arrested and released on bail on Tuesday in connection with the felling of the Sycamore Gap tree, the latest development in the investigation into who chopped down one of Britain’s most photographed trees, which had stood for two centuries in a dip in Hadrian’s Wall.

headline: Bolivia Cuts Diplomatic Ties With Israel Over Strikes in Gaza
abstract: Chile and Colombia said they were recalling their ambassadors to Israel in light of the strikes.
lead_paragraph: Bolivia has severed relations with Israel over its strikes on Gaza, a diplomatic decision that Israel condemned as a “surrender to terrorism” even as its own ties with other countries in Latin America began to fray.

headline: One Person Dead After Collapse at Kentucky Coal Plant
abstract: A second man was missing after an 11-story building, which was being dismantled, fell.
lead_paragraph: One man was dead and another was missing after a structure collapsed at a coal preparation plant in eastern Kentucky on Tuesday evening.

headline: Huey Lewis and the News Musical Is Coming to Broadway in March
abstract: “The Heart of Rock and Roll” is a romantic comedy featuring songs by the chart-topping 1980s band.
lead_paragraph: “The Heart of Rock and Roll,” a new musical powered by the songs of Huey Lewis and the News, is coming to Broadway in the spring.

headline: Frustrated Zelensky Says Ukraine’s War Effort Is Being Underestimated
abstract: As U.S. officials warned senators against halting military aid, President Volodymyr Zelensky said his troops’ achievements were “perceived as a given.”
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has expressed frustration over what he has labeled unrealistic expectations for rapid success on the battlefield amid concerns that slow progress against entrenched Russian forces will discourage Kyiv’s allies from sustaining military aid.

headline: U.S. Job Openings Were Steady in September
abstract: The Labor Department report is a gauge of how well the labor market can withstand the highest interest rates in two decades.
lead_paragraph: Job openings changed little in September, the Labor Department announced on Wednesday.

headline: Classics for a Reason: Crispy Mustard Chicken, Singapore Noodles and Ambrosia Salad
abstract: Don’t even think about skipping those maraschino cherries.
lead_paragraph: My column this week mines the past for crispy mustard chicken with bread crumbs, a fresh take on a retro classic that I confess I never tasted until I was an adult. When I was growing up, my mother was far too busy trying new recipes and ingredients (sun-dried tomatoes, chicken Marbella, anything with oat bran … oh, the ’80s!) to loop back to meals from her own childhood, even the good ones.

headline: Pregnancy Is an Endurance Test. Why Not Train for It?
abstract: If you’re thinking about having a baby, proactively preparing your body through exercise can make a big difference.
lead_paragraph: Pregnancy can feel like a nine-month feat of strength and stamina, filled with relentless physical challenges, from the extreme fatigue of the first trimester to the breathlessness and back pain of the third.

headline: Celebrating the Music of Ligeti: ‘The Incarnation of a Free Spirit’
abstract: The pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, a friend and collaborator of Ligeti, is helping the New York Philharmonic observe the centennial of his birth.
lead_paragraph: If you are going to salute the composer Gyorgy Ligeti, you might as well ask one of his most dedicated and perceptive collaborators to lend a hand.

headline: Inside the Deadly Maui Inferno, Hour by Hour
abstract: The Times reconstructed the day of the Lahaina wildfire, tracing the path of the blaze and the failures that left so many people trapped.
lead_paragraph: The Times reconstructed the day of the Lahaina wildfire, tracing the path of the blaze and the failures that left so many people trapped.

headline: Infant Deaths Have Risen for the First Time in 20 Years
abstract: The increases were particularly stark among babies born to Native American, Alaska Native and white mothers in 2022. Rates among Black infants remained highest of all.
lead_paragraph: The number of American babies who died before their first birthdays rose last year, significantly increasing the nation’s infant mortality rate for the first time in two decades, according to provisional figures released Wednesday by the National Center for Health Statistics.

headline: My Dying Mom Confessed to Euthanizing My Grandma. Should I Tell My Family?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the complications of honoring a deathbed request.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, a few weeks before my mom died, I spent the night with her in intensive care. In the middle of the night, she beckoned me over to her bed. In a voice hoarse from being intubated the day before, she told me, “I killed Grandma.” She shared that her mother — in her 90s, bedridden and miserable — had asked her to do this out of mercy. My mom consulted what used to be known as the Hemlock Society, an end-of-life care advocacy group, and then found a concoction to fulfill her mother’s wish. She’d held this secret, and now that she was about to die, her conscience got the best of her. She asked me to not tell anyone else in my family. To this day, they think Grandma died in her sleep. I think I’d want to know the truth, but I’m worried they would feel betrayed that my mom never told them. Should this be a case of letting bygones be bygones? — S.W.

headline: In Thirsty Suitors, the Dance Battles Are Powered by Family
abstract: The video game, which follows a South Asian bisexual woman as she navigates relationships, tells a distinctly immigrant story.
lead_paragraph: In an entertainment industry where telling authentic cultural stories has gained importance, the indie video game Thirsty Suitors follows Jala, a South Asian bisexual woman who is returning to her sleepy hometown to a judgmental mother and a host of upset exes.

headline: What Fed Rates Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve will announce their latest decision on interest rates on Wednesday, and although they are expected to keep rates steady, their assessment of the economy often moves markets, with implications for borrowers and savers.

headline: Fed Holds Rates Steady and Pledges to Proceed Carefully
abstract: The Federal Reserve left interest rates at 5.25 to 5.5 percent, but its chair, Jerome Powell, said policymakers could still raise rates again.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday while keeping alive the possibility of a future increase, striking a cautious stance as rapid inflation retreats but is not yet vanquished.

headline: Atlanta’s Dining Scene Feels ‘the Keith Lee Effect’
abstract: When Mr. Lee, a TikTok food reviewer with 14 million followers, visited Atlanta, his reviews gave voice to gripes that some have about parts of the city’s dining culture.
lead_paragraph: When a food critic comes to a city that is proud of its dining scene, restaurants and their devotees take notice. But rarely does a traditional reviewer cause as much excitement as Atlanta has seen with the recent visit of Keith Lee, a food obsessive with a vast army of 14 million followers on TikTok.

headline: This ‘Fairy Queen’ Connects the Dots Between Purcell and Street Dance
abstract: A production featuring graduates of Le Jardin des Voix, run by Les Arts Florissants, with choreography by Mourad Merzouki, comes to Lincoln Center on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A dancer spins on his back gyroscopically, his legs spiraling in the air. He bounces off his shoulders and stands on his head. The moves come from breaking and hip-hop, but the music is Baroque opera, and the words the moves illustrate are classically allegorical.

headline: In Protests Against Israel Strikes, G.O.P. Sees ‘Woke Agenda’ at Colleges
abstract: As the Mideast war escalates, the party’s politicians and activists are casting antisemitic incidents and progressive protests as part of a larger cultural battle over education.
lead_paragraph: The newest front in America’s cultural battles is a war taking place thousands of miles away.

headline: ‘Merry Me’ Review: A Loopy Sex Comedy Focused on Female Pleasure
abstract: Hansol Jung’s new play riffs on Greek dramas, the Restoration comedy “The Country Wife” and Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America.”
lead_paragraph: On an imaginary island off the coast of some enemy state that exists only in fantasy, a navy is becalmed. A blackout is to blame, but it’s the good kind of blackout — the kind that stops a war in its tracks.

headline: Election Day Guide: Governor Races, Abortion Access and More
abstract: Two governorships are at stake in the South, while Ohio voters will decide whether to enshrine the right to an abortion in the state constitution.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates from Election Day 2023.

headline: A ‘Big Whack’ Formed the Moon and Left Traces Deep in Earth, a Study Suggests
abstract: Two enormous blobs deep inside Earth could be remnants of the birth of the moon.
lead_paragraph: Where did the moon come from? The most popular theory says that about 4.5 billion years ago, a Mars-size protoplanet slammed into Earth. Some of the resulting debris, tossed into orbit, coalesced to form the moon.

headline: Stephen King and America’s ‘Gun Problem’
abstract: Readers, including a former F.B.I. agent, respond to the novelist on guns. Also: Freedom of expression; support for Jews; the Vatican synod; climate activism.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: G.O.P.’s Buck Won’t Seek Re-Election, Citing His Party’s Election Denialism
abstract: Representative Ken Buck, one of eight Republicans who moved to oust Kevin McCarthy as speaker, said his split with his party was too wide to remain in the House. Others are likely to follow.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ken Buck, a conservative Colorado Republican who played a central role in ousting Kevin McCarthy from the speakership, said he will not seek re-election next year, citing his party’s election denialism and many members’ refusal to condemn the Jan. 6. 2021, assault on the Capitol.

headline: Israel Confirms Deaths of 15 Soldiers in Ground Invasion of Gaza
abstract: The soldiers’ deaths were the first publicly confirmed by the Israeli military inside Gaza since an invasion began on Friday.
lead_paragraph: At least 15 Israeli soldiers have been killed in battles in northern Gaza since Tuesday as its forces press deeper into the enclave, attacking dozens of targets affiliated with its Hamas rulers, the Israeli military said.

headline: The Family That Turned Malcolm X’s Life Into Opera
abstract: Anthony, Christopher and Thulani Davis collaborated on “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,” which has its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Friday.
lead_paragraph: “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,” which arrives at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, was a family affair. The meditative yet dramatic work has a score by Anthony Davis to a scenario by his younger brother, Christopher Davis, and a libretto by their cousin Thulani Davis.

headline: Biden Found Even Modest Israel-Palestinian Peace Steps Impossible
abstract: A president focused on China and Ukraine had little time or inclination for a distant goal that stymied several of his predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Even as President Biden presses Israel to define clearly the goals of its war against Hamas in Gaza, he is turning his eyes to a much larger endgame: the ever-elusive hope for a lasting peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial Nears Finish as Closing Arguments Are Made
abstract: Prosecutors said Mr. Bankman-Fried had built his FTX crypto exchange into a “pyramid of deceit” while the defense said he was simply a “math nerd” who had no intent to defraud.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman Fried, the onetime cryptocurrency mogul, built his FTX crypto exchange into a “pyramid of deceit” resting on a “foundation of lies and false promises,” a federal prosecutor said on Wednesday at the criminal fraud trial.

headline: George Santos to Keep Seat After House Votes Not to Expel Him
abstract: A group of New York Republicans, eager to distance themselves from their embattled colleague, failed in their push to remove him from office.
lead_paragraph: A Republican-led effort to expel Representative George Santos of New York failed decisively on Wednesday night, after a group of lawmakers from Mr. Santos’s home state could not persuade nearly enough of their colleagues that his admitted lies and federal indictment were sufficient grounds to oust him.

headline: Man Sought in Double Homicide Fatally Shot by Police Officers
abstract: Investigators said the man, who was killed in Brooklyn on Wednesday morning, had fatally shot a father and son after an argument over noise complaints.
lead_paragraph: New York City police officers shot and killed a man on Wednesday morning, three days after investigators said he killed a father and son inside a Brooklyn apartment building during an argument over noise.

headline: In Public Art, Sometimes Subtlety Just Doesn’t Cut It
abstract: At Moynihan Train Hall, Joshua Frankel’s piece functions, whether he wants it to or not, as another ad for us to ignore.
lead_paragraph: Zendaya, the stunning actress, hovers in front of the great Victory of Samothrace at the Louvre, her black cape spreading out to echo the classical statue’s white wings. “BEAUTY IS A LIVING ART,” reads the tagline, in this sleek ad for Lancôme cosmetics playing across the 160-foot width of the video screens in Amtrak’s Moynihan Train Hall.

headline: Transgender Minors and Families Ask Supreme Court to Block Tennessee’s Ban
abstract: Should the Supreme Court agree to hear the case on the state’s ban on transition care for minors, any ruling would reverberate across the legal challenges against other states that have passed similar bans.
lead_paragraph: Transgender youth and their families in Tennessee asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to block the state’s ban on transition care for minors, petitioning the nation’s highest court to intervene for the first time on the issue after a wave of conservative-backed legislation targeting transgender people.

headline: Acapulco Saw the Future of Hurricanes: More Sudden and Furious
abstract: Otis intensified more drastically than all but one other eastern Pacific storm.
lead_paragraph: As of last Monday night in Acapulco, Mexico, no formal hurricane warning had been issued for what would become, barely a day later, the first Category 5 storm ever to make landfall on the Pacific Coast of North or South America.

headline: ‘Wingwomen’ Review: A Crew of Femme Fatales
abstract: A feisty Adèle Exarchopoulos does the heavy lifting in this otherwise uninspired action-comedy set in France.
lead_paragraph: “Wingwomen” is the rare French action movie directed by a woman, Mélanie Laurent, the breakout star of “Inglourious Basterds” turned filmmaker in her native France. Laurent’s seventh feature, a girl-power spectacle, purports to be a naughtier version of “Charlie’s Angels” — its leading three ladies party, smoke and have vigorous libidos — so it’s too bad these spicier elements are muted by the film’s flat tone and derivative style.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in November
abstract: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame ceremony will be live-streamed, and “Julia,” “Fargo” and more return. “The Buccaneers” is among the new series out this month.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Normal People’ and More
abstract: I’m a technology reporter based in Washington D.C. Here are five things I've been reading, watching and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a technology reporter based in Washington D.C. Here are five things I've been reading, watching and listening to.

headline: Supreme Court Wary of Trademark for ‘Trump Too Small’
abstract: In earlier cases, the justices struck down provisions of the trademark law on First Amendment grounds. But the one at issue here seemed likely to survive.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, which has in recent years struck down parts of the trademark law that prohibited registration of immoral, scandalous and disparaging marks, did not appear ready on Wednesday to do the same thing in a case concerning a California lawyer’s attempt to trademark the phrase “Trump too small.”

headline: 2023 Holiday Gift Guide
abstract: Wondering what to get for all the beloved but quirky, picky, fancy, practical or eccentric people in your life? Our experts have curated the best gifts to help you check everyone off your list.
lead_paragraph: Wondering what to get for all the beloved but quirky, picky, fancy, practical or eccentric people in your life? Our experts have curated the best gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

headline: Shanghai’s Halloween Party, a Rare Chance for Chinese to Vent in Style
abstract: Thousands paraded the streets in creative, joyful and provocative costumes in a four-day celebration of a city returning to life.
lead_paragraph: There were evil wizards, TV celebrities and undead beings, yes.

headline: An-My Lê Left Vietnam as a Child. She Returned as a Photographer.
abstract: At MoMA, her images of Vietnam, the American South and the California desert show the vanishing line between boot camp and theater, fiction and truth. They are tour-de-force beautiful.
lead_paragraph: The initial photographs of the Hamas-Israeli war arrived, as if out of nowhere, like a kick to the chest. How could this mutual slaughter be happening, so suddenly, and on this scale? I thought of the American poet Walt Whitman’s stuttering shocked reaction to America’s Civil War. “The dead, the dead, the dead,” he keened, “Our dead — South or North, ours all, all, all, all.”

headline: The Fed Could Inadvertently Get Trump Re-Elected. Should It Care?
abstract: The Fed’s efforts to stay out of partisan politics could end up putting its independence in danger.
lead_paragraph: The names Joe Biden and Donald Trump are scarce on the website of the Federal Reserve. When they do appear in a document, it’s rarely something said or written by a Fed governor or staffer. If the occupant of the White House is mentioned at all, it’s generally as “the president” — a role, not a person.

headline: Heidi Klum, Pauly Shore and Anya Taylor-Joy Party in New York for Halloween
abstract: Ms. Klum drew a crowd to the nightclub Marquee and Ivy Getty hosted an event at the restaurant Jean’s on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, inside Heidi Klum’s Halloween party at the nightclub Marquee in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, guests mixed, mingled and, in an attempt to converse over the din of the thumping music, pressed their faces together and shouted into each other’s ears.

headline: Arnold Diaz, TV Reporter Whose Beat Was to Shame, Is Dead at 74
abstract: A correspondent for three city TV stations, he became famous for his “Shame on You” segments that investigated consumer fraud and aggressively confronted wrongdoers on camera.
lead_paragraph: Arnold Diaz, a brash investigative reporter at three New York City television stations who brought righteous passion to segments that shamed con artists, business owners, scammers, government bureaucrats and others who ripped off consumers, died on Oct. 24 in Greenwich, Conn. He was 74.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Is the Pop Music Machine Stuck in Place?
abstract: With certain headliners hogging up space, where are the new stars? We checked in on recent hits from the radio, streaming services and TikTok.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: In New Hampshire, a Democratic Congressman Debates Ramaswamy
abstract: The meeting between Vivek Ramaswamy, a presidential candidate, and Representative Ro Khanna of California, was largely a showcase for Mr. Ramaswamy to try to rescue a flagging campaign.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, a Republican presidential candidate, and Ro Khanna, a Democratic member of the House, squared off on Wednesday in New Hampshire in what was billed as a civil discussion between two Indian Americans over the future of the United States.

headline: Don Laughlin, Who Turned a Patch of Desert Into a Casino Mecca, Dies at 92
abstract: There was just a dirt road and a boarded-up motel in 1964 when he first saw the area at the southern tip of Nevada that would be named after him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Laughlin, who transformed a stretch of desert about 100 miles south of Las Vegas into a sprawling casino boomtown that he named after himself, died there, in Laughlin, Nev., on Oct. 22. He was 92.

headline: Trump 14th Amendment Disqualification Trial Can Continue, Judge Rules
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s team had argued that his words and actions leading up to the attack on the Capitol were protected by the First Amendment, and asked that the Colorado case be thrown out.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado judge on Wednesday refused a request from lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump to throw out a case challenging his eligibility to hold office again, saying she was not yet prepared to decide on what she called “significant legal issues, many of which have never been decided by any court.”

headline: A Brunch for Both the Living and the Dead
abstract: The chef Dominica Rice-Cisneros and the artist Momoca wove together Mexican and Japanese harvest traditions for a meal at the restaurant Bombera in Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Stepping into the courtyard of Bombera, the acclaimed Mexican restaurant in Oakland, Calif., always feels like arriving at a party. Papel picado in marigold orange and saffron yellow flutters overhead, seemingly waving guests into the space, an airy former firehouse. But the restaurant reaches its full splendor in the fall, when the dining room is decorated in preparation for Mexican Day of the Dead.

headline: Are Energy Drinks Safe? A New Lawsuit Raises Questions.
abstract: A woman’s death after drinking a Panera “charged lemonade” has renewed the debate over the health risks of highly caffeinated drinks.
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit over the death of a 21-year-old with a heart condition who died last year after drinking a highly caffeinated lemonade at Panera Bread has renewed longstanding questions about the safety of energy drinks.

headline: Limited Flight From Gaza Strip Begins, as Israelis Close In on Main City
abstract: Hundreds of people, including a few Americans, left the besieged territory for Egypt, the first group allowed across the border since the war began.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of waiting, hundreds of people were allowed to leave the besieged Gaza Strip on Wednesday, the first of thousands of foreigners, aid workers and critically wounded patients who were expected to exit in the coming days, as two million increasingly desperate people remained behind.

headline: David Mitchell, Weekly Editor Who Exposed a Corrupt Cult, Dies at 79
abstract: His tiny California newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize for its exposé of Synanon, a renowned drug rehabilitation program that had turned into a violent operation.
lead_paragraph: David Mitchell, a muckraker whose tiny California newspaper challenged the violent drug rehabilitation cult Synanon and, as a result, became one of only a handful of weeklies to win a Pulitzer Prize, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Point Reyes Station, Calif., in Marin County. He was 79.

headline: Alaska Man Threatened to ‘Kidnap and Injure’ a U.S. Senator, Police Say
abstract: The threat was sent by email in late September, according to the Capitol Police, who did not identify the senator.
lead_paragraph: An Alaska man threatened to “kidnap and injure” a United States senator, the Capitol Police told a federal judge, in the latest example of elected U.S. officials facing direct threats to their physical safety.

headline: Teachers, How Are You Addressing the Israel-Hamas War in Your Classrooms?
abstract: As the conflict intensifies, we wonder how, if at all, you are discussing it with students. Please share your thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several weeks, schools have wrestled with how — and whether — to talk to their students about the Israel-Hamas war. The Hamas attack on Israel and the subsequent Israeli bombardment of Gaza have killed thousands of civilians.

headline: Pairing Celebrity With Audiobook? It’s a ‘Kind of Matchmaking.’
abstract: Snippets of Michelle Williams’s narration of Britney Spears’s new memoir have proved explosively popular online. But what goes into selecting a celebrity reader for an audiobook?
lead_paragraph: It’s not clear how many takes it took to get that “fo’ shiz, fo’ shiz” just right in the recording studio. But however many it was, the actress Michelle Williams landed on a line reading that has resonated on social media.

headline: Judge Hints at a Delay in Trump Documents Trial
abstract: Responding to a request from the former president’s lawyers, Judge Aileen Cannon said she could make “reasonable adjustments” to the timetable for the trial, which is scheduled to start in May.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of mishandling classified documents signaled on Wednesday that she was inclined to make some “reasonable adjustments” to the timing of the case, expressing concern that it could “collide” with Mr. Trump’s other federal trial.

headline: Thursday Briefing: The First Evacuees Leave Gaza
abstract: Plus four days of Halloween in Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: As Israeli forces neared Gaza City yesterday, a multinational deal allowed scores of people — including seriously wounded Palestinians and some with dual nationalities — to enter Egypt from Gaza. They were the first such exits from Gaza since the start of the war.

headline: Federal Reserve Continues to Hold Interest Rates Steady
abstract: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced that interest rates will remain unchanged with a hope that it will lead to price stability and bring down inflation in the future.
lead_paragraph: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced that interest rates will remain unchanged with a hope that it will lead to price stability and bring down inflation in the future.

headline: The Battle Over Aid to Israel
abstract: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
lead_paragraph: The battle over aid to Israel continues to heat up in Washington. While President Biden has proposed a $105 billion package that would distribute aid to Israel, Ukraine and other corners of the world, Mike Johnson, the newly-elected Republican House Speaker, has put forth a package that only addresses aid to Israel.

headline: Climb Aboard Brazil’s Hurricane Truck of Happiness
abstract: We joined a traveling dance crew to understand how they have become a popular, irreverent slice of Brazilian culture.
lead_paragraph: We joined a traveling dance crew to understand how they have become a popular, irreverent slice of Brazilian culture.

headline: Evacuees From Gaza Arrived in Egypt
abstract: Also, the Fed holds rates steady. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people left Gaza and entered Egypt today, the first such exits since the start of the war between Hamas and Israel. They included some people with foreign or dual nationalities as well as seriously injured Palestinians and their families.

headline: Haley Meets With Miriam Adelson, G.O.P. Megadonor
abstract: As Nikki Haley has jumped in presidential polling, her campaign has stepped up its outreach efforts.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador who has been climbing in Republican presidential polls, met with the casino mogul and megadonor Miriam Adelson over the weekend in Las Vegas, two people familiar with the meeting said.

headline: In Gazan Neighborhood Hit by Airstrikes, Death and Despair Reign
abstract: On Wednesday, the devastated neighborhood, where local officials say dozens were killed and hundreds were wounded in a Tuesday attack, was hit again.
lead_paragraph: A day after an Israeli airstrike thundered across a densely populated Gaza Strip neighborhood, Palestinians trying to reach family members there to learn their fates were met largely with unnerving silence.

headline: Disney Says It Will Take Full Control of Hulu
abstract: The company will pay at least $8.61 billion to Comcast, which owned a 33 percent stake of the popular streaming service.
lead_paragraph: The tug of war over Hulu is over.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Denies Responsibility for Company Business Statements
abstract: The former president’s son began the Trump family’s parade to the witness stand in the civil fraud case.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the civil fraud trial against Donald Trump.

headline: Virginia Erroneously Purged Nearly 3,400 From State’s Voter Rolls
abstract: The disclosure came just a week before an election that will decide control of the state’s closely divided legislature.
lead_paragraph: Virginia erroneously purged almost 3,400 voters from the state’s rolls, election officials said in the run-up to statewide elections on Tuesday.

headline: Bobby Knight, Basketball Coach Known for Trophies and Tantrums, Dies at 83
abstract: Knight raised Indiana to the national top tier while upholding academic standards, but he was notorious for the rage he directed at players and referees.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Knight, one of college basketball’s signature coaches and a singular personality renowned for his tempestuousness and hubris, qualities that helped take him to the pinnacle of his sport but that also tainted his success, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 83.

headline: Man Who Stormed Capitol as Princeton Student Gets 2-Month Prison Term
abstract: Larry Giberson was a sophomore studying political science when he joined the riot in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old New Jersey man was sentenced to two months in prison on Wednesday for taking part, as a Princeton University student, in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by a mob loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: I Grew Up in Mike Johnson’s District, Where Kindness Can Mask Cruelty
abstract: Where he and I are from, even would-be oppressors can be affable.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know Mike Johnson, the brand-new speaker of the House of Representatives, but I feel as if I do because we’re from the same neck of the woods. He’s from Shreveport, in Caddo Parish, La., where I was born and where one of my brothers died.

headline: Here’s What Doesn’t Happen After a Mass Shooting
abstract: Another slaughter, another congressional nothingburger.
lead_paragraph: A few things you can bet on when there’s been a terrible mass shooting in this country.

headline: The Words in the Middle East That Are Breaking My Heart
abstract: When children on both sides are slaughtered and people are fearful, it is extremists who invariably are ascendant.
lead_paragraph: One reason I’m afraid that the worst is yet to come in the Middle East is that the mutual dehumanization is the most savage I’ve ever seen in decades of on-the-ground reporting in the region.

headline: Risk of a Wider Middle East War Threatens a ‘Fragile’ World Economy
abstract: After shocks from the pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, there’s little cushion if the fighting between Hamas and Israel becomes a regional conflict.
lead_paragraph: Fears that Israel’s expanding military operations in Gaza could escalate into a regional conflict are clouding the global economy’s outlook, threatening to dampen growth and reignite a rise in energy and food prices.

headline: Indiana Man Charged in 1982 Halloween Killing
abstract: Clifford Smith, 24, was killed by his brother-in-law more than four decades ago, the authorities said. Mr. Smith’s relatives said they had long held suspicions about the suspect.
lead_paragraph: Tammy Anderson, 57, felt unnerved as four Indiana State Police troopers arrived at her apartment on Tuesday to arrest her husband, who never liked to talk much about his past.

headline: Student Protesters Walk Out of Hillary Clinton’s Class at Columbia
abstract: The action was in protest of what they had perceived as the school’s role in publicly shaming students who had signed a statement saying that “the Israeli extremist government” bore responsibility for the war.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 300 students were seated at Columbia University on Wednesday afternoon for a two-hour lecture on women’s involvement in peace processes delivered by Hillary Clinton and Keren Yarhi-Milo, the dean of Columbia’s School of International and Public Affairs.

headline: Dwight Twilley, Power-Pop Hitmaker, Is Dead at 72
abstract: With a sound inspired by the Beatles and Elvis Presley, he climbed the charts and drew critical praise in the 1970s and ’80s. But long-term stardom proved elusive.
lead_paragraph: Dwight Twilley, a singer and songwriter from Tulsa, Okla., who fused Merseybeat melodicism with a chugging rockabilly energy, earning critical praise if not stardom as a progenitor of what came to be called power pop, died on Oct. 18 in Tulsa. He was 72.

headline: Britney Spears’s Memoir Sells 1.1 Million Copies in U.S. in First Week
abstract: Sales of “The Woman in Me,” which chronicles the pop star’s life, from stardom as a teen to the conservatorship that controlled much of her adulthood, demonstrate tremendous interest in Spears’s story.
lead_paragraph: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “The Woman in Me,” sold 1.1 million copies in all formats in the United States in its first week on sale, the book’s publisher, Gallery Books, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Biden to Visit Maine After Lewiston Massacre
abstract: The deadliest mass shooting of the year will present the president with the familiar ritual of comforting grieving families. He will likely also press his case for gun control.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will travel to Maine on Friday to pay his respects to the 18 people killed and more than dozen wounded during a gunman’s rampage through a bar and bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, last week, the White House announced.

headline: Pennsylvania Woman Is Awarded $7.1 Million in Damages From Conagra
abstract: The parent company of Pam and other well-known brands was sued after a can of cooking spray exploded, causing second-degree burns on a woman’s upper body, including her face and arms.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Illinois ordered Chicago-based Conagra Brands to pay $7.1 million to a Pennsylvania woman who was badly burned when a can of cooking spray caught fire at her workplace kitchen.

headline: ‘Poor Yella Rednecks’ Review: A Writer’s Origin Story Remixes Conventions
abstract: Qui Nguyen’s crowd-tickling comedy about a Vietnamese family in Arkansas mixes hip-hop and martial arts with soapy twists and turns.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Qui Nguyen has made a career of imagining marginalized people as heroic leads. That includes his parents, who emigrated from Vietnam and met in an Arkansas refugee camp, a story Nguyen chronicled in his raunchy rom-com-style play “Vietgone.”

headline: Do You Mind?
abstract: Chase Dittrich and Christina Iverson’s crossword messes with our brains, but that’s Thursday puzzles for you.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Quotation of the Day: Familiar Fear Gripping Jews Across Europe
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “France is seeing a wave of antisemitism not equaled since 1945.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 2, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the dilemma Israel faces as it seeks to destroy Hamas and free hostages in Gaza misstated the day that the Israeli military said that Pvt. Ori Megidish had been rescued. They announced her rescue on Monday, not Tuesday.

headline: Toyota Recalls 1.8 Million RAV 4 S.U.V.s Over Potential Fire Risk
abstract: Toyota said on Wednesday that some of the vehicles, which span model years 2013 to 2018, may be equipped with replacement batteries that are too small.
lead_paragraph: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, on Wednesday recalled over 1.8 million RAV 4 sport utility vehicles spanning several model years because a replacement battery could pose a fire risk.

headline: Taylor Tomlinson to Host New CBS Late-Night Show after ‘Colbert’
abstract: The popular comedian will take over the show, which is based on “@midnight,” at a time when the job is being held only by men.
lead_paragraph: In a shake-up of the late-night television landscape, the stand-up comic Taylor Tomlinson, 29, will take over the time slot after “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS. The move makes her not just the only woman in the job on a late-night show on network television now, but also the youngest by two decades.

headline: China Is Winning in Solar Power, but Its Coal Use Is Raising Alarms
abstract: China is building as much clean energy capacity over four years as it had promised to build in 10 years, but continues to add coal-fired power plants.
lead_paragraph: China is installing about as many solar panels and wind turbines as the rest of the world combined, and is on track to meet its target for clean energy six years early. It is using renewables to meet nearly all of the growth in its electricity needs.

headline: The Two Things Worrying U.S. Military Officials About Israel and Hamas
abstract: Israel, Iran, Ukraine and Russia are driving so much about geopolitics today.
lead_paragraph: Step back far enough, and you can see exactly what is driving so much geopolitics today: Ukraine is trying to join the West. Israel is trying to join a new Middle East. And Russia and Iran have teamed up to try to block both.

headline: Mercenaries or Volunteers? Economic Pain Pushes Colombian Veterans to Ukraine
abstract: Hundreds of experienced fighters have joined Kyiv’s ranks to improve their financial fortunes, reflecting the recruitment struggles faced by both sides of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Barrios joined the battle against Russian forces in Ukraine because a bank threatened to repossess his home in Colombia.
