Luis Alejandro Herrera returned to the front to recover the savings he lost in a failed attempt to enter the United States through Mexico. Jhoan Cerón fought to provide for his toddler.

headline: The Horrifying Images Are Real. But They’re Not From the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: Videos and photos of the conflict are competing with misappropriated depictions of unrelated tragedies, a cycle that experts say diminishes the experiences of victims past and present.
lead_paragraph: In a video circulating online meant to convey the horrors of the war between Israel and Hamas, a small boy wails, his face caked in dust. Clinging to the sandwich he was eating when an airstrike razed his family’s home, he sobs for his two teenage sisters lost amid the chaos, one of whom would later be confirmed dead.

headline: No Nation in the World Is Buying More Planes Than India. Here’s Why.
abstract: While most Indians travel by road or rail, the country is engaged in a major expansion of its aviation industry to serve the needs of its middle class.
lead_paragraph: No nation in the world is buying as many airplanes as India. Its largest airlines have ordered nearly 1,000 jets this year, committing tens of billions of dollars to a spending spree that is unparalleled in aviation. In New Delhi, Indira Gandhi International Airport will be ready for 109 million passengers next year, as it prepares to become the world’s second busiest, behind Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport in the United States.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: The first evacuees leave Gaza.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of waiting, hundreds of people were allowed to leave the besieged Gaza Strip yesterday, the first of thousands of foreigners, aid workers and critically wounded patients expected to depart in the coming days.

headline: China’s Male Leaders Signal to Women That Their Place Is in the Home
abstract: The Communist Party’s solution to the country’s demographic crisis and a slowing economy is to push women back into traditional roles.
lead_paragraph: At China’s top political gathering for women, it was mostly a man who was seen and heard.

headline: Ady Barkan, Health Care Activist Spurred by His Illness, Dies at 39
abstract: Mr. Barkan campaigned for Medicare for all while struggling with A.L.S., the terminal neurodegenerative disease.
lead_paragraph: Ady Barkan, a well-known activist who campaigned for Medicare for all while struggling with the neurodegenerative disease A.L.S., died on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 39.

headline: Woman Charged With Murder in Suspected Mushroom Poisoning Case
abstract: In a case that has gripped Australia, three people fell ill and died soon after eating lunch at the home of a relative.
lead_paragraph: Three of the four guests who attended a family lunch in a quiet Australian country town died shortly afterward, with symptoms the police said were consistent with mushroom poisoning. The fourth spent nearly two months hospitalized, critically ill.

headline: Word of the Day: vanguard
abstract: This word has appeared in 203 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word vanguard has appeared in 203 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 15 in “Union Push by Dartmouth Athletes Is Distinct From Previous Failed Efforts” by Santul Nerkar:

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Wind Power, Key to Democrats’ Climate-Change Goals, Faces a Crisis
abstract: Instead of gathering momentum, the industry is confronting obstacles that could hinder its ability to realize the renewable resource’s promised benefits.
lead_paragraph: Before the end of this year, thousands of families in New York could be using electricity produced by a wind farm off the eastern tip of Long Island that will be the state’s first.

headline: Today, Shapewear. Tomorrow, the World.
abstract: Kim Kardashian’s Skims hooks up with Swarovski to bedazzle the body.
lead_paragraph: One Friday afternoon, not long after unleashing the “Skims ultimate nipple bra” on the internet — a bra with a built-in erect nipple — and just before announcing that Skims was going to be the official underwear partner of the N.B.A., W.N.B.A. and USA Basketball, Kim Kardashian was sitting in her office in Calabasas, Calif., framed by two picture windows that offered views of manicured green lawns, and talking about size. Specifically, how big she wanted Skims to be.

headline: Asian Americans’ Political Strength and Alliances Face Test in New York
abstract: Whether they stick with Democrats or continue their shift to the right, Asian American voters will help decide competitive races on Nov. 7.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, many Asian American voters in New York City demonstrated their political muscle by voting for Republicans in traditional Democratic enclaves, voicing their concerns about crime and education while sending a warning signal to Democrats.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Painting
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Engaging and Aging on ‘The Golden Bachelor’
abstract: Two members of The New York Times’s Culture section discuss how a twist on a decades-old reality series has become must-watch television.
lead_paragraph: In August, Julia Jacobs visited a Mediterranean-style mansion in Agoura Hills, Calif., the backdrop of “The Golden Bachelor.” The show is a spinoff of the popular “Bachelor” reality TV franchise, with a surprising twist: Participants are at least 60 years old.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: Donald Trump Jr. Is ‘The Fraudigal Son’
abstract: Late night hosts poked fun at the former president’s eldest son after he testified on Wednesday in the civil fraud trial against the Trump family and their company.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: An ‘Israel Explainer’ Makes Her Country’s Case in America
abstract: Once a celebrated actress in Israel, Noa Tishby has emerged as a leading pro-Israel voice on U.S. TV, on social media and in print.
lead_paragraph: On a stage in Los Angeles last week, two Israeli-born women sat before a rapt audience, discussing their grief and anger in the wake of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas terrorists. More than 500 people had crowded into a synagogue auditorium to listen, and 400 more tuned in via Zoom.

headline: Her Clothes? Fabulous. Her Face? A Fungus.
abstract: Ewa Juszkiewicz’s paintings depict well-dressed women whose faces are hidden by mushrooms, textiles and wild hairdos.
lead_paragraph: Ewa Juszkiewicz was staring at a portrait of Katarzyna Starzenska, a Polish aristocrat and social fixture, completed in 1804.

headline: Kenyan Runners Set the World’s Pace, Chased by a Doping Crisis
abstract: Nearly 300 athletes from Kenya have been punished for using banned substances since 2015, tarnishing the country’s image as a running powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: When Kelvin Kiptum, of Kenya, broke the world marathon record in early October, he threatened a landmark barrier of human possibility: running 26.2 miles in less than two hours in a competitive race.

headline: Rashida Tlaib Draws Attack Ads From Pro-Israel Democratic Group
abstract: Ms. Tlaib, the only Palestinian American in Congress, has been a leading critic of Israel, drawing condemnation from the country’s Democratic supporters.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic pro-Israel group on Thursday is beginning to air television ads that criticize Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, in the first attempt to hit back on the airwaves at the growing caucus of Israel skeptics within the Democratic Party.

headline: ‘More Than Just Rugby’: Championship Generates Harmony in South Africa
abstract: South Africans are savoring a second consecutive World Cup victory, producing a racial unity that even Hollywood couldn’t make up and an escape from the country’s troubles.
lead_paragraph: The towering hall thundered with the euphoria of a nation where everyone seemed, for the moment, to have left their differences behind.

headline: After the Divorce, a Different Kind of Family
abstract: This couple survived tragedies during their relationship, but they couldn’t overcome tight finances and a drinking problem. Today, their love “is like that of brother and sister.”
lead_paragraph: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: Jeff Tweedy Used to Browse Encyclopedias for Hours on End
abstract: “I read them the way that people surf the internet today, maybe,” says the Wilco frontman, whose new memoir is “World Within a Song.” “So I know everything.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: 36 Hours in Durham, N.C.
abstract: The North Carolina city’s evolution from a faded tobacco town to a diverse cultural and culinary destination has been years in the making.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina city’s evolution from a faded tobacco town to a diverse cultural and culinary destination has been years in the making.

headline: Progressive Freshmen Toil to Find Their Footing in a Hard-Right House
abstract: Stymied on legislation and far from the ideological base of power in the Republican-led House, Representative Becca Balint of Vermont and her fellow liberal freshmen look to one another for support.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Becca Balint saw on an encrypted text chain she uses to communicate with other Democratic women that Republicans planned to try to censure a fellow progressive, Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, for participating in a pro-Gaza rally last month at the Capitol, she was angry.

headline: Welcome to Ed Park’s Many-Layered World
abstract: “Same Bed Different Dreams” is the rare sophomore novel that has the wild, freewheeling ambition of a debut.
lead_paragraph: Just after I’d registered for my first semester of college courses, I was meandering among a concourse of clubs and teams, fending off their grinning ambassadors, when a newspaper headline caught my eye: “U.S. Says Soviet Downed Korean Airliner; 269 Lost.” By today’s standards the KAL 007 tragedy seems like a distant relic of Ronald Reagan’s “evil empire” rhetoric, but at the time it was a Cold War grenade: Jet fighters scrambled, sabers rattled, tinfoil-hat theories spiked. Late in his lush, labyrinthine “Same Bed Different Dreams,” Ed Park recreates that moment, twisting the doomed flight’s number into a James Bond motif that resonates throughout the novel. Double agents, sinister corporations, slasher films, U.F.O.s: If Park’s suitcase is stuffed, well, it’s an inspired choice for an odyssey that unpacks, in Pynchonesque fashion, Korean history and American paranoia.

headline: Kirsty MacColl’s Voice Was Singular. A New Box Aims to Bring It Wider.
abstract: The singer-songwriter, who died in 2000, is best known for duetting on “Fairytale of New York.” But in an unusual career, she also made her mark behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: During a fitful 20-year solo career, the singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl released just five full-length albums, achieving a modicum of success in her native England, and little notice in America. Yet MacColl — who died at 41 in 2000 — is omnipresent each holiday season: It’s her voice offering tart rejoinders to Shane MacGowan in the Pogues’ cockeyed Christmas anthem “Fairytale of New York.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Thanksgiving Gift Boxes
abstract: One family gives presents to their guests. Is it too much?
lead_paragraph: Paul writes: My wife and I host American Thanksgiving in Toronto. We give our guests small gift boxes. Lately, my wife has been buying and wrapping extra gifts that don’t fit in the box. I say this is too much.

headline: Jeff Tweedy: I Thought I Hated Pop Music. ‘Dancing Queen’ Changed My Mind.
abstract: It feels good to come clean.
lead_paragraph: It’s important to admit when you’re wrong. And though I once bristled at the notion that there could ever be such a thing as a wrong musical opinion, I have since come to accept that there is, in fact, such a thing. I know because I had one: I was colossally wrong about the song “Dancing Queen” by Abba.

headline: Poem: […]
abstract: In this poem from a Palestinian American writer, absence becomes atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Fady Joudah’s poem, written in the past few weeks, begins with its title’s conspicuous absence. The square brackets that conventionally indicate the first line of an untitled poem here surround an ellipsis, the typographical mark of omission. The weight of the unsaid and the unspeakable, the lost and the left out, hangs over the poem’s head. Perhaps it is Palestine. What is missing defies proportion. It could be as vast as history, as small as a child’s breath. Absence becomes atmosphere. America becomes object: a proverbial impossibility, both the flood and the ark. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: Looking for a Slam-Dunk Place to Eat? Just Ask an N.B.A. Player.
abstract: The best basketball players on the planet travel regularly, embrace local cultures and have deep pockets — making them very credible reviewers of restaurants across the country.
lead_paragraph: Pick a city, any city, on the National Basketball Association’s 30-team circuit, and Kelly Olynyk, a forward for the Utah Jazz, has deep knowledge of the local restaurant scene.

headline: What Question Would You Ask a Politician?
abstract: A 15-year-old has been asking presidential candidates tough questions on the campaign trial. What questions would you pose to someone in a position of power?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wanted to ask a politician, or someone in a position of power, a tough question but were too afraid to ask?

headline: Who Is Hannah Grace? And Why Won’t She Show Her Face?
abstract: The author of “Icebreaker” and “Wildfire” has her own reasons for avoiding the limelight.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Grace doesn’t have an author photo. She doesn’t do events. Neighbors in Manchester, England, don’t know that she’s written two best sellers, “Icebreaker” and “Wildfire,” nor do they know that the unassuming 30-year-old traded her corporate job to become a full-time novelist last year. That’s because Hannah Grace isn’t her real name; it’s a nom de plume.

headline: In Shetland, the Hottest Event of the Year Stars Sheep and Knitters
abstract: The festival of the intricately crafted textiles of the Shetland Islands, a remote archipelago off Scotland’s coast, draws hundreds of knitters from around the world for all things wool.
lead_paragraph: The sheep came spilling over the hillside, emerging through the low mist where the green earth touched the gray sky, running down into the fields below.

headline: With ‘Lovers Grave,’ Tracey Emin Returns, at Full Emotional Volume
abstract: Her illness, her traumas and thorny romantic entanglements are writ loud in her art, on view at White Cube Nov. 4.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Emin carried around a giant tote decades before enormous handbags were fashionable. Back then, in the 1990s, when she was emerging as a gale-like force in a loosely affiliated group that came to be known as the Young British Artists, people often asked her — journalists, fans on London streets — What do you keep in there? She says the real answer was usually a sketch pad, her daily ration of three packs of Marlboro Lights, six Stella Artois beers and a fifth of brandy, but it was easier to say she needed a bag big enough to haul all her insecurities.

headline: The People of Clallam County Haven’t Gotten It Wrong Since 1980
abstract: Voters in one part of Washington State have picked the winner in every presidential election from Reagan to Biden. What do they think now?
lead_paragraph: Clallam County in Washington State is far from Washington, D.C. — almost as far as you can go without leaving the continental United States.

headline: Bistate Battle Over Congestion Pricing Escalates With New Lawsuit
abstract: The mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., is suing New York to halt what he says is the harm the new tolling system will do to his city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out about a second lawsuit from New Jersey challenging New York’s congestion-pricing plan. We’ll also look at a wristwatch that belonged to Andy Warhol, who said everyone would be famous for 15 minutes.

headline: DeSantis Leans Into Vaccine Skepticism to Energize Struggling Campaign
abstract: The Florida governor has so far found little success in getting his criticism of the Trump administration’s Covid-19 policies to stick, but that has not stopped him from trying.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis  had hoped that his response to the coronavirus pandemic, which helped propel him to a resounding re-election in Florida last year, would produce similar results in the Republican presidential primary.

headline: The Democrats Are Their Own Worst Enemies
abstract: John B. Judis and Ruy Teixeira say the Democratic Party is failing in matters of culture and in matters of class.
lead_paragraph: This should be the Democratic Party’s moment. Donald Trump’s stranglehold has lurched the G.O.P. toward the fringe. Republican congressional behavior echoes that of an intemperate toddler and the party’s intellectual and ideological foundations have become completely unmoored.

headline: Is a $500 Marathon Shoe You Can Race In Only Once Worth It?
abstract: A new Adidas model carried a runner to a world record. Athletes say they can feel a difference, but it comes with a high price tag and wears out quickly.
lead_paragraph: When Ashley Mateo went through a recent track workout, something felt different. She hit her intervals faster than usual, her heart rate was lower, and her feet felt lighter. When she ran her next marathon, she achieved a personal record.

headline: Can a Democrat Running the Biden Playbook Win in Deep-Red Kentucky?
abstract: Gov. Andy Beshear, the popular incumbent, is campaigning for re-election on abortion rights, the economy and infrastructure — but distancing himself from the unpopular president.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates from Election Day 2023.

headline: A Tangle of Rules to Protect America’s Water Is Falling Short
abstract: The Times asked all 50 states how they police the use of valuable groundwater. Their answers reveal why the country is draining and damaging its aquifers so rapidly.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked all 50 states how they police the use of valuable groundwater. Their answers reveal why the country is draining and damaging its aquifers so rapidly.

headline: ‘You Don’t Want to Be the Only One Sitting at the Table,’ Mitt Romney Says
abstract: It’s a wretched time to be an institutionalist in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: It’s a wretched time to be an institutionalist in the Republican Party. But it’s a vital time to read about one.

headline: The Signs Were All There. Why Did No One Stop the Maine Shooter?
abstract: Shortcomings in mental health treatment, weak laws and a reluctance to threaten personal liberties can derail even concerted attempts to thwart mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: Robert Card displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices. He told people that he was planning violence. And his behavior had markedly changed in the months leading up to the mass shooting he carried out last week.

headline: Why the Abortion Ballot Question in Ohio Is Confusing Voters
abstract: Ballot questions have been a winning strategy for abortion rights, even in red states. But complicated ballot language and misinformation have some abortion rights supporters worried.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates from Election Day 2023.

headline: A Twist Ending Awaited Two Empty Nesters in San Francisco
abstract: As rental prices sagged in the Bay Area, a couple searched for the ideal two-bedroom apartment. When they found it, they had another big decision to make.
lead_paragraph: As rental prices sagged in the Bay Area, a couple searched for the ideal two-bedroom apartment. When they found it, they had another big decision to make.

headline: Film Club: ‘Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.’
abstract: In the Israel-Hamas War, social media demands that we have to choose a side. A Times Opinion video wonders whether we really do.
lead_paragraph: “Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Pick a Side. Now.” is a four-minute Opinion video that explores the role of social media in the current Israel-Hamas war, and whether it allows any space for nuance or neutrality. “The insistence on picking a side,” the Times filmmakers argue, “threatens the public’s ability to take a holistic view of what is happening, to recognize and acknowledge atrocities irrespective of their perpetrators and to honor and mourn those who lost their lives.”

headline: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 3: ‘Would You Like to Sue the Government?’
abstract: As Wes Clark’s career takes off, he comes across a police report that reveals a stunning clue about how the Rutherford County juvenile justice system really works.
lead_paragraph: After winning their solitary case, Wes Clark and his law partner Mark Downton get a call from the A.C.L.U. Would they like to represent children who were arrested for watching a fight?

headline: Rich Nations Cut Aid for Climate Shocks, Even as Risks Grew
abstract: Poor countries need far more money to adapt to climate change, according to a new United Nations report.
lead_paragraph: Wealthy countries have decreased the amount of money they commit for helping developing countries cope with the effects of climate change, even as the need for that spending has grown, the United Nations said in a report issued on Thursday.

headline: The Many Missed Warnings Before Maine’s Mass Shooting
abstract: The police were warned about the deteriorating mental health of an Army reservist months before a deadly shooting.
lead_paragraph: The mass shooting in Maine last week, which killed 18 people, was the country’s deadliest of the year. It may have also been one of the most avoidable.

headline: Who Killed the Innkeeper With a Sword in 1315?
abstract: A map pinpointing hundreds of homicides in 14th-century England could help teach medieval history.
lead_paragraph: A spice merchant stabbed by a fruit seller over a longstanding feud. A street musician murdered for playing music too loudly after dusk. A deadly quarrel among servants of the Queen of England. And who killed the innkeeper with a sword after a fight?

headline: Voting on Abortion
abstract: A preview of an upcoming vote on abortion access in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Ohio voters will decide whether to protect access to abortion in their state.

headline: Deadly Storm Ciarán Lashes U.K. and Western Europe With Strong Rain and Wind
abstract: With winds expected to exceed 85 miles per hour in some areas, Britain’s weather agency issued its second-highest level of alert for parts of southern England.
lead_paragraph: A storm that battered northwestern France overnight lashed Britain and much of Western Europe on Thursday with heavy rains and strong winds that left at least six people dead.

headline: ‘Treason,’ the Musical Where the Fans Came First
abstract: The producers cultivated online followers for three years before mounting a full production, bringing them along on the show’s journey to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The catchy, folk-tinged numbers from “Treason the Musical” have been streamed online over a million times, in 96 countries. Its fans — known as “Plotters” — have been listening to an EP, an acoustic record and a live album of the songs, as well as sharing their own performances on TikTok. But until this fall, there hadn’t even been a full-scale production of the show.

headline: ‘Going to Mars: The Nikki Giovanni Project’ Review: An Afrofuturist Space Odyssey
abstract: The experimental documentary is punctuated by Giovanni’s poetry, read both by her and the actress Taraji P. Henson. But the film offers only what the poet is willing to give.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Giovanni wants to die in zero gravity.

headline: ‘All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt’ Review: Mississippi Memories
abstract: Raven Jackson’s film offers a rich portrait of growing up in rural Mississippi and heralds a fresh, poetic talent.
lead_paragraph: The opening of Raven Jackson’s debut feature, “All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt,” announces the arrival of a filmmaker grounded in the lyrical beauty of her characters and the loamy grace of the place they so deeply inhabit. In this case, rural Mississippi.

headline: ‘Fingernails’ Review: Love, Factually
abstract: Jessie Buckley and Riz Ahmed play confused lonely-hearts torn between science and emotion in this adorable near-future romance.
lead_paragraph: Heartache and horror walk hand in hand in “Fingernails,” a disarmingly sweet science-fiction romance from the Greek director Christos Nikou. Opening with a brief explanation of the title — the first sign of heart disease is often noticed in the fingernails — and closing on a note of indescribable yearning, this gently humorous movie operates so smoothly you may not notice its subversiveness.

headline: ‘Beyond Utopia’ Review: Exit Strategies
abstract: This film, directed by Madeleine Gavin, documents the experiences of defectors from North Korea.
lead_paragraph: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made. “The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain. The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.

headline: ‘I’m Still Alive’: Sean Young Takes the Stage in ‘Ode to the Wasp Woman’
abstract: “I walk into a show and everybody’s kind of a little afraid. Then I hear, ‘Oh, but you’re so nice,’” the actress said of her Hollywood baggage.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan has dressing rooms dingier than the one in the basement of the Actors Temple Theater. But not many. Sean Young, curled into a folding chair atop peeling linoleum tiles with a smudged mirror behind her, claimed not to mind.

headline: ‘Radical’ Review: To Sergio With Love
abstract: A vaguely unconventional teacher galvanizes disadvantaged sixth graders in this highly conventional drama.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you’ve seen this one before: A free-spirited teacher takes a stake in a classroom full of underprivileged youth and unleashes their true potential. This stale and sometimes patronizing premise is recycled in Christopher Zalla’s “Radical,” a sentimental drama that is based on a true story but boxes neatly into familiar packaging. The title is nearly oxymoronic: It boldly belies how close to convention the film hews.

headline: ‘Sly’ Review: No More Mr. Tough Guy
abstract: This documentary from Thom Zimny tracks Sylvester Stallone’s life and career, though focuses too much on “Rocky” and “Rambo.”
lead_paragraph: “An actor is what he looks like,” Sylvester Stallone told The New York Times in 1976, and more than most stars, Stallone has been viewed as an action figure come to life. In “Sly,” the director Thom Zimny excavates the acts of self-creation behind a career that minted two indelible titular characters in “Rocky” and “Rambo” — whose underdog narratives proved highly influential.

headline: ‘In the Court of the Crimson King’ Review: 50 Years of Off-Kilter Rock
abstract: Toby Amies’s documentary dives into the history of the British progressive rock band King Crimson and its chief disciplinarian, Robert Fripp.
lead_paragraph: The director Toby Amies’s documentary “In the Court of the Crimson King” is part road chronicle and part retrospective, and captures King Crimson, the adventurous British rock ensemble, at what may be the end of its existence. Robert Fripp, for years the band’s sole original member, has strongly suggested that its 2021 tour would be its last. (It hasn’t toured since.)

headline: ‘Nyad’ Review: Neptune’s (Estranged) Daughter
abstract: Annette Bening plays the long-distance swimmer Diana Nyad as a woman who doesn’t pity herself. Neither does the film.
lead_paragraph: “Nyad” is about an athlete creating her own lore. Diana Nyad (Annette Bening) is proud that her last name stems from the naiads of Greek mythology. “My ancestors! The nymphs that swam in the lakes and the rivers and the ocean,” Diana trumpets to everyone in earshot. A record-breaking long-distance swimmer, she’s got the lung capacity of a real blowhard. Her ever-patient best friend, Bonnie (Jodie Foster), spends this exuberant and enervating biopic cutting Diana off mid-crow. Braggadocio takes you far in politics or business; jocks, however, have to prove it in sweat. And so, at 60, Diana vows to conquer the challenge that bested her at age 28. She’ll swim nonstop from Cuba to Florida — over two days of sharks, storms, stinging jellyfish and hallucinatory exhaustion. For most of this riveting crowd-pleaser, she fails.

headline: ‘Quiz Lady’ Review: Dog in Jeopardy
abstract: Sandra Oh shines in this road trip buddy comedy about a pair of sisters getting on a TV quiz show to pay the ransom for their stolen dog.
lead_paragraph: Jenny (Sandra Oh), a 40-something ball of chaos, is introduced in “Quiz Lady” the way you might expect of someone whose life savings are contingent on a hazardous fish bone-related lawsuit against a chain restaurant called Choochie’s: off in the distance, skittering heedlessly across the street before she’s suddenly struck by a car. Naturally, she pops right back up before having a meltdown over the mechanical entrance to the senior home where her younger sister, Anne (Awkwafina), is frustratingly watching from inside.

headline: ‘Subject’ Review: A Question of Ethics
abstract: Filmmaking principles come under scrutiny in “Subject,” a documentary about the making of documentaries.
lead_paragraph: Many of the most compelling documentaries of the past several years, from Nathan Fielder’s HBO mini-series “The Rehearsal” to Kirsten Johnson’s self-reflexive feature “Cameraperson,” actively engage with the ethics of documentary filmmaking, posing difficult questions about participation, consent and the responsibility of the artist to the subjects of their art. These projects differ from “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall’s film about documentary ethics, in that their questions are posed by the filmmaking itself, threaded artfully into the documentary form. “Subject” just speaks the questions out loud, turning them into reductive fodder for talking heads.

headline: ‘The Marsh King’s Daughter’ Review: Smoke on the Water
abstract: Neil Burger’s thriller aims to capture a mother pushed to protect her family from her past.
lead_paragraph: In the director Neil Burger’s harrowing yet thin thriller “The Marsh King’s Daughter,” adapted from Karen Dionne’s same-titled novel, a young Helena (Brooklynn Prince) learns how her fairy tale is actually a nightmare. She lives in a woodland cabin with her stern mother, Beth (Caren Pistorius) and her huntsman father, Jacob (Ben Mendelsohn). Jacob often brands Beth’s white skin with Indigenous inspired tattoos and instructs her how to track and hunt.

headline: ‘What Happens Later’ Review: Meg Ryan Revisits the Meet-Cute
abstract: The rom-com queen directs and stars opposite David Duchovny in this two-hander about former lovers who reconnect after 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Few can compete with Meg Ryan’s rom-com résumé. As the star of three classics penned by Nora Ephron — “When Harry Met Sally,” “Sleepless in Seattle” and “You’ve Got Mail” — she may as well be the mascot of the genre’s late 1980s and ’90s golden era. “What Happens Later,” which she both directs and stars in, is an appropriate homecoming for a seasoned pro.

headline: Uber and Lyft Agree to $328 Million Payout for New York Drivers
abstract: The ride-share companies will also give gig workers sick leave and minimum pay.
lead_paragraph: Uber and Lyft have agreed to pay New York drivers a $328 million settlement after the state attorney general investigated a wage-theft complaint charging that the companies collected certain taxes and fees from drivers rather than passengers.

headline: Law Firms Warn Universities About Antisemitism on Campus
abstract: Two dozen major Wall Street firms sent a letter to top law schools to crack down on discrimination and harassment amid an escalation in incidents targeting Jewish students.
lead_paragraph: With universities across the United States grappling with a rise in antisemitism since the start of the Israel-Hamas war, elite law firms are putting schools on notice. In a letter to some of the nation’s top law schools obtained by DealBook, about two dozen major Wall Street firms warned that what happens on campus could have corporate consequences.

headline: More American Seniors Live Alone
abstract: People over 60 are more likely to live alone in the United States and Europe than in other regions of the world.
lead_paragraph: Who will be by your side in your golden years? That’s a big question for a growing cohort. By 2050, the global population of people aged 60 and over will double from its 2020 total, to 2.1 billion, according to the World Health Organization. This week we examine the size of the households of this growing population in the United States compared with other regions of the world.

headline: Russia Pulled Out of a Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Here’s What That Means.
abstract: In de-ratifying the agreement, Moscow removed another brick in the wall of formal arms control intended to limit proliferation.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark moment marking the closing chapters of the Cold War, Presidents Ronald Reagan of the United States and Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union concluded a 1985 summit in Geneva by issuing a joint statement declaring that “a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.”

headline: Bank of England Holds Rates Steady Amid Signs of Weakening Economy
abstract: Britain’s central bank said that interest rates would need to remain high for an “extended” period, and that economic growth was expected to be flat over much of the next two years.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England held interest rates at the highest levels in 15 years on Thursday, though policymakers were again divided on the best course of action to stamp out high inflation.

headline: How a Campaign of Extremist Violence Is Pushing the West Bank to the Brink
abstract: Israeli settlers and Palestinians have been locked in a cycle of bloodshed for decades. But extremist settler attacks could send the conflict out of control.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, Bilal Mohammad Saleh, a Palestinian sidewalk vendor of sage and thyme, went out with his family to pick olives.

headline: Saudi Arabia Begins Aid Effort for Gaza and Raises $17 Million in Hours
abstract: The belated campaign, announced more than three weeks into the war, appeared consistent with the Saudi government’s ambivalent response to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia on Thursday announced a government campaign to collect humanitarian aid for Gaza, gathering more than 60,000 donations worth more than $17 million in its first few hours.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom Victorian in Nyack, N.Y., and a six-bedroom contemporary in Sherman, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,033-square-foot house built in 1880 and renovated in 2011, with an open living/dining area that has a gas-burning stove, a kitchen with banquette seating, central air-conditioning, an easily accessible finished attic space, a backyard with a stone patio and grassy area, and a glass-enclosed auxiliary structure with heat and air-conditioning, on 0.09 acres. Nancy Blaker Weber, Howard Hanna Rand Realty, 914-263-3403; randrealty.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, on Central Park West and in Sunnyside.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 850-square-foot apartment with a windowed eat-in kitchen, a windowed bathroom, an office nook, a walk-in closet and windowed air-conditioning, on the third floor of a six-story prewar building with a live-in super, bike room, video intercom, shared basement storage and shared laundry. Mihal Gartenberg, 212-327-9677, Coldwell Banker Warburg; cbwarburg.com

headline: In the Catskills, Seasonal Farmhouse Dinners With House-Made Beer
abstract: Plus: A boutique hotel in South Africa, a painter’s imaginary friends and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: My morning routine is how I set myself up for the day. I splash my face with water and will often use Oskia’s Super C Beauty Capsules. I’m a big fan of Augustinus Bader’s The Light Cream and then Merit’s Great Skin Instant Glow Serum, which is very subtle. I’m really into their makeup: they have this Bronze Balm in a stick and blushers that come in little jars that are easy to swipe on. I use RMS UnCoverup Concealer and Supergoop Glowscreen SPF 40. I have an orangy red lipstick from NARS called Heatwave that I’ll wear here and there. I was on a shoot recently and the makeup artist told me about using this Schwarzkopf Styling Gel on your brows — it’s the only thing that actually stays for me. Kure nail varnish has the best range of colors and is the most durable of all the natural products; I like Rose Milk.

headline: Love Letters to California
abstract: Readers share why they adore living in the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to waxing poetic about California, certain spots tend to get the most love. Among them: the palm-tree-lined beaches of Los Angeles, the Golden Gate Bridge, and the stunning waterfalls and granite mountains of Yosemite National Park.

headline: LeVar Burton Wants to Be Heard
abstract: The actor is engaging young audiences again with “Sound Detectives,” a comic mystery podcast that teaches the art of listening.
lead_paragraph: LeVar Burton has spent much of his career encouraging children to read. Now he is urging them to listen — really listen.

headline: Ukraine’s Top Commander Says War Has Hit a ‘Stalemate’
abstract: In a candid assessment, Gen. Valery Zaluzhny said no “beautiful breakthrough” was imminent and that breaking the deadlock could require advances in technological warfare.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s top commander has acknowledged that his forces are locked in a “stalemate” with Russia along a front line that has barely shifted despite months of fierce fighting, and that no significant breakthrough was imminent. It is the most candid assessment so far by a leading Ukrainian official of the military’s stalled counteroffensive.

headline: The West Bank seethes amid the war in Gaza.
abstract: Violence in the West Bank, where millions of Palestinians live under Israeli military occupation, continues to simmer amid the war in Gaza. At least 128 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli security forces or civilians in the West Bank since Oct. 7, according to the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: Violence in the West Bank, where millions of Palestinians live under Israeli military occupation, continues to simmer amid the war in Gaza. At least 128 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli security forces or civilians in the West Bank since Oct. 7, according to the United Nations.

headline: Trump’s Sons Cast the Blame for Fraud on Their Company’s Accountants
abstract: Donald Trump Jr. and his brother Eric Trump both testified in the  trial that accuses their family business of overvaluing its assets.
lead_paragraph: Eric and Donald J. Trump Jr., the elder sons of the 45th president, stepped out of their father’s shadow and into a legal minefield on Thursday, tiptoeing around potentially damaging evidence as they testified in a trial that threatens their family business.

headline: Israel Is Silencing Internal Critics
abstract: Since the war between Israel and Hamas began, free speech in Israel has suffered.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7. In response to another lecturer’s message, she wrote that “the massacre,” referring to the actions of Hamas, reminded her of something the French philosopher and playwright Jean-Paul Sartre once wrote about race relations, adding a paraphrased quote: “‘After so many years that the neck of the occupied has been suffocating under your iron foot and suddenly was given a chance to raise his eyes, what kind of gaze did you expect you would see there?’ We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.

headline: Evacuating From Gaza Is Its Own Ordeal
abstract: For many, the path to the border crossing to reach Egypt has been filled with danger.
lead_paragraph: As people waited at the Rafah crossing on Thursday anticipating a second day of evacuations from Gaza into Egypt, the sound of an airstrike rattled the crowd, and a piece of shrapnel appeared to fall in the area.

headline: The Beatles’ ‘Now and Then’: A Glimpse of Past Greatness
abstract: The “last” song with contributions from all four Beatles, made possible by new technology, finds its power in vulnerability and nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a grand finale. It’s a wistful postscript.

headline: Frustrated With New Rules, Bank Lobbyists Are Making Their Fight Public
abstract: Banking trade groups are using legal action and public campaigns to push back on rules they say go too far.
lead_paragraph: Banks have become increasingly frustrated with their federal regulators and, in a break with tradition, have brought the battle out into the open.

headline: Celebrating Literature That ‘Brings the World Close’
abstract: Words Without Borders, a magazine dedicated to literature in translation, is turning 20 at a fraught time. How to celebrate words when bombs are dropping?
lead_paragraph: Words Without Borders, one of the few magazines in the world dedicated to literature in translation, is turning 20 at a fraught time: Around the world, wars are raging. Writers are being jailed, dissident voices silenced and books banned.

headline: ‘This is the Best Caesar Dressing I’ve Tasted. Ever.’
abstract: Readers love, really love, our vegan Caesar salad.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year when, inevitably, you will be asked to bring a salad to a gathering. You could hardly do better than this reader-favorite vegan Caesar salad with crispy chickpeas, a brilliant recipe by Becky Hughes. (For anyone who thinks it’s not a real Caesar without the egg yolks and anchovies, don’t worry, we have a salad for you, too.) Becky’s creamy dressing is built on a base of blended raw cashews, punched up with plenty of garlic, miso and caper brine. It’s bound to win fans, vegan or not: “Forget best vegan Caesar dressing — this is the best Caesar dressing I’ve tasted. Ever,” wrote Sarah, a reader.

headline: Olympic Hopefuls Needed a Home. A Retirement Community Stepped Up.
abstract: New Zealand’s curling team wanted to train with the “big boys” in Canada, and a group of enthusiastic seniors has provided housing, a cheering section and lots of advice.
lead_paragraph: Ben Smith never could have imagined spending the winter at a retirement home in Calgary, Alberta, sipping Caesar cocktails with three of his best friends — Anton Hood, Brett Sargon and Hunter Walker — while their octogenarian neighbors play bridge and tabletop shuffleboard.

headline: Don’t Shut Down Your Anger. Channel It.
abstract: We’re often told to focus on the positive. But new research shows a healthy dose of anger can be motivating.
lead_paragraph: There is an upside to feeling angry.

headline: On Social Media, People Face Pressure to Speak Out About the War
abstract: Silence is viewed by many as its own statement. Posting, though, can come with costs, including angry outpourings and even personal attacks.
lead_paragraph: Deb Perelman, the best-selling cookbook author and creator of Smitten Kitchen, tends to focus her social media posts on her work, like pasta or chocolate chip cookie recipes. But days after Hamas attacked Israel, she called the violence “repugnant” on Instagram and expressed dread for “death and destruction now ahead on both sides.”

headline: Got Milk … Cartons? School Cafeterias Won’t, Thanks to a Shortage
abstract: A nationwide shortage of half-pint milk cartons is hitting schools in several states, leaving them brainstorming other ways to serve the drink to their students.
lead_paragraph: Half-pint cartons of milk, served in cafeterias and lunchrooms across the country, are ubiquitous on the lunch trays of millions of students. But in some districts, they will soon disappear.

headline: Director of Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas to Retire in 2024
abstract: Jeremy Strick, who helmed the institution for 15 of its 20 years, established the Nasher Prize for Sculpture, one of the art world’s top honors.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Strick, the director of the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas, will retire in June 2024 after 15 years in the role, the center announced on Thursday.

headline: U.S. to Press Israel for ‘Pauses’ in War With Hamas
abstract: Brief cessations of military operations would allow food, water and other aid to reach Gaza and help with hostage releases, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will urge the Israeli government to agree to a series of brief cessations of military operations in Gaza to allow for hostages to be released safely and for humanitarian aid to be distributed, White House officials said on Thursday.

headline: Mike Pence’s Hell Is Ours Too
abstract: Brace yourselves for an apocalyptic campaign season.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to disparage Donald Trump. It’s quite another to throw your body between him and his efforts to steal the presidency. Mike Pence, God love him, did the latter, and that sealed his doom. To the hard-core MAGA corps, tyranny is the meaty breakfast of champions. Virtue and democracy are a wimp’s veggie canapés.

headline: Man Accused in Tupac Shakur’s Murder Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: The suspect, Duane Keith Davis, faces a charge of murder with a deadly weapon. He has spoken openly about his presence at the scene in a memoir and interviews.
lead_paragraph: A man who for years has said he was a critical player in the gang-orchestrated shooting of the rapper Tupac Shakur pleaded not guilty on Thursday to a charge of murder with a deadly weapon, following an indictment that thrust the dormant case back into public view.

headline: U.S. Investigating Whether Adams Received Illegal Donations From Turkey
abstract: A raid at the home of Eric Adams’s chief fund-raiser was part of an inquiry into whether foreign money was funneled into his mayoral campaign, a search warrant shows.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. are conducting a broad public corruption investigation into whether Mayor Eric Adams’s 2021 election campaign conspired with the Turkish government to receive illegal foreign donations, according to a search warrant obtained by The New York Times.

headline: What to Know About the Colorado Trial to Keep Trump Off the Ballot
abstract: The lawsuit in Denver is one of several across the country arguing that former President Donald J. Trump is ineligible to hold office again.
lead_paragraph: The continued existence of former President Donald J. Trump’s 2024 campaign is being litigated in multiple states, with just two months to go until caucusgoers cast their first ballots.

headline: ‘In Egypt Now. Free!’: First Evacuees From Gaza Feel Relief and Gratitude
abstract: “You feel that human beings’ lives are so worthless,” said Ala Al Husseini, 61, an Austrian-Palestinian dual national who was allowed to leave Gaza on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: There was little gas and no phone service in Gaza on Wednesday morning, making it impossible to hail a cab, so Ala Al Husseini nearly missed his chance to escape the war.

headline: Microsoft Criticized for Embedding ‘Crass’ A.I. Poll Beside News Article
abstract: A poll generated by artificial intelligence, embedded next to a Guardian article on Microsoft’s news aggregator platform, asked readers to speculate on the cause of a woman’s death.
lead_paragraph: An auto-generated poll that Microsoft embedded on its news aggregating platform alongside a Guardian article was “crass” and caused significant damage to The Guardian’s reputation, the newspaper said on Thursday.

headline: Learning to Become Openhearted
abstract: Responses to a David Brooks column about how to connect with other people. Also: The kidnapping posters; older prisoners; human needs; extremists in control.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Sun Is Setting Early. Time for Mushrooms.
abstract: Savory, hearty recipes that feel especially cozy as the days get shorter.
lead_paragraph: I tend to commute home on autopilot, taking in very little around me as I zone out to music so loud that my Health app insists I turn it down. So when I emerged from the subway the other day just before 6 p.m., I was startled by what I found: near complete darkness.

headline: Vaping Declines Among High School Students, Survey Shows
abstract: The annual tobacco use survey given to middle and high school students revealed a decrease among older teenagers for the first time in several years.
lead_paragraph: The number of high school students who reported using e-cigarettes fell to 10 percent in the spring of this year from 14 percent last year, according to the results of an annual survey released on Thursday by federal health agencies.

headline: Young Woman Describes ‘Miserable’ Living Conditions in Gaza
abstract: Nour AlSaqqa, 23, describes how scarce basic resources like fresh water and food are in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Nour AlSaqqa, 23, describes how scarce basic resources like fresh water and food are in Gaza.

headline: Former Memphis Officer Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in Tyre Nichols’s Death
abstract: The ex-officer pleaded guilty to two felony counts, becoming the first to admit culpability in the fatal beating of Mr. Nichols. As part of a plea deal, he is also expected to cooperate with a state murder prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Desmond Mills Jr., one of five former Memphis police officers charged in connection with the brutal beating and death of Tyre Nichols, pleaded guilty in federal court on Thursday to two felony charges of obstruction of justice and excessive force.

headline: A young woman describes the crisis in Gaza: ‘If the bombs didn’t kill us, our living situation will.’
abstract: Nour AlSaqqa, who is from Gaza City, has been documenting her life during the Israel-Hamas war. She said she fears that if the shortages of basic necessities persist, she will die.
lead_paragraph: Nour AlSaqqa, who is from Gaza City, has been documenting her life during the Israel-Hamas war. The New York Times last spoke to Ms. AlSaqqa when the war first started. Since then, she has fled south to Rafah, the Gazan city at the territory’s southern border with Egypt, after Israel warned Palestinians to leave northern Gaza to avoid airstrikes.

headline: What if Wine and Cider Had a Baby?
abstract: A growing number of producers are fermenting grapes, apples and other fruits together, or blending wine and ciders, to make fascinating beverages.
lead_paragraph: Wine is made by fermenting grapes or other fruit, although apple and pear wines are distinctive enough to have earned their own categories, cider and perry. But a growing number of producers are blurring the styles, blending grape wines and ciders or fermenting grapes and other fruit together, with remarkable delicious results.

headline: Chief Executive of National Association of Realtors Resigns
abstract: The resignation of Bob Goldberg comes days after a $1.8 billion verdict against N.A.R. and two months after The New York Times exposed complaints of sexual harassment in the group.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the National Association of Realtors resigned from his post two days after a federal jury ruled that the powerful organization conspired to inflate home commissions.

headline: Are Higher Rates Slowing the Economy? A Zoo Offers Clues.
abstract: Economists are surprised by how strong the economy remains with rates at a 22-year high. But there are some signs of slowing, if you know where to look.
lead_paragraph: Leesburg Animal Park in Northern Virginia has seen strong business at its Pumpkin Village festival this autumn. Even with rainy weekends and a jump in admission prices, families have been coming out to visit the petting zoo, ride on giant slides and zigzag through a hay-bale maze.

headline: Senators Plot to Unblock Military Promotions as Tuberville Draws G.O.P. Ire
abstract: Democrats were working to temporarily circumvent Senate rules to outmaneuver the Alabama Republican, and a group of senators in his own party signaled their patience had run out.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats are trying a novel strategy to break Senator Tommy Tuberville’s blockade of senior military promotions, as pressure builds among his fellow Republicans and Defense Department officials to end his monthslong hold in protest of the Pentagon’s abortion access policies.

headline: Lewiston Begins to Heal, One Touchdown at a Time
abstract: At the season’s last football game, between rival high schools in Lewiston and Auburn, two broken cities in Maine found joy again.
lead_paragraph: The Battle of the Bridge is the biggest football game of the year in Lewiston and Auburn, cities separated by a river in Maine.

headline: Juanita McNeely, Intense Artist of the Female Experience, Dies at 87
abstract: Her searing paintings, which could be sweet but also brutal, reflected her interest in the female body and what it could do.
lead_paragraph: Juanita McNeely, an uncompromising painter who used the language of Expressionism to immortalize the sweetest and most brutal moments of her own female experience, died on Oct. 18 at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Celebrity Relationships, Police Robots and the Mall: Argumentative Writing by Teens
abstract: Teenagers weigh in on the news of the day in three recent Picture Prompts.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce. A 400-pound “fully autonomous” security robot in New York City’s subway stations. The value of shopping malls.

headline: Those Online Trolls Attacking TV Critics? They Were From HBO.
abstract: The push to attack television critics through fake Twitter accounts became the talk of the entertainment world on Wednesday after it was reported by Rolling Stone.
lead_paragraph: Casey Bloys, the chairman of HBO, enjoys a reputation in the entertainment industry as an effective programmer and an easygoing executive who stays above the fray.

headline: Listen: “The Run-Up” Returns
abstract: Each week, we share the best of our new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: A Golden Treat for Diwali
abstract: Onion bhajiya, golden fried onion fritters, are a staple for the cookbook author Palak Patel’s Diwali celebrations.
lead_paragraph: At the home of the cookbook author Palak Patel, the days leading up to Diwali are spent cleaning her kitchen and preparing the numerous snacks and mithai, or sweets, they’ll deliver to friends and family for the South Asian festival of light. Her mother, Mala Patel, fries dried snacks, like Mathia, to fill giant frosting buckets she repurposes from Dunkin’, where she works.

headline: Jury Begins Deliberations for a Verdict in Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
abstract: The trial for the founder of the collapsed FTX cryptocurrency exchange has moved more speedily than anticipated.
lead_paragraph: A jury of nine women and three men began deliberating a verdict on Thursday afternoon in the criminal fraud trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced entrepreneur who has been accused of stealing as much as $10 billion in customer funds from his FTX crypto exchange.

headline: Holiday Retail Sales Are Expected to Increase, but at a Slower Pace
abstract: Spending in that crucial period is predicted to rise 3 to 4 percent from last year, as the economy cools and demand normalizes.
lead_paragraph: Holiday spending is expected to increase this year, but analysts foresee it slowing down from peak pandemic years, when Americans spent at record levels.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a lush nature documentary, an aesthetically ambitious comedy special and a distinctive Swedish dramedy.
lead_paragraph: ‘Planet Earth III’

headline: After Antisemitic Threats, Cornell University Cancels Classes on Friday
abstract: The university said it would take a day to allow the campus to reflect and to calm tensions after an arrest in the case.
lead_paragraph: Cornell University has canceled classes for Friday following the arrest of a student charged with making violent antisemitic threats, aiming to give students and faculty time to rest and reflect and to calm campus tensions over the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: ‘Pal Joey’ Review: Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildering
abstract: Joey is still a heel in this major revision of the 1940 antihero musical, but he’s now a Black artist trying to find his true voice.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that the standout star of a show is its music supervisor, arranger or orchestrator, but in the gala presentation of “Pal Joey” at New York City Center through Sunday, all three are one man, Daryl Waters. More than the authors of the ambitious, bewildering revival’s new book, Waters, who has served similar roles on musicals as varied as “Bring in ’Da Noise, Bring in ’Da Funk,” “After Midnight,” “The Cher Show” and “New York, New York,” makes a clear case in beautiful sound for its investigation into the melting pot of American music.

headline: Hezbollah’s Leader to Speak Publicly for 1st Time Since Hamas Attacked Israel
abstract: Many in the region are watching Hassan Nasrallah’s speech for insights into whether Hezbollah will escalate its battle with Israel.
lead_paragraph: Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, will break his public silence on the war in Gaza on Friday in a televised speech that many in the region expect will provide insights into whether the group will escalate its battle with Israel.

headline: House Passes Aid Bill for Israel but Not for Ukraine
abstract: The Republican-led House approved $14.3 billion for Israel’s war with Hamas, tying the aid to spending cuts. The Senate plans to craft its own bill that will include aid for Ukraine and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: A divided House on Thursday passed a Republican-written bill that would tie $14.3 billion in military aid for Israel to domestic spending cuts and provide no money for Ukraine, defying President Biden and dooming its chances in the Senate.

headline: 35 Years After Addressing Congress, James Hansen Has More Climate Warnings
abstract: The former NASA scientist James Hansen says in a new paper that global temperatures will pass a major milestone this decade, faster than other estimates predict.
lead_paragraph: Global warming may be happening more quickly than previously thought, according to a new study by a group of researchers including former NASA scientist James Hansen, whose testimony before Congress 35 years ago helped raise broad awareness of climate change.

headline: Dagestan Mob Riot Targeting Plane From Israel Was Weeks in the Making
abstract: A New York Times analysis of local Telegram channels showed posts falsely claiming Israeli refugees were incoming had been shared long before the antisemitic riot on Oct. 29.
lead_paragraph: A false rumor about the resettlement of Israelis in Dagestan that incited a violent mob at its capital airport Sunday was shared online for longer and more widely than previously reported, according to a New York Times analysis of Telegram posts.

headline: 10 Stellar New York Soups to Keep You Warm
abstract: Wonton soup, goat pepper soup, matzo balls and more soothing classics.
lead_paragraph: We live in the age of small plates meant for sharing, and soup is harder to share than, say, a crab cake. Restaurants don’t make it easier; they rarely offer extra bowls, or even spoons. I don’t get it. Humans have been cooking soup for ages. Why are we turning our backs on it?

headline: The Trap of the Overprotected Childhood
abstract: I wish my kids had the open-ended, play-filled days I had growing up.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I visited the quiet, treesy neighborhood I spent much of my 1970s childhood in. It was late afternoon on a weekday. Fifty years ago, there would have been lots of kids roaming and biking around in the streets; I was one of them. But on the day I was there, there was not a single child to be seen.

headline: Will the Art Market Need to Discount Its Masterpieces?
abstract: Amid fears that a new war could threaten the world economy, New York’s coming auctions will test a growing consensus that the $60 billion art market is headed toward a down cycle.
lead_paragraph: Major auction houses are hedging their bets in the fall season of sales that begins Monday, offering fat guarantees to sellers to secure their works — and pricing some of their top items more conservatively after the spring season demonstrated weakness in the blazing-hot $60 billion art market. And now, sellers are trying to anticipate how the uncertainty of a new war in the Middle East will affect them.

headline: Helen Williams, Top Model in a Segregated Era, Is Dead at 87
abstract: She was one of the most photographed Black models of the 1950s and ’60s, seen mainly in magazines, like Ebony and Jet, aimed at the Black middle class.
lead_paragraph: Swan-necked and with an arched-eyebrow hauteur, Helen Williams was the aspirational face of the Black middle class in the 1950s and 60s — the most photographed, and highest paid, Black model of her era.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Every week in this space, we quote from our reviews of the books we recommend — but we rarely quote from the books themselves, largely because the reviews we link to do such a good job of that on their own, and with context to boot. But what the heck. This week our recommended books include a poetry collection, Robyn Schiff’s “Information Desk,” that offers a reminiscence of her post-college job at the Metropolitan Museum of Art while skipping merrily through sparkling ideas about art and nature and youth and life. Good quotes abound, as in this wry observation on the artistic temperament: “When someone tells me he’s inspired/I usually take/it to mean someone else/does his dishes.”

headline: The Sudden Death of a Model Magnate
abstract: Over his three decades at the top of the industry, Ivan Bart helped engineer the careers of such top models as Gisele Bündchen, Kate Upton and Kate Moss.
lead_paragraph: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful. Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists. Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”

headline: No Tip for Your Delivery Driver? Then Be Prepared to Wait, DoorDash Says.
abstract: The app-based delivery company said it was testing a screen that tells customers who didn’t leave a tip that their order might take longer to arrive.
lead_paragraph: The next time you order those burgers and fries from your couch, be forewarned. If you don’t add a tip for your delivery person, you might have to wait longer for your food.

headline: Six Flags Merges With Cedar Fair, a Rival Amusement Park
abstract: The deal would generate more than $3 billion in revenue for the companies, they projected in a statement. The merger comes after years of financial challenges for Six Flags.
lead_paragraph: Six Flags, an amusement park corporation, is merging with its rival Cedar Fair in an $8 billion deal, the two companies announced on Thursday.

headline: Friday Briefing: China pushes for women to stay home
abstract: Plus New Zealand curlers take over a retirement home
lead_paragraph: The National Women’s Congress, held every five years, has long been a forum for the ruling Communist Party to demonstrate its commitment to women. This year, officials downplayed gender equality and focused on President Xi Jinping’s goal for Chinese women: Get married and have babies.

headline: The Laws of Campus Culture War
abstract: College can be contentious, but it must be safe and free.
lead_paragraph: These are times that try our commitment to the Bill of Rights. Grief, rage and fear are radiating outward from the Middle East and tearing at the fabric of our own liberal democracy, especially on college campuses. The stories are already legion. Activists have ripped down posters of kidnapped Israeli women and children. The chancellor of the State University System of Florida ordered the deactivation of two campus chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine. At Cooper Union in New York City, Jewish students sheltered inside the library while pro-Palestinian protesters pounded on the doors. And in Ithaca, N.Y., a Cornell University student was arrested after publishing vile threats against the school’s Jewish community.

headline: Israeli Troops Encircle Gaza City as Global Criticism of Strikes Mounts
abstract: An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli soldiers had surrounded Gaza’s largest city. White House officials said they would urge Israel to “pause” its bombardment on humanitarian grounds.
lead_paragraph: As the Israeli military announced that ground troops had encircled Gaza City on Thursday, criticism mounted of the death toll inflicted by Israeli airstrikes, with one United Nations agency suggesting the bombing campaign could be a war crime.

headline: NASA’s Lucy Mission Set Its Sights on 1 Asteroid. It Found 2.
abstract: On its way to the Trojan swarms, the spacecraft made a pit stop at a rock named Dinkinesh — and the images it sent back revealed that this asteroid has its own moon.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, NASA’s Lucy spacecraft zoomed by its first asteroid target — and scientists on the mission were shocked to discover that the rock, named Dinkinesh, was actually two rocks. The binary consists of a larger, primary asteroid and a smaller “moon” orbiting around it, as seen in images that Lucy captured of the pair.

headline: With Rangers Win, an Overlooked Texas City Grabs the Spotlight
abstract: Arlington, which is wedged between Dallas and Fort Worth and overshadowed by both, is ready to celebrate the World Series victory of its hometown team.
lead_paragraph: During baseball season, the public buses in Houston flash a message as they rumble through the city: “Go Astros!!”

headline: Apple’s Sales Drop Slightly While Profit Is Up 11 Percent
abstract: Interest in new iPhones and services such as music and cloud storage powered the quarter, but other businesses, such as Mac sales, slowed significantly.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the tech industry’s biggest companies are rebounding from a post-pandemic dip, Apple is suffering through its most prolonged sales slump in more than a decade.

headline: Planned Museum to Honor Pulse Nightclub Victims Canceled
abstract: A foundation that had been working to create the museum said the cost of building it had become prohibitive. A permanent memorial is still planned for the site.
lead_paragraph: The nonprofit onePulse Foundation has ended its plans to construct a museum in Orlando to honor the victims of the Pulse nightclub shooting.

headline: South Carolina Jails to Be Investigated After Reports of Abuse and Violence
abstract: The Justice Department inquiry will focus on “credible allegations” that a number of deaths at two jails resulted from use of force, medical neglect and assaults by inmates.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday opened a far-reaching civil rights investigation of two troubled jails in South Carolina after reports of violent and unhealthy living conditions, failure to treat mentally ill prisoners and the abuse of inmates by guards.

headline: Two Judges, Two Approaches
abstract: He avoids criticizing one. Another draws attacks.
lead_paragraph: As the two federal criminal cases against Donald Trump make their way toward trial, they are bringing into focus a tale of two judges.

headline: Second Woman Accuses Steven Tyler of Sexually Assaulting Her in the 1970s
abstract: In a lawsuit, a woman says that the Aerosmith frontman groped and fondled her in a New York phone booth when she was about 17.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in the past year, Steven Tyler has been accused in a lawsuit of sexually assaulting a teenage girl in the 1970s, when his band Aerosmith was rising to fame.

headline: A Doctor in Gaza Describes ‘Horrific Scenes’ After Israeli Airstrikes
abstract: Gazans under bombardment say there is a surge of severely injured children entering hospitals, doctors operating without anesthesia and morgues overflowing with bodies.
lead_paragraph: The Jabaliya neighborhood north of Gaza City was pummeled with Israeli airstrikes for a third consecutive day on Thursday, while doctors treating the victims described nightmarish scenes of operating without basic supplies or anesthesia.

headline: Ken Mattingly, Astronaut Bumped From Apollo 13, Is Dead at 87
abstract: He later orbited the moon, but in 1970 he was scrubbed from the Apollo flight after being exposed to German measles. Then, from mission control, he helped it avert disaster.
lead_paragraph: Ken Mattingly, who orbited the moon and commanded a pair of NASA shuttle missions, but who was remembered as well for the flight he didn’t make — the near-disastrous mission of Apollo 13 — died on Tuesday in Arlington, Va. He was 87.

headline: The Art Show Highlights Masters — and Artists Under the Radar
abstract: The Art Dealers Association of America fair at the Park Avenue Armory offers 78 international galleries with blue-chip booths, along with artisans rescued from the margins.
lead_paragraph: The world is in tumult but for the moment, the business of art marches on. Artists go to their studios, museums keep their doors open and art critics try to make sense of it all. Meanwhile, the Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), a members-only organization known for its blue-chip brands, has assembled for its annual fair.

headline: Rangers-Diamondbacks World Series Ratings Are Lowest Ever
abstract: The five games averaged 9.1 million viewers, down from the previous low of 9.8 million in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The World Series wrapped up on Wednesday night with the Texas Rangers storming the field to celebrate the team’s first-ever championship.

headline: Penn & Teller Don’t Mind Being Fooled
abstract: Now in its 10th season, “Penn & Teller: Fool Us” has become TV’s premier showcase for magicians and the rare competition show where kindness rules.
lead_paragraph: On the magician Shin Lim’s first appearance on “Penn & Teller: Fool Us,” he made cards rise out of a tabletop and vanish, only for them to reappear inside a clear sealed bag, or emerge from his mouth, engulfed in smoke and folded in four.

headline: The U.S. Will Press Israel for Pauses in the War
abstract: Also, Donald Trump’s eldest sons testify in a fraud trial. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: When Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrives in Israel tomorrow, he plans to urge Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to agree to a series of brief cessations of military operations in Gaza, White House officials said today.

headline: A Surge in Antisemitism in Europe — and What’s Behind It
abstract: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
lead_paragraph: This week, the director of the F.B.I. warned Congress that the Israel-Hamas war had escalated threats against Jews and Muslims in the United States, and that antisemitic threats had reached “historic levels.”

headline: Why the Jet Stream Is Helping Some International Flights Arrive Early
abstract: Flights traveling west to east over the Atlantic Ocean this week have had the wind on their side, pushing some landing times up to an hour ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: Passengers who were on British Airways’ Flight 112, from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Heathrow Airport outside London, received some good news early Thursday morning. The flight, which normally would have taken about six hours, was going to arrive 50 minutes early.

headline: Elon Musk Discusses Perils and Benefits of A.I. With Rishi Sunak
abstract: The prime minister’s conversation with the tech billionaire was part of an effort this week to present Britain as a leader in artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Rishi Sunak, the prime minister of Britain, had one last appointment on Thursday evening after a busy couple of days hosting dozens of government leaders, tech executives and other experts at a summit on the dangers of artificial intelligence: a sit-down with Elon Musk.

headline: An Alabama Newspaper Publisher and Reporter Are Arrested, Raising Alarms
abstract: The publisher of Atmore News in Atmore, Ala., and a reporter at the paper were charged with revealing grand jury evidence in an article published last month.
lead_paragraph: A newspaper publisher and reporter in Alabama were arrested last week and charged with disclosing grand jury evidence in an article, alarming press freedom advocates who raised First Amendment concerns.

headline: Islamic Art Exhibition Postponed in Pittsburgh Amid Israel-Hamas War
abstract: The Frick Pittsburgh cited fears that the show could become “a source of unintended insensitivity or offense.”
lead_paragraph: The Frick Pittsburgh postponed an exhibition featuring 10 centuries of Islamic art that was supposed to open on Saturday, citing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war and the fear that the show could become “a source of unintended insensitivity or offense.”

headline: U.S. Drones Are Flying Over Gaza to Aid in Hostage Recovery, Officials Say
abstract: The military has been sending weapons and advisers to Israel, but the flights suggest a more active American role.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military is flying surveillance drones over the Gaza Strip, according to two Defense Department officials and an analysis by The New York Times. The officials said the drones were being used to aid in hostage recovery efforts, indicating that the U.S. is more involved than previously known.

headline: How to Stay Sane in Brutalizing Times
abstract: Ancient wisdom can help keep us from becoming calloused over.
lead_paragraph: We’re living in a brutalizing time: Scenes of mass savagery pervade the media. Americans have become vicious toward one another amid our disagreements. Everywhere I go, people are coping with an avalanche of negative emotions: shock, pain, contempt, anger, anxiety, fear.

headline: Israel, the I.R.S. and the Big Grift
abstract: Holding national security hostage to help tax cheats.
lead_paragraph: Historians of propaganda are familiar with the concept of the Big Lie, a claim so extreme that many people end up accepting it because they can’t believe that authority figures would make up something so at odds with reality.

headline: ‘All the Light We Cannot See’ Review: The Blind Girl and the Nazi
abstract: A Netflix mini-series brings to the screen Anthony Doerr’s Pulitzer-winning World War II romance.
lead_paragraph: Marie-Laure and Werner, the destined soul mates who will eventually meet in the Netflix mini-series “All the Light We Cannot See,” are on opposite sides of a cataclysmic divide. She is a French teenager delivering coded radio messages to the Allied bombing command in World War II; he is a young Nazi radio technician assigned to track her down in her Saint-Malo garret, as the bombs rain and American troops close in.

headline: The Laws of War Have Limits. What Does That Mean for the Hamas-Israel War?
abstract: For many readers, the events of the past few weeks have raised profound and vexing questions that can illustrate the limits and strengths of international law.
lead_paragraph: It has been 26 days since Hamas launched its attacks on Israel. In my column a few days after the conflict began, I said that international law offered a framework for analyzing what was happening, even while the atrocities committed by Hamas were still being documented, and as the consequences of Israel’s devastating airstrikes on Gaza and cutoff of food, water and fuel were beginning to unfold.

headline: TikTok Pushes Back Against Claims It Fuels Antisemitism
abstract: The company said it had removed millions of TikTok videos in recent weeks related to hate speech, hateful behavior, harassment and bullying.
lead_paragraph: TikTok pushed back on Thursday against growing claims in recent weeks that it had failed to protect Jewish users and had pushed pro-Palestinian content in the United States.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Is Found Guilty of 7 Counts of Fraud and Conspiracy
abstract: The case against the founder of the failed FTX exchange had come to symbolize the excesses of the volatile cryptocurrency industry.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the tousle-haired mogul who founded the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was convicted on Thursday of seven charges of fraud and conspiracy after a monthlong trial that laid bare the rampant hubris and risk-taking across the crypto industry.

headline: Judge Rules in Family Dispute Over Rockwells Long Hung at White House
abstract: Relatives of Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s press secretary went to federal court to resolve a disagreement over who owned Norman Rockwell drawings valued at $8 million.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has made a decision in a dispute between relatives of Franklin D. Roosevelt’s press secretary over ownership of four Norman Rockwell drawings that hung for decades in the White House.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Wild Rise and Abrupt Crash
