abstract: The crypto king gambled that his trading platform would make him a benevolent trillionaire. But after a fraud conviction, all bets are off.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in the development of a new technology when the hype is so common it passes for common sense. Lawyers, accountants and regulators are nowhere to be found. Investors insist entrepreneurs take their money. The world trembles on the brink of change.

headline: Silicon Valley Shrugs Off Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
abstract: Tech investors lauded Mr. Bankman-Fried and helped fund his FTX crypto exchange. The tech industry has since done what it does best: move on.
lead_paragraph: In the four weeks that Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was on trial on fraud charges, the tech industry:

headline: Mets Hire the Former N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Keechant Sewell
abstract: After abruptly resigning from the top job in the Police Department in June, Ms. Sewell will help lead security in Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Keechant Sewell, the former New York City police commissioner, has been hired by the Mets.

headline: Laufey’s Old-Time Pop Is Smooth. Its Relationship to Jazz Is Spikier.
abstract: The 24-year-old multi-instrumentalist found fame on TikTok with her nostalgic songs. But her dedication to her followers may be holding her music back.
lead_paragraph: About 20 minutes into her set at Town Hall on Wednesday night — the first of two sold-out shows at the Midtown Manhattan theater — the nostalgic TikTok star Laufey put down her hollow-body electric guitar. With her hands free, she started singing “Dreamer,” the barbershop-pop tune that opens her second album, “Bewitched.” As she moved across the stage, she struck a new pose for each line: bending forward at the waist, as if to share a morsel of gossip; leg straight, hip bent; head turned sideways, as if mid-sigh.

headline: ‘I Need That’ Review: It’s Always Messy in New Jersey
abstract: Danny DeVito returns to Broadway in a Theresa Rebeck comedy about a lonely old man lost in a houseful of junk.
lead_paragraph: Even before the lights dim at the start of “I Need That,” the new Theresa Rebeck play at the American Airlines Theater, the show curtain and what’s in front of it offer plenty of exposition. The curtain is painted to depict the street grid of a neat New Jersey town, with neat houses on neat lots. But, uh-oh, creeping out from beneath it, on the floor of the stage, are boxes and bins overflowing with junk: ancient copies of Popular Science, bruised holiday decorations, stacks of old clothes, a sad single sneaker.

headline: Inside the early-morning line to see Sam Bankman-Fried’s trial.
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried’s criminal fraud trial was not the only high-stakes struggle that unfolded this past month at the federal courthouse in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried’s criminal fraud trial was not the only high-stakes struggle that unfolded this past month at the federal courthouse in Manhattan.

headline: A First Title for the Rangers, and a Thrill for the Former First Fan
abstract: Ownership of the Texas Rangers helped propel George W. Bush’s political career, and decades later, a friend says, baseball remains “part of who he is.”
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t come with a ring, but this week was still special for former First Fan George W. Bush. Nearly three decades after he sold the Texas Rangers, the team that propelled him into politics finally brought home its first World Series title.

headline: Trump Asks Federal Appeals Court to Lift Gag Order in Election Case
abstract: The former president argued that the order restricting what he can say about the case should not be in effect while he seeks to have it thrown out on appeal.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump filed an emergency request to a federal appeals court on Thursday seeking to lift the gag order imposed on him in the criminal case in which he stands accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Get in Position
abstract: Happy Robyn Weintraub day!
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart build a puzzle in an orderly fashion.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage begins in space and ends in the recesses of our minds, which is no mean feat in some 35 words. It’s an excerpt from a 1987 book by Jean Aitchison, a linguist, called “Words in the Mind: An Introduction to the Mental Lexicon.” In it, Ms. Aitchison differentiates between syntax, which organizes how we link words and structures our communication, like mortar, and vocabulary, which builds up in our memory block by block, like bricks.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Israeli troops enter Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers have encircled Gaza City, the Israeli military said yesterday, waging “face-to-face battles” with Hamas as they push forward with what officials have predicted will be a long and bloody ground invasion.

headline: As Cars Have Grown Bigger, Parking Spaces Might, Too
abstract: Australians are grumbling about a recent invasion of American-style giant pickup trucks. But even before that, vehicle sizes were increasing.
lead_paragraph: Massive American-style pickup trucks are having a surge of popularity in Australia, to the annoyance of some drivers.

headline: Magic in the First Five Minutes. Love Within 15.
abstract: After their first date, Banks Clark slipped a note into Jackie Patmore’s purse. “You have changed everything,” it read.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Marie Patmore and Banks Thomas Clark barely touched their appetizers — deviled eggs, brussels sprouts, onion rings and jalapeño poppers — during their first date one rainy evening in October 2021 at Freebird Kitchen and Bar in White Plains, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 3, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the knowledge of the deteriorating mental health of the man suspected of killing 18 people in a mass shooting in Maine misidentified the people who visited the him in May. It was his brother and sister, not his ex-wife and sister.

headline: A ‘Professional Crush’ Turns Romantic
abstract: When Leah Wong met Dennis Fan, she was inspired by his passion for his work. His advice helped shape a future they are building together.
lead_paragraph: When Leah Wong and Dennis Fan first met at a happy hour at the National Asian Pacific American Bar Association Convention in Austin, Texas, in November 2019, there was a spark. And it was purely professional.

headline: Quote of the Day: What the First One Means
abstract: Quote of the Day for Friday, November 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We were so bad, we made the world’s greatest hitter quit. Ted decided he’d rather go fishing, to hell with this.”

headline: Finding the Right Match After Reconsidering a Swipe Left
abstract: Katherine Corrado was hesitant about dating someone in broadcast journalism. But after seeing Paul Gerke’s dating profile three years ago, she changed her mind.
lead_paragraph: When Katherine Mary Corrado and Paul Ryan Gerke first saw each other’s profiles on the dating app Bumble in September 2020, each found the other to be a breath of fresh air. There was just one problem for Ms. Corrado: Mr. Gerke was a “TV man,” so she swiped left.

headline: A Marriage Problem That Can’t Be Solved
abstract: My husband and I haven’t spoken in more than a year. It can’t go on like this, but it will.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are going through a really difficult time in our marriage, and there doesn’t seem to be a lot of advice for how to proceed. We haven’t spoken in more than a year. When the children ask where he is, I don’t know what to say. I have had to take over all the household tasks, plus a lot of legal and financial paperwork. I’ve had a lot of time to reflect on all the things I’ve done wrong, but I can’t apologize.

headline: Trudging Through Sobriety and Other Challenges, One Step at a Time
abstract: As Morgan Hartman and Phillip de Amezola supported each through personal health crises, their relationship and a “love plant” flourished.
lead_paragraph: In March 2018, Morgan Olivia Hartman, who was new to Alcoholics Anonymous, attended the Miami district annual A.A. banquet dinner. Phillip Xavier de Amezola, who had been sober for four years at the time, was also there, seated at another table.

headline: Somewhat Guiltily, Ukrainians Miss Matthew Perry
abstract: Even as the war’s devastation rages on, Ukrainians have found space to mourn an actor who brought them comfort and laughter.
lead_paragraph: It was the middle of the night in Ukraine, and Natalia Sosnytska couldn’t sleep. So she opened the Instagram app on her phone — and saw that the actor Matthew Perry had died.

headline: How Should Assault Look Onscreen? It Doesn’t Need to Be Seen.
abstract: In new films, including “How to Have Sex,” female British directors emphasize the impact of sexual trauma, rather than portraying the act itself.
lead_paragraph: When Molly Manning-Walker was a teenager, her favorite film was Gaspar Noé’s “Irreversible.” In a recent interview, she remembered being impressed by the film’s infamously brutal, nine-minute rape scene, and how “immersive” it was.

headline: Kyiv’s Exiled Biennial Is the Most Energizing Exhibition of the Year
abstract: The contemporary art show has spread beyond Ukraine’s borders and is now an eight-city European festival about war, democracy and solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Containment is a strategy that works only so long; the war will not stay put, the war will come to you. The Kyiv Biennial, a key fixture of contemporary art in Eastern Europe over the past decade, has opened its fifth edition on time and at full scale, but not (or not principally) at home. It has taken flight, spread beyond Ukraine’s borders. It has multiplied itself into a major European festival on war, democracy and the waning promise of solidarity. It has a scholar’s ambition but a slacker’s style; it spans a continent even as it anchors itself in Kyiv. It’s the most energizing exhibition of the year.

headline: A Giant Leap for the Leap Second. Is Humankind Ready?
abstract: A top scientist has proposed a new way to reconcile the two different ways that our clocks keep time. Meet — wait for it — the leap minute.
lead_paragraph: Later this month, delegations from around the world will head to a conference in Dubai to discuss international treaties involving radio frequencies, satellite coordination and other tricky technical issues. These include the nagging problem of the clocks.

headline: Former Pennsylvania Nurse Is Linked to 17 Nursing Home Deaths
abstract: Heather Pressdee, 41, confessed to trying to kill 19 patients with insulin. She had already been charged in the deaths of two others this year.
lead_paragraph: A former Pennsylvania nurse who had been accused of killing two patients with doses of insulin faces more murder charges and has confessed to trying to kill 19 additional people at several locations, the authorities said Thursday.

headline: Jeff Bezos Says He Is Leaving Seattle for Miami
abstract: The Amazon founder has lived in Seattle since 1994. He said he was returning to Miami, where he attended high school, in part to be closer to his parents.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, who founded Amazon out of his Seattle garage in 1994 and plowed billions of dollars into transforming the city into a tech boomtown, said on Thursday that he was leaving his home of three decades and moving to Miami.

headline: Late Night Celebrates George Santos Sticking Around
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel was selfishly thrilled that the House voted to keep the New York representative in office, saying Santos “will live to scam another day.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: sumptuous
abstract: This word has appeared in 152 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word sumptuous has appeared in 152 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 16 in “Withstanding the Passage of Time, but Not the Shaking of the Earth” by Vivian Yee and Aida Alami:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Was a Grown Up Criminal, Not an Impulsive Man-Child
abstract: Investors bought into the perception of the FTX founder as an unkempt boy genius. The jury didn’t buy it.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, crypto’s Icarus, was convicted of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday night after a trial that generated 10 million pages of documents and only a few hours of jury deliberation. As ever, it is perhaps best to start from the very beginning.

headline: People and Penguins
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Why Run the New York City Marathon When You Can Drive It?
abstract: You’re not going to catch the elite runners. But if you can get over the traffic, the scenery is terrific. And the doughnuts aren’t bad either.
lead_paragraph: An eighteen-wheeler sat motionless at the intersection of 26th Street and Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, completely blocking traffic in all directions. As motorists blasted their horns in an orchestra of rage, the bewildered truck driver hopped down from the cab and began yelling — in a distinctly out-of-town drawl — at the pileup of cars behind him on 26th, demanding they back the heck up.

headline: What It’s Actually Like to Run the New York City Marathon Route
abstract: Want to feel like the most beloved person on the planet? All you have to do is run 26.2 miles through New York City on Marathon Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Marathon is not where world records are set.

headline: The Dreams of Gaza’s Kids, and the Nightmare They Are Living
abstract: Two years ago, filmmakers asked children in Gaza about their dreams for the future. These were their responses.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, filmmakers asked children in Gaza about their dreams for the future. These were their responses.

headline: U.S. Citizen Crosses the Rafah Border
abstract: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen, described her journey from Gaza to Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen, described her journey from Gaza to Egypt.

headline: Some Psychiatrists Have Started Prescribing Ozempic
abstract: Doctors say the diabetes medication, and drugs like it, could counteract the weight patients gain on antipsychotics and antidepressants.
lead_paragraph: It was Joanna Acevedo’s psychiatrist who first raised the idea of a weight-loss drug. Since 2018, Ms. Acevedo has relied on antipsychotic medications to manage her bipolar disorder. The drugs kept her paranoia at bay — really, they kept her alive, she said. They also led her to gain 70 pounds. By age 26, she had become prediabetic.

headline: An Ode to the Women of Hip-Hop That Plays Like a Mixtape
abstract: On the genre’s 50th anniversary, “The Motherlode” honors contributions by the women, like Salt-N-Pepa, Roxanne Shanté and Megan Thee Stallion, who’ve made it what it is today.
lead_paragraph: Clover Hope’s “The Motherlode” pulses with beats of hip-hop history, from its hidden figures to its success stories, all told from a woman’s perspective. Borrowing its title from the West Coast rapper Yo-Yo’s 1991 debut album, “Make Way for the Motherlode,” the audiobook celebrates hip-hop’s 50th anniversary this year by correcting the male-dominated record, re-contextualizing the genre’s history in light of the contributions made by female artists from the 1970s to today.

headline: In the World’s Driest Desert, Ancient Wisdom Blooms Eternal
abstract: Burned out from life in New York, a photographer traveled to northern Chile to study the ancient wisdom of the Lickanantay, the area’s Indigenous people. Here’s what she saw.
lead_paragraph: I was seated with nine other artists in the middle of the Chilean desert, with volcanic Andean peaks ahead of me and the Cordillera de la Sal, or Salt Mountains, behind me. I squinted toward the early morning sun reaching over the peaks, feeling small as it began to light up the desert in every direction. Carlos, our host, had laid out a blanket on the warm sand and was now setting down a bottle of red wine, a bowl of coca leaves and four cups.

headline: The Youngest Senior
abstract: Moving to Florida for early retirement, a native New Jerseyan in her 50s is finding her third act to be the most fun in a community where the average age is 79.
lead_paragraph: When residents at Sun City Center, a sprawling retirement community in West Central Florida, struggle with their electronics, many of them now know who to call on: Maria Hodge, one of their newest residents, and also one of their youngest.

headline: As a Teen, She Loved Video Games. Now She’s Using A.I. to Try to Quash Malaria.
abstract: Rokhaya Diagne, a 25-year-old A.I. entrepreneur in Senegal, is part of a subset of Africa’s enormous youth population that is confident technology can solve the continent’s biggest problems.
lead_paragraph: When she was in her early teens, Rokhaya Diagne would retreat to her brother’s room, where she played online computer games for hours, day after day, until her mother finally got fed up.

headline: ‘Selling Sunset,’ Dressed to the Nines
abstract: The reality show is supposed to be about real estate. But many viewers are coming just for the fashion, and the cast knows it.

headline: Can Humanities Survive the Budget Cuts?
abstract: After years of hand-wringing about their future, liberal arts departments now face the chopping block. At risk: French, German, American studies and women’s studies.
lead_paragraph: The state auditor of Mississippi recently released an eight-page report suggesting that the state should invest more in college degree programs that could “improve the value they provide to both taxpayers and graduates.”

headline: Job Growth Slows, Sowing a Mix of Concern and Calm
abstract: U.S. employers added 150,000 workers in October, falling short of expectations, but the labor market retains spark nearly three years into a recovery.
lead_paragraph: The labor market has been relentlessly hot since the U.S. economy began to recover from the shock of the pandemic. But there are signs of cooling as the holidays approach.

headline: Rock ’n’ Soul: The Amazing Story of Sly & the Family Stone
abstract: At the age of 80, Sly Stone has finally produced his memoir, and it gives a strong sense of this giant’s voice and sensibility.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to convey just how astoundingly unlikely it is that this book exists. Sly Stone is one of pop music’s truest geniuses and greatest mysteries, who essentially disappeared four decades ago in a cloud of drugs and legal problems after recording several albums’ worth of incomparable, visionary songs. Fleeting, baffling, blink-and-you-miss-him appearances at his 1993 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction and a 2006 Grammy tribute only served as reminders that he was still alive and still not well.

headline: 3 New Middle Grade Science Fiction Novels Disturb and Delight
abstract: Jeanne DuPrau’s “Project F,” Patricia Forde’s “The Girl Who Fell to Earth” and Donna Barba Higuera’s “Alebrijes” answer the question, Could this be the beginning of the end?
lead_paragraph: Worldwide flooding. Massive Canadian wildfires. Monster hurricanes. Record-breaking heat waves. Sauna-level sea temperatures. The loss of billions of tons of Arctic and glacial ice. The existential question of the summer was, Could this be the beginning of the end? Three new speculative novels for young readers answer yes, with varying degrees of resignation and sorrow, bitterness and hope.

headline: A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken.
abstract: This flood-prone city on the Hudson River has bundled water-absorbing infrastructure into benefits residents asked for, like parks and safer streets.
lead_paragraph: The city of Hoboken, N.J., once a marshy outcropping that the Lenape inhabited only seasonally, hugs the Hudson River. Three-quarters of it occupies a flood plain. It is, in other words, a water magnet. Some scientists have forecast that, with rising seas, a big chunk of Hoboken will be Atlantis by 2100.

headline: A $75 Million Sale at 220 Central Park South Is One of the Year’s Biggest
abstract: The full-floor apartment was sold to a buyer who already owns a condo in the building. Another property went for $66 million, and still others for $50 million or more.
lead_paragraph: A flurry of big sales closed in New York City during October, including one of the year’s priciest, a full-floor aerie at 220 Central Park South purchased in a private deal for $75 million.

headline: Electric Planes, Once a Fantasy, Start to Take to the Skies
abstract: How a small plane’s 16-day trip from Vermont to Florida might foreshadow a new era of battery-powered air travel long considered implausible.
lead_paragraph: Chris Caputo stood on the tarmac at Burlington International Airport in Vermont in early October and looked to the clouds in the distance. He had piloted military and commercial aircraft over a long career, racking up thousands of flight hours, but the trip he was about to take would be very different.

headline: The Original Birders Gave Photography a Run for Its Money
abstract: Two art books revisit 19th-century illustrations by John James Audubon and Elizabeth Gould.
lead_paragraph: As the National Audubon Society recovers from a referendum to change its name in light of the fact that America’s founding birder was a slave owner (the name stayed), a luxe reissue of John James Audubon’s magnum opus, BIRDS OF AMERICA (Abbeville, $195), proves the man’s artistry itself unimpeachable.

headline: In a New Memoir, Tracy K. Smith Connects Her Life to a Bigger Picture
abstract: The former poet laureate examines our country’s oldest wounds — and ongoing racism — through the lens of her own family’s experience.
lead_paragraph: Since her first book of poetry, “The Body’s Question,” was published in 2003, Tracy K. Smith has been a writer to watch. Her poems and prose are forceful, intelligent and musical, earning her a Whiting Award and a Pulitzer Prize, among other accolades.

headline: The Presidential Fantasy Draft America Needs
abstract: Our 2024 options are terrible. Can we hope for more than Biden or Trump?
lead_paragraph: The polls are clear: Neither Joe Biden nor Donald Trump has the full confidence of American voters. But is Biden’s latest competition, Democratic Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, the answer to voters’ malaise? Or perhaps an independent candidate like Robert F. Kennedy Jr.?

headline: The Man Who Moved the Marathon Beyond Central Park
abstract: Ted Corbitt, who wore bib No. 1 in the first marathon in 1970, pitched the idea of expanding the race to all five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about one of the most important marathon runners many participants in Sunday’s New York City Marathon have probably never heard of. We’ll also get details on a settlement that will mean a $328 million payout for Uber and Lyft drivers.

headline: Biden Can’t Stop Immigration. Time to Embrace It.
abstract: No matter how cruel or restrictive his policies, they will never be enough to appease his critics.
lead_paragraph: When Joe Biden became president, he assumed a nearly impossible task: stopping migrants from crossing the U.S.-Mexico border amid a global displacement crisis. Despite his efforts, under his watch the number of people who crossed the border has risen sharply. Republicans have blamed the president, claiming that he has opened the borders.

headline: An Unarmed Teen Was Shot During a Cease-Fire. Israel Was Never Held to Account.
abstract: The people of Gaza deserve to enjoy full civil rights, including the right to compensatory damages. Without those rights, what can we expect them to do with their pain?
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of his 15th birthday, Attiya Nabaheen was walking home from his school in Gaza when an Israeli soldier shot him in the neck. It was November 2014, and Mr. Nabaheen was on his family’s land, situated about 500 meters from the militarized Green Line demarcating the Gaza Strip. In court proceedings, a lawyer representing the Israeli government claimed that Mr. Nabaheen was too close to the fence and didn’t heed warning shots before he was hit. Neither his age nor the fact that he was unarmed stopped the soldier from firing at the boy. The injury left Mr. Nabaheen permanently paralyzed and wheelchair bound for the rest of his life. This all happened during a cease-fire, a time of supposed peace, or status quo, in Gaza.

headline: Help! We’re Booked on a Nile Cruise but Worry About Our Safety.
abstract: A Jewish couple about to go on a long-delayed $29,000 dream trip to Egypt and Jordan are afraid to travel because of the war in Gaza, but Viking says it’s safe.
lead_paragraph: After two pandemic-related delays, we were finally set to take a $34,309 Nile cruise with Viking, leaving Oct. 25 and including several days in Cairo and additional excursions to Jerusalem and Petra, in Jordan. But the war broke out, and the Middle East is very unstable. Viking canceled our excursion to Jerusalem, refunded that money and rebooked our flights for Oct. 29. But we don’t think Egypt or Jordan is particularly safe right now either, especially for Jews. We are older, and are heartsick at not seeing Jerusalem and terrified at the thought of being targeted as American Jewish tourists during this war. Viking still has $29,435 of our money. We only want a voucher to take the same trip in the future. Can you help? Joseph and Antonia, Oakland, Calif.

headline: Otto Klemperer’s Conducting Still Stuns, 50 Years After His Death
abstract: Recording collections reveal the talents of an essential 20th-century musician who lived through mental illness, Nazism and other tribulations.
lead_paragraph: There is a touching documentary about Otto Klemperer, that steadfast titan of conducting who died 50 years ago, by the filmmaker Philo Bregstein. Watch it for long enough, and a rather surprising face appears — surprising, at least, if you think of Klemperer as he is so often imagined, as only the last in a venerable line of German musicians, and not as the architect of something new.

headline: When Have You Felt That You Mattered?
abstract: On a sports team? In a class project? With your family? Tell us about a time when you felt important and needed.
lead_paragraph: When somebody tells you that you “matter,” what does that mean to you? How does it feel?

headline: What Is Happening on College Campuses Is Not Free Speech
abstract: Not only are harassment and intimidation not protected by the First Amendment, but they fly in the face of the purpose of a university.
lead_paragraph: Since the Hamas terrorist attacks on Oct. 7, campus life in the United States has imploded into a daily trial of intimidation and insult for Jewish students. A hostile environment that began with statements from pro-Palestinian student organizations justifying terrorism has now rapidly spiraled into death threats and physical attacks, leaving Jewish students alarmed and vulnerable.

headline: What It Takes to Wear the Sudoku Crown
abstract: Pens, pencils and a facility with numbers. Also helpful: earplugs, plushies, a water bottle, calming herbal oil and the occasional “wild bifurcation” (a.k.a. a wild guess).
lead_paragraph: On a mid-October Monday, shortly before 9 a.m., 179 elite puzzlers made their way into the ballroom of a Toronto hotel and found their allocated seats for the World Sudoku and Puzzle Championships. Valentin Miakinen of France positioned a plastic, pigeon-shaped hunting decoy at the front of his desk, for luck. Hwangrae Lee, from Korea, polished his pencil sharpener with a tissue. Quiet descended as proctors distributed booklets for Round 1: nine Sudoku puzzles, with a 45-minute time limit. Thomas Snyder, the general manager of the event, announced: “We begin in 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 — go!”

headline: Economists Ignored Inequality for Years. Now They Can’t Stop Talking About It.
abstract: A flurry of new books highlights broad disagreements over how to address the problem.
lead_paragraph: When the economist Angus Deaton moved to the United States in 1983, he was “in awe,” as he puts it in his new book, “Economics in America.” Born in Scotland and educated at the University of Cambridge, he remembers the swell of optimism he felt upon arriving at Princeton University. It was a “splendid place to work,” especially for someone who had been poor enough as a child to appreciate the measure of security provided by an “American salary.”

headline: Not the Brightest Killer of the Flower Moon
abstract: Leonardo DiCaprio’s Ernest is unlike any Scorsese protagonist because, well, he’s dumb as rocks. And that changes the film in a fundamental way.
lead_paragraph: The demimondes depicted by the American master Martin Scorsese vary widely — his New York stories alone span three centuries — but they have one common requirement: It takes intelligence, of one kind or another, to navigate them. His protagonists are smart, street smart, shrewd, skillful or some combination of those qualities as a rule.

headline: N.F.L., on Lookout for Growth, Finds Open Arms in Germany
abstract: Football was introduced to the country by U.S. soldiers after World War II, but interests soared when the N.F.L. played its first regular-season game there last year.
lead_paragraph: About 60 hardcore fans of the National Football League piled into the party space at Der Player, a fancy eatery, on a chilly evening in Hamburg, Germany, last month. Wearing jerseys and hoodies of teams like the Chicago Bears, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Las Vegas Raiders, they grabbed seats to watch a taping of “Prime Time Football Live,” which attracts thousands of viewers on YouTube.

headline: The Dreams of Gaza’s Kids, and the Nightmare They Are Living
abstract: Two years ago, filmmakers asked children in Gaza about their dreams for the future. These were their responses.
lead_paragraph: We often measure the tragedy of war in the suffering of children, but rarely do we hear from them. Two years ago, filmmakers asked children in Gaza, where nearly half the population is under 18, a seemingly simple question: What is your dream? The video above reveals their answers which, in light of the violence that has embroiled the region in recent weeks, are all the more poignant.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film "Fingernails."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film "Fingernails."

headline: Labor Movements Sprinkled With ‘Salts’
abstract: The term refers to people who take jobs at a workplace to help unionize it, a practice that appears to be on the rise.
lead_paragraph: The term refers to people who take jobs at a workplace to help unionize it, a practice that appears to be on the rise.

headline: She Polled Gazans on Oct. 6. Here’s What She Found.
abstract: On the eve of the Oct. 7 attacks, Amaney Jamal asked Gazans what they thought about Hamas, their economic circumstances and their hopes for long-term peace.
lead_paragraph: The day before Hamas’s horrific attacks in Israel, the Arab Barometer, one of the leading polling operations in the Arab world, was finishing up a survey of public opinion in Gaza.

headline: Don’t Underestimate the Power of a Compliment
abstract: Offering praise benefits everyone, experts say. Here’s how to do it like a pro.
lead_paragraph: A stranger gave me a compliment 10 years ago that I’ll never forget. I was at a diner in Brooklyn with my then 3-year-old and a few of her friends. I was making them laugh by acting silly — inserting two long French fries under my upper lip so I looked like a walrus, for example.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 3, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Orhan Pamuk, Rob Delaney, Carolyn Hays and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Orhan Pamuk, Rob Delaney, Carolyn Hays and more.

headline: Casey Goes to the White House + The Copyright Battle Over Artificial Intelligence + HatGPT
abstract: “It’s America, you can always sue.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s new executive order on artificial intelligence has a little bit of everything for everyone concerned about A.I. Casey takes us inside the White House as the order was signed.

headline: On TikTok, Gen Z Beatles Fans Share Thoughts on ‘Now and Then’
abstract: “Can’t believe it’s 2023 and I get the joy of hearing a new Beatles song for the first time ever,” a 23-year-old says in a video post.
lead_paragraph: Eloise Smith, 23, posted a reaction video on TikTok immediately after listening to “Now and Then,” the Beatles song released on Thursday.

headline: Fire at Drug Rehab Center in Iran Kills at Least 32, State Media Report
abstract: A local official reportedly said the center’s manager had been arrested, and he blamed overcrowding at the facility for the high toll.
lead_paragraph: At least 32 people were killed and 16 others injured when a fire tore through a drug rehabilitation center in northern Iran on Friday, state media reported.

abstract: How the events of that fateful year shaped the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades to come.
lead_paragraph: As the Israeli-Palestinian conflict enters its darkest chapter in decades, both sides are evoking the same foundational moment in their past: the events of 1948.

headline: Revisiting the Gaza Hospital Explosion
abstract: We look at the evidence for who is responsible.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a few days after the explosion at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, I walked you through the debate over who was responsible. At the time, there wasn’t much evidence that outsiders could assess on their own. The dispute revolved around competing claims from Israel and Hamas.

headline: After a 40-Year Wait, a Trap Shooter Returns to the Olympics
abstract: Leonel Martínez, a trap shooter from Venezuela, left the Summer Games in 1984 without making the podium. At 60, he’s again vying for a medal.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, Leonel Martínez of Venezuela competed in the trap shooting event at the Los Angeles Olympic Games. He finished tied for 41st.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a restored Disney classic, a wholesome family romp and an underdog dramedy.
lead_paragraph: In 1937, “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs” captured the imaginations of children and adults, and set Disney on a path to creating endless classics, including “Fantasia” (1940), “The Lion King” (1994) and more. To celebrate the company’s 100th anniversary this year, Disney+ is streaming a 4K restoration of “Snow White.” While kids might be familiar with the story of the dark-haired princess, her mirror-loving evil stepmother and the seven dwarfs, it’s worth showing them the restored film version so they can absorb the tale in all its original glory (beautified by modern technology, of course).

headline: What the Suburbs Did for Billy Joel and Bruce Springsteen
abstract: A new book by the author Jim Cullen explores the uncanny parallels between the careers of these two musicians, and how they were products of their time and place.
lead_paragraph: It was the 25th anniversary concert celebrating the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame at Madison Square Garden in 2009 when Bruce Springsteen bellowed to the crowd: “Are you ready for the bridge-and-tunnel summit meeting right here, right now? Because Long Island is about to meet New Jersey on the neutral ground of New York City!”

headline: As Gaza War Enters New Phase, Israel Faces Pressure Over Civilian Deaths
abstract: Fears are rising that the conflict could spread to the occupied West Bank, where tensions are soaring among Palestinians angered over deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a week after Israeli tanks and troops poured into Gaza, Israeli military officials say they have made steady gains against Hamas. But the ground operation, which now encircles Gaza City, is entering an acutely perilous phase, with Israeli troops advancing in an urban landscape that is honeycombed with tunnels and home to many Palestinians.

headline: Guilty on All Counts, Bankman-Fried Completes a Fall From Grace
abstract: The verdict in the FTX founder’s fraud trial leaves the crypto industry’s onetime poster child facing a lifetime behind bars.
lead_paragraph: It took jurors just four-and-a-half hours yesterday to reach a verdict in the monthlong fraud trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the fallen cryptocurrency exchange FTX. The result was unanimous: guilty on all counts.

headline: New Phase of Gateway Tunnel Project in Hudson River to Begin
abstract: Work on the long-delayed rail tunnel is set to speed up this month, as Senator Chuck Schumer announces an additional $3.8 billion in federal funding.
lead_paragraph: Construction of the long-delayed rail tunnel under the Hudson River is about to speed up, as the project gets an additional $3.8 billion in federal funding.

headline: The President of Israel: This Is Not a Battle Just Between Israel and Hamas
abstract: All nations should realize that they could be the next target for terrorists.
lead_paragraph: I write these lines from Jerusalem, after spending time with the families of some of the 240 people kidnapped by Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7. The hostages now held in Gaza include Jewish Israelis, Muslim Israelis and foreign citizens of different ethnicities.

headline: Open Enrollment Begins for Affordable Care Act Health Plans
abstract: Pandemic-era help with the monthly insurance premium costs continues through 2025.
lead_paragraph: The annual sign-up window for Affordable Care Act plans, which offer health insurance to millions of Americans who do not receive it through work, opened this week in most states. And the good news is that temporarily expanded federal help is expected to keep monthly costs manageable for many people next year.

headline: In a Warming World, Clean Energy Stocks Fall While Oil Prospers
abstract: The market is focused on making money now and isn’t heeding urgent warnings about climate change, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Heat, drought, flood and famine. Evidence of climate change is all around us.

headline: The Woman Who Has Fought to Save L.A. History From Demolition
abstract: A conversation with Linda Dishman, the outgoing president of the Los Angeles Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: Some California cities are famed for their love of historic and cultural attractions. Los Angeles is not one of them — an unfair omission, I’ve always thought.

headline: How to Make the Most of the Morning Light
abstract: Now that the clocks have fallen back, it’s dark much earlier. Here’s how to become a morning person.
lead_paragraph: The dread sets in around 4 p.m., as the sun inches closer to the horizon and starts to wind down for the day. The end of Daylight Saving Time every fall can feel like something out of a Stephen King novel.

headline: In High-Stakes Speech, Hezbollah’s Leader Stops Short of Call to Expand Hamas War
abstract: In his first public comments since the war in Gaza began, Hassan Nasrallah said his powerful Lebanese militia had bogged down Israeli forces to help Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Since the war in Gaza began after Hamas’s surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7, people across the Middle East have feared it could set off a second war between Israel and Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militia, and ignite a broader regional conflagration.

headline: Remembering Food’s Punk-Rock Moment and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Trump Lawyers Attack Judge’s Clerk, Eclipsing His Son’s Testimony
abstract: The law clerk, a Democrat, has irritated the former president as she communicates with the judge overseeing his civil fraud trial.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s legal team on Friday repeatedly attacked a law clerk during the former president’s civil fraud trial, overshadowing Eric Trump’s second day on the witness stand and prompting the judge to bar the lawyers from making public statements about his private communications with his staff.

headline: How to Store Print Photographs
abstract: The most important thing is to select a safe location.
lead_paragraph: The most important thing is to select a safe location.

headline: Less Pollution, More Global Warming
abstract: As we clean up the air, we also seem to making warming a bit worse.
lead_paragraph: Some good news: The air we breathe has been getting cleaner.

headline: Headwind Cycling Race Called Off Over Too Much Wind
abstract: Storm Ciarán, which has battered Western Europe this week, proved too much for a quirky Dutch cycling competition.
lead_paragraph: One of the most eccentric sporting events on the Dutch calendar was canceled this week over safety concerns as Ciarán, a deadly storm, brought heavy rains and winds over 85 m.p.h. to parts of Western Europe.

headline: F.B.I. Raid of Adams Ally Brings Corruption Question to Mayor’s Doorstep
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has faced ethics issues for years. A raid of his chief fund-raiser’s home poses a serious threat.
lead_paragraph: Even as Eric Adams completed his rise in New York City politics and became mayor, questions remained over ethical issues and his ties to people with troubling pasts.

headline: Russia Sends Biggest Drone Barrage in Weeks, Ukrainian Officials Say
abstract: Army officials and military analysts say it is part of a campaign to wear down and probe Ukrainian air defenses ahead of winter.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces targeted Ukraine overnight with their biggest drone attack in weeks, part of what Ukrainian officials and military analysts say appears to be a campaign to wear down and probe Ukrainian air defenses ahead of winter.

headline: Noah Kahan’s Rootsy Rock Revival
abstract: Revisiting the rustic mainstream sound of the early 2010s, the Vermont singer-songwriter has broken through with “Stick Season.”
lead_paragraph: Noah Kahan’s song “Stick Season” currently sits at No. 43 on the Billboard Hot 100. On its own, that’s a moderately impressive feat. But it’s more remarkable because “Stick Season” is the title track of an album released just over a year ago. Via diligent touring and an instinctual grip on how to leverage TikTok, Kahan has squeezed a fan favorite so hard it became a hit.

headline: What Is a Covenant Marriage?
abstract: A marriage contract that makes divorce difficult is a way for some couples to protect their partnerships. However, some experts believe that this type of union has both advantages and disadvantages.
lead_paragraph: Many states in America, depending on state-specific laws, allow “no-fault” divorces, in which either partner can end their marriage for any reason. But with a covenant marriage, there are stricter guidelines for ending a marriage. Revelations concerning Mike Johnson, the new speaker of the House, and his own covenant marriage have brought the unconventional commitment arrangement into the spotlight.

headline: Biden Hosts Leaders of South American Nations for an Economic Summit
abstract: One goal is to help bolster economies of countries across the region so they can better absorb the millions of migrants who are fleeing poverty, political instability and natural disasters.
lead_paragraph: President Biden hosted officials from 11 countries in the Western Hemisphere on Friday for a meeting intended in part to address the historic flow of migrants in the region by bolstering the economies of Mexico, Ecuador, Panama and other countries.

headline: Opinion Today: Israel’s President on the Conflict With Hamas
abstract: Isaac Herzog’s guest essay is a valuable look at how Israel’s leadership views the war.
lead_paragraph: Our goal in Opinion is to publish a wide range of ideas, arguments and commentary that help readers see an issue or a debate in a new light, challenge their assumptions and grapple with the hardest problems societies face.

headline: New Delhi Chokes as Annual Curse of Pollution Returns With a Vengeance
abstract: Schools shut down and residents were told to stay indoors as the government seems unable to avert an airborne calamity with multiple culprits that descends at the onset of winter.
lead_paragraph: Schools closed in New Delhi on Friday, while some diesel-burning vehicles were ordered off the roads and much of the city’s incessant construction was halted, as the authorities tried to mitigate the effects of a thick haze of pollution that has descended on India’s capital, a calamity that has come to be an annual blight.

headline: 4 Shows to Catch at the New York Comedy Festival
abstract: It’s a sprawling, citywide event, but our expert has a strategy and some suggestions for you.
lead_paragraph: The offerings at the annual New York Comedy Festival, which takes place across the city Friday through Nov. 12, are vast enough to be overwhelming. Stars like Bill Burr, Anthony Jeselnik, Nicole Byer and Michelle Wolf stand out. Then there are New York club veterans like Sam Morril and Matteo Lane moving up a class by playing big rooms at Madison Square Garden and Carnegie Hall. And if you study the schedule, you can also find many smaller acts. The best way to enjoy the festival is by seeing some familiar names, but also taking a few shots in the dark on comics you don’t know or only a little. That’s the fun part for me. If you’re looking for a start, here are a few promising options.

headline: With ‘Subject,’ Doc Stars Look Back
abstract: A talk with the directors Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall about their film that checks in on the subjects of high-profile documentaries.
lead_paragraph: Being a documentary subject can be a thankless kind of stardom, without much control over how your life story is told. In “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall went back to five famous documentaries and asked their stars about their experiences: “Hoop Dreams,” “The Staircase,” “Capturing the Friedmans,” “The Square” and “The Wolfpack.”

headline: Mount Sinai Seeks to Close One of Lower Manhattan’s Last Hospitals
abstract: The private hospital system asked state regulators to close Mount Sinai Beth Israel, which serves a swath of Lower Manhattan that has already lost several major medical institutions.
lead_paragraph: One of the last remaining hospitals serving Lower Manhattan may well close next year, despite opposition from local officials and health activists who say the lessons of the pandemic are going unheeded.

headline: Among American Chefs, the Israel-Hamas War Has Spread to Food
abstract: A recent petition signed by nearly 900 food professionals calling for a cease-fire raises, once again, questions of contested cuisines.
lead_paragraph: Theirs was an unlikely friendship.

headline: Orange Cake, Orange Chicken and Gumbo (Which Is Also Kind of Orange)
abstract: Recipes that capture the flavors, and colors, of the season.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Lisa Donovan is a pastry chef who happens to be an exquisite writer. “You cannot understand New Orleans, truly,” she wrote in “Our Lady of Perpetual Hunger,” her 2021 memoir,  “until someone who was raised by her, someone who loves her and is loved by her in return, takes you there.” Which is both a true statement and a wonderful sentence.

headline: Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?
abstract: A soccer revolution started with a text message, but the broader game wants proof. A win in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday might provide it.
lead_paragraph: The story starts with a message. Everything that has followed and everything that might yet — the glory and the acclaim, the opportunity and the revolution — has unspooled from a simple text. Everyone involved can agree on that. What is not entirely clear, though, is precisely which message was the one that counted.

headline: G.M.’s Cruise Moved Fast in the Driverless Race. It Got Ugly.
abstract: Cruise has hired a law firm to investigate how it responded to regulators, as its cars sit idle and questions grow about its C.E.O.’s expansion plans.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Kyle Vogt, the chief executive of Cruise, choked up as he recounted how a driver had killed a 4-year-old girl in a stroller at a San Francisco intersection. “It barely made the news,” he said, pausing to collect himself. “Sorry. I get emotional.”

headline: Japan and Philippines, Wary of China, Look to Expand Military Ties
abstract: An agreement, driven by the shared view that Beijing increasingly poses a threat to the region, would give Tokyo access to bases and make it easier to conduct joint drills.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan said on Friday that his country would start formal talks with the Philippines to allow the deployment of Japanese troops to the Southeast Asian country, further strengthening ties between two countries that have embraced each other as bulwarks against China.

headline: ‘Sabbath’s Theater’ Review: John Turturro Embodies a Life and a Libido
abstract: Though a tour de force for its actors, an Off Broadway adaptation of Philip Roth’s willfully obscene 1995 novel is too faithful to its source.
lead_paragraph: John Turturro begins the New Group’s “Sabbath’s Theater” with his pants down. He ends it with his pants off. In between, he masturbates on his lover’s grave, wears a pair of pink panties on his head and lingers on an oncology ward discussing outré sexual practices. This suggests a work meant to shock or at the very least goose the viewer. But excepting the performances of Turturro and Elizabeth Marvel as Sabbath’s wives and lovers, the show, for all its full-frontal nudity, is strangely inert. Flaccid? Sure.

headline: In a Worldwide War of Words, Russia, China and Iran Back Hamas
abstract: Officials and researchers say the deluge of online propaganda and disinformation is larger than anything seen before.
lead_paragraph: The conflict between Israel and Hamas is fast becoming a world war online.

headline: Review: Ligeti’s Fascinating Polyrhythm at the New York Phil
abstract: The conductor Susanna Mälkki led a program centered on Ligeti’s Piano Concerto, propelled by the soloist Pierre-Laurent Aimard.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the conductor Susanna Mälkki led the New York Philharmonic at David Geffen Hall in an unusually cohesive program built around the bizarro sound world of Ligeti’s Piano Concerto. It was part of the orchestra’s centennial celebrations of the composer.

headline: Shakespeare’s First Folio Turns 400
abstract: Sarah Lyall talks to Adrian Edwards, head of the Printed Heritage Collections at the British Library, about the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s First Folio.
lead_paragraph: In 1623, seven years after William Shakespeare died, two of his friends and fellow actors led an effort to publish a single volume containing 36 of the plays he had written, half of which had never been officially published before. Now known as the First Folio, that volume has become a lodestone of Shakespeare scholarship over the centuries, offering the most definitive versions of his work along with clues to his process and plenty of disputes about authorship and intention.

headline: William Pelham Jr., Who Rethought How A.D.H.D. Is Treated, Dies at 75
abstract: A child psychologist, he argued that behavioral therapy had to come first in addressing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, with drugs like Ritalin as a supplement.
lead_paragraph: William E. Pelham Jr., a child psychologist who challenged how his field approached attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children, arguing for a therapy-based regimen that used drugs like Ritalin and Adderall as an optional supplement, died on Oct. 21 in Miami. He was 75.

headline: A YouTube Gossip Spills a Secret of Her Own
abstract: For years, people have wondered who’s behind the popular Spill Sesh channel. On Friday, the person behind the account unmasked herself.
lead_paragraph: For the last five years, Spill Sesh, a popular YouTube channel, has covered the world of social media stars, providing detailed recaps and tart commentary on their scandals and beefs du jour.

headline: Netflix DVDs, Scorsese and Me
abstract: For a singular marathon of the filmmaker’s work, the discs were vital amid lockdown. A look at the newly shuttered service and how other renters used it.
lead_paragraph: The death notice arrived softly one Tuesday in April, to an email alert that chimed like a chapel bell.

headline: At Paul Taylor, the Music Calls for a Dance. The Men Respond.
abstract: Lauren Lovette, the resident choreographer of Paul Taylor Dance Company, presents two new works as part of the group’s Lincoln Center season.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a race, but Lauren Lovette seems to be running, not walking, to create a body of work for the Paul Taylor Dance Company. Last year, after becoming Taylor’s resident choreographer, she presented two new works; this week, as part of the Taylor season at Lincoln Center, she added two more, including the world premiere of “Echo” on Thursday. It’s her finest offering yet.

headline: Olivia Rodrigo’s Haunting ‘Hunger Games’ Tune, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Megan Thee Stallion, Torres, Mount Kimbie and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Work From Home Isn’t Always Good
abstract: Responses to an essay about home and office work. Also: Mideast carnage; punishing lawyers; the Trump fraud trial; health care burnout; truth and comedy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Köln Concert,’ Dancing Like Everyone’s Watching
abstract: Music by Keith Jarrett and Joni Mitchell set Trajal Harrell and his dancers in motion, but this pandemic-era piece feels mannered instead of spontaneous.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, the American jazz pianist Keith Jarrett played a solo concert in Cologne, Germany, improvising without a preset structure. The recording of that performance, “The Köln Concert,” became one of the best-selling solo jazz albums ever, its one-man-jam-band free exploration of sounds that you might associate with Rachmaninoff, gospel and country-folk proving as popular with fans of the Grateful Dead as with jazz aficionados.

headline: Jewish Viewers Find a Refuge in Fox News
abstract: The network’s unflinching support for Israel in its fight against Hamas has put the conservative network in the good graces of many Jews who see other coverage of Israel as biased.
lead_paragraph: Ross Abramson, a software engineer and recent New York University graduate, had a fairly conventional news diet until recently. He regularly checked his phone for The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. And as a Jew with an interest in Israel, he would browse a handful of outlets like The Times of Israel.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a story of female revenge, a tale of a flying swordsman and a rip-roaring disaster flick.
lead_paragraph: Between “Gunpowder Milkshake,” “Baby Assassins,” and “Kill Boksoon,” the hit woman subgenre is bubbling with new subversive takes on the masculine hired gun motif. The Korean director Lee Chung-hyun’s “Ballerina” picks up those reins for a film about Okju (Jun Jong-seo), a retired bodyguard seeking to avenge the brutal murder of her dancer friend Minhee (Park Yu-rim) at the hands of a ruthless underworld predator (Kim Ji-hun).

headline: Saleemul Huq, 71, Bangladeshi Spearhead on Climate Change, Dies
abstract: He pressed rich nations to compensate poorer ones for the disproportionate “loss and damage” they’ve endured because of greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Saleemul Huq, a Bangladeshi-British scientist who played a leading role in trying to get rich nations to compensate poorer ones for the damaging effects of climate change largely brought about by the developed world, died on Saturday in Dhaka, Bangladesh, the capital. He was 71.

headline: New York City Deserves Better Than Mayor Adams’s Scandals
abstract: The drama and foolishness involving the mayor’s inner circle doesn’t serve the city well and is the last thing New York needs right now.
lead_paragraph: No sooner did Mayor Eric Adams of New York land in Washington, D.C., on city business Thursday than he had to turn right back around to take care of his own.

headline: Flooding in Tuscany Leaves Six Dead
abstract: Storm Ciaran swept into Italy with torrential rains overnight, continuing its deadly push across Western Europe.
lead_paragraph: At least six people have died in Tuscany, Italy, amid widespread flooding, local officials said on Friday, after Storm Ciaran swept into the country with torrential rains overnight on a path of destruction across Western Europe.

headline: Helen Marcus, Prolific Photographer of the Famous, Dies at 97
abstract: One of the few women at the top of her field in book and magazine publishing, she was also a champion of her fellow professionals.
lead_paragraph: Helen Marcus, a late-blooming photographer whose evocative black-and-white portraits of literary figures and film and television personalities graced book jackets and magazine covers for decades, died on Oct. 1 at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: The Big Number: $42.60
abstract: Tentative accords at Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades, with wage increases of 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: Tentative accords at Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades, with wage increases of 25 percent.

headline: Two Ways of Looking at the West’s Population Dilemma
abstract: Old age and mass migration are the great forces of the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: In my Wednesday column, I wrote about the various unveilings and intimations of new alignments that have accompanied the Israel-Gaza crisis — with one reveal being the extent to which immigration is transforming European politics, forging a mass movement of Arab-Muslim protest that in turn may be driving European voters and even European elites toward the anti-immigration right.

headline: Biden Mourns With Lewiston After Mass Shooting: ‘You’re Not Alone’
abstract: President Biden met with the families of those killed or injured during last month’s rampage in Maine, which killed 18 people.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office, President Biden has traveled a grim path through American communities desperately grieving in the wake of mass shootings: Uvalde, Texas; Monterey Park, Calif.; Buffalo; Atlanta.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Amaney Jamal
abstract: The Nov. 3, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Amaney Jamal. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: What to Know About Seasonal Depression
abstract: If you notice drastic shifts in your mood during certain times of the year, you could have seasonal affective disorder. Here are answers to your top questions about the condition.
lead_paragraph: The fall and winter months often signal the season of celebration and holidays. But for many, the darker, colder days herald another type of period: one of fatigue, lethargy and depression.

headline: Swift Reversal in Bonds and Rally in Stocks Cap Wild Week for Markets
abstract: A series of data reports and actions by policymakers have led investors to reassess their assumptions about interest rates and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Stocks and bonds rallied on Friday, extending a sharp reversal after fresh data about the health of the U.S. labor market capped a tumultuous week for investors.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in November
abstract: The final season of “The Crown” and the mini-series adaptation of a Pulitzer-winning novel highlight this month’s slate.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Ohio Lawsuit Punches Back in Battle Over How to Teach Reading
abstract: A nonprofit group is trying to stop a new state law requiring “the science of reading,” underscoring how money and ideology influence the national debate.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio set out to overhaul reading instruction in his state this year, it seemed like another sign that the decades-long debate over how to teach reading had come to a tipping point.

headline: An Apparent Cyberattack Hushes the British Library
abstract: Libraries across Europe appear to be facing attacks from cybercriminals. At Britain’s national library, an “incident” is sending scholars back to an analog age.
lead_paragraph: The British Library in London is normally a place of quiet study, its reading rooms filled with authors, academics and students often surrounded by piles of books from the library’s collection of about 170 million items.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts riffed on former Vice President Mike Pence ending his presidential campaign and former President Donald Trump’s sons testifying in the $250 million civil fraud trial in New York. Here’s what they hosts had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts riffed on former Vice President Mike Pence ending his presidential campaign and former President Donald Trump’s sons testifying in the $250 million civil fraud trial in New York. Here’s what they hosts had to say.

headline: David Kirke, Who Made the First Modern Bungee Jump, Dies at 78
abstract: An Oxford-educated prankster as colorful as he was daring, he accidentally helped invent a new extreme sport in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: David Kirke, a flamboyant thrill-seeker who performed — and, more important, survived — what is widely acknowledged as the first modern bungee jump, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Oxford, England. He was 78.

headline: New York Tightens Special Education Rules, Aiming to Reduce Fraud
abstract: New York City’s public schools will step up oversight of funding for private tutoring and other services after a New York Times investigation revealed questionable billing.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, New York City has faced a startling rise in requests to pay for special education services for private school students, a deluge that has cost billions of dollars and raised concerns about fraud.

headline: Many are killed near a Gaza hospital, its chief says, in a strike the Israelis say was aimed at Hamas.
abstract: The Israeli military said it targeted an ambulance “being used by a Hamas terrorist cell.” At the time, Palestinians said, a convoy of ambulances was preparing to take wounded people to the Gaza border.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike hit near the entrance of Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday, killing multiple people, according to Gazan and Israeli officials, just as Palestinians said a convoy of ambulances was preparing to leave the hospital carrying wounded people to the Gaza border, to cross into Egypt for treatment.

headline: Mint, One of the First Budgeting Apps, Is Shutting Down
abstract: Intuit, which acquired Mint in 2009, is encouraging users to switch to Credit Karma, its money management and credit score service.
lead_paragraph: Mint, one of the earliest and most popular personal finance apps, is shutting down, and its owner, Intuit, is encouraging users to switch to Credit Karma, its platform that offers free credit scores and helps users track their money.

headline: Thousands of Gazan Workers Stranded in Israel Return Home
abstract: About 3,300 Gazans who had been working in Israel were able to return home through the Kerem Shalom crossing in southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: About 3,300 Gazans who had been working in Israel were able to return home through the Kerem Shalom crossing in southern Gaza.

headline: Sofia Coppola’s Best Needle Drops
abstract: Hear songs that memorably accompanied scenes in “The Virgin Suicides,” “Lost in Translation,” “Priscilla” and more.
lead_paragraph: Few working filmmakers curate soundtracks with as much flair, style and intentionality as Sofia Coppola: Consider the melancholy dream-pop smeared through “Lost in Translation,” the new-wave tunes that give “Marie Antoinette” a playful modernity, or the eerie, weightless Air score that haunts the sleepy suburbs of “The Virgin Suicides.”

headline: A Rare Trump Gun Control Measure Faces a Supreme Court Test
abstract: The justices agreed to decide whether the Trump administration had acted lawfully in banning bump stocks, the attachments that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire in sustained, rapid bursts.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether the Trump administration had acted lawfully in banning bump stocks, the attachments that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire in sustained, rapid bursts.

headline: The Best Artificial Christmas Trees
Our Favorite Advent Calendars
How Patrick Stewart Made the Jump to Warp Speed
How to Build a Skin Care Routine
How to Solve the New York Times Crossword
Want to Give Yoga a Try?
How to Meditate
How to Age Well
How to Pack a Suitcase
Jill Ellis Still Wants to Win
abstract: The former coach of the U.S. women’s soccer team is now the president of the San Diego Wave, which is in the semifinals of the National Women’s Soccer League playoffs.
lead_paragraph: When Jill Ellis stepped back from coaching after winning back-to-back World Cups in 2015 and 2019 with the U.S. women’s team, her wife, Betsy Stephenson, thought the number of soccer matches watched in their house might decrease.

headline: U.S. Faces Tricky Questions With African Trade Group
abstract: Tensions hung over a trade summit in Johannesburg after the Biden administration suspended four African countries that had belonged to a program aimed at promoting economic development.
lead_paragraph: As the United States seeks to deepen its relationships with African nations and counter the influence of rivals like Russia and China, it confronts a tricky question: How does it respond when countries do things that run afoul of Washington’s stated commitment to democracy and human rights?

headline: The World Series Didn’t Match the Very Best
abstract: The growing role of luck has made sports more exciting to watch, but at a cost.
lead_paragraph: This year’s World Series brought to mind the verse in Ecclesiastes about how the race is not to the swift nor the battle to the strong, but time and chance happen to them all. Swift and strong teams faltered in the playoffs, leaving the championship series to a couple of lucky unlikelies: the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Texas Rangers.

headline: Death, Disability: It’s All Fair Game for the Comic Daniel Sloss
abstract: The Scottish standup went viral for being the sole comic to go on the record in support of Russell Brand’s accusers. He’s made a career of finding humor in “things that we should not be laughing at.”
lead_paragraph: The Scottish comedian Daniel Sloss likes to flout conventional humor.

headline: Republican National Committee Announces Tougher Criteria for Fourth Debate
abstract: Over the objections of its front-runner, the party has set a date for a fourth primary debate that will take place in Tuscaloosa, Ala., next month.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee has set a date for the fourth debate of the 2024 primaries — over the objection of the party’s front-runner, Donald J. Trump — and incrementally ratcheted up the criteria to make the stage, according to a memo sent to campaigns on Friday.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear N.R.A.’s Free Speech Case Against New York Official
abstract: The case is the second one this term asking the justices to decide when government activity crosses the line to become coercion forbidden by the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would decide whether a state official in New York violated the First Amendment by encouraging companies to stop doing business with the National Rifle Association after the 2018 school shooting in Parkland, Fla.

headline: The U.S. Says It Wants a Two-State Solution. What Do Its Arab Allies Want?
abstract: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war, with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken made a brief visit to Israel on Friday to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other leaders. In addition to pushing for the safety of civilians in Gaza, Mr. Blinken emphasized the U.S. commitment to a two-state solution as the best path forward, and called on Arab partners to support that goal.

headline: A Humanitarian Pause in Gaza
abstract: Civilians in Gaza have paid a grave price and urgently need relief.
lead_paragraph: Four weeks ago, Israel began its military campaign to defeat Hamas, in retaliation for the attack on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people, kidnapped some 240 others and destroyed a fundamental sense of security for all Israelis. Israel has a right to defend itself against this threat at its border, and the United States, its closest ally, has rightly pledged to stand by its side until that sense of security is restored.

headline: Jane Garrett, Book Editor With a Prizewinning Touch, Dies at 88
abstract: In 44 years at Knopf, she shepherded history books that won a raft of Pulitzers — seven in all — as well as Bancrofts, although one recipient set off a furious debate.
lead_paragraph: Jane Garrett, who as an editor at the Alfred A. Knopf publishing house guided seven books to Pulitzer Prizes for history but watched another book lose its prestigious Bancroft Prize over scholars’ criticism of the author’s research, died on Oct. 12 at her home in Middlebury, Vt. She was 88.

headline: A Fast, Foolproof Carbonara for Orzo Lovers
abstract: Combining the last-minute simplicity of a carbonara, and the rich-tasting comfort of a long-cooked risotto, this dish is the perfect cold-weather weeknight dinner.
lead_paragraph: The Italian carbonara police don’t want you to put ham in your spaghetti carbonara; they’ve made that clear. And don’t even think about splashing in cream or grating over Parmesan instead of pecorino.

headline: Blinken Urges ‘Pauses’ in Fighting to Deliver Aid for Gaza Civilians
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel appeared to rebuff the Biden administration’s request, saying that any cease-fire would be contingent on the release of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who traveled to Israel on Friday as the ground war against Hamas in Gaza escalated, urged protections for Palestinian noncombatants and “humanitarian pauses” in the fighting, even as he spoke of “solidarity” with Israel’s right to defend itself.

headline: Former State Department Aide Sentenced to Nearly Six Years in Jan. 6 Attack
abstract: Federico G. Klein used a stolen riot shield to repeatedly assault officers on Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Marine who served in the Trump administration as a low-level State Department aide was sentenced on Friday to nearly six years in prison for his role in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Biden Visits Lewiston After Mass Shooting
abstract: The president paid tribute to the 18 people killed in shootings at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.
lead_paragraph: The president paid tribute to the 18 people killed in shootings at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.

headline: U.S. Job Growth Slows
abstract: Also, Eric Adams’s campaign faces corruption questions. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: U.S. employers added 150,000 jobs last month, according to data released today. The number was lower than experts had projected, and it signaled a cooling in the economy, but it remained not far off from the monthly job growth that the U.S. was experiencing before the pandemic.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, November 5, 2023
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Trump Misleads on Energy and Jobs at Houston Rally
abstract: A Biden electric Army tank mandate? A decimation of auto jobs? The G.O.P. front-runner used misleading and recycled claims to talk about energy and jobs.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign rally in Houston on Thursday that opened with former President Donald J. Trump erroneously referring to jailed Jan. 6 Capitol riot defendants as “hostages,” the Republican primary front-runner used a series of false and misleading claims to make his case for another term in the White House.

headline: Manhattan Jury Clears Ex-Prosecutor of Rape and Assault Charges
abstract: Adam Foss, a prominent criminal justice reform advocate, had been accused of assaulting a woman in a Midtown hotel room in 2017.
lead_paragraph: A former Boston prosecutor who was charged with rape and sexual abuse in Manhattan last year was acquitted of all charges by a jury on Friday.

headline: Murder Victim’s Daughter Helps Clear Brooklyn Man Convicted in Killing
abstract: Prosecutors said they reviewed a 1982 case at the urging of the victim’s daughter, who became convinced the wrong man was convicted of her father’s killing.
lead_paragraph: In December 1982, four armed men burst into a bodega in Brooklyn serving as a front for marijuana dealing and ordered two men working inside to hand over drugs.

headline: Jeffrey A. Bader, Who Helped Steer Obama’s ‘Pivot’ to Asia, Dies at 78
abstract: A veteran China expert, he advised Presidents Clinton and Obama as they navigated the complexities of Beijing’s rise to global power.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey A. Bader, one of the country’s leading experts on China and an architect of President Barack Obama’s so-called pivot to the Pacific during his first administration, died on Oct. 22 in Los Angeles. He was 78.

headline: Earthquake in Western Nepal Kills More Than 150
abstract: Thousands of families were left under the open sky as rescuers searched for survivors in the mountainous villages where the earthquake struck.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from a powerful midnight earthquake that struck western Nepal climbed to more than 150 people on Saturday, as the authorities and aid organizations rushed to provide relief for thousands of families stranded under the open sky and fearful of aftershocks.

headline: In the Aftermath of the Hamas Attack: Portraits of Survivors
abstract: Thousands of Israelis were attacked on the morning of Oct. 7, after Hamas gunmen surged into southern Israel from Gaza. Many survivors remain traumatized by the experience.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Israelis were attacked on the morning of Oct. 7, after Hamas gunmen surged into southern Israel from Gaza. Many survivors remain traumatized by the experience.

headline: Appeals Court Temporarily Frees Trump From Gag Order in Election Case
abstract: A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington lifted the order for the time being, freeing the former president to say what he wants about prosecutors and witnesses.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court in Washington on Friday paused the gag order imposed on former President Donald J. Trump in the federal case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election, temporarily freeing him to go back to attacking the prosecutors and witnesses involved in the proceeding.

headline: Jurors in Trump Defamation Trial to Go Unnamed for Their Own Protection
abstract: A federal judge overseeing the case filed by the writer E. Jean Carroll said that the former president had not abided by gag orders in other cases, and that could lead to harassment.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled Friday that the jury in a forthcoming defamation trial against Donald J. Trump will be kept anonymous for the jurors’ own protection, citing the potential for harassment by the former president’s supporters.

headline: New York Times Writer Resigns After Signing Letter Protesting the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: The writer, Jazmine Hughes, who has won awards for her work, had signed another letter of protest this year.
lead_paragraph: Jazmine Hughes, an award-winning New York Times Magazine staff writer, resigned from the publication on Friday after she violated the newsroom’s policies by signing a letter that voiced support for Palestinians and protested Israel’s siege in Gaza.

headline: Palestinian TV Reporter and 11 Family Members Killed in Gaza
abstract: Mohammed Abu Hatab is the latest journalist to die while covering the Israel-Hamas war, which has killed more media workers than any other conflict in the area since 1992.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Abu Hatab, a correspondent for a Palestinian television channel, and 11 members of his family were killed in the city of Khan Younis in southern Gaza on Thursday.

headline: Hamas put wounded fighters on departure lists, delaying efforts to evacuate foreigners, a U.S. official says.
abstract: People holding dual, U.S. or other foreign citizenship had been unable to cross the Gaza border into Egypt for weeks.
