abstract: A recent college graduate, Brianna Suggs was an unusual choice to run Eric Adams’s big-money fund-raising operation as he campaigned for mayor.
lead_paragraph: The choice was unconventional: Eric Adams, the candidate who would go on to win the 2021 election for mayor of the nation’s financial capital, had picked an inexperienced 23-year-old to run his campaign’s fund-raising operation.

headline: Before Sunrise, Before the Runners, a Guerrilla Bike Marathon
abstract: For the last two decades, cyclists have been riding the course in the magic time after the roads are closed and before the thousands of racers begin.
lead_paragraph: It was well before dawn on Sunday when the cyclists first began to congregate — a handful at first, then a few dozen, then hundreds.

headline: In This Country, Most People Rent for Life. Is That Really What They Want?
abstract: At a time when many young people in places like California and New York can’t see a path to buying a home, Switzerland offers a glimpse of a post-ownership society.
lead_paragraph: In any other country, Philip Skiba, a well-paid analyst working in the finance industry, might not hesitate to buy a home. But in the town where he lives, on the outskirts of Zurich, even the ugly houses, as he describes them, go for millions.

headline: The Heart of ‘Priscilla’ Is for Sale
abstract: Is there such a thing as cool movie merch? The film studio A24 makes a case for it — now with a $400 necklace based on Sofia Coppola’s “Priscilla.”
lead_paragraph: It is curious how some things never go out of style.

headline: Can the Parole Process Make Prison Sentences More Just?
abstract: In “Correction,” Ben Austen investigates a system meant to promote rehabilitation, and reward prisoners who change, but that no longer seems to work the way it was intended.
lead_paragraph: One morning in late September, around the time I was finishing Ben Austen’s “Correction: Parole, Prison, and the Possibility of Change,” I was walking the perimeter of a prison yard in upstate New York with a fellow inmate, 68-year-old Kasiem Chaves. We call him “Old God.” Gray and gangly, he was about to go before the parole board for the third time, having served nearly 41 years. By the time I finished writing this review, I would know whether Old God would go free.

headline: Tech Start-Ups Try to Sell a Cautious Pentagon on A.I.
abstract: Shield AI, a tech start-up, already has a drone run by artificial intelligence being used by the Israeli military. But persuading the Pentagon to embrace the technology remains a big challenge.
lead_paragraph: When he reflected on his time as a Navy SEAL serving in Afghanistan a decade ago, Brandon Tseng wondered why he and his team did not have any way to see inside buildings they were about to raid and reduce the chances of walking into a deadly trap.

headline: Will the Supreme Court Toss Out a Gun Law Meant to Protect Women?
abstract: Even pro-firearms politicians are absent in the briefs supporting a lawsuit to make it harder to keep weapons out of abusers’ hands.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Supreme Court agreed in June to hear the government’s appeal of a particularly noxious Second Amendment ruling, I had been curious to see which “friends of the court” might emerge on the gun-rights side.

headline: Ending TB Is Within Reach — So Why Are Millions Still Dying?
abstract: Tuberculosis has passed Covid as the top infectious disease killer, despite new medicines and better diagnostic tools.
lead_paragraph: At Kaneshie Polyclinic, a health center in a hardscrabble neighborhood of Accra, the capital of Ghana, there is a rule. Every patient who walks through the door — a woman in labor, a construction worker with an injury, a child with malaria — is screened for tuberculosis.

headline: The Man Behind 250 Masks
abstract: Inside the sizable collection amassed by the artist Marcel Dzama, whose work plays with disguise.
lead_paragraph: The collection: Handmade masks, in materials ranging from paper to wood to cloth.

headline: For Stephanie Land, College Was the School of Hard Knocks
abstract: In her second memoir, the author of “Maid” recounts the struggle of getting educated in America below the poverty line.
lead_paragraph: The last time we encountered Stephanie Land, the author of the best-selling “Maid,” she was a single mother who cleaned houses in the Pacific Northwest to get away from an abusive boyfriend, stay out of a homeless shelter and sustain a seemingly far-fetched dream of one day returning to college to become a writer.

headline: The Novel Source for This Space Mystery? A Novel.
abstract: Video games rarely adapt books. But with The Invincible, a Polish studio embraces a science fiction story by Stanislaw Lem.
lead_paragraph: Humanity’s first contact with tiny quasi-intelligent robots felt fresh and believable to the video game producer Marek Markuszewski as he devoured “The Invincible,” Stanislaw Lem’s 1964 science fiction novel, in two evenings. Its precise descriptions of force fields and antimatter cannons seemed ready-made for the screen.

headline: This Season’s Most Striking Sculptural Bags
abstract: Accessories with distinctive silhouettes, from soft-sided globes to hard-edged minaudières.

headline: Vapes Get a Gen Z Makeover
abstract: In candy shades and eggy shapes, many of today’s most popular vaping devices look like toys. Experts worry they will hook a new generation of users.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Addison remembers what vapes looked like when she was in high school. The dominant e-cigarette was Juul, a slim, black rectangle with sharp corners that resembled a flash drive.

headline: Would You Take Mental Health Advice From TikTok?
abstract: What, if anything, would make you trust the creator who shared it?
lead_paragraph: Think about the advice you have seen on TikTok or other social media platforms. How often do you find these tips — whether they are about health, relationships, skin care, fashion, fitness or anything else — helpful? How often do you question if they are based on fact? How much do you care about whether the people creating the content identify as experts, or at least have a background in what they’re talking about?

headline: Some Covid Vaccines Are Still Hard to Find
abstract: Vaccine appointments for kids remain limited, and Novavax shots are hard to come by.
lead_paragraph: The recently authorized Covid vaccines promised to protect the public against an expected uptick of respiratory illness this winter. But getting shots into arms is still proving challenging.

headline: It Is Not Dead Yet! ‘Spamalot’ Returns to Broadway. (Cue the Coconuts.)
abstract: The Monty Python-inspired show wants to give audiences a reason “to laugh and enjoy and be taken away by this lunacy, in the best way possible.”
lead_paragraph: The terrifying knights still say “Ni!” The dead? Well, they are not quite dead yet. And King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table (not dawn, not dusk, not late afternoon, but knights) still trot around to the sounds of coconuts banging together.

headline: Republicans Have Chosen Nihilism
abstract: Conservatives have to find a way to turn back toward their original ideals.
lead_paragraph: Over the past half-century, one of the books that most electrified conservatives was Allan Bloom’s “The Closing of the American Mind.” Bloom, a political philosopher, warned of the dangers posed by moral relativism and nihilism, of “accepting everything and denying reason’s power.”

headline: The U.S. Can Counter China’s Control of Minerals for the Energy Transition
abstract: America needs to invest in mining and build resilient supply chains for the building blocks of electric batteries.
lead_paragraph: China recently rattled the world’s electric vehicle supply chains by announcing new export controls on graphite, a key component of lithium-ion batteries. If China uses the export controls, which take effect on Dec. 1, to reduce exports of graphite or to favor Chinese-owned companies operating abroad, it could slow down efforts to scale up advanced battery manufacturing globally.

headline: Father of Accused Gunman Goes on Trial in Illinois Parade Shooting
abstract: The prosecution of a Fourth of July attack that killed seven in 2022 could broaden the legal interpretation of who bears responsibility for a mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: In a case that could broaden the legal interpretation of who bears responsibility for a mass shooting, the father of the man accused of killing seven people at a Fourth of July parade in suburban Chicago will stand trial on Monday for reckless conduct.

headline: A Democratic Governor in Mississippi? He Thinks It’s Possible.
abstract: With a promise to expand Medicaid and a focus on turning out Black voters, Brandon Presley is confident he can do what no Democrat has done in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates from Election Day 2023.

headline: Most Americans still have to commute every day. Here’s how that experience has changed.
abstract: More than three years since the beginning of the pandemic, more than 100 million workers are back to commuting or never stopped. For many, their commutes have changed in ways both good and bad. Take a data-driven dive into what’s happened to the American commute.
lead_paragraph: More than three years since the beginning of the pandemic, more than 100 million workers are back to commuting or never stopped. For many, their commutes have changed in ways both good and bad. Take a data-driven dive into what’s happened to the American commute.

headline: What I Read to My Son When the World Is on Fire
abstract: Children’s literature, in its simplicity, brevity and empathy, can make it a singularly effective way to understand the chaos of the world.
lead_paragraph: Last May, my husband and I invited a Palestinian friend for Shabbat dinner, and when he asked what to bring, I requested a book about his homeland for our 7-year-old son. Because this friend is lavishly generous and wasn’t sure of our child’s reading level, he showed up with a gift bag of titles about Palestinian children and their experiences, ranging from picture books to a four-volume series of middle-grade novels.

headline: Ukraine’s Secret Plan to Save a City Trapped in Purgatory
abstract: Since Russian troops were pushed out of the city of Kherson, they have bombed it relentlessly. Closely held river operations could change that.
lead_paragraph: It was just after 1 p.m. when the first of three artillery shells shrieked past Maryna Korifadze’s bomb shelter in Kherson, landing nearby with a bone-rattling crump.

headline: In Queens, Strangers Become Neighbors
abstract: Rent increases in a building in Sunnyside encouraged tenants to band together. Now they know one another’s names and help keep an eye on building management.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a dramatic rent increase. “Just $35.01,” said Sam Ida, who received a letter informing him of the change.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern house in Claremont, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1937 home in Glendale.
lead_paragraph: This house won a 1964 design award sponsored by a trade group to promote the use of concrete in residential building. It was designed by Fred McDowell, an architect who worked extensively in Southern California in the mid-20th century and was responsible for a number of buildings at nearby Pitzer College.

headline: All the Trimmings, None of the Work: Thanksgiving in a Hotel
abstract: Turkey trots, holiday-themed spa treatments and multicourse feasts for those who don’t want to lift a finger: Here are five places to spend the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is just a few weeks away, and while many Americans will be staying at home or with family and friends, others will be checking into hotels where guests can participate in turkey trots and try Thanksgiving-themed spa treatments — all while letting someone else worry about cooking.

headline: Warring Billionaires, a Rogue Employee, a Divorce: One Hedge Fund’s Tale of Woe
abstract: Two Sigma, the $60 billion quantitative trading firm, has been beset by troubles this year that have tarnished its image and could hurt its future.
lead_paragraph: Two Sigma, one of the world’s largest hedge funds, has long prided itself on two things: the sophisticated, in-house algorithms that power its trading, and its commitment to secrecy. But recent internal troubles have forced Two Sigma to air its dirty laundry.

headline: Food Apps Catering to Chinese Speakers Deliver a Piece of Home
abstract: Some mobile platforms are helping Chinese speakers in the United States and elsewhere order in their native language.
lead_paragraph: When Chong Zhou moved to New York City in 2013, she and her friends would organize entire days around trips to the Chinatown in Flushing, Queens, to eat, get foot massages and shop for groceries. Ms. Zhou, a business analyst at Meta, arrived in the United States from Shenzhen, China, in 2009 to attend Ohio State University. She had struggled to satiate her culinary homesickness in Columbus, but New York was a revelation.

headline: How Rebecca Yarros Packed Dragons, Magic and Steamy Sex Into a Blockbuster Fantasy
abstract: Yarros drew on her experience with chronic illness and life in a military family to write “Fourth Wing,” a huge best seller that spawned a spicy fantasy series.
lead_paragraph: When Rebecca Yarros pitched her publisher a sexy fantasy about telepathic dragons and their riders, she thought it might be a tough sell.

headline: Chatbots May ‘Hallucinate’ More Often Than Many Realize
abstract: When summarizing facts, ChatGPT technology makes things up about 3 percent of the time, according to research from a new start-up. A Google system’s rate was 27 percent.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI unveiled its ChatGPT online chatbot late last year, millions were wowed by the humanlike way it answered questions, wrote poetry and discussed almost any topic. But most people were slow to realize that this new kind of chatbot often makes things up.

headline: As Gaza Hospitals Collapse, Medical Workers Face the Hardest Choices
abstract: Doctors say they are performing surgeries without anesthesia after weeks of Israeli bombings and siege left severe shortages of medicine, water, food and fuel. “We choose who gets ventilation by deciding who has the best chance of survival,” one doctor said.
lead_paragraph: Every day is a choice between who lives and who dies.

headline: Why Don’t Women’s Clothes Have More Pockets?
abstract: A reader wonders why pockets in women’s wear remain “small and useless” — when they’re included at all. The answer is tangled up with a host of social issues, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: The pocket problem is a perennial one, for good reason. The story of those — often, as you say, tiny — compartments is crammed to the brim with plot twists that involve sexism, racism, control, economic disparity and more. Who knew so many hot-button social issues could be contained in such a tiny space?

headline: Trump Indictments Haven’t Sunk His Campaign, but a Conviction Might
abstract: Polls by The New York Times and Siena College show his strength in key swing states, in part because of concerns about President Biden’s age. But a conviction could be the difference in 2024.
lead_paragraph: For Donald J. Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.

headline: Called to Serve, Israeli Reservists Wait to Deploy
abstract: Facing a military campaign with no end in sight, tens of thousands of soldiers in Israel find themselves in a holding pattern.
lead_paragraph: For the 360,000 reservists who have been called up as Israel goes to war in Gaza, there are plenty of ways to conjure up nightmares: taking part in a combat operation that accidentally kills an Israeli hostage held by Hamas, confronting Hamas fighters as they pop up from tunnels in a chaotic urban landscape or simply coming upon a Palestinian child who strays within rifle range.

headline: Teleprompter! Makeup! Gavel! Art Auctions Become ‘Must-See TV.’
abstract: Auction houses no longer play exclusively to the art world as viewers flock to YouTube, Instagram and TikTok to see how the one percent spends.
lead_paragraph: As Sotheby’s and Christie’s prepare for the start this week of the  major New York auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art — at which a 1932 Picasso is expected to bring in more than $120 million — teams of tech experts, producers and show directors are readying their salesrooms as if they were CNN Central.

headline: Matthew Perry Told the Truth About Everything
abstract: Few people can relate to a life of fame and excess like Matthew Perry’s. But many of us can recognize a struggle with shame.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Matthew Perry’s autobiography, he wrote about an encounter in which his mother told him she was proud of him.

headline: Trump May Not Need a Coup This Time
abstract: The new Times/Siena poll is to Biden’s second-term ambitions what sunlight is to morning fog.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I know you’re busy writing about your reporting trip to Israel, and I am looking forward to reading all your thoughts. But, gee, can we talk about the Times/Siena poll on the presidential race that came out on Sunday? Donald Trump is ahead in almost all the critical states.

headline: Arrests Motivated by Politics Face a Supreme Court Test
abstract: A 72-year-old city councilwoman in Texas, accused of misplacing a document, says she was the victim of retaliation for exercising her First Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: In her memoir, Justice Sonia Sotomayor confessed that she does not always observe the letter of the law. “I’m a New Yorker,” she wrote, “and I jaywalk with the best of them.”

headline: Artificial Intelligence War Machines Take Flight
abstract: Far out in the prairies of North Dakota, we saw firsthand how artificial intelligence tools are being merged with military surveillance and weapons.
lead_paragraph: Far out in the prairies of North Dakota, we saw firsthand how artificial intelligence tools are being merged with military surveillance and weapons.

headline: Treasury Secretary Yellen to Hold Economic Talks With Chinese Counterpart
abstract: The high-level meetings in San Francisco will lay the groundwork for talks between President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will hold two days of high-level meetings with her Chinese counterpart, Vice Premier He Lifeng, this week, as the United States and China look to build upon an effort that started this year to improve communication between the world’s two largest economies.

headline: What We Can Expect Donald Trump to Say in Court Today
abstract: When he takes the stand in his civil fraud trial, the former president is likely to testify that he was too busy to bother with the details of forms for banks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out what to listen for today when Donald Trump testifies in his civil trial in Manhattan.

headline: Swing State Voters Are Souring on Biden
abstract: A new Times/Siena poll finds Donald Trump leading President Biden in five of six key battlegrounds.
lead_paragraph: In a major new campaign poll from The New York Times and Siena College, former President Donald J. Trump leads President Biden in five of the six battleground states likeliest to decide the 2024 presidential race. Widespread discontent with the state of the country and growing doubts about Biden’s ability to perform his job as president threaten to unravel the diverse coalition that elected him in 2020.

headline: Israel’s ‘Large Attack’ on Gaza, and More
abstract: Plus, Trump faces questioning in his fraud trial and a Times poll finds Biden trailing in swing states.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: What Can Biden Do?
abstract: The president’s strategic options for 2024.
lead_paragraph: With President Biden having fallen behind Donald Trump in the early 2024 polls, Trump’s strategy seems fairly straightforward: more of the same. Trump will portray Biden as old, inflation as high, immigration as out of control and the nation as weak. All these arguments play into the concerns of many voters.

headline: How 7,500 More Reader Drawings Changed Our New York City Maps
abstract: We’ve added 36 new neighborhood names, and we’ll continue to update them.
lead_paragraph: Since we published this extremely detailed map of New York City neighborhoods last week, readers have sent in more than 7,500 new submissions from across the city.

headline: City to Dismiss Citations Issued to Reporter for Asking Too Many Questions
abstract: A reporter for The Daily Southtown received three citations from the government of Calumet City, Ill., but the city said that it would dismiss them after hearing from the media company’s lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Officials in a Chicago suburb on Monday said that their city would dismiss citations that it had issued to a local news reporter in late October after he persistently contacted elected officials about a flooding issue.

headline: Antisemitic and Islamophobic Incidents Surge in Australia
abstract: Tensions between religious groups in Australia have risen since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: Posters plastered across Sydney portraying Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel as Adolf Hitler in disguise. A record increase in reports of Islamophobia, including threats to Muslim community organizations. Antisemitic chants at a pro-Palestinian rally and charges that Nazi salutes were performed outside a Jewish museum.

headline: Peter Meijer, a Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Is Running for Senate
abstract: The one-term representative of Michigan who was defeated by a Trump-backed primary challenger is aiming for a political comeback.
lead_paragraph: Peter Meijer, the one-term Republican congressman who lost his seat after voting to impeach President Donald J. Trump, has announced he is running for Senate in Michigan, jumping into a crowded primary in a key battleground.

headline: Voters Aren’t Believing in Bidenomics
abstract: A new Times/Siena poll shows the president behind in five of six key states. Voters cite his economic track record, indicators notwithstanding.
lead_paragraph: There was little good news for President Biden in the latest Times/Siena poll of 2024 battlegrounds, which found him trailing Donald Trump in five of six key states one year before voters head to the polls. (That’s despite Trump being nearly as unpopular and fighting multiple legal battles; he is taking the stand on Monday in one of them. And, on PredictIt, which is watched by political experts, Biden holds a six-point lead on Trump.)

headline: How to Line Up a Great Connections Solve
abstract: Get tips and tricks from other solvers and the game’s editors.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been getting a lot of questions about how to get better at Connections, the newest game in the New York Times Games catalog. While there’s not a single best strategy, we’ve had a lot of fun over the past few months developing our own approaches. We spoke to a few experienced solvers and the game’s editors to get some tips.

headline: Texas Man at Center of Supreme Court Case Says He No Longer Wants Guns
abstract: Zackey Rahimi has vowed “to stay away from all firearms and weapons” in a case that could expand gun rights protections, but advocates say he is not an ideal poster boy for the Second Amendment.
lead_paragraph: In a handwritten letter from jail, the man at the center of a major Supreme Court gun rights case to be heard on Tuesday apologized for going down “a wrong path” and wrote that he would no longer carry a gun.

headline: Supreme Court’s Devotion to Gun Rights Faces a Challenging Test
abstract: The justices will hear arguments on Tuesday on whether the government can disarm people subject to restraining orders for domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: The big gun rights case the Supreme Court is set to hear on Tuesday presents the justices with a tricky problem.

headline: San Francisco Shop Owner Responds to Hate Crime With Message of Love
abstract: An ice cream shop owner was devastated by vandalism to her store, but she now sees a new way forward.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. A San Francisco shop owner is trying to turn a hate crime into a positive. Plus, what the Golden Gate Bridge is (finally) doing to prevent suicides.

headline: The Biden campaign was hardly shocked by the Times/Siena polling.
abstract: The campaign has circulated talking points that downplay the relevance of polling, suggest voters are not tuned in right now and offer a reminder that past presidents have recovered from low points.
lead_paragraph: The sour numbers for President Biden in the new polls of battleground states from The New York Times and Siena College did not come as a surprise to officials in his re-election campaign.

headline: How and why we did this swing-state poll.
abstract: The Times/Siena College polls were conducted in six swing states that are likely to decide the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: The Times/Siena College battleground polls released on Sunday and Monday were conducted over the past week in six swing states that are likely to decide the election: Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Five of the states were won by Donald J. Trump in 2016 and then flipped by Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2020. Nevada, which has always been a close state, came down to less than one percentage point in the 2022 U.S. Senate election.

headline: Trump Assails Judge and Concedes a Role in Valuing His Empire’s Property
abstract: The former president, who railed against New York’s attorney general while testifying before a packed courtroom, denied he committed fraud and called the fraud trial “very unfair.”
lead_paragraph: He was belligerent and brash, unrepentant and verbose — regardless of the courtroom setting, he was the quintessential Donald J. Trump.

headline: Jordan Airdrops Medical Aid to Its Field Hospital in Gaza
abstract: It appeared to be the first time in the war that aid was dropped from a plane. Israel’s siege of Gaza has put some hospitals out of service.
lead_paragraph: King Abdullah II of Jordan said on Monday that his country’s air force had airdropped “urgent medical aid” to a field hospital operated by the kingdom in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military confirmed the unusual move and said in a statement that it had been a coordinated effort between the neighboring nations.

headline: Paul Auster Walks the Long Valley of Grief in a New Novel
abstract: In “Baumgartner,” a professor contends with mortality and the haunting memory of his wife.
lead_paragraph: I can hear the whingeing already: Nothing happens in this novel. It’s too slow, it’s boring, it’s not high concept or high event. And in a nod to how conditioned we — or at least I — have become to expect high event, I spent the first 25 pages of “Baumgartner” waiting for its namesake to be kidnapped, maimed or just locked in a closet by the meter man. When it was clear this just wasn’t going to be that kind of novel, I had to start over.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Blockbuster ‘1989’ Rerecording Tops Sales of Original
abstract: In a record-breaking week, the “Taylor’s Version” of the pop star’s 2014 album sold the equivalent of 1,653,000 copies in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Exactly nine years ago, Taylor Swift made a huge splash on the music charts with “1989,” the album that represented her full transformation into a mainstream pop star. With 1,287,000 sales in the United States, it was the biggest start for any album in more than a decade, and affirmed Swift as a megaselling force.

headline: Ever Had a Horrible Boss? ‘The Fund’ Is the Perfect Rage-Read.
abstract: In Rob Copeland’s “The Fund,” we learn about the notorious hedge-fund giant Ray Dalio — and the manipulative professional hellscape over which he has presided.
lead_paragraph: Ray Dalio is the titan behind the world’s biggest hedge fund — a deep thinker and confidant of some of Earth’s most powerful people. Now 74, he has worked diligently over the past few years to publicize his “Principles,” perhaps in the hope that his name will live on.

headline: Fighting a Cold, Pope Francis Hands Out a Speech Instead of Reading It
abstract: The pope, 86, who has had a number of medical scares in recent years, met Monday with European rabbis. The Vatican stressed his illness was nothing serious.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis delivered written instead of verbal remarks on Monday in a meeting with a delegation of European rabbis because he has a slight cold, according to the Vatican.

headline: Trump’s Testimony in Fraud Trial Will Not Be Televised
abstract: Those hoping to watch Donald J. Trump on the witness stand in his civil fraud trial had to go to the courtroom in person.
lead_paragraph: People wishing to watch Donald J. Trump testify in his civil fraud trial on Monday will be largely out of luck.

headline: As Black Voters Drift to Trump, Biden’s Allies Say They Have Work to Do
abstract: New York Times/Siena College polling painted a worrisome picture of the president’s standing with a crucial constituency. Democratic strategists warned that the erosion could threaten his re-election.
lead_paragraph: Black voters are more disconnected from the Democratic Party than they have been in decades, frustrated with what many see as inaction on their political priorities and unhappy with President Biden, a candidate they helped lift to the White House just three years ago.

headline: Do You Know These Military-Themed Books That Became Movies?
abstract: With Veterans Day coming up, here’s short quiz that tests your knowledge on the film adaptations of books about those who served.
lead_paragraph: With Veterans Day coming up, here’s short quiz that tests your knowledge on the film adaptations of books about those who served.

headline: The Easiest Chicken Noodle Soup for the Busiest Season
abstract: Alexa Weibel’s clever recipe gets maximal flavor out of minimal ingredients.
lead_paragraph: A nasty bug took up residence in our house recently, felling us all for a miserable few days. Boy were we grateful for the miracle nutrition of Alexa Weibel’s easiest chicken noodle soup!

headline: Were These Artworks Looted? After Seizures and Lawsuits, Some Still Debate
abstract: Several museums and collectors have surrendered artworks by Egon Schiele to investigators who say they were looted. But others are asserting that the evidence is inconclusive.
lead_paragraph: For decades, several important museums and collectors ignored suggestions that the works they owned by the Austrian master Egon Schiele had been stolen by the Nazis from a Viennese cabaret performer, Fritz Grünbaum.

headline: In ‘Food,’ Geoff Sobelle Explores the Extremes of Eating
abstract: “I don’t want to tell people what to think,” the performance artist said of his latest show. “I just hope it tickles them and their curiosity.”
lead_paragraph: It was a little before 6:30 on a recent weeknight, and the kitchen in Geoff Sobelle’s West Village home was in chaos. Two toddlers zoomed around on a ride-on truck and begged him to read from an “Alice in Wonderland” pop-up book. “In a minute,” Sobelle told his son as he stirred artichokes that were simmering on the stove. All the while, he talked to a reporter about his solo show, “Food,” which is running as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave festival through Nov. 18.

headline: The Times/Siena Poll Isn’t the Only One Indicating an Unhappy Electorate
abstract: Three polls offered warning signs for President Biden.
lead_paragraph: With the 2024 election one year away, The New York Times/Siena College polls released Sunday combined with surveys from two other organizations showed a consistent picture: a deeply unhappy electorate dissatisfied with both of its main options and offering warning signs for President Biden.

headline: Poland’s Art World Awaits a Culture War Counteroffensive
abstract: The Law and Justice party tried to reshape the country via the arts. Now that it appears set to lose office, its critics are split over how to move on.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after becoming Poland’s culture minister, in 2015, Piotr Glinski began a yearslong effort to shift his country’s cultural life toward the political right.

headline: Filipino Radio Journalist Fatally Shot During Live Broadcast
abstract: A gunman shot and killed Juan Jumalon, known to his followers as D.J. Johnny Walker, while he was livestreaming his radio show on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: A Filipino radio journalist, Juan Jumalon, was shot and killed during a live broadcast at his home in the southwest Philippines early on Sunday, according to the local authorities, who were searching for possibly multiple attackers.

headline: Five Wounded as Russian Missiles Strike Odesa, Damaging an Art Museum
abstract: In another setback, Ukraine said 19 soldiers had been killed in a strike on a medals ceremony last week. Unusually, the ceremony had been held in the open, rather than a protected space.
lead_paragraph: A day after Ukraine damaged a Russian naval vessel in an airstrike on Crimea, Russia hit the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa with missiles and drones, injuring five people and damaging an art museum founded in the 19th century, local and military authorities said Monday.

headline: Boy George Will Join ‘Moulin Rouge!’ on Broadway in 2024
abstract: The British pop star will take over the role of the club owner Harold Zidler from Feb. 6 to May 12.
lead_paragraph: The British pop star Boy George will play the role of the enthusiastic club owner Harold Zidler in “Moulin Rouge! The Musical” next year, returning to Broadway for the first time in two decades.

headline: How Do You Use Checks? And Do They Work Well for You?
abstract: Banks are worried about check fraud and are trying to discourage the use of paper checks. But nevertheless, they persist.
lead_paragraph: Fewer people are writing paper checks these days, and for banks that’s a good thing. With check fraud on the rise, banks prefer other forms of payment.

headline: At 50, the Kronos Quartet Is Still Playing for the Future
abstract: The group, which celebrated its birthday on Friday at Carnegie Hall, changed music with its open-eared and open-minded approach.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in 1973, a young violinist named David Harrington was listening to the radio. He heard some music that was just a few years old: George Crumb’s “Black Angels,” a harsh and eerie, prayerful and screaming piece for amplified string quartet, full of grief and anger about the quagmire in Vietnam.

headline: Whitney Wolfe Herd Is Stepping Down as Bumble’s C.E.O. After a Decade
abstract: Ms. Wolfe Herd, who founded the women-centered dating app in 2014, will be replaced by Lidiane Jones, the chief executive of Slack.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Wolfe Herd, who founded the women-centered dating app Bumble a decade ago, is stepping down and will be replaced by Lidiane Jones, the chief executive of the workplace-messaging platform Slack, Bumble said on Monday.

headline: After Two Years in Solitude, ‘Britain’s Loneliest Sheep’ Finds a Home
abstract: Fiona was rescued from the bottom of a Scottish cliff on Saturday and was brought to a farm, though some animal rights activists are concerned about her new home.
lead_paragraph: Fiona, a now-famous and once-lonely British sheep, is at the center of a social media frenzy as well as a local dispute.

headline: Man Whose Son Is Accused of Parade Shooting Pleads Guilty to Misdemeanors
abstract: Robert Crimo Jr., whose son is accused in a shooting at a Fourth of July parade in 2022, agreed to a plea that will send him to jail for 60 days.
lead_paragraph: Robert Crimo Jr. knew that his young son had threatened violence in the family home, promising to “kill everyone,” prosecutors said. The son, Robert Crimo III, had expressed interest in committing a mass shooting in an exchange with a camp counselor and later sent text messages suggesting that he wanted to end his own life.

headline: Could a Prominent Democrat Really Challenge Biden? It’s Unlikely, at This Point.
abstract: Worried Democrats have thrown out the names of popular governors and senators as possible alternatives to the president. But such a challenge appears improbable for a host of reasons.
lead_paragraph: Forty-four years ago tomorrow, the last serious primary opponent to a sitting Democratic president announced his campaign before 5,000 supporters in Boston.

headline: At Paul Taylor, a Drum Circle and a Fierce Sisterhood
abstract: A new work by Larry Keigwin and a company premiere by Ulysses Dove join programs that benefit from live music.
lead_paragraph: When designing sets for the choreographer Paul Taylor, the artist Alex Katz had a habit he called “killing the center.” Katz would stick obstacles in the middle of the stage — fake boulders, a bunch of mirrors, cutouts of dogs — to deny Taylor the easy power of that theatrical focal point. Taylor always rose to the creative challenge.

headline: Inside the Courtroom at Trump’s Fraud Trial
abstract: Here’s a closer look at the scene through a photograph taken Monday just before former President Donald J. Trump took the stand.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump began his testimony Monday before a packed Manhattan courtroom, filled with onlookers. They had come to witness the spectacle of a former U.S. president taking the witness stand at trial to defend his family business and his reputation as a real estate mogul.

headline: With Poll Results Favoring Trump, Should Biden Step Aside?
abstract: Readers discuss a poll showing the president behind his predecessor in five battleground states. Also: I.R.S. funding; health insurance, simplified.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Blinken Warns Iran Against Widening the Conflict Between Israel and Hamas
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned Iran during a weekend of diplomacy in the Middle East. The U.S. military posted a photo of one of its submarines in the region.
lead_paragraph: If Iran had any doubts about American resolve in the Middle East, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, with an assist from the Pentagon, spent the weekend reinforcing the notion that the United States was not going anywhere.

headline: A Knock at the Door
abstract: A child looks on as sheriff’s deputies take inventory of her home.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t like having to do this, believe me,” the uniformed man at the door said in a tone that implied he had no strong feelings about it one way or the other. “We’ll try to get it over with quick.”

headline: The Trumps’ Seven Springs estate has carried very different values over the years.
abstract: The former president purchased the 212-acre estate in Westchester County, N.Y., in the mid-1990s with the hope of developing a golf course or luxury homes, but locals blocked his plans.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump testified on Monday that he had lowered the value of one of his properties — the sprawling Seven Springs estate in New York City’s northern suburbs — because he “thought it was too high.”

headline: OpenAI Lets Mom-and-Pop Shops Customize ChatGPT
abstract: With a new GPTs service, anyone can build a chatbot and instantly share it with friends, family and the general public.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Monday that it had created a service that allows individuals and small businesses to build customized versions of its popular online chatbot, ChatGPT, and instantly share them on the internet.

headline: Zdenek Macal, Conductor With an International Reach, Dies at 87
abstract: Shuttling between Europe and the United States, he conducted the world’s great orchestras. He was music director of the New Jersey Symphony for 11 years.
lead_paragraph: Zdenek Macal, a Czech-born conductor who drew a distinctively rich and full sound from orchestras in several countries, including the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, where his tenure is regarded by musicians and administrators as something of a golden age, died on Oct. 25 in Prague. He was 87.

headline: Frankies 457 Sicilian Olive Oils for Drizzling Over Everything
abstract: A chocolate snowflake for the holiday table, a new hot sauce from Noma and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Frank Falcinelli and Frank Castronovo, the owners of Frankies 457 in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, also happen to have a piece of the Asaro Family Farm, in the Belice Valley in southwest Sicily. The Franks have added some new products bearing the restaurant’s name. A basic everyday oil, sold by the liter, is a blend of Nocellara del Belice, Biancolilla and hearty Cerasuola olives, all Sicilian natives, golden, with a peppery edge in its finish ($27.99 for 1 liter). Then there’s a Calabrian Chili Oil ($21.99 for 17 ounces), ruddy, with vibrant heat from three kinds of chiles blended into the Sicilian oil; the Franks suggest drizzling it on pizza. The organic extra virgin oil made entirely from Nocellara del Belice, greener and more herbal ($34.99 for 17 ounces), has been on the market for some time and is still available. They have also introduced six traditional organic pastas made from ancient grains, cut on bronze dies and air-dried ($7.49 a pound), and deliciously meaty Castelvetrano olives and whole Sicilian black (brownish) olives, each $8.49 for 12 ounces.

headline: U.N. Says Israel-Gaza War Is Deadliest Ever for Its Personnel
abstract: The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, said Monday that 89 employees of UNRWA, its agency aiding Palestinian refugees, had been killed since the war began.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, said on Monday that 89 employees of the U.N. agency aiding Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, had been killed in Gaza in the month of war between Israel and Hamas.

headline: Cody Dorman, Who Forged a Close Bond With a Top Racehorse, Dies at 17
abstract: A boy with a rare genetic disorder inspired the name of the horse Cody’s Wish, who won at the Breeders’ Cup on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Cody Dorman, who inspired the name of the racehorse Cody’s Wish, died on Sunday, a day after the horse won at the Breeders’ Cup in Southern California. He was 17.

headline: Investigators Head to Antarctica Research Base After Claims of Sexual Violence
abstract: The National Science Foundation watchdog is sending agents to a U.S. research base in Antarctica after a 2022 report raised concerns about sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: The independent monitor for the National Science Foundation is sending investigators to McMurdo Station in Antarctica who should arrive on Monday after a report last year raised concerns about sexual assault and harassment at a U.S. research base.

headline: How Democrats Lost Voters With a ‘Compensate Losers’ Strategy
abstract: A shift from preventing inequality in the first place to fixing it after the fact has cost the party, a paper argues.
lead_paragraph: A lot of Democrats are bewildered by why their party isn’t doing better in campaigns against a Republican Party that is deeply dysfunctional. A new paper by three economists proposes a fresh explanation that seems persuasive to me. It says the Democrats went astray right around … 1976.

headline: Male-Killing Virus Is Discovered in Insects
abstract: The chance finding in a Japanese university’s greenhouse could help researchers find ways to control agricultural pests or even insects that spread disease.
lead_paragraph: Scientists in Japan have identified a virus that selectively kills males — and it happens to be inheritable, creating generation upon generation of all females.

headline: Trump’s lawyers in the case have different approaches to representing the former president.
abstract: Christopher M. Kise and Alina Habba, the two lawyers who joined Donald J. Trump at the defense table before he testified Monday at his civil fraud trial in New York, represent different aspects of what the former president looks for in a defender.
lead_paragraph: Christopher M. Kise and Alina Habba, the two lawyers who joined Donald J. Trump at the defense table before he testified Monday at his civil fraud trial in New York, represent different aspects of what the former president looks for in a defender.

headline: The State Department Approves $320 Million Sale of Guided Bomb Equipment to Israel
abstract: Israel has been using the kits during its bombing campaign in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. State Department has approved a $320 million sale to Israel of equipment for kits that turn unguided bombs into more precise, GPS-guided munitions, according to a letter sent by the department to Congress that was obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Imprisoned Nobel Winner and Iranian Rights Activist Begins a Hunger Strike
abstract: Narges Mohammadi is protesting the prison’s denial of hospital treatment for her heart condition, her family said.
lead_paragraph: Narges Mohammadi, the imprisoned Iranian human rights activist who won this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, began a hunger strike on Monday, after she was denied hospital treatment for two blocked coronary arteries, her family said.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Cuts the Gaza Strip in Two
abstract: Plus, Trump testifies at his civil fraud trial.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said yesterday that it had encircled Gaza City, effectively splitting the Gaza Strip in half. Israel said the move would make it harder for Hamas to retain control of the area.

headline: When a Child Is Shot, Trauma Ripples Through Families, Study Finds
abstract: Gunshots are the top cause of death for children and teenagers in the U.S. Fatal or not, the wounds reverberate through communities and the health care system.
lead_paragraph: With each mass shooting, Americans look to one grim indicator — the number of dead — as a measure of the destructive impact. But damage left behind by gunshot wounds reverberates among survivors and families, sending mental health disorders soaring and shifting huge burdens onto the health care system, a new analysis of private health insurance claims shows.

headline: Biden Administration, After Setbacks, Talks Up Renewable Power Gains
abstract: The administration said 15 clean energy projects were making solid progress and that it was on track to meet its goals for 2025.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Monday progress on 15 large renewable energy projects, an apparent effort to project confidence in an industry that is facing steep challenges.

headline: Young Men Seek Answers to an Age-Old Question: How to Be Hot
abstract: “Looksmaxxers” are a booming online community creating new terms for age-old insecurities.
lead_paragraph: Skin-care routines, hair care, a good night’s sleep: These are not cutting-edge suggestions for how to look one’s best, at least not for anyone who has ever consulted a women’s magazine.

headline: Biden Announces New Investments in Passenger Rail Projects
abstract: President Biden, a longtime Amtrak rider, exhibited a business-as-usual approach in announcing $16.4 billion in awards for rail projects, despite polls showing him trailing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, perhaps Amtrak’s most famous advocate, announced $16.4 billion in funding for rail projects on Monday, exhibiting a business-as-usual approach as polls show him trailing former President Donald J. Trump one year before Election Day.

headline: Review: In This ‘120 Days of Sodom,’ Sadism Stands in the Way
abstract: The provocations in Milo Rau’s stage adaptation, featuring actors with Down syndrome, confuse the production as it grapples with weighty issues.
lead_paragraph: Is anything even shocking on a stage anymore? Simulated rape, coprophilia and torture all feature heavily in Milo Rau’s “The Last Generation, or the 120 Days of Sodom,” a theater production starring actors with Down syndrome that opened Saturday at the Théâtre de Liège, in Belgium.

headline: A Judge Tries to Do What Few Have Accomplished: Rein in Trump
abstract: Through the first few hours of Donald J. Trump’s time on the witness stand, he and Judge Arthur F. Engoron traded irritated facial expressions.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of Donald J. Trump’s testimony in Manhattan, the judge presiding over the civil fraud case against the former president tried to do what Hillary Clinton, a star-studded lineup of debate moderators and even Mr. Trump’s own lawyers could not: make Mr. Trump stop talking.

headline: Four Men Charged in the Case of the Missing Golden Toilet
abstract: The fully functioning 18-karat gold toilet, an artwork estimated to be worth $5.9 million, was stolen in 2019 from an exhibition at a stately British home.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a fully functioning 18-karat gold toilet was stolen from an art exhibition at Blenheim Palace, the birthplace of Winston Churchill.

headline: Second Police Officer Acquitted in Elijah McClain Death
abstract: Nathan Woodyard was the first officer to stop Mr. McClain in what became a violent encounter. The young, unarmed Black man died days later.
lead_paragraph: A second Colorado police officer has been acquitted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young, unarmed Black man whose case attracted national attention and became central to debates about police brutality and race.

headline: Trump Testified at His New York Civil Fraud Trial
abstract: Also, Israel said it encircled Gaza City. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: During four hours of testimony in a Manhattan courtroom today, Donald Trump repeatedly attacked the judge overseeing the trial and defended himself against accusations of fraudulently misvaluing his properties.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Birds, Baseball, Bankman-Fried
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: China Is Lending Billions to Countries in Financial Trouble
abstract: Instead of lending money for highways and bridges, China has shifted to providing emergency rescues for previous borrowers.
lead_paragraph: After lending $1.3 trillion to developing countries, mainly for big-ticket infrastructure projects, China has shifted its focus to bailing out many of those same countries from piles of debt.

headline: Democrats in Congress Weigh Calls for Cease-Fire Amid Pressure From the Left
abstract: They have grown more vocal about urging measures to mitigate civilian casualties in Gaza, but supporters of a cease-fire are few and far between.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress, torn between their support for Israel in its war with Hamas and concern about civilian suffering in Gaza, are struggling with how far to go in calling for measures to mitigate civilian casualties as the left wing of the party escalates pressure for a cease-fire.

headline: The Statue of Liberty Is the Setting for an Israel-Hamas War Protest
abstract: Protests over the war have been organized almost daily across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of protesters boarded ferries to the Statue of Liberty on Monday, carrying banners calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war that they unfurled from the statue’s pedestal.

headline: Prosecutors Assail Trump’s Bid to Have Federal Election Case Dismissed
abstract: Prosecutors said that Mr. Trump’s barrage of motions to have the case tossed out were full of “distortions and misrepresentations.”
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to reject a barrage of motions filed last month by former President Donald J. Trump that sought to toss out the indictment charging him with plotting to overturn the 2020 election and said his claims were full of “distortions and misrepresentations.”

headline: Why Does the Right Hate America?
abstract: In many ways, social change has made us a better nation.
lead_paragraph: U.S. democracy is clearly in crisis. It’s entirely possible that in less than two years dissenters will face the power of a government with an authoritarian bent; if that sounds to you like hyperbole, you aren’t paying attention.

headline: DeSantis Lands a Big Endorsement: Kim Reynolds, Iowa’s Popular Governor
abstract: After saying she would stay neutral in her state’s 2024 caucuses, angering Donald Trump in the process, Ms. Reynolds said “we have too much at stake.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida needed a lift in his quest to beat former President Donald J. Trump in the crucial Iowa caucuses.

headline: Biden Confronts the Limits of U.S. Leverage in Two Conflicts
abstract: President Biden’s influence over Israel and Ukraine seems far more constrained than expected, given his central role as the supplier of arms and intelligence.
lead_paragraph: After four weeks of terror and retaliation in Israel and Gaza, and 20 months of war in Ukraine, President Biden is confronting the limits of his leverage in the two international conflicts defining his presidency.

headline: Gaza Death Toll Has Hit 10,000, Its Health Ministry Says
abstract: The figures could not be independently verified, but a Pentagon spokesman acknowledged on Monday that “we know the numbers are in the thousands.”
lead_paragraph: In just under a month, Israeli strikes have killed more than 10,000 people in Gaza and injured more than 25,000 others, the Gaza Health Ministry said on Monday.

headline: Excerpts From Nashville School Shooter’s Writings Are Published Online
abstract: The publication of the apparent excerpts by a conservative commentator enraged the parents of surviving students, who have been fighting to keep the writings from ever becoming public.
lead_paragraph: A conservative political commentator published three photographs on Monday that appeared to show excerpts from writings by the shooter who killed six people at a Nashville Christian school, enraging parents of the surviving students and prompting an investigation into the leak.

headline: Here’s Who Qualified for the Third Republican Presidential Debate
abstract: Chris Christie, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott will meet again on the stage on Wednesday night, but Doug Burgum missed the cut.
lead_paragraph: Five candidates have qualified for the third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday evening, the Republican National Committee announced on Monday.

headline: Flaco the Owl, Zoo Escapee, Leaves Central Park for the East Village
abstract: Nine months after settling into a new life in the park, Flaco turned up about five miles away on a tree branch in a sculpture garden.
lead_paragraph: Flaco the Eurasian eagle-owl, whose February escape from the Central Park Zoo captured the public’s attention in New York and beyond, turned up in Manhattan’s East Village on Monday, about five miles from the wooded park area he had settled into since flying free.

headline: WeWork Files for Bankruptcy Amid Glut of Empty Offices
abstract: The move is a blow for landlords who have rented space to the co-working group, which is planning a “comprehensive reorganization” that includes cutting some of its leases.
lead_paragraph: WeWork, the real estate company that offered start-ups and individuals sleek quarters to pursue their entrepreneurial dreams, filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Monday after years of struggling to find its footing.

headline: Conditions
abstract: Kevin Curry and Daniel Bodily tee up their first collaboration for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Florida Dentist Convicted in Murder-for-Hire Plot Against Law Professor
abstract: A jury in Tallahassee found Charles Adelson guilty of murder and conspiracy in the 2014 death of his former brother-in-law, Dan Markel.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, the sensational killing of a prominent Florida law professor in 2014 centered on a single, sordid question: Did his ex-wife’s family, motivated by an ugly custody dispute, hire hit men to murder him?

headline: Corrections: Nov. 7, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A quotation highlighted in an article on Sunday about injuries suffered by U.S. troops who  fired vast numbers of artillery rounds against the Islamic State misidentified the speaker, a former gunner who killed a man during a psychotic episode. It was Brady Zipoy,  not Austin Powell.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Amid Mideast Violence, Food Can’t Offer a Route to Peace
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We have this romantic idea that if we eat the same food and break the same bread somehow we can come together, but that doesn’t seem to be the case here.”

headline: Israel Says It Has Split Gaza Strip in Two in Drive to Isolate Hamas’s Leadership
abstract: Israel’s military surrounded Gaza City as the enclave plunged into another communications blackout, sowing panic among relatives fearful of the fate of loved ones who remain there.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said its forces had split the Gaza Strip in two after a night of heavy airstrikes, a move that Israel said would make it more difficult for Hamas to control the enclave.

headline: Jewish Man’s Death After California Protest Clash Is Under Investigation
abstract: The episode occurred in a suburb outside Los Angeles amid pro-Israel and pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: As a fatal clash between suburban protesters in Southern California threatened to become an international incident on Tuesday, the authorities said that it wasn’t “exactly crystal clear” how a 69-year-old Jewish man died from an altercation with a pro-Palestinian demonstrator over the weekend.

headline: Virginia: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: All 140 seats in Virginia’s General Assembly are on the ballot, and Republicans led by Gov. Glenn Youngkin are seeking full control of the state government.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Mississippi, and Kentucky.]

headline: Kentucky: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: The governor’s race is the state’s marquee contest on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Mississippi, and Virginia.]

headline: Mississippi: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: The state’s Republican governor, Tate Reeves, is facing a credible threat from his Democratic challenger, Brandon Presley.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Kentucky, and Virginia.]

headline: It’s Election Day in New Jersey: Here’s What to Know
abstract: All of the seats in the State Legislature are on the ballot, and Republicans are hoping to make gains.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]

headline: Ohio: How to Vote, Where to Vote and What’s on the Ballot
abstract: On Election Day, voters in Ohio will decide on two ballot measures: one on abortion rights and one on the recreational use of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in New Jersey, New York, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]

headline: It’s Election Day in New York: Here’s What to Know
abstract: Although no citywide offices are being contested this year, the New York City Council is up for election, and voters statewide will consider two ballot questions.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in New Jersey, Ohio, Mississippi, Kentucky, and Virginia.]

headline: Her Name Is Barbra, but It Wasn’t Always
abstract: In a chatty and candid new memoir, Barbra Streisand talks about her early determination to be famous and tallies the hurdles and helpers she met along the way.
lead_paragraph: Hello, enormous.

headline: Brazil Cracks Down on Surprising New Threat: Neo-Nazis
abstract: The Brazilian government has raided neo-Nazi groups across 10 states this year, part of a push by the new Lula administration to prosecute far-right extremists.
lead_paragraph: In southern Brazil in July, Laureano Toscani and João Guilherme Correa were smoking cigarettes along a busy road in their prison-issued garb, shorts and sandals, waiting for a ride after seven months in jail.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The death toll in Gaza climbs.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after Israel began its bombardment of Gaza, the territory’s Hamas-run health ministry said more than 10,000 people had been killed and more than 25,000 injured. The figures could not be independently verified, but a Pentagon spokesman said that “we know the numbers are in the thousands.”

headline: I’m a Ukrainian, and I Refuse to Compete for Your Attention
abstract: Ukrainians have been infantilized by the need to vie for international interest.
lead_paragraph: The day Hamas attacked Israel, I unexpectedly reunited with my best friend in Kyiv.

headline: ‘Vortenses’ and the Storms of Space-Time
abstract: In verse and in color, a Nobel physicist and a visual artist collaborate to portray black holes, gravitational waves and other preposterous features of Einstein’s universe.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever wondered what it might feel like to be sucked into a black hole — twisted, stretched, confused, doomed — you could do worse than trip through “The Warped Side of Our Universe, An Odyssey Through Black Holes, Wormholes, Time Travel and Gravitational Waves,” a collaborative book project by Kip Thorne, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology, and Lia Halloran, a visual artist and chair of the art department at Chapman University in Orange, Calif.

headline: California Boat Captain Convicted of Manslaughter in Fire That Killed 34
abstract: The 2019 fire near Santa Barbara killed all 33 passengers of the dive boat. On Monday, a federal jury found the captain guilty of “seaman’s manslaughter.”
lead_paragraph: The captain of a dive boat that caught fire off the coast of Southern California in 2019, killing all 33 passengers and one of its six crew members, was found guilty by a federal jury on Monday on one count of an offense known as “seaman’s manslaughter.”

headline: Word of the Day: onus
abstract: This word has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word onus has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in the Opinion essay “We’re Teaching Music to Kids All Wrong” by Sammy Miller:

headline: Late Night Riffs on Trump’s Lead Over Biden in Early Poll
abstract: “Polling a year ahead of an election is always super-accurate — and if you don’t believe me, just ask President Hillary Clinton,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: King Charles III, Climate Advocate, Delivers Speech at Odds With His Beliefs
abstract: In keeping with tradition, he outlined the priorities of the prime minister at the opening of Parliament — including, this year, more fossil fuel extraction.
lead_paragraph: For a lifelong supporter of environmental causes, a plan to expand oil and gas drilling in the North Sea was probably not what King Charles III had hoped to announce when he opened Britain’s Parliament for the first time as monarch.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Time Change
abstract: Do you look forward to “falling back” an hour — or dread it?
lead_paragraph: Sunday marked the end of Daylight Saving Time, where, in some parts of the world, including the United States, people set their clocks back an hour.

headline: N.F.L. Fans, Take a Number for Your Team’s Chances
abstract: The Upshot’s N.F.L. Playoff Simulator is churning out options for the 10th straight year.
lead_paragraph: There are some drawbacks to being a Minnesota Vikings fan, said Kevin Quealy, editor of The Upshot, The New York Times’s data-driven site about politics, economics and everyday life. His team has never won the Super Bowl, and just trying to calculate their playoff odds can become a headache. Even sportscasters appear to be run ragged by the probabilities.

headline: 5 Things We Learned During Trump’s Trial Testimony
abstract: The former president took the witness stand Monday in a Manhattan courtroom as he tried to preserve the business empire that made his name.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump took the witness stand on Monday in a packed New York courtroom in a trial that threatens the business empire underpinning his public persona as he kicks off another run for the White House.

headline: Does Anyone Know How to Behave on the Subway Anymore?
abstract: New Yorkers are reacquainting themselves with the subway code — no eye contact; no stinky food — as the city rebounds from the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: There are unwritten rules when riding the New York City subway.

headline: From Substance to Shouting: The Demise of Political Debate in America
abstract: Presidential debates weren’t always so hostile.
lead_paragraph: Presidential debates weren’t always so hostile.

headline: Grave Robbers of the Wild West
abstract: In “Sins of the Shovel,” Rachel Morgan describes the dark, chaotic early days of American archaeology.
lead_paragraph: Archaeology in its formative years was often less a meticulous science than an exercise in vandalism.

headline: In ‘The Future,’ Earth Barrels Toward Fiery Destruction
abstract: Naomi Alderman’s new novel imagines an end of the world that only the wealthiest can survive — or can they?
lead_paragraph: There are few figures in the Bible more cruelly evocative than Lot’s wife, who is transfigured into a pillar of salt for looking back at Sodom. The poet Anna Akhmatova mourned “her swift legs rooted to the ground”; Kurt Vonnegut wrote of her backward glance, “I love her for that, because it was so human.” Naomi Alderman’s “The Future,” like much great science fiction, turns the symbolic into tangible, chemical reality. Early in her novel, a woman is frozen to death with a chemical refrigerant made of paramagnetic salts: a Lot’s wife for the Information Age.

headline: He Believes He’s Been Reincarnated. Here’s His Tale of Life, Love and Fate.
abstract: In Jonathan Evison’s new novel, “Again and Again,” a curmudgeonly old man in an elder-care facility finds an unlikely connection as he recounts the stories of his past lives.
lead_paragraph: It is “the most beautiful of all possible worlds,” a chapter heading proclaims at the beginning of Jonathan Evison’s new novel, “Again and Again.” But it’s easy to doubt this cheerful echo of “Candide” as we are introduced to the book’s protagonist, Eugene Miles, a centenarian curmudgeon living in an elder-care facility in the California desert who insists — a bit too loudly and often — on his desire to be left alone to await death.

headline: Setting a Table for the Holidays? Designers Share Their Secrets.
abstract: For starters, don’t worry if there isn’t much space: “The closer the people are, the better the party.”
lead_paragraph: Serving a meal is about more than just feeding your guests.

headline: Gazing Into the Past and Future at Historic Observatories
abstract: As ever-larger telescopes are launched into space or built at high-altitude sites, these observatories still have wonders to share with visitors and astronomers alike.
lead_paragraph: At the top of Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, Calif., Lick Observatory looks out over the dense sprawl of the San Francisco Bay Area. On a clear day from the 4,200-foot summit, you can see San Francisco to the north, as well as the entrance to Yosemite Valley, 120 miles east, as the crow flies. At night you can see even farther — millions of light-years into space.

headline: I Just Got Over Covid but Still Feel Awful
abstract: Symptoms can linger for days or weeks after testing negative, even for those who don’t develop long Covid.
lead_paragraph: Q: It’s been a week since I tested negative for Covid, but I don’t feel totally better. Why am I still sick?

headline: Desire Marea’s Genre-Melting Music Stirs South Africa, and the World
abstract: The 32-year-old’s work in Zulu and English traverses styles and explores queer histories. This week he releases a new EP, “The Baddies of Isandlwana.”
lead_paragraph: On a crisp Thursday morning hours before Desire Marea’s performance at the Transform Festival in Leeds, England, earlier this month, the South African songwriter sat in Kirkstall Valley Nature Reserve, communing with his Zulu ancestors. It’s a practice he honed through his training as a sangoma, a traditional spiritual healer, and it is essential to his craft.

headline: How the Humble Sheet Cake Became Top Tier
abstract: In the world of special occasion baked goods, pastry chefs are embracing the birthday party staple for its vast canvas.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based baker Michelle Boulos can still picture the sheet cakes she ate as a child: slathered with bright white frosting, decorated with tiny plastic balloons. But the confections she makes and sells via her Instagram account No Good Cakes are something else entirely. On one recent creation, frills of buttercream surrounded an acid green ombré surface inspired by a chemical spill. On another, foraged blooms sprouted from bronze-colored barnacles, some of them embedded with tiny light bulbs. Boulos, 34, started baking the fantastical cakes out of her home in 2022 after making one for a wedding. “I got bitten by the sheet cake bug,” she says. “It can be so versatile but also really complex.”

headline: Why Palestinians Feel They’ve Been ‘Duped’
abstract: The Palestinian policy analyst and writer Amjad Iraqi on how Gaza’s past, present and future look from his eyes.
lead_paragraph: Before there can be any kind of stable coexistence of Israelis and Palestinians, there will have to be a stable coexistence of narratives. And that’s what we’ll be attempting this week on the show: to look at both the present and the past through Israeli and Palestinian perspectives. The point is not to choose between them. The point is to really listen to them. Even — especially — when what’s being said is hard for us to hear.

headline: Winter Accessories That Sparkle and Shine
abstract: Sequins, paillettes and rhinestones light up this season’s shoes and bags.

headline: A Wood-Lined Retreat in the Heart of Paris
abstract: On one of the most Parisian streets in the city, two interior designers create a new kind of French fantasy.
lead_paragraph: IN THE CENTER of Paris, in the First Arrondissement, around the corner from the Jardin du Palais-Royal — with its orderly tree-lined promenades — there’s a ragged bistro called Juveniles at which tourists jostle for tables and locals buy bottles of wine to bring home after work. It’s a true neighborhood spot in an office-dominated district where most Parisians could never imagine living, even if they wanted to: Nearby are the Louvre, the Opéra Garnier, Sainte-Chapelle and other landmarks so intrinsic to the grand cinematic vision of the city that the relatively few apartments that become available around here are almost immediately snatched up.

headline: Hungry (but Not for Human Contact), Americans Head for the Drive-Through
abstract: A national fixture is enjoying a fresh surge as post-pandemic customers crave speed and solitude. And restaurants are responding with a raft of innovations.
lead_paragraph: Faith Enokian loves a drive-through. The senior at the University of South Alabama loves them so much she pulls into one at least eight times a week.

headline: Why Salmonella Makes So Many People Sick
abstract: The bacteria are a leading cause of food poisoning. Here’s how to avoid an infection.
lead_paragraph: Cantaloupe, diced onions, cookie dough, alfalfa sprouts, peanut butter — what do these very different foods have in common?

headline: Did a 2008 Rule Change Ruin Presidential Debates?
abstract: Presidential candidates’s meetings weren’t always so hostile.
lead_paragraph: Sophomoric insults. Rudeness. Personal attacks. Cross talk.

headline: How Your Child’s School Bus Might Prevent Blackouts
abstract: When not driving around, electric buses and other vehicles could help utilities by storing their solar and wind energy and releasing it to meet surges in demand.
lead_paragraph: The four vehicles parked at a depot in South Burlington, Vt., look no different from the yellow school buses familiar to millions of schoolchildren. But beneath their steel shells, these buses are packed with technology that could be vital in the transition to clean energy.

headline: Should Schools Ban Cellphones?
abstract: Rules restricting when students can use phones are on the rise. Do they work? Are they fair?
lead_paragraph: Nearly one in four countries has laws or policies banning or restricting student cellphone use in schools.

headline: Lavish Tax Credits and Trade Protections Lure Solar Firms to U.S.
abstract: A combination of government policies is finally succeeding in reversing a long decline in solar manufacturing in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, an executive from Suniva, a bankrupt solar panel manufacturer, warned a packed hearing room in Washington that competition from companies in China and Southeast Asia was causing a “blood bath” in his industry. More than 30 U.S.-based solar companies had been forced to shut down in the previous five years alone, he said, and others would soon follow unless the government supported them.

headline: What’s Behind Kennedy’s Poll Numbers? Voters Dread a Trump-Biden Rematch.
abstract: Frustration with the two men likely to be the major parties’ nominees has led voters to entertain the idea of other options, New York Times/Siena College polls found.
lead_paragraph: A looming rematch next year between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump has left voters deeply dissatisfied with their options, longing for alternatives and curious about independent candidates like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., according to new polls of six battleground states conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: In Regulating A.I., We May Be Doing Too Much. And Too Little.
abstract: Success will mean staying focused on concrete problems like deep fakes.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden signed his sweeping executive order on artificial intelligence last week, he joked about the strange experience of watching a “deep fake” of himself, saying, “When the hell did I say that?”

headline: Their Final Wish? A Burial in Space.
abstract: Why some people decide to send their remains into orbit.
lead_paragraph: There are two ways to contemplate the question Where do we go when we die? One is philosophical, ultimately unanswerable; the other is logistical. Humans, being human, have tended to see them as being intertwined: The many traditions we’ve devised for handling our remains are meant to honor the selves that left those bodies behind.

headline: Step 1 if You’re Going to Beat Trump
abstract: His opponents have to take him on with sustained attacks that don’t alienate his supporters. There’s a right approach and a wrong approach.
lead_paragraph: In the movie “Back to the Future II,” Michael J. Fox’s character, Marty McFly, is transported to the fall of 2015 and encounters a world of self-tying shoes and hoverboards. He finds himself trying to make sense of how people behave and the choices they make.

headline: Extreme Weather May Be Displacing Animals, Too, a New Study Suggests
abstract: An analysis by researchers in China found that weather disasters might be helping nonnative animals replace native species in the wild.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis published this week suggests that extreme weather linked to climate change might be much harder on native species than on nonnative ones.

headline: Thousands of Gazans fled south during a window given by Israel, the U.N. says.
abstract: About 5,000 people left the northern half of Gaza during a four-hour window given by the Israeli military on Monday, according to United Nations monitors, a day after Israel said its forces had cleaved the territory in two.
lead_paragraph: About 5,000 people left the northern half of Gaza during a four-hour window given by the Israeli military on Monday, according to United Nations monitors, a day after Israel said its forces had cleaved the territory in two.

headline: Under Scrutiny Over Gaza, Israel Points to Civilian Toll of U.S. Wars
abstract: Israeli officials say it is impossible to defeat Hamas without killing innocents, a lesson they argue Americans and their allies should understand.
lead_paragraph: Falluja. Mosul. Copenhagen. Hiroshima.

headline: Where New York Stands on a Groundwater Crisis
abstract: Overpumping and depletion of groundwater is a threat to farmers and is even more important because of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll see how New York is managing its groundwater amid a nationwide crisis. And, because it’s Election Day, we’ll catch up on contests to watch.

headline: Supreme Court Seems Likely to Uphold Law Disarming Domestic Abusers
abstract: A decision in the case could extend far beyond domestic abuse by clarifying the scope of a court ruling last year on gun rights.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seemed ready on Tuesday to rule that the government may disarm people under domestic violence orders, limiting the sweep of last year’s blockbuster decision that vastly expanded gun rights.

headline: Special Counsel Rebuts Claims of Favoritism Toward Hunter Biden
abstract: David C. Weiss told a House committee that he has always had authority over the investigation.
lead_paragraph: David C. Weiss, who negotiated an ill-fated plea deal with President Biden’s son, Hunter, fiercely defended the integrity of his investigation before House Republicans on Tuesday, the first time a special counsel has fielded questions from lawmakers before concluding an inquiry.

headline: Viewed Warily by Democrats, a Netanyahu Ally Is a Key Conduit to U.S.
abstract: Ron Dermer sits in Israel’s five-member war cabinet and is a crucial liaison to the Biden administration, including U.S. officials he clashed with when he was ambassador to Washington.
