lead_paragraph: I am 55, and my husband is 75. We’ve been married for 25 years. He is retired and keeps himself busy while I am at work. Lately, he waits for me every day — with bated breath — so we can have sex when I get home. He complains that I can’t keep up with him sexually. But I need some me time: He doesn’t consider that I work full time, have a lengthy commute and still have to make dinner. I can’t talk to my friends about this; they would think I was crazy. Should I have him checked by a doctor? Is he suffering from early dementia? I love him, but he is wearing me out. Would I be better off without him?

headline: How a Patchwork of Rules to Protect America’s Water Is Falling Short
abstract: A conversation with the Times reporter Delger Erdenesanaa, who helped lead an investigation on the poor oversight of our country’s aquifers.
lead_paragraph: Groundwater is one of America’s most precious resources. The water that fills wells, stored naturally in underground aquifers, allowed vast cities to emerge and turned the nation into an agricultural powerhouse.

headline: ‘What’s Cooking in the Kremlin’? A Heady Mix of Propaganda and Paranoia.
abstract: The new book by Witold Szablowski features the chefs who were expected to prepare sumptuous meals for Russian leaders — and keep them from being poisoned.
lead_paragraph: Witold Szablowski describes a number of surprising dishes in his entertaining yet unnerving new book, “What’s Cooking in the Kremlin,” which explores the last century of Russian history through its food. But none is as surreal as the recipe for one of Lenin’s favorites. The instructions for making his “scrambled eggs using three eggs” orders you to break the eggs but not to beat them. What Lenin called “scrambled eggs” were actually fried eggs, with their yolks and whites intact — not scrambled at all.

headline: Nikki Haley Wears the Skirts
abstract: Whether on the debate stage or “The Daily Show,” the Republican presidential candidate is strategic about standing out — in every way.
lead_paragraph: In a crowded field of Republican presidential candidates, Nikki R. Haley is starting to stand out. Such, anyway, seems to be the conclusion of pollsters, voters and donors alike, who have helped bolster her numbers since she first took to the debate stage back in August. She’s on enough of an upswing that “Saturday Night Live” has started to prep a Haley character in anticipation.

headline: Las Vegas Unions and Caesars Reach Tentative Agreement as Strike Looms
abstract: The deal was announced two days before a strike deadline set by two unions. The walkout threat still hangs over other resorts and the city’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Unions representing hospitality workers in Las Vegas reached a tentative agreement on Wednesday with one of the city’s three major resort operators, two days before a strike deadline that loomed just as tourists arrive for a major sporting event.

headline: Lucky Find at Auction Identifies Man on Cover of ‘Led Zeppelin IV’
abstract: It’s not a painting. It’s a picture of a Victorian artisan taken in the English countryside in 1892.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 8, 1971, Led Zeppelin released its iconic fourth studio album, which was untitled but is widely known as “Led Zeppelin IV.” It features the band’s major hit “Stairway to Heaven,” and the wordless cover shows the framed image of a bearded, older man with a large bundle of sticks on his back against the backdrop of a decaying wall.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Loves His Heritage. Just Don’t Call Him an Indian American.
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate says the celebration of diversity in America has come at the cost of national unity.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy does not shy away from his Indian heritage.

headline: Yusef Salaam, Exonerated ‘Central Park Five’ Member, Wins Council Race
abstract: Mr. Salaam ran unopposed to represent Harlem on the New York City Council, after winning a competitive Democratic primary for the seat in June.
lead_paragraph: Yusef Salaam, who was one of five Black and Latino teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park and exonerated decades later, was elected on Tuesday night to represent Harlem on the New York City Council.

headline: The Next Costume Institute Fashion Blockbuster Is Revealed
abstract: Gala-goers, start thinking green.
lead_paragraph: After the pop culture bonanza of this summer’s “Barbie,” the hoo-ha surrounding the live action remake of “The Little Mermaid” and the attention paid to anything in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, observers could be forgiven for hearing the title of the next Costume Institute blockbuster at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and think they were in for a Disney spectacle. After all, it is called “Sleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion.” And those princess costumes have been very influential.

headline: Does the Boss Need to Weigh In on the War in the Middle East?
abstract: It’s become the norm for company executives to issue notes to employees about social upheaval. But the Israel-Hamas war presents a special challenge.
lead_paragraph: After reading the details of Hamas’s attacks on Israel on Oct. 7, Brad Karp, who runs the law firm Paul, Weiss, sat at his computer and wrote a memo to his roughly 2,000 employees.

headline: Senate Democrats Challenge Biden on Israel, Seeking Assurances About Aid
abstract: A majority of the Democratic caucus signed a letter asking President Biden to ensure that Israel has a viable plan for defeating Hamas and will use U.S. military assistance in keeping with international law.
lead_paragraph: A majority of the Senate Democratic caucus called on President Biden on Wednesday to defend his request for $14.3 billion in emergency military assistance for Israel, seeking assurances that the Jewish state has a viable plan for defeating Hamas and that the United States will not be funding actions that run afoul of international and U.S. laws.

headline: Democrat Beshear Charted Pragmatic Path to Re-election in Kentucky
abstract: In a conservative state, the governor won over many Republican voters with his handling of crises. But the G.O.P. still controls the state’s powerful Legislature.
lead_paragraph: It seemed to be a fluke.

headline: Melissa Clark’s Brilliant Make-and-Take Turkey
abstract: A perfectly roasted (and reheated) centerpiece dish for wherever your Thanksgiving may be.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been working on new Thanksgiving recipes since summer, but the holiday somehow still sneaked up on me. Turkey Day is two weeks away! Do you know what you’re making yet?

headline: Mental Illness, Especially Later in Life, Can Increase the Risk of Dementia
abstract: Research is revealing an inextricable link between mental disorders and neurological disorders.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Sharon Niederhaus, then 77, lost her husband of more than 50 years. Her daughter, Kristin Henry, said her mother was never the same afterward. “We feel like we lost both our parents at the same time,” Ms. Henry said, referring to her and her brother.

headline: France Links Conversation in Russian to Star of David Graffiti
abstract: After more than 200 blue stars were stenciled on buildings in and around Paris, prosecutors say they are investigating whether a foreign intermediary paid a couple to spray paint them.
lead_paragraph: French prosecutors are investigating whether a foreign intermediary was behind the painting of more than 200 blue Stars of David on buildings in and around Paris last month amid a surge of antisemitic acts in Europe since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: 2023 Virtually Certain to Be the Hottest Year on Record, Scientists Say
abstract: Analyzing data from October, European climate scientists found another record-breaking month for temperatures around the world.
lead_paragraph: October 2023 was the warmest October on record globally, according to data from European climate scientists released on Wednesday. It comes on the heels of the hottest September on record and the hottest summer months globally, rounding out a year of record temperatures around the planet.

headline: Citigroup Discriminated Against Armenian Americans, Regulator Says
abstract: The bank agreed to pay nearly $26 million to settle claims that its employees denied an immigrant community in Southern California fair access to its credit cards.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup employees labeled a group of roughly 80,000 Armenian Americans living near Los Angeles — the largest Armenian community outside Yerevan, the Armenian capital — as “bad guys” and secretly denied them fair access to the bank’s credit card products, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Elections Offer Respite for Biden, but Show Disparity Between Him and His Party
abstract: Tuesday’s results were a win for the president after demoralizing poll numbers. But some strategists argue the outcomes show only that Democrats are doing well, not necessarily the president.
lead_paragraph: Poll? What poll? The Democratic victories in Tuesday’s off-year elections gave President Biden’s White House some desperately needed breathing space just when it needed it.

headline: Candidates Circle Each Other on Israel Ahead of G.O.P. Debate
abstract: Israel’s war in Gaza has become a major focus of the 2024 Republican presidential race. Lisa Lerer reports on how that’s likely to play out at the next debate.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s war in Gaza has become a major focus of the 2024 Republican presidential race. Lisa Lerer reports on how that’s likely to play out at the next debate.

headline: Oleg Protopopov, Who Skated With His Wife to Olympic Gold, Dies at 91
abstract: Twice Soviet champions at the Games, he and Ludmila Belousova revolutionized pairs figure skating in the 1960s with a balletic style before defecting to the West.
lead_paragraph: Oleg Protopopov, who, with his wife, Ludmila Belousova, revolutionized pairs figure skating in the 1960s with a balletic style, and who twice won Olympic gold medals with her for the Soviet Union before defecting to the West, died on Oct. 31 in Interlaken, Switzerland. He was 91.

headline: How Has Biden Done on His 2020 Campaign Promises?
abstract: President Biden campaigned on stopping construction of the border wall, allowing Medicare to negotiate drug prices and ending the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden campaigns for re-election, Democrats have heralded a series of accomplishments under his tenure. At times, Mr. Biden has called attention to promises by his predecessor, Donald J. Trump, that fell short.

headline: Can’t Make the Concert? Livestreamers Are Coming to the Rescue.
abstract: As fans struggle to buy increasingly hard-to-get tickets (at escalating costs), livestreamers packing cellphones and batteries are offering another way to see the show.
lead_paragraph: Live music tentatively returned in 2021 after Covid shutdowns. More artists got back on the road in 2022, yet still hit pandemic-related snags. But 2023 has been a blockbuster for the live-music business: Taylor Swift and Beyoncé circled the globe with headline-grabbing extravaganzas, and they weren’t the only story. Bruce Springsteen, Metallica, Drake, Travis Scott, Ed Sheeran, Morgan Wallen, Maluma and Madonna filled arenas and stadiums.

headline: Tuesday Was Great for Democrats. It Doesn’t Change the Outlook for 2024.
abstract: A pattern continued with success in low-turnout elections, which favors highly engaged voters. Presidential years tend to be different.
lead_paragraph: Almost every Tuesday election since the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has brought good news for Democrats.

headline: Mass Grave Recalls the Ugly Past of a City Where ‘Life Is Sweeter’
abstract: The Houston suburb Sugar Land got its name from a business reliant on the forced labor of convicts. But efforts to memorialize those people have stalled.
lead_paragraph: In Sugar Land, Texas, there’s a refrain you may hear from residents — an unofficial city motto of sorts: Life is sweeter here.

headline: Sunak Clashes With Police Chief Over Planned Pro-Palestinian March
abstract: A demonstration in London that will coincide with remembrance events has divided the prime minister and the country’s most senior police officer.
lead_paragraph: A pro-Palestinian demonstration planned for Saturday in London has become embroiled in a tense political debate that has put Prime Minister Rishi Sunak at odds with Britain’s most senior police official over whether the event should take place at all.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): ‘Priscilla’ and ‘The Golden Bachelor’ Plumb Heartbreak
abstract: A conversation about Sofia Coppola’s impressionistic take on Elvis and Priscilla Presley’s relationship, plus: the surprising depth of a reality TV spinoff.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Michigan Democrats Win 2 Mayoral Races but Lose Full Command of State Government
abstract: The shift is likely to only be temporary, but control of Michigan’s House will be evenly divided after two members resign to become suburban mayors.
lead_paragraph: Ten months ago, Michigan Democrats took full control of state government for the first time in 40 years.

headline: Congressional Split on Immigration Hangs Over Year-End Spending Fights
abstract: Republicans and Democrats, including President Biden, appear to agree that any war spending package must include immigration changes, but the parties are divided over how far such a deal should go.
lead_paragraph: There is growing consensus on Capitol Hill and at the White House that any deal to fund foreign wars, and possibly the entire government, must include significant new measures to address the U.S.-Mexico border, but Republicans and Democrats are deeply split over what changes to make.

headline: Reading List: Scams and Scammers
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried’s conviction reminds us of the real talent behind the schemes — knowing what people yearn for.
lead_paragraph: This week, following the guilty verdict in the Sam Bankman-Fried trial, I’ve had scammers on my mind.

headline: F.D.A. Approves New Obesity Drug That Will Compete With Wegovy
abstract: Zepbound, which is already sold by Eli Lilly as the diabetes treatment Mounjaro, was shown to reduce patients’ weight by as much as one-fifth in drug trials.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved an obesity drug from the company Eli Lilly that will be a direct competitor to the wildly popular Wegovy.

headline: What to Know About Zepbound, the New Weight Loss Drug
abstract: The obesity medication contains tirzepatide, the same active ingredient in the diabetes drug Mounjaro.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday to approve the weight loss drug tirzepatide adds a potent new tool to the fast-growing arsenal of obesity drugs.

headline: Paris’s Newest Hotels Embrace Color and Quirk
abstract: From the Marais to the Champs-Élysées, the French capital is suddenly full of small, exuberantly designed places to stay.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, few Parisian hotels dared to distract from the classic aesthetics of the city itself. The décor of its gilded palace hotels, single-minded embassies of French heritage, was, largely, fussy and excessively impersonal, as if a misplaced streak of color could break the city’s spell. Today the capital is finally overcoming its self-seriousness, thanks in part to its vibrant post-Brexit ascendancy in the contemporary arts and culture scenes. Many of its new hotels seek to delight rather than simply impress, and often conjure other worlds, as in the Marais’s Maison Proust, a candlelit Belle Époque fantasy half-hidden behind tasseled indigo velvet curtains, or the nearby Le Grand Mazarin, fashioned by the London-based Swedish designer Martin Brudnizki from contrasting styles and eras, all in a swirl of candy colors. “It took longer than New York and London,” says the Italian architect and designer Fabrizio Casiraghi, “but Paris is at last discovering the kind of small hotel that has something to say.”

headline: Thousands Flee Northern Gaza as Israel’s Ground Invasion Continues
abstract: Palestinians walked, drove and rode on donkey carts as they fled Gaza City and other parts of the northern Gaza Strip for the south.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians walked, drove and rode on donkey carts as they fled Gaza City and other parts of the northern Gaza Strip for the south.

headline: As Israel Pushes Deeper Into Northern Gaza, Thousands Trek South
abstract: The United Nations estimates that 15,000 people used the only route out of the northern part of the enclave on Tuesday, three times the number that passed the day before.
lead_paragraph: Pocked with airstrike craters and lined by Israeli tanks and the shells of what used to be buildings, Salah al-Din Road is the only way to leave the northern part of Gaza for the south, where Israel has told civilians to go “for their own safety.”

headline: ‘The Buccaneers’ Arrives With More Arrivistes
abstract: This Apple TV+ drama joins HBO’s “The Gilded Age,” back for its second season, in portraying the late-19th-century collision of old money and new.
lead_paragraph: A newly moneyed woman in Gilded Age New York is desperate to gain the acceptance of the aristocracy. So she schemes to get the ultimate symbol of old money approval: a box at the exclusive Academy of Music. When she is denied, she helps spearhead the construction of a new see-and-be-seen cultural playground, the Metropolitan Opera House. Take that, aristocracy.

headline: ‘You Were My First Boyfriend’ Review: Diary of a Former Teen
abstract: In this documentary, Cecilia Aldarondo relives her high school trauma by directing cinematic re-enactments of her adolescent years.
lead_paragraph: Cecilia Aldarondo takes the process of reliving adolescent trauma to a literal degree in “You Were My First Boyfriend,” her feature that falls somewhere between documentary and diaristic re-enactment. Spurred by her 20-year high school reunion in Winter Park, Fla., Aldarondo pulls back layers of memories and old home-movie footage to investigate the significant relationships of her formative years: her first intense crush, her bullies, and her childhood best friend and fellow outsider, Caroline.

headline: The ’23 Elections and the Abortion Effect
abstract: Readers discuss an Ohio ballot measure and Andy Beshear’s re-election as Kentucky’s governor. Also: Jews in America; conversion therapy; no swearing in class.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Justice Dept. Watchdog Describes Unsanitary Conditions at Florida Prison
abstract: Moldy bread, rodent droppings and leaky roofs: An inspector general offered a vivid and at times nauseating glimpse of a vast, dysfunctional system.
lead_paragraph: When inspectors with the Justice Department’s internal watchdog appeared unannounced at a federal women’s prison in Tallahassee, Fla., in May, they expected to find serious problems endemic to other crumbling, understaffed facilities run by the Bureau of Prisons.

headline: Don’t Bedazzle Your Steering Wheel, U.S. Warns
abstract: Decorated steering wheels could cause injuries in a crash, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said.
lead_paragraph: Adding decorations to a steering wheel can liven up a dull commute, and the internet now offers endless possibilities. Fuzzy steering wheel covers, stickers that look like diamonds or embroidered flowers, and even steering wheel trays with room for electronics and food are all easy to find online.

headline: Tales That Crackle With Vitality, With or Without a Puppeteer
abstract: La MaMa Puppet Festival and other stage works this fall highlight the power of storytelling through puppetry.
lead_paragraph: In a crisp white gallery space on Great Jones Street, in Manhattan’s East Village, a large wooden box contains a meticulous mise-en-scène: a midcentury roadside motel room constructed at puppet scale, which means it’s half of human scale. Standing on a step built into the outside of the box, spectators can gaze down into the installation, a time-capsule environment called “Motel,” by the master puppet artist Dan Hurlin.

headline: A Gaza ‘Cease-Fire’ or a ‘Pause’? Even World Leaders Are Confused.
abstract: Experts say neither term is defined under international law.
lead_paragraph: Pause, or cease-fire?

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Paatal Lok’ and More
abstract: I am a reporter for The Times covering India and South Asia. Here are five things I've been reading, watching and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I am a reporter for The Times covering India and South Asia. Here are five things I've been reading, watching and listening to.

headline: Israel and Hamas Nearly Struck a Deal to Free Up to 50 Hostages
abstract: Indirect talks mediated by Qatar snagged after Israel’s ground invasion of Gaza on Oct. 27. They have resumed, but hopes for a quick release have faded.
lead_paragraph: Days before Israel launched its ground invasion of Gaza, it was closing in on a deal for Hamas to release up to 50 hostages in exchange for pausing the bombardment unleashed in response to the militants’ Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, according to Arab and Western officials with knowledge of the talks.

headline: A Hairy Truth About Your Sense of Touch
abstract: Researchers showed that cells in your hair follicles release important chemical messengers in response to gentle touches to your skin.
lead_paragraph: When someone brushes a hand across your skin, it’s like a breeze blowing through a forest of countless small hairs. Nerves that surround your hair follicles detect that contact, and very far away in your brain, other cells fire. Some of the neurons responding to light contact might make you shiver and give you goose bumps. Some might tell you to move away. Or they might tell you to move closer.

headline: The Godfather of Climate Science Turns Up the Heat
abstract: James Hansen says we must realize that we’ve underestimated how much the planet is warming.
lead_paragraph: It is, James Hansen says, worse than you think.

headline: Lice Genes Offer Clues to Ancient Human History
abstract: The jumpy parasites have followed our ancestors around for at least 25 million years, adapting along with us through major upheavals.
lead_paragraph: Along our evolutionary journey from monkey-like primates to bipedal apes to big-brained humans, we have had the company of an extraordinarily loyal companion: Pediculus humanus, otherwise known as the human louse.

headline: Philip Meyer, Reporter Who Pioneered Data-Driven Journalism, Dies at 93
abstract: First as a correspondent and later as a professor, he pushed his industry to adopt more rigorous, quantitative methods.
lead_paragraph: Philip Meyer, a former reporter who pioneered new ways to incorporate data, quantitative methods and computers into investigative journalism, died on Saturday at his home in Carrboro, N.C., a suburb of Chapel Hill. He was 93.

headline: Xi Jinping to Address U.S. Business Leaders Amid Rising Skepticism of China Ties
abstract: Corporate executives will pay $2,000 a head to dine with China’s leader in San Francisco next week, in one of a series of engagements aimed at stabilizing the U.S.-China relationship.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese leader Xi Jinping, who is set to meet with President Biden in San Francisco next week, is expected to speak to top American business executives at a dinner following that bilateral meeting.

headline: ‘Sleep No More’ to Close in January
abstract: The Off Broadway production opened at the McKittrick Hotel in 2011, and helped to alter and expand the landscape of immersive theater.
lead_paragraph: After more than a decade of performances, “Sleep No More” — the immersive, Hitchcockian riff on Shakespeare’s “Macbeth” — will close the doors of its cargo elevator for good when it plays its final performance on Jan. 28.

headline: Israel Raises Alarms by Suggesting ‘Indefinite’ Role in Gaza
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken quickly pushed back, but what exactly comes next is far from clear.
lead_paragraph: By saying that Israel will maintain security control over Gaza  “for an indefinite period,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu set off alarm bells in Washington and questions at home.

headline: Danica Roem Will Become the First Transgender State Senator in the South
abstract: A Democrat in her third term in the Virginia House of Delegates and a former journalist, she won a competitive race in the northern part of the state in Tuesday’s election.
lead_paragraph: Danica Roem, a three-term Virginia lawmaker and a former journalist, on Tuesday became the first openly transgender person to be elected to a State Senate seat in the South, winning a competitive race that helped Democrats take control of the Virginia legislature.

headline: Why Voters Are So Down on the Biden Economy
abstract: Economists and voters often talk past each other. That doesn’t make voters wrong.
lead_paragraph: Economists, meet Sara. She is in her early 50s, white, an office manager who lives in South Carolina and a Republican who is unenthusiastic about Donald Trump. When she thinks about the direction of the country right now, what she’s most worried about is the economy. And whom does she blame for the economy?

headline: In Bridgeport, the Mayoral Election Isn’t Over Until It’s Over
abstract: The mayor was re-elected, but another vote may take place after a judge voided the Democratic primary results because of credible allegations of ballot fraud.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Joe Ganim of Bridgeport, Conn., was the top vote-getter in his bid for re-election on Tuesday, beating his closest opponent by 175 votes. Ordinarily that would guarantee him another term in office.

headline: Democrats, No Longer Squeamish on Abortion, Lean Into Searing Personal Ads
abstract: Graphic details and shock value used to characterize Republican political ads on abortion. But Democrats ran explicit, visceral ads ahead of Tuesday’s elections, and it paid off.
lead_paragraph: In the days before Tuesday’s election, voters across Ohio heard a stark warning in an ad that blanketed the airwaves. “She could be your neighbor, or niece, your sister or daughter,” the ad said, “But if she is raped and gets pregnant, a law in Ohio would force her to have the child.”

headline: Enhanced transcript for an excerpt from Kinetic Light’s “DESCENT” (2018)
abstract: This transcript is for an edited excerpt of Kinetic Light’s “DESCENT”, portraying two short scenes from near the end of the first act.
lead_paragraph: This transcript is for an edited excerpt of Kinetic Light’s “DESCENT”, portraying two short scenes from near the end of the first act.

headline: What We Learned From Barbra Streisand’s Memoir
abstract: “My Name Is Barbra,” her long-awaited (and rather enormous) autobiography, doesn’t have an index. But here are the best bits.
lead_paragraph: “Looking back, it was much more fun to dream of being famous than to actually be famous,” Barbra Streisand writes near the end of “My Name Is Barbra,” her new memoir. “I didn’t like all the ridiculous stories they made up, or the envy my success provoked.” Here, culled from the book’s 970 pages, is her version of a very examined life, replete with triumphs and slights, love affairs and famous friends, anxiety and antiques and (always) food.

headline: House Republicans Subpoena Biden’s Son and Brother in Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: Representative James Comer, the chairman of the Oversight Committee, demanded testimony from James Biden and Hunter Biden as he hunts for evidence of bribery and corruption by the president.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Wednesday issued subpoenas demanding testimony from Hunter and James Biden, the president’s son and brother, as they hunt for evidence to try to build an impeachment case against him.

headline: Musician Sues Former Grammys Head, Accusing Him of Rape
abstract: The woman, who is not named in the lawsuit, said that she was drugged by Neil Portnow, and that the Recording Academy was negligent in investigating her complaint.
lead_paragraph: The former head of the Grammy Awards was sued on Wednesday by a woman who said he drugged and raped her in a New York hotel room in 2018.

headline: Mayor Adams Denies Wrongdoing and Retains Lawyer After Federal Raid
abstract: In his first open media availability since agents raided his chief fund-raiser’s home, Eric Adams insisted he often reminds his team, “We’ve got to follow the law.”
lead_paragraph: Six days after F.B.I. agents searched the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s chief campaign fund-raiser, the mayor used his first open question-and-answer session with reporters since the raid to insist that he had done nothing wrong.

headline: In School Board Elections, Parental Rights Movement Is Dealt Setbacks
abstract: Culture battles on gender and race did not seem to move many voters.
lead_paragraph: Conservative activists for parental rights in education were dealt several high-profile losses in state and school board elections on Tuesday.

headline: The Traffic Jam in Low Earth Orbit
abstract: Elon Musk's satellites. Stuffed animals. Tomatoes? You wouldn't believe what's circling Earth these days.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk's satellites. Stuffed animals. Tomatoes? You wouldn't believe what's circling Earth these days.

headline: A Dedicated Taylor Swift Reporter Faces Swift Criticism
abstract: Bryan West landed a much-coveted job. Then came the internet.
lead_paragraph: Everything has changed for Bryan West.

headline: Thursday Briefing: What’s Next in the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: Plus, a cook’s tour of the Tokyo food scene.
lead_paragraph: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war ends, the strongest signal yet from the Biden administration about what it would like to see at the end of Israel’s fight against Hamas. But what Israel will do in Gaza is largely unclear.

headline: Colorado Couple Arrested After Funeral Home ‘Improperly Stored’ 190 Bodies
abstract: The Return to Nature Funeral Home in Colorado Springs and Penrose, Colo., offered so-called green burial services. Investigators had been drawn by a foul odor.
lead_paragraph: A husband and wife who owned a Colorado funeral home were arrested in Oklahoma on Wednesday in connection to the improper handling of at least 190 bodies that had been left in their care, the authorities said.

headline: Disney Adds 5 Million Streaming Subscribers
abstract: The company is in the midst of a major transformation, exploring options for traditional businesses like ESPN.
lead_paragraph: As Robert A. Iger approaches the first anniversary of his return as chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, he delivered a strong earnings report on Wednesday, telling investors that the company added roughly five million subscribers to its streaming services in the last three months.

headline: Love Can Win Trump the Nomination. It Will Take Hate to Win Back the White House.
abstract: His base can get him through the primaries. Then what?
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I was talking to a local pastor here in Tennessee, and he started the conversation by asking a question I hear all the time: “Can anybody beat Trump?” He was desperate for someone else, anyone else, to claim the Republican nomination. He ticked through the names — DeSantis, Haley, Scott, Pence (he was still in the race then) — and they were all better. Why can’t they gain traction? “It’s not a binary choice anymore,” he said. “It’s not Trump or Biden.”

headline: Lawmakers Renew Calls to Ban TikTok After Accusations of Anti-Israel Content
abstract: The criticism has put the popular video app on its heels at a precarious time.
lead_paragraph: TikTok is back in the cross hairs of Washington, with Republican lawmakers again calling to ban the popular short-form video app amid accusations that it is amplifying pro-Palestinian and anti-Israel videos through its powerful algorithmic feed.

headline: F.B.I. Searching New Jersey for Man Accused in Capitol Riot
abstract: Officers were seen searching a home and shed in a suburban community for the Jan. 6 suspect, who fled when agents tried to arrest him at home.
lead_paragraph: A manhunt was underway on Wednesday as the F.B.I. and several local police departments searched central New Jersey for a man wanted in connection with the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol.

headline: Tate Reeves Is Not Hugely Popular. Voters in Mississippi Stuck With Him Anyway.
abstract: Even with a perceived likability problem and a Democratic opponent who out-raised him, Mr. Reeves won re-election as governor by a comfortable margin.
lead_paragraph: National Democratic groups routed millions of dollars into Mississippi, sensing that Tate Reeves, the Republican governor, might be vulnerable. Inside the state, some Republicans quietly fretted. Mr. Reeves’s likability had been a persistent concern, and there were signs that enthusiasm among conservatives had been flagging.

headline: ‘Mean Girls’ Adaptation Trailer Inspires Mixed Reactions
abstract: Ahead of the release of the film adaptation of the “Mean Girls” musical, some fans said the new spin on the classic 2004 movie had a lot to live up to. Others said they felt old.
lead_paragraph: Paramount Pictures on Wednesday released a trailer for the film adaptation of the Broadway musical “Mean Girls,” which was itself an adaptation of the beloved 2004 movie about a girl trying to fit in with the popular crowd at her high school. The new film is due to hit theaters on Jan. 12.

headline: Which Candidates Got the Most Speaking Time in the Third Republican Debate
abstract: See who got the most speaking time and which subjects the candidates discussed most.
lead_paragraph: See who got the most speaking time and which subjects the candidates discussed most.

headline: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Deadly Strike on Civilian Ship at Black Sea Port
abstract: The episode, which killed one and injured four others, comes amid a recent uptick in military activity and attacks in the Black Sea, a hot spot in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said on Wednesday that a Russian missile had struck a civilian ship while it was moored in a port in the Black Sea region of Odesa, killing a port pilot on board and injuring three crew members and a port worker.

headline: Domenico Spano Dies at 79; Clothier of Stars Found Fame of His Own
abstract: Born in Italy, he dressed billionaires and film stars while turning heads for his own outfits in his adopted city, New York.
lead_paragraph: Domenico Spano, a New York custom clothier who outfitted captains of industry and Hollywood stars, and whose own dandyish style made him a highly recognizable peacock on the streets of the city as well as in newspaper fashion pages, died on Oct. 23 in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: White House Says It Does Not Support a Cease-Fire at This Time
abstract: John F. Kirby, the White House national security spokesman, said that a cease-fire would give Hamas a “propaganda win,” legitimizing its Oct. 7 attack on Israel.
lead_paragraph: John F. Kirby, the White House national security spokesman, said that a cease-fire would give Hamas a “propaganda win,” legitimizing its Oct. 7 attack on Israel.

headline: Tens of Thousands Flee Northern Gaza Strip, as Israel’s Invasion Advances
abstract: The United Nations estimated that 15,000 civilians walked out of northern Gaza on Tuesday, three times as many as the day before, while Israeli troops battled Hamas in Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of desperate civilians, some waving white flags, have fled the northern Gaza Strip this week, marching along a road pocked with airstrike craters and lined with ruined buildings, as Israeli officials reported that their troops had pushed into the heart of the densely populated Hamas stronghold of Gaza City.

headline: Minnesota Justices Rebuff Attempt to Bar Trump From Ballot Under 14th Amendment
abstract: In rejecting a petition arguing that former President Donald J. Trump was ineligible, the Minnesota Supreme Court did not rule on the merits and said the claims could be filed again later.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday dismissed a petition seeking to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump from holding office again under the 14th Amendment.

headline: A Good Night for Democrats. A Bad Poll for Biden.
abstract: Which will matter more in 2024?
lead_paragraph: The election results on Tuesday made it clear that voters support Democratic policies and state politicians — but new polling shows they don’t love the president.

headline: A Package of Bold Laws Puts Michigan on a Fast Track to Renewable Energy
abstract: Included in the new legislation is a requirement that the state generate all of its electricity from wind, solar and other carbon-free sources by 2040.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Senate gave final approval on Wednesday to a bundle of clean energy bills, transforming a state at the center of industrial America into a leader in the fight against climate change.

headline: Ending 40-Year Hiatus, G.O.P. Wins a City Council Seat in the Bronx
abstract: Although Democrats won contentious races all across New York, losses in the Bronx and throughout Long Island gave Republicans hope.
lead_paragraph: The last time voters in the Bronx were represented by a Republican on the City Council, Mayor Ed Koch was still asking voters “How’m I doin’,” Ronald Reagan was president and hip-hop music was mostly a local phenomenon.

headline: Lesson Plan | ‘An American Puzzle: Fitting Race in a Box’
abstract: Census categories for race and ethnicity have changed over the last 230 years. What might that suggest about the United States’ past and future?
lead_paragraph: Since 1790, the U.S. government has taken a census every decade of all the country’s residents. In each one, the government has asked about race, but the questions and language it has used have changed over time.

headline: Democrats Won Big in Last Night’s Elections
abstract: Also, the F.D.A. approved a new obesity drug. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Abortion rights and marijuana legalization prevailed in Ohio. Democrats held the governor’s mansion in Kentucky, took full control of the General Assembly in Virginia and won a Supreme Court election in Pennsylvania. They were even competitive in Mississippi.

headline: Trump Asks Appeals Court to Throw Out Election Case Gag Order
abstract: The former president’s lawyers claimed he was being muzzled in the midst of a campaign, but their filing exaggerated the constraints put on him by the order.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked an appeals court in Washington on Wednesday to throw out the gag order imposed on him in the federal case in which he stands accused of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, calling it an effort to “muzzle” a presidential candidate “at the height of his re-election campaign.”

headline: U.S. Strikes Iran-Linked Facility in Syria in Round of Retaliation
abstract: Drone and rocket attacks on U.S. forces have continued in recent weeks, prompting a second round of retaliatory airstrikes in eastern Syria.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in nearly two weeks, the United States carried out airstrikes against a facility used by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and its proxies in eastern Syria early Thursday, ratcheting up retaliation for a steady stream of rocket and drone attacks against American forces in Iraq and Syria.

headline: 8 Killed as Human Smuggling Suspect Crashes Into S.U.V., Authorities Say
abstract: The driver, who had five passengers in the vehicle, collided head-on with an S.U.V. carrying two people while trying to elude law enforcement, the Texas Department of Public Safety said.
lead_paragraph: Eight people were killed in southwest Texas on Wednesday morning when a driver suspected of human smuggling tried to elude law enforcement officers and slammed head-on into an S.U.V., the Texas Department of Public Safety said.

headline: Who Are the Moderators for Wednesday’s Republican Debate?
abstract: Hugh Hewitt, Lester Holt and Kristen Welker will ask questions of the candidates, a familiar role for each of them.
lead_paragraph: Three experienced moderators will lead Wednesday’s meeting in Miami of the remaining Republican presidential candidates, although former President Donald J. Trump will again be absent.

headline: The White House condemns Rashida Tlaib’s embrace of the phrase ‘river to the sea.’
abstract: The term is widely regarded as a rallying cry for the eradication of Israel, but the congresswoman says it was used as “an aspirational call” for freedom and peace.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Wednesday condemned Representative Rashida Tlaib for embracing a phrase used by some pro-Palestinian groups, a day after the House censured her for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Nuclear Energy Project in Idaho Is Canceled
abstract: The project that NuScale Power and Western energy companies had developed struggled to attract enough utility customers.
lead_paragraph: A developer of small nuclear reactors announced on Wednesday that it was canceling a project that had been widely expected to usher in a new wave of power plants.

headline: U.S. Charges 10 in Gambino Scheme to Control Carting and Demolition
abstract: The defendants have organized crime ties and used violence, threats and fraud to infiltrate the two industries in New York, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: On the Friday before Labor Day, Joseph Lanni and Vincent Minsquero stopped into Roxy’s Bar and Grille in Toms River, N.J. At around 8:15 p.m., federal prosecutors say, they began to argue with another patron. Restaurant employees asked them to leave, and the men became belligerent as they were escorted out.

headline: Blinken Lays Out Possible Endgame in Gaza Under Palestinian Authority
abstract: The secretary of state said Gaza should be overseen by the Palestinian Authority, which has a tenuous hold on power in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Wednesday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war is over, offering a strong signal about what the United States sees as its preferred endgame in the fight between Israel and Hamas.

headline: Elizabeth Moynihan, Engine of the Senator’s Success, Dies at 94
abstract: She not only had an outsize role in New York and Washington politics as the wife of Daniel Patrick Moynihan; she also made a significant archaeological discovery in India.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Moynihan, who was a vital political partner to her husband, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, during his four terms as a U.S. senator from New York; played a consequential role in Washington herself; and, as an architectural historian, made a signal discovery in India, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: Meet the Champions of Nuance and Empathy We Need
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians who’ve lost family members to the conflict find strength in grieving together — and offer hope.
lead_paragraph: My columns from Israel and the West Bank over the past few weeks have been depressing, reflecting my fear that we’re on a bloody, downward spiral that will make everything worse. So let me share what I saw as an ember of hope.

headline: The Joe Biden Re-election Dilemma
abstract: The risk of a loss for the president is real, and no amount of political ego can disguise that.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden should be far and away the favorite to win re-election in 2024.

headline: Music Executive L.A. Reid Is Accused of Sexual Assault in Lawsuit
abstract: The lawsuit, filed by Drew Dixon in federal court in Manhattan under the Adult Survivors Act, says that Mr. Reid’s misconduct cut short her career in music.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy-winning music executive Antonio Reid, who is known as L.A. and rose in the industry working with artists including Usher and TLC, has been accused of sexual assault and harassment in a lawsuit by Drew Dixon, who worked for Mr. Reid at Arista Records.

headline: Houthi Rebels Shot Down a U.S. Drone Off Yemen’s Coast, Pentagon Says
abstract: The downing of a Reaper drone, the mainstay of the American military’s aerial surveillance fleet, was the latest escalation of violence between the U.S. and Iran-backed groups in Yemen, Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. military surveillance drone was shot down off the coast of Yemen on Wednesday by Iran-backed Houthi rebels, the Pentagon said.

headline: Striking Actors and Hollywood Studios Agree to a Deal
abstract: The agreement all but ends one of the longest labor crises in the history of the entertainment industry. Union members still have to approve the deal.
lead_paragraph: One of the longest labor crises in Hollywood history is finally coming to an end.

headline: Picasso Sells for $139.4 Million, Despite a Sagging Art Market
abstract: The blue-chip collection of Emily Fisher Landau sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night for a total of $406.4 million.
lead_paragraph: A brilliant blue painting by Pablo Picasso of his young mistress was crowned the prized lot of the November auction season so far after it sold at Sotheby’s in New York for $139.4 million, with buyer’s fees, on Wednesday.

headline: F.B.I. to Move Headquarters to Maryland
abstract: The plan could still face internal hurdles and zoning or funding issues, but if it goes through it would end one of the most hotly contested bureaucratic decisions of the past decade.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has chosen a vacant lot in Greenbelt, Md., for the new headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, despite the lingering concerns of some senior bureau officials, four people familiar with the situation said late Wednesday.

headline: ‘Watch Night’ Review: For Spacious Skies, for Rancorous Waves of Hate
abstract: Conceived in part by Bill T. Jones, this multigenre work at the Perelman Performing Arts Center is interested in homegrown prejudice, but lacks dramatic focus.
lead_paragraph: Entering the Perelman Performing Arts Center’s auditorium, you quickly notice detritus that looks as if it has been blown in from a bewildering protest: A few small American flags here, color copies of a Greetings From Hollywood postcard there, wrinkled fliers everywhere. Some of them are imprinted with the text of the Second Amendment, others a rallying cry: “We fight fascists.” Among the most eye-catching is an ad for N.R.A. memberships, with its promise of “$5,000 Accidental Death and Dismemberment insurance.”

headline: Ramaswamy Compares Republican Rivals to Dick Cheney ‘in Heels’
abstract: One of the first clashes at the Republican debate in Miami was about footwear.
lead_paragraph: Forget tax-cut pledges and RINO accusations. Heels, of all things, are the new political cudgel in Republican politics.

headline: Man Charged With Firing Gun in Subway Station to Stop a Mugging
abstract: John Rote fired two shots in an effort to stop a homeless man from robbing a woman at a Manhattan station, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Queens man who fired two shots in a Manhattan subway station in an effort to stop a homeless man from robbing a woman was charged on Wednesday with weapons counts and other crimes, officials said.

headline: With the Strikes Over, the Mood in Hollywood Is Decidedly Mixed
abstract: Celebratory feelings are competing with resentment over the work stoppage and worries about the business era that is coming.
lead_paragraph: It should be a rapturous time in Hollywood.

headline: The Republican candidates rushed to line up behind Israel.
abstract: The five candidates at the third debate rejected calls for Israel to rein in its retaliation in Gaza after Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack.
lead_paragraph: The five Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday’s debate stage gave staunch support to Israel’s invasion of Gaza, rejecting pleas to rein in the conflict and calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to destroy Hamas, the Islamic militant group that killed 1,400 civilians and Israeli soldiers in a surprise attack last month.

headline: ‘You’re Just Scum’: Haley and Ramaswamy Tussle Onstage
abstract: An exchange over TikTok turned into a heated confrontation that ended with Nikki Haley calling Vivek Ramaswamy “scum.”
lead_paragraph: It quickly got personal. Then it turned ugly.

headline: Seat in Parliament
abstract: Simeon Seigel messes with our sense of order.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: China’s Prices Fall Again, Renewing Fears of Deflation
abstract: Consumer prices declined for the second time in four months, while prices charged by factories and other large producers have now been tumbling for over a year.
lead_paragraph: Prices are falling again in China after a two-month reprieve, with households and businesses wary of spending even as state-controlled banks pump money into the construction of more factories.

headline: Candidates Accuse Student Protesters of ‘Siding With Hamas’
abstract: Asked how they would address antisemitism, Republicans promised punishments for college activists. Only Vivek Ramaswamy dissented, describing pro-Palestinian protests as a free-speech issue.
lead_paragraph: The candidates on the Republican debate stage on Wednesday were largely united in declaring their full-throated support for the Israeli government in its war with Hamas. But on how to grapple with responses to the conflict within the United States, they differed — a little bit.

headline: 3 Charged With Running Prostitution Service Used by Politicians and Others
abstract: The Justice Department did not name the clients of what it called the “high-end brothel network,” who were also said to include military officers, executives and government contractors.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced charges on Wednesday against three people accused of running a “high-end brothel network” in the Washington and Boston suburbs and unveiled an investigation into potentially hundreds of high-profile clients who had paid for sexual services.

headline: Ramaswamy Seemed to Call Zelensky a Nazi. His Campaign Says That’s Not What He Meant.
abstract: A spokeswoman for Mr. Ramaswamy acknowledged that, without context, his remark could be easily misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy drew shock and criticism online on Wednesday when he appeared to accuse the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, who is Jewish, of being a Nazi — but Mr. Ramaswamy’s campaign insisted that wasn’t what he meant.

headline: Haley Calls Ramaswamy ‘Scum’ in Heated Exchange
abstract: During a confrontation over TikTok, Nikki Haley snapped at Vivek Ramaswamy after he scolded Ms. Haley over her daughter’s use of the app.
lead_paragraph: During a confrontation over TikTok, Nikki Haley snapped at Vivek Ramaswamy after he scolded Ms. Haley over her daughter’s use of the app.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Garment Workers Reject Wage Hike in Bangladesh
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Garment workers should remember that if they damage factories, they may have to return to their villages and live without employment.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the singer Desire Marea misidentified the year of the Battle of Isandlwana. It occurred in 1879, not 1897.

headline: When a Dancer’s Moves Include a Wheelchair
abstract: How Chelsie Hill, the founder of the Rollettes dance team in Los Angeles, created a sisterhood for women and girls with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

headline: Russia Steps Up Efforts to Lure Wagner Veterans Back Into Ukraine War
abstract: A force led by President Vladimir Putin’s former bodyguard is trying to recruit veterans of the paramilitary force, which mutinied against Russian military leaders and saw its leader killed in a plane crash.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s armed forces are stepping up their efforts to recruit veterans of the Wagner paramilitary group, according to former fighters and military bloggers, as the Kremlin tries to avoid another round of mobilization and salvage some of the force’s fighting potential in the wake of its leader’s mutiny and death.

headline: I Have Never Been to This Israel Before
abstract: After traveling across Israel and the West Bank, I now understand why so much has changed.
lead_paragraph: People warned me before I came to Tel Aviv a few days ago that the Israel of Oct. 7 is an Israel that I’ve never been to before. They were right. It is a place in which Israelis have never lived before, a nation that Israeli generals have never had to protect before, an ally that America has never had to defend before — certainly not with the urgency and resolve that would lead a U.S. president to fly over and buck up the whole nation.

headline: Ukraine. Israel. Can America Support Two Wars and Still Handle China?
abstract: To U.S. allies in Asia, the sudden focus on Gaza risks progress on America’s long-delayed pivot to the Indo-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: America’s long-promised pivot to Asia was finally gathering momentum — new security deals with the Philippines and India, expanded military exercises, and plans with allies to stay ahead of Chinese technology.

headline: Haley Compares Antisemitism on College Campuses to Racism
abstract: The former South Carolina governor said antisemitism is “just as awful” as racism.
lead_paragraph: The former South Carolina governor said antisemitism is “just as awful” as racism.

headline: 6 Takeaways From the Republican Debate
abstract: Nikki Haley staked out a clear, hawkish vision. Ron DeSantis avoided risks. And the night’s glaring absentee, Donald Trump, again emerged untouched.
lead_paragraph: It was the undercard that underwhelmed.

headline: Tim Scott’s Debate Night Date Night
abstract: A long-running mystery of Mr. Scott’s campaign was solved at the G.O.P. debate, and it had nothing to do with politics.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott’s most viral debate moment didn’t actually happen during the debate. It came shortly afterward.

headline: Who Won the Third Republican Debate?
abstract: Nikki Haley stood out, absorbing attacks and doling out many of her own. But political observers wondered how any of the candidates onstage cut into former President Donald J. Trump’s dominance.
lead_paragraph: The third Republican presidential debate this year, held on Wednesday in Miami, was packed with heated exchanges over abortion policy, immigration and China as the candidates tried to shine as the front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump, once again declined to join them onstage.

headline: Nikki Haley Tells Israel to ‘Finish’ Hamas
abstract: Ms. Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said that there would be no Hamas without Iran.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said that there would be no Hamas without Iran.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war ends, the strongest signal yet of the Biden administration’s hopes for the future of the conflict. But what Israel will do in Gaza is largely unclear.

headline: Scott Says He Will Stand ‘Shoulder to Shoulder’ With Israel
abstract: Tim Scott said “diplomacy only“ in the Israel-Hamas war was “a weak strategy.“
lead_paragraph: Tim Scott said “diplomacy only“ in the Israel-Hamas war was “a weak strategy.“

headline: 35 Years After Its Debut, Tracy Chapman’s ‘Fast Car’ Wins a Song of the Year Award
abstract: She is the first Black songwriter to receive the honor from the Country Music Awards. Her 1988 hit reached a new generation of fans as a cover by Luke Combs.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Chapman won song of the year at the Country Music Awards on Wednesday for “Fast Car,” a folk ballad that topped the country charts more than three decades after it was first released thanks to a cover by the singer Luke Combs.

headline: Ron DeSantis: ‘I’m Sick of Republicans Losing’
abstract: The Florida governor criticized Donald Trump’s absence from the debate stage.
lead_paragraph: The Florida governor criticized Donald Trump’s absence from the debate stage.

headline: Word of the Day: ad nauseam
abstract: This term has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The term ad nauseam has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 27 in “Their Reputations Precede Them. And That’s the Problem” by Andrew Keh:

headline: Italy Misses a #MeToo Moment in Meloni’s Breakup
abstract: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni dumped her partner after leaks about come-ons to colleagues. But workplace harassment is still being taken for granted.
lead_paragraph: Since Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s first female prime minister, announced over social media last month that she was dumping her longtime boyfriend, Italians have hardly stopped talking about it.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Pans the Republican Debate
abstract: Kimmel called the five candidates in the latest G.O.P. face-off “a Who’s Who of who has no chance to beat Donald Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Map of New York, With Details Up for Debate
abstract: A project from The Upshot captures residents’ disagreements over neighborhood names and borders.
lead_paragraph: In New York, the answer to the seemingly simple question “Where do you live?” can be contentious.

headline: In N.Y.P.D.’s Harsh Tactics Under Adams, Critics See a Broken Promise
abstract: As a candidate, Eric Adams promised a new kind of policing. But some fear that increased stops and aggressive tactics will erode trust.
lead_paragraph: Edwin Raymond doubted he would ever be promoted to sergeant after he sued the New York Police Department over arrest quotas that fell hardest on Black and Latino men. But he had a prominent ally.

headline: Walking Through Town
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: 3 Things We Learned From Ivanka Trump’s Trial Testimony
abstract: The former president’s daughter said she had little knowledge of the financial documents at the heart of the civil fraud case.
lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump spent five hours on the witness stand on Wednesday, two days after her father testified in a fraud trial that threatens his business empire as he kicks off another run for the White House.

headline: The Quiet Rage of Caregivers
abstract: Looking after a sick family member can mean putting your own life on hold, often with little recognition or outside support.
lead_paragraph: Ann Brenoff didn’t worry when her dogs returned from a walk without her husband in 2015. He often dropped their leashes and let them race up the steep driveway to their home in the canyons of Los Angeles. “But after 20 or 30 minutes, we said ‘OK, where’s Dad?’” said Ms. Brenoff, 73, whose two children were then teenagers.

headline: Sore After Working Out? Here’s How to Manage.
abstract: Post-exercise stiffness is a part of any fitness regimen, but many treatments don’t address the underlying cause. Here’s what actually works.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was an intense spin class that put you over the edge, or reaching for a personal best in the squat. Perhaps it was dancing all night at a wedding reception, using muscles you haven’t worked in years. Whatever the cause, the next day you’re stiff, sore and moving a little slowly.

headline: After Antidepressants, a Loss of Sexuality
abstract: Some patients are speaking up about lasting sexual problems after stopping antidepressants, a poorly understood condition.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and patients have long known that antidepressants can cause sexual problems. No libido. Pleasureless orgasms. Numb genitals. Well over half of people taking the drugs report such side effects.

headline: ‘Fear of Flying’ Is 50. What Happened to Its Dream of Freedom Through Sex?
abstract: With its feminist take on sexual pleasure, Erica Jong’s novel caused a sensation in 1973. But the revolution Jong promoted never came to pass.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies. “Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women. Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire. She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.

headline: 36 Hours in Washington, D.C.
abstract: Even in a time of transition, Washington is still a hub of art, history and social-justice leadership, and is home to many of the world’s best free museums.
lead_paragraph: Even in a time of transition, Washington is still a hub of art, history and social-justice leadership, and is home to many of the world’s best free museums.

headline: Heat Pump Installations Slow, Impeding Biden’s Climate Goals
abstract: The devices can heat and cool homes more efficiently than furnaces and air-conditioners, but their sales have slowed because of higher interest rates and a slow rollout of federal incentives.
lead_paragraph: More Americans are buying heat pumps, an environmentally friendly alternative to furnaces and air-conditioners that can significantly lower monthly energy bills. But the pace of installations has slowed in the past year, posing an obstacle to the Biden administration’s climate plans.

headline: Where Women Learn to Hunt, Fish and Field-Dress a Deer, Among Women
abstract: At the Becoming an Outdoors Woman workshop, no one feels uncomfortable discussing the ick factor of live fishing bait.
lead_paragraph: With some tweaks, the colorful minnow and feathered lures would make pretty cute earrings, I thought, or great Christmas tree ornaments.

headline: The Enduring, Transformational Power of Pilgrimage
abstract: The writer Aatish Taseer embarked on a journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq. What he learned was less a life-altering revelation and more a lesson in curiosity itself.
lead_paragraph: Travel, the movement of people from one place to another, has always existed. But long before we thought to travel for pleasure, we traveled for purpose: for commerce, and for faith.

headline: Inside Shary Boyle’s Head-Spinning Palace of Wonders
abstract: The artist creates a fun house of a show at the Museum of Arts and Design that explores how we create our identities and present them to others.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, I have a love-hate relationship with social media: sometimes I’m thrilled by the genuine sense of connection it provides, other times I feel pressured to perform for a distant audience. It’s that second feeling I thought about while visiting Shary Boyle’s “Outside the Palace of Me” at the Museum of Arts and Design (MAD), an exhibition that considers how we create our identities and present them to others — and in turn, how those performances feed back into who we are.

headline: ‘Our Family Can Have a Future’: Ford Workers on a New Union Contract
abstract: A couple who work at a Ford factory that was on strike for 41 days said the terms of a tentative contract agreement would be transformative for them.
lead_paragraph: Before autoworkers went on strike in September, Dave and Bailey Hodge were struggling to juggle the demands of working at a Ford Motor plant in Michigan and raising their young family.

headline: After Antisemitic Attacks, Colleges Debate What Kind of Speech Is Out of Bounds
abstract: Pro-Palestinian students say that they are speaking up for an oppressed people, but critics say that their rhetoric is deeply offensive.
lead_paragraph: In the days after the Hamas attack on Israel, Max Strozenberg, a first-year student at Northwestern University, experienced a couple of jarring incidents.

headline: The War in Gaza Is Also Unfolding on Instagram
abstract: Trapped in the enclave, Palestinians on the social media platform are documenting and sharing their harrowing experiences of life under Israeli airstrikes and a ground invasion.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza is unfolding on your cellphone.

headline: Even for Two Pros, Collaboration Was No Picnic
abstract: Welcome to the occasionally fraught partnership of Bill Watterson, the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes,” and John Kascht, a renowned celebrity caricaturist.
lead_paragraph: “I always enjoy it when Calvin and Hobbes argue,” the cartoonist Bill Watterson once wrote of the wildly popular comic strip he drew in the ’80s and ’90s about a 6-year-old boy named Calvin and his best friend, a tiger named Hobbes. “A funny conversation is more interesting to me than a one-liner.”

headline: Do You Use Swear Words?
abstract: A guest essayist writes about the reasons people swear and the power behind cursing. Is profanity part of your vocabulary?
lead_paragraph: Do you use curse words? If you use them, do you ever think about why? Does it feel good to unleash some foul language? Does it get attention? Does it help you bond with others or fit into a group?

headline: The Biden Campaign Wants Democrats to Calm Down
abstract: Yes, President Biden’s team has seen the polls that show him struggling in a 2024 rematch with Donald Trump. But it says it’s focused on other things — like how well Democrats are doing at the ballot box.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a few days this week, we got two pretty remarkable data points for the 2024 election.

headline: ‘The Killer’ Review: He’s a Deadly Bore
abstract: Michael Fassbender stars as a loquaciously dull hit man in David Fincher’s latest film about bloody exploits.
lead_paragraph: David Fincher can’t get enough of that murderous stuff — his filmography bleedeth over with miscreants (“Alien 3”), home invaders (“Panic Room”) and multiple maniacs (“Seven,” “Zodiac,” “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” “Gone Girl”). During one of his periodic breaks from painting the big screen red, Fincher served as a producer and director on the Netflix show “Mindhunter,” another of his visually impeccable, morgue-cold creep-outs. This one was about F.B.I. agents profiling serial killers like Edmund Kemper, a ghoul whose silkily insinuating manner resonated more deeply than the show, which ended after two seasons.

headline: Holocaust Survivors in Israel Faced Fresh Horror When Hamas Attacked
abstract: At least one Holocaust survivor was killed during the Oct. 7 attack. Others pressed against safe room doors to keep assailants out. One saw a video of her grandson’s abduction.
lead_paragraph: Moshe Ridler’s life ended much the way it began, at the hands of people who wanted to kill him.

headline: ‘Orlando, My Political Biography’ Review: A Collective Approach to Joy
abstract: The filmmaker Paul B. Preciado shares the title role with 20 trans and nonbinary performers to make a point about the cage of identity.
lead_paragraph: Few movies this year have lived in my head as long and as happily as “Orlando: My Political Biography,” which I’ve been thinking about since I first saw it in September. Written and directed by the Spanish-born philosopher and activist Paul B. Preciado — a trans man making his feature directing debut — the movie is, at its simplest, an essayistic documentary about transgender and nonbinary identity that draws inspiration from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Orlando: A Biography.” Yet trying to squeeze “My Political Biography” into a tidy categorical box is fundamentally at odds with Preciado’s expansive project, which is at once an argument, a confession, a celebration and a road map.

headline: What to Know About the Sexual Side Effects of Antidepressants
abstract: S.S.R.I.s, the most widely prescribed antidepressants, frequently cause sexual problems. Here’s what patients can do about it.
lead_paragraph: Antidepressants have long been among the most widely prescribed drugs in the U.S. Their popularity only grew at the start of the coronavirus pandemic, when many people struggled with depression and anxiety. Some surveys have found a striking rise among adolescents, particularly teenage girls.

headline: It’s Not Kids With the Cellphone Problem, It’s Parents
abstract: Banning phones in school is hard. But it’s the right thing to do.
lead_paragraph: The hardest rule I ever set for my kids was refusing them cellphones until high school.

headline: Is Reading the Hottest Thing You Can Do as a Single Person?
abstract: Pop culture has conditioned us to believe that a meet-cute that doesn’t happen in a bookstore is hardly worth having. But is being an avid reader truly essential to romance?
lead_paragraph: One of the first questions men ask Angela Liu on dating apps is “What are you reading?” The question is a softball for Ms. Liu, a self-proclaimed lover of literature. “I really care about the human condition and emotions and stuff,” she said.

headline: Dawoud Bey, Full Frame: On Richmond’s Trail of the Enslaved
abstract: In haunting studies of places charged with Black American history, a photographer celebrated for portraits now lets the land do the talking.
lead_paragraph: The urban parkland along the James River running through Richmond, Va., is true forest. Here grow maple, oak, hickory, cottonwood, sycamore, river birch, hackberry, fronds bowed under climbing English ivy, with winter creeper spreading underfoot.

headline: This Simple Hack Yields the Best Mashed Potatoes
abstract: Browning a little butter goes a long way to making a Thanksgiving staple all the better.
lead_paragraph: Mashed potatoes, while buttery and delicious, can also be a little uninspired. To me, they’ve always felt like filler on my Thanksgiving plate — an afterthought, more vehicle for gravy than anything else.

headline: Read With Jenna, Who Writes With Barbara
abstract: The twin sisters Jenna Bush Hager and Barbara Pierce Bush published their third picture book this week. They sat down to discuss fighting, writing and chosen family.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Bush Hager and Barbara Pierce Bush are busy women.

headline: These Five Thanksgiving Pies Are a Dessert Lover’s Dream
abstract: Make one or all of these updated classics and brand-new favorites from Claire Saffitz.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is a major production if you’re the host, and generally I encourage cutting a few corners. If it eases your workload, I say go ahead and buy the gravy or use the canned cranberry sauce.

headline: Getting Hollywood Back Up and Running Won’t Be Easy
abstract: With the industry hustling to make up for months of lost work, juggling production schedules and the availability of actors and crew members will be complicated.
lead_paragraph: Daisy Edgar-Jones, the 25-year-old British actress with an increasingly crowded dance card, will soon experience just how complicated Hollywood’s rush to return to work is going to be.

headline: Helping New York Face Climate Problems of the Future
abstract: Stephen Hammer, the new chief executive of the New York Climate Exchange, hopes to bring urgency to environmental issues facing the city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we will meet the new chief executive of the New York Climate Exchange, who describes it as “part think tank, part do tank.” We’ll also find out about Ivanka Trump’s day on the witness stand.

headline: ‘She Certainly Beat All the Boys’: Winners and Losers of the Third G.O.P. Debate
abstract: Opinion columnists and contributors assess the candidates in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnists and contributors assess the candidates in Miami.

headline: Hank Azaria: To Matthew Perry, God Was a Bunch of Drunks in a Room
abstract: Matthew Perry wanted to be remembered for helping people get sober. I was one of them.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Perry said that he wanted to be remembered as someone who helped people get sober, even more than he wanted to be remembered as a very funny, famous Friend. I think he’ll be remembered as both.

headline: ‘This Is Not a Whodunit’: Lawyer Lays Out Narrow Defense in Pelosi Attack Case
abstract: David DePape, 43, faces charges of attempted kidnapping and assault on an immediate family member of a federal official in the 2022 attack against Paul Pelosi.
lead_paragraph: David DePape lived a solitary life, worked carpentry jobs and was seemingly obsessed with right-wing conspiracy theories on the internet, where he railed about “wokism,” questioned the Holocaust and embraced Pizzagate and QAnon.

headline: Suburbs Were Democratic Turf on Tuesday. What About in 2024?
abstract: Republicans had hope after 2022 that the nation’s residential redoubts were coming back to the G.O.P. But aside from New York, the suburbs on Tuesday swung back to the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: From Northern Virginia to Northern Kentucky, the American suburbs rejected Republican candidates on Tuesday, sending a message that leafy residential communities where elections were once won and lost increasingly side with the Democratic Party — especially on abortion rights.

headline: Three Friends Bought a Brooklyn House Where They Could Live Alone Together. Which Was the Right Fit?
abstract: With a combined budget of up to $3.5 million, the trio sought a townhouse that could offer communal living space and separate apartments, but options were scarce. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: With a combined budget of up to $3.5 million, the trio sought a townhouse that could offer communal living space and separate apartments, but options were scarce. Here’s what they found.

headline: Behind the Story: How a Writer Prepared for a 40,000-Mile Trip
abstract: The dozens of books that T writer Aatish Taseer read before his journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq, and what he learned from each pilgrimage.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months ago, when the New York-based T writer at large Aatish Taseer began planning his reporting trips for this month’s three-part feature story — an exploration of religious travel in Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq — he was already well acquainted with the idea of pilgrimage. His first book, the 2009 memoir “Stranger to History,” opens with what is arguably the world’s best-known faith-motivated journey, the hajj to Mecca, and ends with what he describes as a personal pilgrimage to meet his estranged father in Pakistan. In Delhi, India, where Taseer grew up, quick trips for the purpose of worship were commonplace. “People would do a pilgrimage on an ordinary Sunday,” he says, “instead of going to an amusement park.”

headline: An Epic Pilgrimage Across Three Great Religions
abstract: Before there was tourism, there was pilgrimage. One writer’s 40,000-mile journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq reveals the ritual’s enduring transformational power.
lead_paragraph: Before there was tourism, there was pilgrimage. One writer’s 40,000-mile journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq reveals the ritual’s enduring transformational power.

headline: Are We Looking at George H.W. Biden?
abstract: Two aged, dutiful Washington insiders. One tough re-election road.
lead_paragraph: When you played second fiddle to a revered, charismatic, transformative president who chose you as his running mate not because you dazzled him but because you dully rounded him out, not because he saw you as the party’s future but because you were a link to its past, can you ever shine as brightly as you deserve to?

headline: Prince Fashion Items, Including the Ruffled Shirt, Go Up for Auction
abstract: The market for Prince’s wardrobe, guitars and other items has been robust since his death in 2016. Now more than 200 pieces are available for bids.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Bertrand Brillois, a Parisian businessman, began contacting seamstresses, costume designers, fabric dyers, production assistants and others who had worked for Prince. He told them that he thought Prince was not only a musical genius but also a fashion icon, and he wanted to buy clothing, jewelry and other accessories designed or worn by him.

headline: Biden Bolsters Union Support in Illinois
abstract: The trip, including a meeting with the president of the United Automobile Workers, offered the president a chance to celebrate a landmark labor deal.
lead_paragraph: President Biden pulled a red United Automobile Workers T-shirt over his button-down on Thursday and celebrated a landmark labor deal that kept a Stellantis manufacturing plant in business, using an appearance in Illinois to shore up crucial union support.

headline: WeWork’s Bankruptcy Tests Claims of a Co-Working Revolution
abstract: The business of offering offices on flexible, short leases will survive the company’s troubles, but commercial real estate experts say it will probably remain a niche.
lead_paragraph: In its heyday a few years ago, WeWork said it would reinvent offices. But the company never created a sustainable business or changed how most people worked.

headline: Hamas Is Said to Discuss Freeing Some Hostages, and More
abstract: Plus, a tense Republican debate and a tentative deal to end the Hollywood actors’ strike.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Supreme Court Tests Its Own Limits on Guns
abstract: Justices who have pushed against restrictions on gun ownership seemed sympathetic to limits for people under domestic violence restraining orders.
lead_paragraph: A critical gun case was argued before the Supreme Court this week.
