But instead of opening further freedoms for gun owners — as the court, with its conservative supermajority, did in a blockbuster decision last year — justices seemed ready to rule that the government may disarm people under restraining orders for domestic violence.

headline: In a U.S. First, a Commercial Plant Starts Pulling Carbon From the Air
abstract: The technique is expensive but it could help fight climate change. Backers hope fast growth can bring down costs.
lead_paragraph: In an open-air warehouse in California’s Central Valley, 40-foot-tall racks hold hundreds of trays filled with a white powder that turns crusty as it absorbs carbon dioxide from the sky.

headline: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 4: Dedicated Public Servants
abstract: The lawsuit against Rutherford County comes to an end, but the hard part is actually getting everybody paid.
lead_paragraph: The lawyers settle their case on behalf of the children who were wrongfully arrested or illegally jailed by Rutherford County. The county ends its illegal detention policy, and some of the kids who were wronged by the system are paid. But none of the adults behind the illegal policies face serious consequences. So what has changed in Rutherford County, and what hasn’t?

headline: A First-Class Dinner Menu From the Titanic Could Fetch Thousands at Auction
abstract: The menu, dated April 11, 1912, is part of a larger sale of maritime items taking place this weekend in England.
lead_paragraph: There were oysters, salmon with Hollandaise sauce, beef, squab, duck, roast chicken, green peas, parsnip purée and Victoria pudding. The feast described is not a Thanksgiving meal, but a snapshot of what first-class passengers on the Titanic ate for dinner on April 11, 1912, when the ship left Queenstown, Ireland, for New York.

headline: A Case Study in Abortion Politics
abstract: Ohio was at the center of the abortion fight in this year’s election.
lead_paragraph: Many Democrats have come to believe that abortion access is the solution to their political problems. This week’s election results — with Ohio guaranteeing abortion access in a landslide and Democrats winning in both Virginia and Kentucky — support this notion.

headline: ‘A Still Small Voice’ Review: Grant Them the Serenity
abstract: This absorbing documentary follows a chaplain at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office. There are cubicles, roller chairs, a water cooler and flat lighting that the director, Luke Lorentzen, would never dishonor by gussying up with a lamp. These are the chaplains’ quarters at The Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and Mati and her colleagues are here to comfort the dying and the families of the dead — to transform this 1,134-bed institution into a sacred space. They are Olympian empaths and they are exhausted.

headline: ‘Journey to Bethlehem’ Review: No Room at the Inn? Try the Multiplex
abstract: It’s no “Home Alone” or “Jesus Christ Superstar,” but it does have Antonio Banderas as a song-slinging Herod and Lecrae as a quavering Angel Gabriel.
lead_paragraph: Christmas announces its coming earlier every year. We haven’t even hit Thanksgiving and here is this peculiar Nativity movie for, um, someone’s whole family, directed and co-written by Adam Anders. Anders, making his feature debut here, is a former “Glee” writer and music producer, and his co-writer, Peter Barsocchini, is a veteran of “High School Musical.” While their treatment of the ancient world is informed, to say the least, by their prior work, the scenario also feels like Hallmark pulped through a Disney strainer.

headline: ‘Manodrome’ Review: The Manosphere Gets a Crude Awakening
abstract: An unemployed dad-to-be is seduced by a misogynist group who call themselves “the guys” in this sensationalizing drama starring Jesse Eisenberg.
lead_paragraph: The word “Manodrome,” the title of a new film starring Jesse Eisenberg, is a riff on the “manosphere” — a catchall term for misogynist online communities including so-called incels and men’s rights activists. If your first instinct, like mine, is to snicker, know that this self-important drama is devoid of humor.

headline: ‘Youth (Spring)’ Review: Garment Rending
abstract: The documentarian Wang Bing examines the cloistered world of young textile workers in China.
lead_paragraph: Despite running three and a half hours, the documentary “Youth (Spring)” withholds a great deal. That isn’t necessarily a criticism. The film is the latest documentary from Wang Bing, a persistent and widely admired chronicler of China’s downtrodden — its migrants, its outsiders, its mental patients and its survivors of forced-labor camps.

headline: ‘Dream Scenario’ Review: Space Invader
abstract: Nicolas Cage plays a mild-mannered professor who inexplicably wanders into others’ dreams in this wonderfully weird dark comedy.
lead_paragraph: Balding, bespectacled and bowed by the weight of a thousand disappointments, Paul Matthews (Nicolas Cage) moves through “Dream Scenario” with a schlubby passivity. At the college where he teaches evolutionary biology, his students sigh and fidget; during a lesson on zebras, he explains that their stripes keep them safe by ensuring that they don’t stand out from the herd. Not standing out is Paul’s entire vibe.

headline: ‘Albert Brooks: Defending My Life’ Review: Revisiting Past Hilarity
abstract: This actor, comic, writer and director is seen in a cinematic retrospective that celebrates his talent, but not always in a critically discerning way.
lead_paragraph: “Albert Brooks: Defending My Life,” a documentary about the venerable comedian, filmmaker, actor and writer, directed by his lifelong friend Rob Reiner, has the easy, amiable air of a career retrospective — wistful and hagiographic, it’s the kind of thing that usually accompanies a lifetime achievement award.

headline: Why Are Oil Prices Falling While War Rages in the Middle East?
abstract: Energy markets have shrugged off the fighting between Israel and Hamas so far, focusing instead on forecasts of subdued demand.
lead_paragraph: Intense fighting is underway in a region that holds much of the world’s petroleum resources. Yet, after a few days of anxiety following the bloody Oct. 7 raids by Hamas militants in Israel, energy markets have been slumping. Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, is selling for about $80 a barrel, cheaper than when the fighting started.

headline: New Contract May Not Solve Hollywood Actors’ Troubles
abstract: An end to the monthslong labor fight is in sight, but the industry’s changing economics could temper some of the actors’ gains.
lead_paragraph: After months of strikes that shut down most of Hollywood, the end appears in sight. The SAG-AFTRA union that represents some 160,000 members tentatively agreed to a new contract with media giants that, if approved, will reinvigorate the $134 billion American movie and television business.

headline: Palestinian Authority Open to Gaza Role if U.S. Backs 2-State Solution
abstract: The organization, which oversees the West Bank, says it will consider helping run Gaza after the war — if Washington pushes for the creation of a Palestinian state alongside the Israeli one.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Authority has told the Biden administration that it is open to a governance role in post-Hamas Gaza if the United States commits to a full-fledged two-state solution to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, according to a top official of its parent, the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: America’s Most Expensive ZIP Codes
abstract: California areas dominated the top 100 this year (and last).
lead_paragraph: If California’s home prices had physical weight, they’d tip the state into the Pacific Ocean. Among the 100 most expensive ZIP codes in the United States in 2023, 61 were found in the Golden State, according to a study by RealtyHop. New York was next, with 18 ZIP codes in the top 100. To compile the rankings, researchers analyzed more than 3.6 million active home listings from Jan. 1 to Oct. 15, using the median list price in each ZIP to identify the most expensive ones.

headline: Biden Finalizes Significant Overhaul in Federal Regulations
abstract: New rules from the Office of Management and Budget will change how the federal government weighs costs, enabling new efforts on climate change and poverty.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has overhauled how the federal government assesses the costs and benefits of regulation and some government spending programs, clearing a path for more aggressive efforts to fight climate change and help the poor.

headline: Archaeologists Look for Traces of Missing in Ashes of Hamas Attack
abstract: A team of about 15 have recovered the remains of at least 60 people so far, most of them from an Israeli village that suffered devastating losses.
lead_paragraph: Moshe Ajami, a veteran Israeli archaeologist, has spent decades sifting through the country’s southern desert to excavate lost ruins that date back more than 2,000 years. But in the past couple of weeks, he has been focused on searching the ashes of homes burned down by Hamas terrorists during last month’s surprise attack, looking for the bones, blood and teeth of Israelis who remain missing.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom in Moorestown, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Garden City, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 5,518-square-foot English Tudor house built in 1929 and updated in 2020, with a formal living room, family and media rooms, an eat-in kitchen with center island, two staircases, three gas fireplaces, an in-ground pool, a walled English garden, a bluestone patio, a large landscaped yard and a two-car garage, on 1.61 acres that back up to a golf course. Claire McHugh, Weichert Realtors, 609-332-2222, Weichert.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in SoHo, Kips Bay and Fieldston.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 550-square-foot apartment that has an open kitchen with quartz countertops, a windowed bathroom with stone flooring, and window unit air-conditioning, on the top floor of a six-story prewar walk-up building with a super, a shared patio and a virtual intercom. Barbara Helms, 917-771-3047, Sotheby’s International Realty; sothebysrealty.com

headline: A Cozy Hudson Valley Bookshop With an Emphasis on Female Authors
abstract: Plus: handcrafted steamer trunks, a new Chinese restaurant in Lower Manhattan and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: For over ten years, the Jaipur, India-based brothers and founders of Trunks Company, Priyank and Paritosh Mehta, have been on a mission to revive the steamer trunk and support local artists who make them. This week, they’ll be exhibiting 11 of the most ornate examples of the company’s work at the Salon Art + Design fair at the Park Avenue Armory, from a library trunk with quilted leather lining that’s embedded with speakers and lit with LED spotlights to a hand-painted red, white and navy blue Games Island Trunk that unfolds to become a tiny casino featuring amusements like Jenga, poker and chess. About a dozen craftspeople work two to three months on each of the trunks, which are meant to be statement pieces in a home rather than accompanying their owners on a trip, says Paritosh. “We’ve been commissioned to craft a trunk in the shape of the Taj Mahal Palace by the hotel, and to make a trunk for a collector to display his watch collection,” he says. “We’re building a whole lifestyle around heritage trunks.” Next year, though, the company plans to debut its most practical collection to date: hand-painted trunks with wheels that one can actually travel with. Price on request, on view at the Park Avenue Armory from Nov. 9 through 13, thesalonny.com.

headline: Five Years After Devastating Fire, the Town of Paradise Rebuilds
abstract: The town is pushing forward with climate-proofing as residents return.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, what would become the deadliest wildfire in California history erupted in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

headline: Trump Family Trial Style
abstract: Ivanka Trump and her siblings dress for court — and the cameras.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s office has finished presenting its case in the civil fraud trial of former President Donald J. Trump. The first act of the first episode in the extended series known as the Trump lawsuits has come to an end. (The defense begins next week, and four more criminal cases are pending.) The show, however, is only beginning.

headline: A Bundle of 18th-Century Love Letters Is Unsealed at Last
abstract: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
lead_paragraph: The ink has barely faded, and the paper has only slightly yellowed. For nearly 250 years, the letters, more than 100 of them, sat sealed in Britain’s National Archives, unopened and unexamined until a history professor stumbled upon them. He found, to his delight, a treasure trove bearing intimate details about romance and daily life in mid-18th-century France.

headline: Las Vegas Unions and MGM Resorts Reach Tentative Labor Agreement
abstract: The deal, the second in two days with a major resort operator, was announced on the day before a strike deadline set by two major unions.
lead_paragraph: Two unions representing hospitality workers announced on Thursday a tentative labor agreement with a second major Las Vegas hotel operator, MGM Resorts International, a day before a strike deadline set by the unions.

headline: Your Favorite Song Is Now a Norteña
abstract: The EZ Band’s blend of norteña music and Top 40 hits offers some Americans a way to connect with their parents’ culture and exposes others to a new sound.
lead_paragraph: At first, Jaime Guevara’s version of “Hey There Delilah” sounds like just another cover of the Plain White T’s original. But some seconds in, an accordion enters the mix. Then, Guevara shifts his crooning from English to Spanish.

headline: At Least 2 Million Children Have Lost Medicaid Insurance This Year
abstract: Many of the children were eligible for federal aid, experts said, but errors have been common as states “unwind” assistance from earlier in the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: At least two million low-income children have lost health insurance since the end of a federal policy that guaranteed coverage through Medicaid earlier in the Covid-19 pandemic, according to new analyses by researchers at the Georgetown Center for Children and Families and KFF, a health policy research organization.

headline: Lesson Plan: ‘A Beginner’s Guide to Looking at the Universe’
abstract: In this lesson, students explore how the James Webb Space Telescope is changing what we see in the distant universe.
lead_paragraph: The James Webb Space Telescope is a giant leap in the history of stargazing. Our view of the universe will never be the same.

headline: Family Wants Answers After No Amber Alert Came When a Boy Disappeared
abstract: The Milwaukee Police Department wanted an alert when Prince McCree, 5, was reported missing. The state denied the request, and the boy was found dead the next day.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 25, 5-year-old Prince McCree was home sick from school, playing video games. Then, he disappeared.

headline: Dr. Ruth Saved People’s Sex Lives. Now She Wants to Cure Loneliness.
abstract: Taking the lessons of pandemic isolation — and her adolescent diary — Dr. Ruth Westheimer, 95, decided she should be New York’s Loneliness Ambassador. And so she is.
lead_paragraph: “I still will talk about orgasms,” Dr. Ruth Westheimer said during a conversation over the summer. “I still will talk about sexual dysfunction. But I have done that.” She had recently turned 95, and after a long and spirited career as America’s most famous and least likely sex counselor, she was driven by a new challenge.

headline: ‘The Marvels’ Review: You’ve Seen This Movie 32 Times Before
abstract: Brie Larson stars alongside two Disney+ stars in this trope-ridden franchise installment, the 33rd movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
lead_paragraph: As with a lot of studio-created girl groups, the women fronting “The Marvels” are carefully styled, wear coordinated outfits during their big numbers, have a few flashily choreographed moves and, because they’ve clearly put in the rehearsal time, know how to harmonize (more or less). The group has been created for maximum bankability, familiarity and relatability, and to that instrumental end, it delivers exactly what you expect of it and not a single thing, idea or beat more. Its members are nice, even at their most ostensibly fierce, and so unrelievedly bland that it feels like an affront, especially to all the women here doing so much hard work.

headline: Our Go-To, Won’t-Fail Roasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe
abstract: You cook them in a cast-iron skillet, meaning the sheet pan is free for the 534 other dishes on your menu.
lead_paragraph: Chances are that you, savvy New York Times Cooking cooker, don’t exactly need a roasted brussels sprouts recipe. Maybe you play fast and loose with it, switching up the seasonings, bringing in the broiler. But winging a dish can be risky when it comes to dinner gatherings with multiple dishes (and people) to juggle, to say nothing of unfamiliar ovens and equipment. So lean on Mark Bittman’s popular go-to recipe, which starts the sprouts cut-side down on the stovetop (for maximum browning) and finishes them in the oven. Bonus: You cook your sprouts in a cast-iron pan, freeing up that sheet pan for any of the other 534 dishes on your menu.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Global Population Growth and Decline
abstract: How might declining fertility rates affect the world’s future well-being?
lead_paragraph: Economists and demographers who study population size project that the world’s population will reach a peak of about 10 billion people around 2085, if not earlier. Thereafter, the population is not expected to plateau, but instead decline to less than two billion about 300 years later, over perhaps 10 generations. Factors that influence population size of a country include fertility, mortality, migration and age structure. One of the results of population decline may include reduced economic growth.

headline: Two Studies on Greenland Reveal Ominous Signs for Sea Level Rise
abstract: Some glaciers on the island are melting at double the rate of just a few decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Greenland’s mountain glaciers and floating ice shelves are melting faster than they were just a few decades ago and becoming destabilized, according to two separate studies published this week.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Review: People Who Live in Glass Houses
abstract: Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie’s breathtaking, uncomfortable series takes home-renovation TV into the heart of darkness.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a mishegas,” Whitney Siegel (Emma Stone), a convert to Judaism, says to her husband, Asher Siegel (Nathan Fielder), as they do a good deed for a needy family. “Mitzvah,” Asher corrects her. “Mishegas means something else.” (It means, roughly, “craziness” in Yiddish.)

headline: An Old Master’s Song for the Nation That Broke His Heart
abstract: For his fellow exiles, Sadiq Fitrat Nashenas, an 88-year-old star from a golden era, evokes the Afghanistan they left behind, and one that could have been.
lead_paragraph: For four nights before the concert, the old master had trouble sleeping. In his dreams, he was haunted by defeat after defeat — a failed exam, a knockout in the boxing ring. During the day, an upset stomach reduced his diet to gentle soup.

headline: Kidnapped Father of Colombian Soccer Star Is Freed
abstract: Luis Manuel Díaz was abducted 12 days ago by a guerrilla group called the National Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: The father of Luis Díaz, a Colombian soccer star for the English club Liverpool, was freed on Thursday after he was kidnapped by a guerrilla group, Colombian officials said.

headline: Gary Winnick, Who Won and Lost With Global Crossing, Dies at 76
abstract: He masterminded the building of a transoceanic fiber-optics network to speed the internet and phone traffic. But in five years the company went bankrupt in a historic failure.
lead_paragraph: Gary Winnick, a former junk-bond salesman who in 1997 founded Global Crossing, a telecommunications company that laid fiber-optic cable underwater around the world to speed internet and phone traffic, but that imploded five years later under billions of dollars in debt, died on Saturday at his estate in Los Angeles. He was 76.

headline: Jezebel, the Pioneering Feminist Website, Will Shut Down
abstract: Citing “economic headwinds rattling our business,” Jim Spanfeller, the chief executive of Jezebel’s parent company, G/O Media, announced the suspension of the publication and staff layoffs.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of the website Jezebel announced on Thursday that it was shutting down the site and laying off its staff, citing economic headwinds and shifting audience priorities.

headline: In Mexico, Surveillance Orders That Read Like a Political Power List
abstract: The Mexico City attorney general’s office ordered the phone records of politicians and officials, court filings show. Many of the people targeted say they were singled out for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: A leading presidential candidate. The head of the country’s customs agency. At least three borough mayors in the capital. It’s a list that includes powerful members of Mexico’s government.

headline: ‘Mysterious Case of Kitsy Rainey’ Review: Mikel Murfi’s Trilogy Has Bittersweet End
abstract: At Irish Arts Center, the actor delivers the final installment of his solo plays about the cobbler Pat and his eccentric beloved.
lead_paragraph: Falling in love came as a surprise to Pat Farnon — a late-life development he hadn’t been looking for any more than he’d been looking for the marriage proposal that set that romance in motion. When a whirlwind of a woman named Kitsy Rainey asked him to marry her even though they’d never so much as dated, he acquiesced.

headline: A New Chapter for a Checkered Scarf
abstract: As demonstrations have cropped up globally in support of civilians in Gaza, some Palestinians are encouraging non-Palestinians to wear kaffiyehs as a show of solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Around the neck, over the head, draped down the back, pinned into hair, wrapped around a face — there are many ways to style a kaffiyeh, the square checkered scarf traditionally worn in parts of the Middle East.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Big, Bold Sci-Fi Bet on the Device That Comes After the Smartphone
abstract: Humane, a company started by two former Apple employees, says its new artificial intelligence pin can stop all the scrolling. Can it live up to the hype?
lead_paragraph: Inside a former horse stable in the San Francisco neighborhood of SoMa, a wave of gentle chirps emerged from small, blinking devices pinned to the chests of employees at a start-up called Humane.

headline: Matisse and Derain: The Audacious ‘Wild Beasts’ of Fauvism in a Radiant Show
abstract: The leaders of a short-lived but consequential art movement that flourished early in the 20th century take center stage at the Met Museum.
lead_paragraph: If you ever took an art history survey in college, you may recall the blur of Fauvism. In the parade of projected images, it was the shocking flash of pure color that sped past as the course made its way to the more demanding rigors and longer shelf lives of Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” and Cubism.

headline: Can A.I. and Lasers Cure Our Smartphone Addiction?
abstract: A first impression of Humane’s new magnetic Ai Pin: equal parts magical and awkward.
lead_paragraph: An aqua blue light appeared on my outstretched palm, showing a menu. Slowly, I circled my wrist to scroll, pressing an index finger and thumb together in a pinching motion to select an item. I wanted to send a text message. The device on my sweater, a two-inch square magnetic pin from a start-up called Humane, let out a soft “clink.”

headline: Megyn Kelly Will Moderate the Next G.O.P. Debate, on NewsNation
abstract: The event, on Dec. 6, is an opportunity for an upstart cable news network to expand its relatively small viewership.
lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly, whose high-flying career as a Fox News anchor fell to earth after an ill-advised move to NBC — and then remade herself as a conservative podcaster and radio host — is set to return to the political spotlight next month as a moderator for the next Republican primary debate.

headline: The Republican Alternatives to Trump
abstract: Responses to an essay offering advice on winning the nomination. Also: Civil debates; questions for Hamas and Israel; fraught times; antipsychotic drugs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Young Thug Lyrics Will Be Allowed as Evidence in YSL RICO Trial
abstract: A judge ruled on Thursday that at least 17 specific sets of lines from the Atlanta rapper and his collaborators could be used by prosecutors in their gang conspiracy case.
lead_paragraph: A judge decided on Thursday that rap lyrics by the Atlanta artist Young Thug and his collaborators will be allowed as evidence in the racketeering trial of YSL, a chart-topping hip-hop label and collective that prosecutors say is also a criminal street gang responsible for violent crimes.

headline: Barbra Streisand Has Always Called the Shots
abstract: Our critics Wesley Morris and Alexandra Jacobs on the icon’s tell-all memoir.
lead_paragraph: Barbra Streisand’s long-awaited memoir, “My Name Is Barbra,” is nearly a thousand pages of soul-baring and score-settling — with plenty of Yiddish thrown in. Wesley Morris and Alexandra Jacobs discuss the book’s most surprising revelations. Plus, we get a glimpse of Wesley’s visit with the living legend at her Malibu home.

headline: They Risked Their Lives to Clean New York Offices. Now They May Strike.
abstract: The office cleaners’ union is preparing to walk out to protect their health care benefits, amid the worst commercial real estate slump in decades.
lead_paragraph: Danuta Klimas, an office cleaner, went back to work in Lower Manhattan days after the Sept. 11 attacks, as toxic dust from ground zero hung in the air. She was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer years later.

headline: Deal Granting Amnesty to Separatists Sets Off Turmoil in Spain
abstract: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez’s agreement with Catalan separatists will likely keep him in power, but it has provoked an upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain sealed a deal to extend amnesty to Catalan separatists on Thursday in exchange for their political support, likely allowing him to stay in power but causing turmoil throughout Spain, doubts in Europe and questions about the country’s stability.

headline: Blue Lagoon in Iceland Temporarily Closes After Thousands of Earthquakes
abstract: The tourist attraction, a geothermal spa that is popular with Americans, said it would “carefully monitor the seismic developments” as a precautionary measure.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of earthquakes recorded over the past few days have led to the pre-emptive closure of the Blue Lagoon, a popular tourist destination in Iceland.

headline: F.B.I. Director Casts Doubt on Decision to Relocate Its Headquarters to Maryland
abstract: Christopher Wray’s comments could have serious implications for a long-awaited plan whose announcement seemed to mark the end of a hotly contested debate over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Christopher A. Wray, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on Thursday blasted the Biden administration’s selection of Greenbelt, Md., for the bureau’s new headquarters, citing a flawed process and suggesting that a top federal official had a conflict of interest.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A couple of nights ago, I got to see the 2016 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature doing his thing onstage — his thing being music, not books, since the laureate in question is Bob Dylan. But as it happens, there is an expansive new Dylan book on the shelves right now, which combs through his vast archives to offer a selection of letters, handwritten lyrics, old photos and other ephemera.

headline: ‘This Much We Know’ Review: Asking Why After a Friend’s Death
abstract: L. Frances Henderson’s intricate debut documentary investigates a suicide, raising plenty of questions, including one about its own ethics.
lead_paragraph: Our yearning for answers and the limits of knowing are at the heart of the intricately crafted, unsettling documentary “This Much We Know.” The director L. Frances Henderson based this very personal debut on John D’Agata’s lauded book “About a Mountain,” which deftly yoked the suicide of a teenager in Las Vegas to the Department of Energy’s since-scuttled plans to use Yucca Mountain, 100 miles northwest of that city, as a repository for nuclear waste.

headline: Review: Kyle Marshall’s History Lessons, in Fragments
abstract: His company’s debut program at the Joyce Theater has three New York premieres, including one about the Black roots of rock.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Marshall’s dance “Onyx” has a historical subject: the Black roots of rock ‘n’ roll. But don’t expect the work — one of the three New York premieres that make up his company’s debut program at the Joyce Theater this week — to be a straightforward parade of Black artists and their jukebox hits. Marshall’s approach is exploratory and questioning.

headline: Alan Hevesi, New York Official Who Fell From Grace, Dies at 83
abstract: A state legislator from Queens and a city and state comptroller, he was forced to resign in a scandal and later imprisoned in a pay-to-play scheme.
lead_paragraph: Alan G. Hevesi, a cerebral, suave and blunt New York politician who spent 35 years as an elected official until he suffered a dizzying fall that led to his resignation as state comptroller and 20 months in prison for corruption, died on Thursday in the hamlet of East Meadow on Long Island. He was 83.

headline: Coming Soon: More Oil, Gas and Coal
abstract: An alarming picture of planned fossil fuel production before the global climate talks.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that fossil fuels are still going strong, as we discussed last month. But a new United Nations-backed report paints an alarming picture of how dramatically coal, oil and gas production is expected to grow in the coming years.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Consider a throwback detective show, a new basketball documentary or a holiday baking extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: ‘Moonlighting’

headline: 8 Nonalcoholic Wines for the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: These alcohol-free wines will help everyone give thanks this Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: With wine, there’s no point in fighting Thanksgiving dinner’s kaleidoscope of flavors. It’s best to find an easy way to flatter them.

headline: U.K. Home Secretary Stirs Political Storm After Writing Article Attacking the Police
abstract: The future of Suella Braverman hung in the balance after she wrote an incendiary opinion article. Downing Street said the piece was unauthorized.
lead_paragraph: One of Britain’s most senior cabinet ministers, Suella Braverman, has triggered political turmoil by writing a newspaper article that attacked the country’s largest police force over its approach to a pro-Palestinian protest, and implicitly challenged the authority of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

headline: How to Host Without a Guest Room
abstract: Your guests can still be comfortable in the living room.
lead_paragraph: Your guests can still be comfortable in the living room.

headline: America’s New Wildfire Risk Goes Beyond Forests
abstract: Grassland and shrubland fires burn more land and destroy more homes across the United States than forest fires, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Forest fires may get more attention, but a new study reveals that grassland fires are more widespread and destructive across the United States. Almost every year since 1990, the study found, grass and shrub fires burned more land than forest fires did, and they destroyed more homes, too.

headline: Fed Chair Recalls Inflation ‘Head Fakes’ and Pledges to Do More if Needed
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said officials would proceed carefully. But if more policy action is needed, he pledged to take it.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, on Thursday expressed little urgency to make another interest rate increase imminently — but he reiterated that officials would adjust policy further if doing so proved necessary to cool the economy and fully restrain inflation.

headline: Move Over, Gels. Heinz Wants Runners to Refuel With Ketchup.
abstract: Despite a video advertising ketchup as runners’ fuel, experts are far from sure that gobbling the packets is a good move for your next long run.
lead_paragraph: You can put ketchup on a burger or fries, sure. It’s a key ingredient in Russian salad dressing and meatloaf. Ketchup was once even declared a vegetable by the U.S. Agriculture Department under President Ronald Reagan.

headline: The Sensory Transcendence of a French Meal, via the Big Screen
abstract: “The Taste of Things” is the latest movie to luxuriate in France’s gourmand tradition, a safe way of attracting audiences outside the country.
lead_paragraph: In France, a robust appetite is a virtue if not a heroic trait.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Accountability at School
abstract: Teachers say they are pressured to pass students even when they don’t show up to class or do the work. Teenagers tell us what they think about such policies.
lead_paragraph: We asked students recently: Do schools need to do more to hold students accountable?

headline: Film Club: ‘A Toast to Raising Alcohol Taxes’
abstract: What can be done to reduce the destructive effects of excessive drinking? A Times Opinion video proposes a simple but effective idea.
lead_paragraph: “A Toast to Raising Alcohol Taxes” is a five-minute Opinion video addressing the quiet drug epidemic facing our nation — excessive drinking. “Imagine a way,” the Times filmmakers ask, “to drastically cut the number of deaths on America’s roads, to spare many from fatal disease, something that could reduce violence and even unwanted pregnancies.” The good news, they inform us, is that it actually exists: raise taxes on alcohol. The bad news is that politicians are petrified to do so.

headline: An Enduring Fall Dessert for Thanksgiving
abstract: Pumpkin empanadas, popular in communities along the U.S.-Mexico border, have a special place on the holiday table.
lead_paragraph: Every year after Halloween, when Yvette Marquez-Sharpnack’s carved jack-o’-lanterns looked soggy, her grandmother in El Paso saw an opportunity to repurpose them.

headline: Annie Ernaux Can Read Anywhere, So Long as It’s Quiet
abstract: “The first condition is silence,” says the 2022 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, whose most recent book is “The Young Man.” “The when and where do not matter.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: In Congress and on Campuses, ‘From the River to the Sea’ Inflames Debate
abstract: The pro-Palestinian rallying cry has become a fixture of protests in the United States and was a focus of the congressional censure of Representative Rashida Tlaib. It has a fraught history.
lead_paragraph: When House Republicans and a solid bloc of Democrats banded together this week to censure Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, for her statements about the Israel-Gaza war, they homed in on her embrace and defense of one pro-Palestinian slogan they called unacceptable: “from the river to the sea.”

headline: Senate Panel Punts Effort to Force Testimony in Supreme Court Ethics Inquiry
abstract: The Judiciary Committee postponed votes to issue subpoenas for benefactors of Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel Alito after Republicans threatened a politically charged fight.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday abruptly put off its push to subpoena two conservative allies of Justices Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Clarence Thomas as part of a Supreme Court ethics inquiry that has met stiff resistance from Republicans.

headline: Jill Stein Announces Third-Party Bid for President
abstract: Ms. Stein will seek the Green Party nomination, a spokesman said. Her last two campaigns with the party were unsuccessful.
lead_paragraph: Jill Stein, who ran unsuccessfully for president on the Green Party ticket in 2012 and 2016, will run again in 2024, she announced on Thursday — adding yet another name to the field even as the two major parties appear almost certain to nominate the same two candidates who ran in 2020.

headline: Manchin Says He Will Not Seek Re-election, Dealing Blow to Democrats
abstract: The decision by Senator Joe Manchin III will leave open a seat in a deeply red state, threatening Democrats’ hold on the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III, the conservative West Virginia Democrat known for bipartisan deal-making and also for frustrating some of his party’s most ambitious policy goals, announced on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, dealing a blow to Democrats’ chances of holding the Senate next year.

headline: Linda R. Hirshman, Who Challenged Stay-at-Home Mothers, Dies at 79
abstract: A feminist provocateur, she went on to write about the gay rights movement and transformative figures like the first two female Supreme Court justices.
lead_paragraph: Linda R. Hirshman, a union lawyer turned law and philosophy professor turned feminist provocateur, author and cultural historian who managed, to her delight, to enrage liberals and conservatives alike with an attack on so-called choice feminism, died on Oct. 31 in Burlington, Vt. She was 79.

headline: I.O.C. Says It Was Target of Elaborate ‘Fake News’ Campaign
abstract: Olympic officials said the effort included fabricated quotes about the Israel-Gaza war and a four-part, Netflix-style documentary.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee issued an unusual statement on Thursday saying it had been targeted by “fake news posts” that it said contained “defamatory content, a fake narrative and false information.” The elaborate campaign included manufactured quotations from I.O.C. representatives, fake news stories citing those fabricated comments and even a Netflix-style documentary series released online and narrated by a voice purporting to be the actor Tom Cruise.

headline: Israeli Forces Have Limited Time in Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks has fueled sympathy around the world for the Palestinian cause even as Israel continues to bury its dead.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military has limited time to carry out its operations in Gaza before anger among Arabs in the region and frustration in the United States and other countries over the spiraling civilian death toll constrain Israel’s goal of eradicating Hamas, U.S. officials said this week.

headline: House Republicans Clash Over Spending Days Ahead of Shutdown Deadline
abstract: Party divisions forced Republicans to abandon two of their own spending measures this week as they toiled to agree on a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown next Saturday.
lead_paragraph: At odds with one another on spending, House Republicans abruptly scrapped their legislative work on Thursday and left Washington with little progress toward funding the government and no plan to avert a shutdown next week.

headline: Germany Remembers Kristallnacht at a Fraught Moment
abstract: As reports of antisemitism surge in Germany and elsewhere, commemorations of the Nazi pogrom have taken on special resonance this year.
lead_paragraph: In a moment heavy with symbolism, Germany on Thursday marked the 85th anniversary of Kristallnacht, the eruption of murderous Nazi violence against the country’s Jews on the night of Nov. 9, 1938.

headline: No Gluten or Dairy, but Plenty to Love in These Thanksgiving Dishes
abstract: Welcome guests with dietary restrictions to the table with these recipes that everyone can enjoy.
lead_paragraph: In “Amelia Bedelia,” the first volume of the children’s book series created by Peggy Parish, the title character starts a new job as a housekeeper. Before she gets to her long list of tasks, she bakes a pie with ease, even joy, because she does “make a good pie.” She then follows the instructions for her duties literally — when asked to dust the furniture, she sprinkles powder all over it.

headline: At a Hollywood Screening, Footage of Hamas Killing Israelis
abstract: After a screening at the Museum of Tolerance aimed to show the brutality of the Oct. 7 attack on Israeli civilians, fights broke out among protesters outside.
lead_paragraph: Having produced movies like “Pulp Fiction” and “Reservoir Dogs,” Lawrence Bender has a high tolerance for make-believe violence on film. But he wasn’t sure he could sit through raw footage of the real thing: the killings of Israeli civilians by Hamas.

headline: 8 Excellent Asian Noodle Soups (in Three Boroughs)
abstract: In Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens you’ll find superlative versions of prawn mee, mohinga and more.
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote about soup, which I suggested is not as popular as it once was, possibly because it is not cut out for the age of share plates.

headline: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Pauses in Combat
abstract: Plus, Hollywood is coming back to life.
lead_paragraph: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in selected areas of northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, a White House spokesman said.

headline: Former Baltimore Prosecutor Found Guilty of Perjury in Federal Court
abstract: A jury found Marilyn Mosby, once the state’s attorney for Baltimore City, guilty of lying about hardships tied to the pandemic to withdraw retirement funds.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Mosby, a former Baltimore prosecutor who rose to national prominence for pursuing charges against police officers in connection with the death of Freddie Gray, was found guilty in federal court on two counts of perjury for falsely claiming financial hardship to withdraw money from a retirement fund.

headline: Vatican Says Transgender People Can Be Baptized and Become Godparents
abstract: A document approved by Pope Francis lays out nuanced guidance in keeping with his vision of a more inclusive church, but it does not amount to a policy change in the church, the Vatican says.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, who has made reaching out to L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics a hallmark of his papacy, has made clear that transgender people can be baptized, serve as godparents and be witnesses at church weddings, furthering his vision of a more inclusive church.

headline: Investigator Stole Items From Dead Men, Prosecutors Say
abstract: An investigator with the Los Angeles County medical examiner’s office took a gold necklace and rare antique coins from two men whose deaths he was handling, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An investigator with the Los Angeles County medical examiner’s office has been charged with stealing items, including a gold necklace, from two dead men, the authorities said.

headline: Omegle Shuts Down as Founder Acknowledges Crime on Video Chat Site
abstract: Omegle’s popularity surged during the pandemic. But critics said that it let online sexual predators go unchecked.
lead_paragraph: Omegle, the popular website and app that paired random users through video chat, has shut down after its founder acknowledged persistent criminal activity and critics said that it had become a haven for pedophilia and child sexual abuse.

headline: How to Shave Your Eyebrows
abstract: The makeup artist and model Raisa Flowers shaves her brows and creates a glamorous makeup look.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist and model Raisa Flowers shaves her brows and creates a glamorous makeup look.

headline: Why More People Are Shaving Their Eyebrows — And How to Do It Yourself
abstract: The dramatic beauty look, once most closely associated with punks, goths and drag queens, is entering the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: There is something distinctly queer about shaved eyebrows: their presence, or rather absence, challenges our expectations about what a face should be. And indeed, for much of the past century, they were a signal of deviance from the norm — either because a person couldn’t fit in or because they refused to. Take the drag queen Divine, who in the filmmaker John Waters’s 1972 trash epic, “Pink Flamingos,” struts down a Baltimore sidewalk wearing a slinky wrap dress, peep-toe heels and a pair of impossibly arched brows. She is undeniably glamorous, yet her brows — painted by the makeup artist and costume designer Van Smith, who first removed Divine’s natural ones along with part of her hairline — stamp her face with a permanent glare, as if underlining her character’s self-declared status as “the filthiest person alive.”

headline: Trump on the Stand
abstract: Courtroom fireworks and some risky admissions.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in about a decade, Donald Trump took the witness stand this week and testified extensively under oath in court. The setting was his civil fraud trial in Manhattan, where a judge is deciding what penalties he should face for inflating the value of his properties to secure favorable loan terms from banks.

headline: Hearing the Music in Black American English
abstract: The music of African languages comes through in the play “Purlie Victorious.”
lead_paragraph: Broadway, as always, is giving us lessons on language and its connection to music. The stellar new production of “Purlie Victorious,” not seen on Broadway since 1961, is Exhibit A.

headline: Gazans Flee ‘Destruction and Death’ as They Head South
abstract: Israel agreed to pause military operations for a few hours daily to allow civilians in Gaza to evacuate the northern part of the strip, the White House announced.
lead_paragraph: Israel agreed to pause military operations for a few hours daily to allow civilians in Gaza to evacuate the northern part of the strip, the White House announced.

headline: Robert De Niro’s Company Is Found Liable for Gender Discrimination
abstract: Graham Chase Robinson, a former assistant of Mr. De Niro’s, was awarded $1.3 million by a jury. She said she was assigned “stereotypically female” job responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Manhattan on Thursday found Robert De Niro’s company liable for gender discrimination against a former employee who claimed that the actor assigned her “stereotypically female” job responsibilities such as washing his sheets and attending to his home even as she climbed the ranks of his company, awarding her $1.3 million in damages.

headline: Listen: Final Episode of ‘The Kids of Rutherford County’
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Michelle Williams, Julianne Moore and Salman Rushdie Hit New York Galas
abstract: Actors reacted to a tentative deal to end their strike at a Creative Time fund-raiser, and the New York Public Library hosted its annual Library Lions gala.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, inside a cavernous event space on the Lower East Side, at the annual gala for the public art organization Creative Time, the actor Jeremy Strong said the news that striking actors and Hollywood studios had reached a tentative deal, “went around the room like wildfire.”

headline: Israel Will Pause Combat for Hours Each Day, the U.S. Said
abstract: Also, Senator Joe Manchin says he will not seek re-election. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, according to the White House.

headline: Judge Approves JPMorgan’s $290 Million Settlement With Epstein Victims
abstract: The nation’s largest bank was sued for ignoring red flags about Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking operation while he was a client.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday approved a settlement of a class-action lawsuit in which JPMorgan Chase will pay $290 million to sexual abuse victims of Jeffrey Epstein who claimed that the bank ignored warnings about the disgraced financier.

headline: Israel Accuses Freelance Photographers of Advance Knowledge of Oct. 7 Attack
abstract: The New York Times said there was “no evidence” to support such claims about its freelancer.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli government on Thursday accused freelance photographers for several major news organizations, including The New York Times, of being “accomplices” in the killing and abductions of Israeli soldiers and civilians by Hamas fighters — an allegation The Times vigorously denied about its freelancer.

headline: Frank Borman, Astronaut Who Led First Orbit of the Moon, Dies at 95
abstract: He commanded the 1968 Apollo 8 mission that carried three astronauts farther from Earth than anyone had ever traveled. He later led Eastern Airlines.
lead_paragraph: Frank Borman, the commander of NASA’s 1968 Apollo 8 spaceflight, whose astronauts became the first men to orbit the moon, captured the famed image known as Earthrise and read lines from Genesis to deliver a brief Christmastime uplift to a troubled America, died on Tuesday in Billings, Mont. He was 95.

headline: Yuri Temirkanov, Conductor Who Celebrated Russia’s Music, Dies at 84
abstract: Immersed in his native land’s repertoire — Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev — he drew bold, rich sounds from the world’s major orchestras. In Russia, he was adored.
lead_paragraph: Yuri Temirkanov, a well-traveled Russian conductor steeped in his country’s bygone musical culture, died on Nov. 2 in St. Petersburg, the city where he held sway for over 30 years. He was 84.

headline: Democrats: You Can Chill Out Now!
abstract: Despite his bad poll numbers, I see a path to victory for Biden.
lead_paragraph: Well, this week has been an emotional roller coaster. On Sunday, a New York Times/Siena College poll showed President Biden behind Donald Trump in a bunch of battleground states, sending Democrats into a tizzy. Then on Tuesday, voters handed Democrats a string of election victories — the kind they have enjoyed in election after election since Trump was inaugurated in 2017.

headline: What History Tells Us About the Feel-Bad Economy
abstract: Why are voters unhappy about low unemployment and falling inflation?
lead_paragraph: Since Tuesday’s big Democratic electoral victories, I’ve been seeing some speculation to the effect that the 2024 election may be marked by a reverse coattail effect: that President Biden, whose poll numbers have supposedly been weighed down by a bad economy, may be lifted up by local candidates who have been racking up wins over social issues.

headline: An Expedition Finds a ‘Lost’ Mammal and a Shrimp That Lives in Trees
abstract: In the Cyclops Mountains in the Indonesian part of the island of New Guinea, Oxford scientists and local guides made a series of spectacular discoveries.
lead_paragraph: A scientific expedition to a treacherous mountain range on the island of New Guinea has collected the first-ever photographic evidence confirming the survival of a bizarre, egg-laying mammal. The team also found dozens of undescribed species of insects, as well as newfound arachnids, amphibians and even a shrimp that dwells in trees.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Set to Visit South Carolina for Campaign Kickoff
abstract: The vice president is said to be planning a surprise Friday trip to file paperwork for the state’s primary, which will be the first party-approved voting of 2024.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Columbia, S.C., on Friday to formally file President Biden’s paperwork to appear on the Democratic primary ballot in the state, according to two people familiar with her plans.

headline: Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon Falls to a Five-Year Low
abstract: Tree loss was down 20 percent from the previous year, the environment minister announced.
lead_paragraph: Deforestation in the Amazon rainforest in Brazil fell to a five-year low, the country’s National Institute of Space Research announced on Thursday, a sign that Brazil, which has the biggest share of tropical forest in the world, was making progress on its pledge to halt all deforestation by the end of the decade.

headline: Joe Manchin’s Retirement Adds Fuel to 2024 Rumors
abstract: The West Virginia senator, who announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election, has stoked chatter about a third-party run. But his allies have been tight-lipped about his plans.
lead_paragraph: Almost since he arrived in Washington, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has complained about the partisan nature of the Capitol and insisted that Americans aren’t as politically divided as the people they send to Congress.

headline: Byron Wien, Wall Street Seer of the Unexpected, Dies at 90
abstract: A widely read financial analyst, he was known for his annual forecast “Ten Surprises.” But he was fallible, as when he predicted a President Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer. “Never retire” was No. 20. “If you work forever, you can live forever,’’ he explained. “I know there is an abundance of biological evidence against this theory, but I’m going with it anyway.”

headline: As Haley Rises, the Clock Is Ticking on Taking Down Trump
abstract: Her latest debate performance prompted more than $1 million in donations — and drew in Ray Hunt, a billionaire backer. She’s still banking on a breakthrough to catch up to the front-runner.
lead_paragraph: In the Republican nomination contest, even five-inch stilettos might not be enough to overcome the towering figure of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Intense Protests Again Shut Down Midtown Manhattan Streets
abstract: Protesters marched at campuses and through Midtown on Thursday as anger and fear over the war in the Middle East escalated.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war shut down traffic in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night, marking one of the largest actions in New York City in recent weeks.

headline: Letters With Suspicious Substances Sent to Election Offices Spur Alarm
abstract: Letters, some apparently containing fentanyl or other substances, were sent to local election offices in at least four states.
lead_paragraph: Suspicious letters were sent to local elections officials in at least four states, the authorities said on Thursday, including to two locations in Washington State that were said to include white powders containing the toxic drug fentanyl.

headline: Apple Co-Founder Steve Wozniak Is ‘Doing Good’ After Minor Stroke
abstract: The technology pioneer said he was back home in California after a brief stay in a Mexico City hospital.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, suffered a dizzy spell on Wednesday, he took a precautionary trip to the hospital and learned that he had suffered a minor stroke. A day later, he said in an interview, the hospital released him and he was “doing good.”

headline: Crocodile Bites Man. Man Bites Back.
abstract: A surprising tale of Northern Territory chutzpah.
lead_paragraph: It was a story that seemed almost too Australian to be true: The incredible tale of a crocodile attack, foiled by the gnashing of the victim’s jaws.

headline: A Lean and Hungry Look
abstract: Kate Hawkins gives us a run for our money.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Vowel-less Crossword
abstract: Ryan McCarty throws everything but the kitchen sink at us, or rather the ktchn snk.
lead_paragraph: VOWEL-LESS CROSSWORD — This kind of puzzle is growing on me, and today’s grid is extra alluring because of its constructor. Ryan McCarty regularly creates gnarly Saturday crosswords but has never before ventured into the weird world of variety puzzles. The vowel-less crosswords are strange enough that I find myself giggling when I solve one; I can’t help but imagine someone looking over my shoulder at a jumbled sea of consonants, for starters. I also find myself counting letters on my fingers throughout and becoming lost in the process, which is a bit humbling.

headline: ‘Timepiece Gentleman’ Swindled Customers Out of $3 Million, U.S. Says
abstract: Anthony Farrer, 35, who ran a consignment store in Beverly Hills, used money from the sale of customers’ luxury watches to finance a lavish lifestyle for himself, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The businessman collected the luxury watches from customers, promising them that he would sell the watches on consignment and take no more than a 5 percent fee, the authorities said.

headline: Celebrating a Marriage and ‘a Second Chance at Life’
abstract: When Adam Jankelowitz was 2, he received a liver transplant. Decades later, he finally got to thank the donor’s parents in person — at his wedding with Jill Schreider.
lead_paragraph: Neither Jill Meredith Schreider nor Adam Jesse Jankelowitz drinks much alcohol — if any. But on their first date, both were too polite to interrupt the server’s lengthy presentation about the restaurant’s four-page tequila menu.

headline: A Fumbled First Kiss and the Encouragement of a Stranger
abstract: For Daniel Andrew, the third date with Monica Pastor was the charm.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Daniel Kneip Andrew made a deal with himself. He was between law school and his new job at a law firm and he decided to go on five dates. He had some time on his hands and would soon be busy. But after four lackluster meetings, his “expectations were at the lowest point,” Mr. Andrew said.

headline: A Reconnection, Long Distance and Then a Death Bed Wedding
abstract: Michaela Cook, an Australian pop-country singer known as Micks, and Jake Moyle found their way back to each other after losing touch. Soon, they were inseparable.
lead_paragraph: At one time, Michaela Elizabeth Cook and Jake Christopher Moyle were such close friends that he helped her choose her stage name as a singer, Micks. Even then, they would go on to lose touch for two years.

headline: Quotation of the Day: No Regrets or What-Ifs, Just a Goal of Returning Georgetown to the Top
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Never use the word ‘never.’ Never is forever, and that would be the mistake I made. Never comes back to haunt you.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 10, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Danica Roem, the first transgender state senator in the South, misstated the type of meal program supported by Ms. Roem. It’s a universal free school one, not a universal preschool one.

headline: Nothing Could Happen Between Us
abstract: We only had a few weeks together. Why did that allow us to fall so hard so fast?
lead_paragraph: Last year, two days before my 29th birthday, I slipped on ice at the restaurant where I worked and sprained my ankle. Told to stay home and recover, I quickly grew bored and did what any single person with sudden downtime would do — re-downloaded my dating apps. Within 24 hours, I matched with Motorcycle Man.

headline: The Greatest, and Sometimes Silliest, Love of All
abstract: Zeke Smith of “Survivor” and Nico Santos of “Superstore” describe themselves as “cartoon characters that live with one another.”
lead_paragraph: Before Ezekiel Oliver Smith and Michael Nicolas Briones Santos attended the GLAAD Media Awards in Los Angeles in April 2018, Mr. Smith enjoyed his time alone more than his time on dates. He loved his own company, and he had a strong community and a thriving social life. When he was alone, he never felt lonely, and he thought that maybe he was happiest when he was single.

headline: President’s War Against ‘Fake News’ Raises Alarms in South Korea
abstract: He calls fake news an enemy that threatens democracy. Critics of President Yoon Suk Yeol say he is silencing journalists in the name of fighting disinformation.
lead_paragraph: Allies of President Yoon Suk Yeol are attacking what they see as an existential threat to South Korea, and they are mincing few words. The head of Mr. Yoon’s party has called for the death sentence for a case of “high treason.” The culture ministry has vowed to root out what it called an “organized and dirty” conspiracy to undermine the country’s democracy.

headline: Restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. Depictions Rattle Hungary’s Cultural World
abstract: A government campaign against what it calls “homosexual propaganda” is unsettling booksellers and has resulted in the firing of the director of one of the country’s leading museums.
lead_paragraph: When a far-right member of Hungary’s Parliament invited the media three years ago to watch her shred a book of fairy tales that included a gay Cinderella, only one reporter showed up.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A push from the U.S. for Israel to curtail its bombardment of Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military has limited time to carry out its operations in the Gaza Strip before anger among Arabs in the region and global frustration over the rising civilian death toll constrain Israel’s goal of eradicating Hamas, U.S. officials said this week.

headline: In Israel, There Is Grief and There Is Fury. Beneath the Fury, Fear.
abstract: Israelis were shattered on Oct. 7. Can they recover?
lead_paragraph: I landed in Israel and went straight to a funeral.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Rally in New York City
abstract: On the steps of the New York Public Library, demonstrators waved flags and called for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: On the steps of the New York Public Library, demonstrators waved flags and called for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Late Night Recaps the Worst of the G.O.P. Presidential Debate
abstract: “Oh, yeah, there was name-calling, wild rants and personal attacks. Even Trump was watching like, ‘Game recognize game,’” Jimmy Fallon said of the event.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A New York Reporter With a New Perspective
abstract: Luis Ferré-Sadurní’s plans took an unexpected turn when Gov. Kathy Hochul announced an impromptu trip to Israel last month.
lead_paragraph: On a warm Friday afternoon in October, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, who covers New York State politics for The New York Times, scanned the faces of a crowd at a beachfront resort in Puerto Rico. He had hoped to spot Robert Menendez, the New Jersey senator who had been indicted on federal bribery charges — and who was, nevertheless, holding his annual fund-raiser at the hotel.

headline: Why the Bronx Voted Republican for the First Time in a Generation
abstract: Was the Democratic incumbent — called the ‘Benedict Arnold’ of Throgs Neck in an ad — punished for allowing new construction?
lead_paragraph: Even in New York, where so many people pride themselves on their political engagement, hyperlocal elections rarely generate much interest either in terms of buzz or turnout, and they lead to surprising results even less often. But a City Council race on Tuesday managed to bring uncommon suspense. By Wednesday the contest had been called in favor of an X-ray technician who became the first Republican to win public office in the Bronx in nearly 20 years, a place where Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than 10 to 1.

headline: Gadfly Lawyer for Gilgo Beach Families Courts Cameras and Tipsters
abstract: John Ray held news conferences championing the victims for years as law enforcement dragged its feet. Now, he’s a magnet for information.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a classic John Ray news conference last month, with the flamboyant Long Island lawyer stepping up to news cameras, bedecked in a polka dot tie and matching fedora.

headline: Hidden Demon Uncovered in 18th-Century Painting
abstract: “The Death of Cardinal Beaufort” by Sir Joshua Reynolds was originally maligned for its depiction of a fanged figure, which was later painted over.
lead_paragraph: “The Death of Cardinal Beaufort,” a painting by Sir Joshua Reynolds depicting a scene from Shakespeare’s play “Henry VI, Part 2,” stirred controversy when it was first shown in 1789, because of a demon that lurked in its shadows.

headline: U.K. Economy Stagnates as High Interest Rates Take Toll
abstract: The British economy flatlined in the third quarter, entering what is expected to be a protracted period of stagnation.
lead_paragraph: The British economy flatlined in the third quarter, entering what is expected to be a protracted period of stagnation on the cusp of a recession.

headline: The Window Treatments to the Soul
abstract: In her perceptive cultural history, “Eyeliner,” Zahra Hankir shows that liquid versus pencil is only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: In August 2014, I was drinking alone in North London. I Googled an address, then climbed into a cab and gave it to the driver: 30 Camden Square. The car pulled up to a four-story home in a leafy neighborhood, and I immediately felt embarrassed by my macabre mission. But I’d come this far. I got out of the car. The house where Amy Winehouse had died three years earlier was behind a black fence and a white wall. Across the street, there was a clearing with a tree, where a memorial collection had accumulated: photos of the beloved jazz-pop singer, flowers, candles, whiskey bottles.

headline: Innocence, Here and Abroad
abstract: Taboos about what can’t be shown in picture books vary around the world.
lead_paragraph: One of the funniest books I know includes a spread illustrating some of the different positions in which a man and a woman can “fit together.” One configuration involves a space hopper, another a skateboard. Published in 1993, Babette Cole’s “Mummy Laid an Egg!” is a Where-do-babies-come-from? book for young kids that not only tells it like it is (space hopper and all), but also jokes about the outlandish fairy tales desperate parents use to avoid discussing something they really, really don’t want to talk about.

headline: Deadly Fire in Africa’s Richest City Exposed a Secret in Plain Sight
abstract: Officials blame immigrants and liberal housing laws, but a Times investigation found the entrenched problems that turned downtown Johannesburg into a blighted tinderbox.
lead_paragraph: Days after the fire, officials in Johannesburg reached for a well-worn script. They gathered the media for a made-for-television police raid.

headline: Listen to a Wellness-Culture Satire That Delves a Few Levels Deeper
abstract: In Jessie Gaynor’s debut novel, “The Glow,” read by Gabra Zackman, a P.R. rep immerses herself in the woo-woo world of a cultlike “spiritual retreat,” and its enigmatic leader.
lead_paragraph: In a last-ditch effort to impress her boss and not get fired from her public relations job — and to keep chipping away at an overwhelming medical debt — Jane attends a woo-woo wellness retreat in order to bag its enigmatic leader, Cass, as a new client. She’s warned that this retreat may be a cult, but maybe this cult could bring in a lot of money.

headline: This Is Our Music
abstract: The folk musicians Dom Flemons, Kara Jackson, Amythyst Kiah and Tray Wellington discuss the complications of being a Black performer working in a genre now commonly associated with whiteness.
lead_paragraph: The folk musicians Dom Flemons, Kara Jackson, Amythyst Kiah and Tray Wellington discuss the complications of being a Black performer working in a genre now commonly associated with whiteness.

headline: A Garden Shed Becomes a Retreat Filled With Treasures
abstract: At the far end of her London yard, a British interior designer has created a richly adorned work space.
lead_paragraph: The window of the British interior designer Tamsin Saunders’s childhood bedroom looked out onto the South Downs, the rolling hills that culminate abruptly in steep chalk cliffs along England’s southeast coast. The landscape’s rugged beauty instilled in her an affinity for the patterns and textures of the natural world. She spent her early years in the nearby forests, collecting fossils and gathering fragments of wood to decorate with paint.

headline: Black Folk Musicians Are Reclaiming the Genre
abstract: In returning to a songbook that is decades — if not centuries — old, a new generation of performers is expanding the definition of what their traditional art form can be.
lead_paragraph: TRAY WELLINGTON KNOWS that many will take the title of his 2022 album, “Black Banjo,” as an oxymoron. The banjo, and with it an entire body of folk-based music, is now so thoroughly associated with whiteness as to obscure its origins in Black musical tradition. “One of the first things I heard when I started playing banjo was, ‘You’re not supposed to be doing this,’” says Wellington, 24, whose father is Black and mother is white. But for him, playing the banjo has become an act of reclamation.

headline: The Village Home of George Lois, Visionary Adman, Is Listed for $6 Million
abstract: Mr. Lois, who died in 2022, combined two apartments at the Butterfield House in the early 1960s with his wife, Rosemary, who predeceased him by two months.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, as his career as an art director and graphic designer was taking off, George Lois and his wife, Rosemary, set out to find a larger home for their expanding family. The two ultimately fell in love with the brand-new Butterfield House in Greenwich Village, so much so that they ended up buying two apartments there.

headline: Rugs That Ripple Like a Stream
abstract: Plus: a taste for beeswax, rare soaps and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Marco Zanini’s mother is Swedish, but growing up in his father’s native Italy, he never gave his Nordic roots much thought. It wasn’t until he turned 30 that he “became passionate about anything Scandinavian,” says the Milan-based 52-year-old, who served as the creative director of Halston, Rochas and Schiaparelli before launching his namesake ready-to-wear brand in 2019. “I started to spend my summers there, digging into anything that felt and looked Swedish.”

headline: Lahaina’s Immigrants Weigh an Uncertain Future
abstract: Consumed by loss after the August wildfire, many immigrants who have made the historic town their home wonder if they will have to move.
lead_paragraph: It was a nice life, and by the sea.

headline: Sofia Coppola and All the Sad Girls
abstract: The film director helped populate the Internet with sad girls and elevate the cultural allure of feminine ennui. Has she put pop culture in a gilded cage?
lead_paragraph: For 25 years, Sofia Coppola’s films have served as a stylistic manual for how to be sad, or at least disaffected, in our modern age.

headline: The 2023 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books
abstract: Take a peek at this year’s winners.
lead_paragraph: The 10 winners of The New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Award are chosen each year by a rotating panel of three expert judges.

headline: What Israelis Fear the World Does Not Understand
abstract: The writer Yossi Klein Halevi talks about why many Israelis see the ongoing conflict as an “existential war.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, we heard a Palestinian perspective on the conflict. Today, I wanted to have on an Israeli perspective.

headline: I’m a Pollster. Democrats Need Young Voters to Win in 2024.
abstract: Gen Z and millennials aren’t hot on Biden — or government generally. But the Democrats can win them back.
lead_paragraph: Well before the latest Times/Siena poll raised concerns about Joe Biden’s re-election prospects, John Della Volpe was sounding alarms. The Harvard Kennedy School pollster — who worked on Biden’s 2020 campaign — first noticed a change in the way young voters were thinking about politics last spring. For months he has heard dissatisfaction with the two parties and increasing attraction to third party options from young voters in his town halls.

headline: The Tunnels of Gaza
abstract: A maze of tunnels extends below the Gaza Strip, allowing Hamas fighters to stay out of sight and smuggle weapons and goods.
lead_paragraph: A maze of tunnels extends below the Gaza Strip, allowing Hamas fighters to stay out of sight and smuggle weapons and goods.

headline: The Literary Lives of New York City’s Youth
abstract: Archival photos of children’s reading rooms at the New York Public Library over the years.
lead_paragraph: In 1906, Anne Carroll Moore was anointed the first head of the Department of Work With Children at the New York Public Library. There she oversaw the creation of the Central Children’s Room at the newly built flagship on 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue, established story hours and opened the previously locked shelves to all children provided they agreed to sign a pledge that read: “When I write my name in this book I promise to take good care of the books I use in the Library and at home, and to obey the rules of the Library.” By 1913, one third of the titles borrowed from all branches of the N.Y.P.L. were children’s books. To celebrate this year’s Best Illustrated Children’s Books, we looked through archival photos of the library’s children’s reading rooms.

headline: Man vs. Musk: A Whistleblower Creates Headaches for Tesla
abstract: An employee who was fired after expressing safety concerns leaked personnel records and sensitive data about driver-assistance software.
lead_paragraph: A day after Lukasz Krupski put out a fire at a Tesla car delivery location in Norway, seriously burning his hands and preventing a disaster, he got an email from Elon Musk.

headline: What I Believe as a Historian of Genocide
abstract: We know from history that it is crucial to warn of the potential for genocide beforehand rather than condemn it afterward. We still have that time.
lead_paragraph: Israeli military operations have created an untenable humanitarian crisis, which will only worsen over time. But are Israel’s actions — as the nation’s opponents argue — verging on ethnic cleansing or, most explosively, genocide?

headline: Welcome to Hochatown, the Town Created by Airbnb
abstract: In a rural corner of Oklahoma, rustic cabins have been replaced by $1 million rental homes. But even as Airbnb reports record profits, the boom has softened. What will that mean for hosts?
lead_paragraph: The tiny town of Hochatown, on the shores of Broken Bow Lake in the southeast corner of Oklahoma, was created exactly one year ago. And it’s almost entirely thanks to Airbnb.

headline: Gonorrhea Is Becoming Drug Resistant. Scientists Just Found a Solution.
abstract: A new antibiotic, zoliflodacin, is as effective as the current standard of care. Its creation may hasten the arrival of other needed antibiotics.
lead_paragraph: A new antibiotic, the first to be developed in decades, can cure gonorrhea infections at least as effectively as the most powerful current treatment, a large clinical trial has found. The drug, zoliflodacin, is taken as a single dose, and it has not yet been approved for use in any country.

headline: Debut Novels About Women Longing in Obsessive, Sometimes Uncanny Ways
abstract: A lonely Londoner cyber-stalks her married lover and his other paramours; a dispersed Guatemalan American family comes together in crisis; a Mohawk mother navigates life off the rez.
lead_paragraph: Sheena Patel’s I’M A FAN (Graywolf, 203 pp., paperback, $17) is an impolite novel about romantic obsession, set in a liberalized but inequitable sexual economy that rewards the white and rich. The unnamed narrator, a young brown woman living in London, spends much of the book online, fixating on the white, married and much older “man I want to be with” and the other women in his life. Imagining herself meeting one paramour in particular, she wonders, “Would I tell her I know who all her friends are and I watch their stories too, would I tell her I screenshot the photos she takes of herself and study her face so intently sometimes I fear I’ve picked up some facial expressions or tonal inflections from her?”

headline: Germany’s Stifling of Pro-Palestinian Voices Pits Historical Guilt Against Free Speech
abstract: The country’s authorities have banned many protests in the name of fighting antisemitism. Critics say such restrictions are discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: Since fleeing Syria a decade ago, Wafa Mustafa has spoken out for political prisoners at the United Nations, held vigils outside war crimes trials and chanted in solidarity with Iranians protesting their authoritarian government.

headline: A Marine Veteran, 91, Takes Joy in Building Model Ships
abstract: Raymond Daughtry Jr. served in the Korean War. A history buff, he has made model battleships including one of the U.S.S. Arizona, which was sunk at Pearl Harbor.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday, the federal holiday for Veterans Day. We’ll meet a 91-year-old Marine Corps veteran who builds model ships. We’ll also find out why Dr. Ruth Westheimer has just been named New York’s loneliness ambassador.

headline: The G.O.P’s Culture War Shtick Is Wearing Thin With Voters
abstract: It is an approach that repels and alienates far more than it persuades.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party has always leaned on culture war issues to win elections, but for the past three years, since Joe Biden won office in 2020, an aggressive and virulent form of culture war demagoguery has been at the center of Republican political strategy.

headline: American Elections Are About Abortion Now
abstract: This week’s electoral victories for abortion rights offer lessons ahead of next November.
lead_paragraph: With two election cycles after the decision in Dobbs v.
