Jackson Women’s Health Organization under our belts, it cannot be denied: Abortion rights are the dominant issue in American politics. And when supporters of abortion rights — a clear majority of Americans — see a connection between their votes and protecting what was once guaranteed by Roe v. Wade, they are more likely to vote.

headline: Personalized A.I. Agents Are Here. Is the World Ready for Them?
abstract: The age of autonomous A.I. assistants could have huge implications.
lead_paragraph: You could think of the recent history of A.I. chatbots as having two distinct phases.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 10, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of the Showtime series "The Curse."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of the Showtime series "The Curse."

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by John Edgar Wideman, Yasunari Kawabata, Allegra Goodman and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by John Edgar Wideman, Yasunari Kawabata, Allegra Goodman and more.

headline: Liberal Donor Group Targets New York and California House Seats for 2024
abstract: The Democracy Alliance looks to two large blue states — with $10 million aimed at New York alone — as a way for Democrats to retake control of the House.
lead_paragraph: The Democracy Alliance, a powerful network of major liberal donors, will prioritize winning back control of the House for Democrats next year by planning to pour funds into crucial races in New York and California.

headline: How the T. Rex Built Up That Bone-Crushing Bite
abstract: An analysis of nine species of tyrannosaurs documented the evolutionary forces that led to the dinosaur’s reign.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever stood in the presence of a complete fossil of a Tyrannosaurus rex, there is no doubt it was the apex predator of its era. The adults were enormous, with giant skulls and banana-size serrated teeth. The strength of the bite of a full-grown T. rex has been the subject of numerous scientific studies, but mysteries endure about what led to this powerful chomp that ruled the end of the dinosaur era.

headline: Hold That Thought! Here’s Why Being Interrupted Is So Irritating.
abstract: Plus, a few things you can do about it.
lead_paragraph: My parents have been married for 60 years. At this point, they’ve worked out most of their issues. But if my father interrupts my mother, her eyes grow unnaturally bright, and she rises up like a cobra.

headline: Personalized GPTs Are Here, F.T.C. Chair Lina Khan on A.I. Competition, and Mayhem at Apefest
abstract: “On this podcast, we’re automating the haters.”
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains some explicit language.

headline: A Treasure May Be Off the Coast of Colombia, but Who Can Claim It?
abstract: The San José galleon was destroyed in 1708, sinking with goods now worth billions. Colombia’s government is planning a recovery, but not everyone wants to see the shipwreck brought to the surface.
lead_paragraph: When the San José made its final voyage from Seville, Spain, to the Americas in 1706, the Spanish galleon was considered to be one of the most complex machines ever built.

headline: After Averting a Hotel Strike, Las Vegas Still Has a Lot of Work to Do
abstract: Two big unions reached contract agreements with the three largest resort operators ahead of a series of events crucial to the city’s economic rebound.
lead_paragraph: Debra Jefferies, a cocktail waitress at the Horseshoe Las Vegas, spent much of the week wondering whether she would be walking a picket line, as she did in 1984 — the last time there was a major strike among hospitality workers in the city.

headline: Israel Agrees to Short Pauses in Gaza Fighting, and More
abstract: Plus, Joe Manchin’s retirement fuels 2024 rumors, and House Republicans clash over spending.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Your New Music Mixtape
abstract: The Beatles, Megan Thee Stallion and more.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The New York Times, brings you a playlist of five recently released songs worth checking out:

headline: What Adidas Knew About Kanye
abstract: The runaway success of the Yeezy collaboration came at a heavy price.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains some explicit language.

headline: How Tropical Birds Took Over This European Capital, Bringing a ‘Splash of Color’
abstract: After a small group of parakeets were released from a zoo in Brussels in the 1970s, their numbers soared. A population increase has also occurred across the continent.
lead_paragraph: In the lively Brussels neighborhood of Flagey, you can be sure of two things: People will be lined up for fries at Frit Flagey, and pigeons will be nearby, pecking at scraps.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Resume Military Dialogue With Beijing
abstract: The Joint Chiefs chairman said in a letter to his Chinese counterpart that restoring communications was crucial to avoiding misunderstandings.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top military adviser has told China that the United States is open to resuming military-to-military communication that Beijing suspended last year to protest then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan.

headline: Israel’s Ticking Clock
abstract: The country has slowed down to protect its troops and consult allies. But as outrage over the war grows, it’s running out of time to defeat Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The invasion seemed imminent. In the hours after Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, Benjamin Netanyahu appeared ready to send his troops storming into Gaza. Instead, he chose a different strategy.

headline: Rebels Are Notching Key Wins Against the Military Junta in Myanmar
abstract: An offensive by an alliance of armed ethnic groups based in the north has seized key towns, galvanized groups elsewhere and spotlighted the military’s weakness.
lead_paragraph: An alliance of rebel forces in war-torn Myanmar has taken several key towns from the country’s military regime in recent weeks, the most successful challenge to the junta that seized power in a coup in 2021 and the latest evidence of how overstretched the military has become.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A national surge in drive-throughs, an interview with Barbra Streisand and a beginner’s guide to looking at the universe.

headline: A Buttermilk-Brined Chicken in Advance of the Big Bird
abstract: With roasted brussels sprouts and Ina Garten’s lemony puréed potatoes, it’s a nice warm-up for Turkey Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Two weeks from today Thanksgiving will be a memory, so it’s definitely not too early to start your planning for the feast. Order your bird this weekend (birds, in my case). Sketch out a menu with the aid of our Thanksgiving recipe guide. Take an inventory of plates and platters, serving spoons, glasses, knives, forks and napkins. And consider the book of the rules.

headline: Biden and Xi to Seek to Stabilize Relations in California Meeting
abstract: Taiwan, election interference and the war in the Middle East will be on the agenda, officials say. But the leaders will also look for ways to strengthen ties.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China plan to meet in California on Wednesday for a discussion that Mr. Biden’s advisers say is meant to stabilize relations even as it features a host of topics on which the two fiercely competitive countries disagree.

headline: What Ended the Market Rally
abstract: A disappointing Treasury auction and hawkish comments by the Federal Reserve’s chair underscored investor fears about inflation.
lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 was on its way to a ninth straight day of gains on Thursday when investors got hit by a double whammy: a lackluster auction for 30-year Treasury bonds and more hawkish words from Jay Powell, the Fed chair, that prompted a sell-off in stocks and bonds.

headline: Thousands Wait at Ukraine Border After Polish Truckers Blockade It
abstract: As drivers protested what they say is unfair competition from their Ukrainian counterparts, the waiting time at one checkpoint was estimated to be seven days.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of trucks were lined up at several border crossings between Ukraine and Poland on Friday, preventing goods from being delivered to Europe and causing traffic jams lasting several days as Polish truckers blocked checkpoints over what they said was unfair competition from their Ukrainian counterparts.

headline: Prince Harry Can Proceed With a Lawsuit Against Daily Mail Publisher
abstract: A judge rejected an attempt by the publisher to have Harry’s case thrown out, paving the way for the trial to move ahead.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry and other celebrities can proceed with their case against The Daily Mail’s publisher, a British judge ruled on Friday, paving the way for a lengthy court battle over phone hacking and other alleged violations of privacy.

headline: Mac Barnett Has ‘Nothing’ to Talk About
abstract: From mouse holes and doughnut holes to a world without night, these five picture books have it all.
lead_paragraph: Five new picture books all contemplate nothingness. From emptiness to absence to an intangible rhinoceros, we have a whole lot of nothing to discuss, so let’s get to it.

headline: Surviving the Holidays at Work When You Dread the Season
abstract: Just because you’re not feeling festive doesn’t make you the office Grinch.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Higher Contribution Limits Are Coming for 401(k) Retirement Plans
abstract: But, financial advisers note, most people cannot afford to set aside the maximum amount. “This is a system geared for high earners,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Those with enough means will be able to save more money in their workplace retirement accounts next year.

headline: The Betting on the Presidential Election Has Begun
abstract: While two leading prediction markets are fighting regulatory restrictions in court, wagers on politics and economics are still being made.
lead_paragraph: Financial journalists love Wall Street aphorisms. I use them whenever I can.

headline: The Little Match Girl Lives to Tell the Tale
abstract: Two new middle grade novels insist Hans Christian Andersen got it all wrong.
lead_paragraph: One might think Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Little Match Girl,” an 1845 tear-jerker about a poverty-stricken child who freezes to death one snowy New Year’s Eve, would be a hard sell for today’s kids. But the sad tale and its author get a second chance in two new middle grade novels.

headline: For Max Beckmann, Art’s Ironist, Crisis and Rediscovery
abstract: A real vigor emerges in this exhibition at the Neue Galerie, which focuses on the painter’s unflinching Weimar scenes.
lead_paragraph: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea. He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction. Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army. He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres. He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.

headline: Britain’s Prisons Are Dangerously Close to Capacity
abstract: In England and Wales, prisons are almost full, part of a troubling trend that experts say creates unsafe conditions for both those in detention and the staff who manage them.
lead_paragraph: The prison system in England and Wales is dangerously close to capacity, with 98 percent of available spaces full, according to data released by Britain’s Ministry of Justice on Friday that experts said underscored an ongoing crisis within the criminal justice system.

headline: Chris Christie to Travel to Israel
abstract: The trip will be his second to a war zone since opening his presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who is running for president, will go to Israel on Sunday, pressing what he sees as his foreign policy advantage in the race and challenging the other Republicans seeking the White House nomination to join him.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Yossi Klein Halevi
abstract: The Nov. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Yossi Klein Halevi. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts spent most of the week riffing on the third Republican debate, but also took time to discuss former President Trump’s lead over President Biden in an early poll. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: The hosts spent most of the week riffing on the third Republican debate, but also took time to discuss former President Trump’s lead over President Biden in an early poll. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: A Grocery Chain Just Fired Its Self-Checkouts
abstract: They’re bringing the humans back.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to grocery shopping, there seem to be two kinds of people in this world: those who prefer self-checkout, and those who prefer interaction with a human.

headline: Making a Murderer, David Fincher Style
abstract: With “The Killer,” how to build an oddball executioner in seven easy steps.
lead_paragraph: Movie assassins tend to move through the world like chic land sharks: sleek, ruthless, undetectable until it’s too late. But the numerous quirks of the nameless lead portrayed by Michael Fassbender in David Fincher’s latest film, “The Killer” (streaming on Netflix) defy the genre stereotypes of a suave, soulless hit man. Instead, the screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker, adapting from a French graphic novel series by Alexis Nolent, said via Zoom that he deliberately designed his bucket-hat-wearing, McMuffin-eating muse as “the anti-James Bond, almost alien.” He added, “The fact that he doesn’t care whether his drink is shaken or stirred makes sense for his character. We wanted him to hide in plain sight.” Below, how to build an oddball executioner in seven easy steps.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Series Premiere Recap: The Cameras Are Rolling
abstract: Nathan Fielder is not playing himself for once but his core fascinations are still on display.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Fielder’s career to this point has been defined by an obsession with the way people act when they are being filmed. In his Comedy Central series, “Nathan for You,” he came up with outlandish ideas to promote small businesses, often capturing the surreality of human behavior as he instituted his plans. He followed that up with “The Rehearsal,” an HBO show in which he tested the idea that one could “rehearse” for real life scenarios — confrontations with friends or even parenthood — and filmed the results.

headline: America’s top diplomat says ‘far too many Palestinians have been killed.’
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s comments were the latest indication that the Biden administration is increasingly concerned about the civilian death toll in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Friday that “far too many Palestinians have been killed” in Gaza, in the latest indication that the Biden administration is growing increasingly concerned about the civilian death toll under Israel’s bombardment and ground invasion.

headline: Overlooked No More: Ángela Ruiz Robles, Inventor of an Early E-Reader
abstract: Long before Kindles and iPads became popular, Ruiz Robles, a teacher, created her Mechanical Encyclopedia to help lighten her students’ textbook load.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include an evil void, an unshakable sniper and a delightfully demonic cable box.
lead_paragraph: Oh man, how to describe Guillaume Nicloux’s profoundly despairing film. “The Mist” meets “Yellowjackets”? Close, but not sinister enough. I’ll just say this: The movie crushed me.

headline: Grammy Awards 2024: The Full List of Nominees
abstract: Artists, albums and songs competing for trophies at the 66th annual ceremony are being announced on Friday. The show will take place on Feb. 4 at Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: SZA is the top nominee for the 66th annual Grammy Awards with nine nods, all for her album “SOS,” which topped the Billboard 200 for 10 weeks.

headline: ‘Is This Hell?’ The Pilot Accused of Trying to Crash a Plane Tells His Story.
abstract: Joseph Emerson, charged with attempted murder, said he felt trapped in a dream after taking mushrooms. He had feared mental health treatments that could disrupt his career.
lead_paragraph: In the minutes before he boarded an Alaska Airlines flight home last month, Joseph Emerson, a pilot for the airline, texted his wife. He was eager to be home with their two young children and longing to be next to her. “I just want to hold you,” he wrote.

headline: Three Stories of Pregnancy and Birth in Ukraine
abstract: One of the first sounds my son ever heard was an air siren. He is one of the lucky ones.
lead_paragraph: One of the first sounds my son ever heard was an air siren. He is one of the lucky ones.

headline: SZA, ‘Barbie’ Songs and Young Women Lead 2024 Grammy Nominees
abstract: The indie-rock group boygenius, Olivia Rodrigo, Taylor Swift and Victoria Monét are among the most nominated artists for the 66th annual awards in February.
lead_paragraph: SZA, Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo, the indie supergroup boygenius and the eclectic bandleader Jon Batiste are among the top nominees for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, leading a class of contenders dominated by young women.

headline: The Big Number: 98%
abstract: Shares in the co-working company WeWork had already fallen precipitously before it filed for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Shares in the co-working company WeWork had already fallen precipitously before it filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Megan Rapinoe, Emma Hayes and a Women’s Soccer Crossroads
abstract: Rapinoe, who helped define U.S. soccer for a decade, is retiring after this week’s N.W.S.L. final. Hayes, the Chelsea coach, will try to put her stamp on it next.
lead_paragraph: Emma Hayes first met Megan Rapinoe before she was Megan Rapinoe. Or, rather, just as she was becoming Megan Rapinoe. She was not yet a winner of two World Cups, not yet an Olympic champion, not yet captain of her country, not yet a powerful and urgent voice away from the field. Rapinoe was not even a professional soccer player back then, not quite.

headline: Before World Leaders Arrive, San Francisco Races to Clean Up
abstract: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference comes at a pivotal moment for the city as it struggles to rebound from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco had the air this week of teenagers frantically cleaning up after a house party with their parents on the way home.

headline: He’s Gone From Miami, to Celebrity, to Upending Greek Politics
abstract: The rapid ascent of Stefanos Kasselakis, a former Goldman Sachs trader and Greece’s first openly gay party leader, has gripped the nation. But his leadership is dividing the country’s main opposition party.
lead_paragraph: Stefanos Kasselakis was virtually unknown in Greece just six months ago when he was a no-chance election candidate with Syriza, the country’s main opposition party.

headline: Judge Puts Off Decision on Whether to Delay Trump Documents Trial
abstract: Judge Aileen M. Cannon said she would meet with prosecutors and defense lawyers in March to settle on a schedule for the former president’s trial in federal court in Florida.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday put off until at least March the fraught and consequential decision of whether to delay the start of former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of illegally holding on to a trove of highly classified national security secrets after he left office.

headline: A Debate Over the Value of the Humanities
abstract: Readers discuss the value of liberal arts as some universities cut programs. Also: Barbra Streisand’s new memoir.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Trump Testifies, Republicans Attack Judge in Civil Fraud Trial
abstract: Justice Arthur Engoron imposed a narrow gag order on Donald Trump. Right-wing allies are going after the judge on his behalf, through official channels and online.
lead_paragraph: Representative Elise Stefanik, a member of the House Republican leadership and an ally of former President Donald J. Trump, filed an ethics complaint Friday attacking the judge presiding over Mr. Trump’s civil fraud trial, the latest salvo in a right-wing war against the case.

headline: Curtains Down, Bottoms Up: When the Show Ends, the Night’s Just Getting Started
abstract: “Dead Letter No. 9,” “Cocktail Magique” and “Hypnotique” are offering theatergoers a taste of nightlife.
lead_paragraph: A funny thing happened at Dead Letter No. 9, a new performance space in Brooklyn. It was just after 10 p.m. on a Saturday in late October. The evening’s show had finished, but the audience wouldn’t leave — crowding instead into the adjoining bar for cocktails, mocktails and flatbreads.

headline: Grammy Snubs and Surprises: boygenius Thrives, Country and Rap Wither
abstract: A look at the Grammys’ most unexpected and interesting story lines, including Olivia Rodrigo’s intergenerational rock battle with the Rolling Stones.
lead_paragraph: Young women from across genres — along with the Recording Academy’s favorite polymath spoiler Jon Batiste — reigned atop the nominations on Friday for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, to be held Feb. 4 in Los Angeles.

headline: Alarmed by Off-Year Losses, Mainstream Republicans Balk at Abortion Curbs
abstract: Worried about alienating critical blocs of voters, House Republicans from competitive districts are digging in against using spending bills for abortion and contraception restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Republicans across the country suffered a drubbing, dragged down by their opposition to abortion rights in the off-year elections, G.O.P. leaders on Capitol Hill appeared not to have gotten the memo.

headline: Davide Renne, Moschino Creative Director, Dead at 46
abstract: The Italian fashion designer died in Milan this week, just nine days after joining the famed Italian fashion house.
lead_paragraph: Davide Renne, the Italian fashion designer and former head of women’s wear at Gucci, died on Friday in Milan, Italy, nine days after becoming the creative director of Moschino. He was 46.

headline: Review: With Premieres, an Orchestra Keeps Facing Forward
abstract: The American Composers Orchestra, which occupies an essential place in the New York scene, presented an evening of several new works at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Pity the American composer interested in writing orchestral music. Unless your last name is Glass, Reich or Adams, opportunities are destined to come few and far between.

headline: Swiss Museum in Financial Straits Sells Three Cézannes for $53 Million
abstract: Museum Langmatt said the sales were necessary to keep its doors open. Critics had said they violated industry guidelines on when a museum should sell off parts of its collection.
lead_paragraph: Three paintings by Paul Cézanne that a Swiss museum foundation said it had to sell to ward off insolvency fetched $52.5 million, with buyer’s fees, at a Christie’s auction in New York last night.

headline: Rice Krispie Treats in a Plastic Tube, and Other Dances
abstract: In her funny and fidgety way, the choreographer Michelle Ellsworth presents new works that probe the uses and limits of language and movement.
lead_paragraph: “I should try and solve some problems,” the artist Michelle Ellsworth said on Thursday at the Chocolate Factory Theater in Queens, as five dancers buzzed around a hulking wooden contraption that looked like a cross between a kitchen, a playground structure and an MRI machine.

headline: With Manchin Out, Democrats’ Path to Holding the Senate Is Narrow
abstract: While the party will be on defense in every competitive race, Republicans face some messy primaries and a recent history of nominating extreme candidates who have lost key contests.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III said he decided to forgo re-election because he’d accomplished all his goals. But for the Democrats he’s leaving behind in Washington, the work to hold the party’s already slim Senate majority is just beginning.

headline: The Success of Rebecca Yarros and Barbra Streisand’s Mammoth Memoir
abstract: Alexandra Alter talks about her profile of the best-selling author behind “Fourth Wing” and Alexandra Jacobs discusses her review of “My Name is Barbra.”
lead_paragraph: It’s dueling Alexandras on this week’s Book Review podcast.

headline: Antisemitic Hate Crimes Soar in New York City
abstract: Several high-profile incidents are being investigated as hate crimes in New York, where anti-Jewish incidents more than tripled in October compared with last year.
lead_paragraph: The police in New York City are searching for vandals who scrawled “Hamas” and antisemitic graffiti on several Upper East Side apartment buildings last month amid a sharp increase in hate crimes directed at the Jewish community.

headline: 12 Grammy Nominees You Need to Hear
abstract: Some of the best competitions are the under-the-radar ones. Listen to nominated songs by Bettye LaVette, Molly Tuttle, Tainy and more.
lead_paragraph: I’m Jon Pareles, sitting in for Lindsay this week because while she’s on vacation, we couldn’t let the Grammy Awards nominations go by without a playlist.

headline: Marina Cicogna, Italy’s First Major Female Film Producer, Dies at 89
abstract: A countess from an influential Italian family, she charted her own course and produced films by the likes of Pasolini and Zeffirelli.
lead_paragraph: Marina Cicogna, an Italian countess who became her country’s first major female film producer, guiding to the screen celebrated films by Pier Paolo Pasolini, Franco Zeffirelli and Elio Petri, died on Nov. 4 at her home in Rome. She was 89.

headline: TikTokers Mourn the Shutdown of Omegle
abstract: The popular video app was beloved for producing spontaneous encounters, which many content creators turned into followers and profits.
lead_paragraph: Romain Degrave first discovered Omegle three years ago, when he was still in high school. Since its inception in 2009, the online service, which randomly pairs strangers for anonymous video chat sessions, had been connecting users across the globe for moments of discovery, whimsy, cross-cultural exchange and political debate.

headline: Suspect in Jan. 6 Capitol Attack Surrenders After Two-Day Manhunt
abstract: Gregory Yetman, who has been charged in the Jan. 6 attack, surrendered on Friday after fleeing the authorities serving him an arrest warrant.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Yetman, a former member of the New Jersey Army National Guard, surrendered to the authorities on Friday on charges related to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, concluding an intense manhunt.

headline: After a Scare, Croatian Authorities Declare Coca-Cola Products Safe
abstract: After worries that a man had been sickened by his soft drink, the authorities said that it was an isolated incident and not a cause for wider concern.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola brand beverages have been deemed safe to drink in Croatia, government officials said on Thursday, following illnesses in the country that had raised fears that the bottles had been contaminated.

headline: Victoria Monét on Her 7 Grammy Nods (and One for Her Toddler)
abstract: The pop and R&B singer and songwriter has long aspired to be a solo star. Now she’s landed the second-most nominations this year, and is “trying to wrap my head around it.”
lead_paragraph: On the morning of this year’s Grammy Award nominations, Victoria Monét, the pop and R&B singer and songwriter, had the champagne ready no matter what.

headline: I Earn Much More Than My Husband. Shouldn’t He Get a Better Job?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to address financial imbalances in a marriage.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been happily married for more than 10 years, and my husband is wonderful — he’s my best friend and a great partner in almost every respect. The only major issue is that, while I earn a relatively modest salary, I still make more than 80 percent of the household income and have done so for almost all of our time together, though I’ve never consented to this. He has a small business that he has never tried to properly expand, and because of where we live, he can only work remotely, which is not easy.

headline: Blinken Stresses Need for Humanitarian Aid for Gaza
abstract: During a trip to New Delhi, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that “far too many Palestinians have been killed” in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: During a trip to New Delhi, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that “far too many Palestinians have been killed” in Gaza.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, November 12, 2023
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: F.B.I. Seizes Eric Adams’s Phones as Campaign Investigation Intensifies
abstract: Days after a raid at Mr. Adams’s chief fund-raiser’s home, federal agents took the mayor’s phones and iPad, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
lead_paragraph: F.B.I. agents seized Mayor Eric Adams’s electronic devices early this week in what appeared to be a dramatic escalation of a criminal inquiry into whether his 2021 campaign conspired with the Turkish government and others to funnel money into its coffers.

headline: Pittsburgh Museum Apologizes for Handling of Islamic Art Show
abstract: The Frick Pittsburgh, which postponed an exhibition featuring 10 centuries of Islamic art after the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, apologized for the offense its leader’s explanation caused.
lead_paragraph: The head of the Frick Pittsburgh apologized Thursday for the way she handled the postponement of an exhibition of Islamic art, which had been scheduled to open this month before museum leaders decided to delay it because of the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Taylor Swift Takes Her Eras Tour Global, Shaking Argentina
abstract: The singer-songwriter began her Eras Tour outside North America, and some Swifties in Argentina camped out for more than five months.
lead_paragraph: On May 31, Florencia Romeo slept in a tent outside Argentina’s largest stadium with her girlfriend and her sister. They had heard rumors that Taylor Swift might be coming to Buenos Aires, and they wanted to be first in line.

headline: Rabbis From Across the Globe Flock to New York for Prayer — and Hope
abstract: Participants in an annual conference of rabbis visited the burial place of the spiritual leader of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement.
lead_paragraph: The rabbis came from Israel and Ukraine, from Azerbaijan and France, from Thailand and farther still, as thousands of Jews filed into a graveyard in Queens under a sea of black hats.

headline: Conservative Thinkers Didn’t Create Trumpism
abstract: But Trumpism recreated them.
lead_paragraph: There is a story that professional ideamongers like to tell about political history that gives pride of place to their own work. It’s a story that usually begins with some small tribe of writers or intellectuals who come up with a set of theories that describe the world in a new way. Marginal at first, their arguments eventually break out into the wider sphere of campaigns and candidates, capturing one or the other major political coalition and finally emerging as the consensus of an age.

headline: The Egyptian Rapper Wegz Wants to Take Arabic Hip-Hop Worldwide
abstract: The 25-year-old has become a streaming star without releasing a full album. He just wrapped his first shows in the United States, and hopes to take his music even further.
lead_paragraph: On the ninth stop of his first world tour, the Egyptian rapper Wegz finished soundcheck at the Howard Theater in Washington, D.C., and relaxed on a worn black leather couch wearing a gray Carhartt fleece jacket and cream New Balance 990 sneakers. In his unflashy attire, passers-by might not have recognized one of the biggest artists in the emerging Arabic music scene calmly awaiting his set time.

headline: Yellen Says U.S. Wants ‘Healthy’ Economic Ties With China
abstract: The Treasury secretary said she had pressed her Chinese counterpart on China’s export controls and cautioned against supporting Russia.
lead_paragraph: The United States and China agreed on Friday that they would not seek to “decouple” their economies and pledged to take steps to improve the business climates for American and Chinese companies operating in both countries, a significant step toward thawing relations between the world’s largest economies.

headline: Gaza City Hospitals Are Caught in Deadly Crossfire
abstract: Battling Hamas fighters, Israeli forces are “closing in” on hospitals where thousands of people are stranded, while the chief U.S. diplomat says “far too many Palestinians have been killed.”
lead_paragraph: Gaza City’s hospitals were increasingly under siege on Friday, with hundreds of seriously ill and wounded patients and thousands of displaced people stranded on hospital grounds as intense, close-quarters combat between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged around them.

headline: Street Battles Rage in Gaza City Ruins, as Residents Flee on Foot
abstract: The Biden administration, which has pressed Israel to do more to safeguard civilian lives, said Israel had agreed to steps to help people flee the northern Gaza Strip and receive aid.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers and armored vehicles have engaged Hamas fighters in days of running gun battles in Gaza City, fighting through rubble-filled streets and blasted-out buildings for control of the Gaza Strip’s largest urban center and the militants’ main stronghold.

headline: Lara Parker, a Memorable Witch on ‘Dark Shadows,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Her three-dimensional portrayal of a character who was also a vampire helped the Gothic soap opera develop a cult following.
lead_paragraph: Lara Parker, who found small-screen fame in the 1960s and ’70s as a beguiling and vengeful witch on the popular Gothic soap opera “Dark Shadows,” died on Oct. 12 at her home in Topanga, Calif. She was 84.

headline: PinkPantheress Leaves the Bedroom for the Wider Pop World
abstract: A conversation about the 22-year-old singer, songwriter and producer’s new album and the art of sampling.
lead_paragraph: The British producer, singer and songwriter PinkPantheress, 22, emerged during the pandemic with a hushed and nostalgic play on dance music, turning canny samples from the club and beyond into intimate, original bedroom pop.

headline: Moody’s Changes U.S. Credit Outlook to ‘Negative’
abstract: Moody’s reaffirmed America’s credit rating at the highest AAA level but expressed concern about the nation’s fiscal trajectory amid congressional dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: The outlook on the credit rating of the United States was changed  to “negative” from “stable” on Friday by the ratings firm Moody’s, which pointed to the nation’s worsening fiscal position and political polarization as long-term concerns for America’s economy.

headline: Pastor Indicted With Trump in Georgia Asks Evangelical Supporters for Help
abstract: The Rev. Stephen C. Lee says he was pastoring to people in Georgia after the 2020 election. The indictment says he was pressuring an elections worker.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Stephen C. Lee is one of the lesser-known figures indicted with former President Donald J. Trump in Fulton County, Ga., on charges of unlawfully conspiring to keep Mr. Trump in power after the 2020 election.

headline: boygenius on Its First Grammy Nominations and Keeping Rock Fun
abstract: Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus earned six nods for their debut LP, “The Record.” Texts from fellow nominees Taylor Swift and Billie Eilish followed.
lead_paragraph: For boygenius, the indie-rock supergroup with a penchant for neckties and introspective songs, this fall has held the kind of firsts that prove a rock band has turned into a phenomenon: its first arena show at a Madison Square Garden packed with fans chanting every lyric, its first performance at the Hollywood Bowl, and soon, its first feature on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Harvard, Columbia and Penn Pledge to Fight Antisemitism on Campus
abstract: The universities are trying to address criticism by banning pro-Palestinian student groups, condemning slogans and starting task forces to address antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, university presidents have been battered by a vocal cohort of alumni and faculty members who have accused them of not being strong enough in their denunciations of antisemitism in the wake of the Hamas attack on Israel.

headline: Family in ‘Take Care of Maya’ Documentary Is Awarded $261 Million
abstract: A jury found that a Florida hospital, which had suspected child abuse, was liable for charges including medical negligence and false imprisonment in its treatment of Maya Kowalski in 2016.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Florida ordered a hospital to pay $261 million in damages to a family after the parents were accused of abusing their daughter and barred from seeing her during months of treatment. Their story was chronicled in the Netflix documentary “Take Care of Maya.”

headline: Hollywood Actors to Start Voting Tuesday on Contract Deal
abstract: The SAG-AFTRA board voted on Friday to send the agreement with studios to its members for a ratification process that will end in early December.
lead_paragraph: The union that represents movie and television actors said on Friday that its 76-member national board had voted with 86 percent support to send a tentative contract with studios to members for ratification.

headline: Florida-Bound Plane Had Missing and Damaged Windowpanes After Takeoff
abstract: Passengers aboard the plane, which took off from London, told investigators that the cabin had seemed noisier and colder than they were used to.
lead_paragraph: A plane flying from London to Orlando, Fla., last month was forced to turn around because some windowpanes were missing or damaged, startling passengers who had reported hearing roaring sounds inside the cabin, the authorities said.

headline: ‘These babies, these ladies, these old people’: Macron mourns civilian deaths and urges an Israeli cease-fire.
abstract: Against a backdrop of mounting international outrage over civilian casualties as Israel wages war on Hamas, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Friday called on Israel to stop the killing in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Against a backdrop of mounting international outrage over civilian casualties as Israel wages war on Hamas, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Friday called on Israel to stop the killing in Gaza.

headline: Storm Warning
abstract: Blake Slonecker delivers a relaxing but cerebral themeless.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle has a little something for the neophyte, and a little something for the grizzled vet. Anyone interested in a juicy solve that’s vibrant and likely to build your confidence rather than tear it to shreds? Well, walk this way.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Switzerland, Buying a Home Is Out of Reach
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It’s beyond luxury. Two kids, a house, a garden, two cars — I don’t know anybody who has that.”

headline: Louisiana Must Finalize New Voting Map by January, Federal Appeals Court Says
abstract: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit agreed with a lower-court ruling that the latest congressional map very likely diluted the power of Black voters.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday agreed with a lower-court ruling that Louisiana’s latest congressional map very likely violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the power of Black voters, and ordered the state to finalize a new map by Jan. 15.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 11, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the U.S. Space Force misspelled the surname of a member of the U.S. Space Force. He is Lt. Col. Galen Thorp, not Thorpe.

headline: No, 11,200 Climate Refugees Aren’t Heading to Australia
abstract: Low-lying Tuvalu has reached a deal with its large Pacific neighbor to address the challenge of rising oceans, but it is not planning to pack up and go.
lead_paragraph: The Pacific island nation of Tuvalu once comprised 11 islands. It is now down to nine flecks of land totaling less than 10 square miles, which, like their lost siblings before them, risk gradually being eaten away by the rising tides of the world’s warming oceans.

headline: Life in Gaza City: Privation, Rationing and Desperate Fear
abstract: Mohammad Matar, a civil engineer, and his family have remained in the city even as Israeli ground forces continue their relentless assault.
lead_paragraph: For years, Mohammad Matar worked on constructing pipelines that moved water across the Gaza Strip — from northern Beit Lahia to southern Rafah. Now, he can barely get access to water himself.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Portraits From a Photo Shoot Far, Far Away
abstract: For an article about people who plan to send their remains to space, The New York Times Magazine arranged a remote-photography process. The sessions captured an astral mood.
lead_paragraph: While some people look up into the night sky and wonder what’s out there, Guy Pignolet, an 81-year-old space educator, can be confident that he will one day be part of the answer. After he dies, Mr. Pignolet plans to have his ashes launched into space.

headline: When Aviation Was More Than the News
abstract: The Times didn’t just cover the pioneering aviators of the early 20th century. It sponsored their flights.
lead_paragraph: In charting the flight of the battery-powered CX300 aircraft recently, The New York Times was back where it has spent a lot of time over the last 120 years: in the clouds.

headline: Two Young Democratic Stars Collide Over Israel and Their Party’s Future
abstract: Representing neighboring districts in the Bronx, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ritchie Torres have staked sharply divergent positions on the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: They are among the brightest political stars rising from New York. They were born just months apart, 40 years after the founding of Israel.

headline: How a Friend of the High Line Spends His Sundays
abstract: Alan van Capelle said he was “living the dream” with his husband and two children, a life he once thought was out of reach for someone like him.
lead_paragraph: Alan van Capelle spends a lot of time trying to foster equality and a sense of belonging as the executive director of Friends of the High Line, the nonprofit that oversees the park’s operations.

headline: They Arrived Homeless. Now They’re Helping Others Make New York Home.
abstract: At a makeshift welcome center in the Lower East Side, those who came before help those who are new, and a community begins to grow.
lead_paragraph: The migrants started lining up by dawn. After trekking to New York from across Latin America, young people and families had made their way to an elementary school on the Lower East Side to be greeted, in Spanish, by immigrants who had come before them.

headline: Mint, the Budgeting App, Is Going Away. Here Are Some Alternatives.
abstract: Finding a money app that works best for you requires personal testing. We asked popular competitors to Mint why you should try their offerings.
lead_paragraph: The demise of Mint, the beloved budgeting app, has caused its millions of users to consider alternatives. That makes it as good a time as any for everyone to consider a money management tool.

headline: Major Pro-Palestinian March Staged in London as Police Ramp Up Security
abstract: The gathering drew an estimated 300,000 people, the police said, making it one of the largest protests in Britain in recent years. Before it began, far-right demonstrators scuffled with officers.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through central London in a huge pro-Palestinian demonstration on Saturday, a tense day in which the police battled with a small right-wing group to keep order on some city streets.

headline: How a Decaying Warship Beached on a Tiny Shoal Provoked China’s Ire
abstract: After multiple maritime clashes, the Philippines invited journalists on a mission to resupply the Sierra Madre. A reporter for The Times was given rare access.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, it has been an unlikely flashpoint in the South China Sea: a rusty, World War II-era ship beached on a tiny reef that has become a symbol of Philippine resistance against Beijing.

headline: Chapter 4: The Wedding
abstract: It was the moment two families had long waited for. But Arti feared it could be the end of her dreams for a career.
lead_paragraph: For Indian families, a modest wedding is an oxymoron. No matter how meager a household’s earnings, no expense can be spared. It was no different for Arti Kumari’s parents, despite their limited means as an NGO worker and a subsistence farmer.

headline: Three Days That Changed the Thinking About Black Women’s Health
abstract: Forty years ago, Black women convened to discuss how race affected their health. They helped reimagine what medical care could look like.
lead_paragraph: On June 24, 1983, Byllye Avery welcomed busloads of Black women to the campus of Spelman College in Atlanta. She was in a state of disbelief. The women had traveled from Mississippi, New York, Pennsylvania — even as far away as California — for a three-day event billed as the First National Conference on Black Women’s Health Issues.

headline: Inside Facebook’s Dangerous Battle Between Integrity and Engagement
abstract: Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” draws on 25,000 pages of internal documents to reveal the company’s tumultuous inner workings — and their devastating impact on humanity.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome departure from the subgenre of stories about Facebook, Jeff Horwitz’s “Broken Code” doesn’t open in a Harvard dorm room. Expanding on the revelations of his blockbuster “Facebook Files” series of articles in The Wall Street Journal, the book focuses squarely on the past decade. It begins when Facebook is already a global behemoth with a user count in the billions — and a company ethos that has yet to account for its capacity to effect enormous social and political change.

headline: One Year in the Infuriating and Humiliating Search for a Job in South Africa
abstract: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
lead_paragraph: This is a part of a series on how Africa’s youth boom is changing the continent, and beyond.

headline: Florida Man Chases Poachers
abstract: In “Gator Country,” Rebecca Renner goes beyond the stereotypes to pay tribute to her beloved Everglades.
lead_paragraph: The journalist Rebecca Renner still lives in Central Florida, where she grew up playing in a swamp near her house and had her first close encounter with a full-size alligator at age 7.

headline: The Members of This ‘Manuscripts Club’ Were Obsessed With Medieval Books
abstract: The bibliophiles in Christopher de Hamel’s lavishly illustrated book ensured the survival of medieval texts over centuries.
lead_paragraph: A harrowing passage in Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall” describes the ransacking of Cardinal Wolsey’s house in 1529 by the Dukes of Norfolk and Sussex, a pillage that included recklessly emptying Wolsey’s chests of their medieval books: “The texts are heavy to hold in the arms, and awkward as if they breathed; their pages are made of slunk vellum from stillborn calves, reveined by the illuminator in tints of lapis and leaf-green.”

headline: A Gamy Picaresque for the Age of the Notes-App Apology
abstract: In Lexi Freiman’s “The Book of Ayn,” a canceled novelist drifts from New York parties to L.A. parties to a commune in Greece, spreading the gospel of Ayn Rand.
lead_paragraph: A bucket of moldy jam stored in the walk-in storage closet of an L.A. cafe; famous men masturbating in front of young women; misappropriated campaign funds: Such real-life cancellation plots provide the unspoken backdrop to Lexi Freiman’s angular, careening latest, “The Book of Ayn,” which charts a writer’s undoing after she publishes an opioid crisis satire, written from a rent-free pied-à-terre with a view of the Empire State Building. This is a gamy picaresque for the age of the notes-app apology: a cutting novel of ego and its death, Freudian yearning, Randian Hollywood, scatological epiphany and the vileness of the pursuit of a career in letters.

headline: Doechii Stays Balanced With 24-Hour Spas and a Good Girls Night
abstract: This 25-year-old rapper is ready for a “new era” inspired by movies and theater. But first: a tour with Doja Cat. Here’s what keeps her on track.
lead_paragraph: Before the 25-year-old rapper and singer Doechii began opening for Doja Cat on the Scarlet Tour last month, she had a high-profile warm-up gig in Los Angeles, performing before Beyoncé on her Renaissance World Tour.

headline: Hear the Dance: Audio Description Comes of Age
abstract: Recent experiments in describing dance, like the film “Telephone,” approach it not just as an accessibility service but as a space for artistic exploration.
lead_paragraph: The dancer Krishna Washburn remembers attending a performance years ago by a well-known modern dance company at a large New York City theater. Washburn, who is blind, opted to experience the show with audio description: in this case, a track that narrated the dance as it was happening, delivered through a headset.

headline: They Wanted to Get Sober. They Got a Nightmare Instead.
abstract: Arizona spent $1 billion on addiction treatment, much of it fraudulent, officials said. Scores of Native Americans who sought help are still struggling with untreated addiction — and some died in rehab.
lead_paragraph: The white vans were the first thing people noticed.

headline: A Black Woman’s Rise in Architecture Shows How Far Is Left to Go
abstract: They have worked for decades to make their way in a profession that remains overwhelmingly white and male, but there are signs of change.
lead_paragraph: When Kimberly Dowdell becomes president of the American Institute of Architects next month, her ascent will be noteworthy. Ms. Dowdell, an architect in a profession that is overwhelmingly white and male, is a Black woman, the first to fill the post in the group’s 166-year history.

headline: How Millions of Borrowers Got $127 Billion in Student Loans Canceled
abstract: The Biden administration may have been blocked from canceling debt for tens of millions of borrowers by the Supreme Court, but it has still managed to eliminate billions in education debt.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s $400 billion plan to forgive up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt for 43 million borrowers, the prospect of substantive debt relief appeared to vanish.

headline: Overwhelmed With Writing Your Vows? A Professional Wordsmith Could Help.
abstract: In recent years, social media has helped increase demand in this new wedding vendor category. “Vows have gone viral,” one expert said, “and there’s greater attention to the moments that go wrong.”
lead_paragraph: The 200 guests at Rachel Mumford’s backyard wedding in Malibu, Calif., were suddenly on their feet, clapping, giving her an unexpected ovation. Forty-eight hours earlier, she probably wouldn’t have felt as calm or confident.

headline: My Landlord Disappeared With the Security Deposit. How Do I Get It Back?
abstract: State law requires landlords to return security deposits within 14 days.
lead_paragraph: Q: After selling our apartment in Brooklyn, my family and I rented for 14 months from an owner in our building. We thought we had a good relationship with her and took excellent care of the apartment. But when we moved out, she returned only a small portion of our security deposit and said she was withholding the rest while she assessed some “questionable” issues. All were either her responsibility, like changing the locks, or the building’s. She never told us where the security deposit was being held, nor produced an invoice showing how the deposit was used to address any issues. We’ve heard nothing since August, despite our attempts to reach her. We are now living overseas and are out thousands of dollars. What can we do?

headline: They Left Gaza to Work in Israel. Now They’re Stranded.
abstract: Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on October 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on October 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home.

headline: Sweeping Raids, Giant Camps and Mass Deportations: Inside Trump’s 2025 Immigration Plans
abstract: If he regains power, Donald Trump wants not only to revive some of the immigration policies criticized as draconian during his presidency, but expand and toughen them.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is planning an extreme expansion of his first-term crackdown on immigration if he returns to power in 2025 — including preparing to round up undocumented people already in the United States on a vast scale and detain them in sprawling camps while they wait to be expelled.

headline: Ohio Voted to Protect Abortion Rights. Could Florida Be Next?
abstract: A coalition of groups collecting petition signatures for a ballot protecting abortion rights says its fund-raising got a boost after the Ohio results.
lead_paragraph: Since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, campaigns to protect abortion rights have galvanized voters in state after state. It has become Democrats’ most successful issue ahead of an uncertain 2024 election cycle — and their biggest hope, especially after voters in Ohio approved on Tuesday a measure to enshrine abortion rights in the State Constitution.

headline: They Ran Into a Bomb Shelter for Safety. Instead, They Were Slaughtered.
abstract: Hamas’s assault on southern Israel began with a barrage of rockets, sending scores of people into roadside refuges. Then gunmen came to hunt them.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.

headline: Russia Glorifies Its World War II Dead. He Tries to Give Them Decent Burials.
abstract: Konstantin Dobrovolsky searches for the remains of soldiers left to rot on the battlefield almost 80 years ago. Then he had to bury his own son, who fought in a war he despises.
lead_paragraph: The skeletons are never far away from Konstantin A. Dobrovolsky. Sometimes he sleeps above them in a tiny olive-green trailer in the woods. The people they might once have been appear in his dreams.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Nov. 4-10
abstract: A European stroll might have helped you find this week’s hardest word.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: The Only People Who Understand What a Caregiver Goes Through
abstract: Mentoring programs bring together those just starting to care for family members with dementia and those who have been coping for some time.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday mornings, Julia Sadtler and Debora Dunbar log onto Zoom to talk about caring for their husbands with Alzheimer’s disease, in hourlong conversations that are usually informative, sometimes emotional and always supportive.

headline: For Both Trudeau and Biden, Polls Suggest an Uphill Political Path
abstract: The economy, and particularly inflation, has soured voters on both leaders, polls indicate, though well in advance of upcoming votes.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and President Biden next meet, they will have something to commiserate over: their dismal standings in polls.

headline: Our Merch, Ourselves
abstract: What do the bands and brands whose merchandise we buy say about who we are and what we value?
lead_paragraph: If you want to recreate the 1960s winged eyeliner that Cailee Spaeny wears in “Priscilla,” you’ll have to do so without the aid of the limited-edition makeup kit produced by the film’s studio, A24. It’s sold out. Ditto the dark gray sweatshirt with tonal “Priscilla” embroidery across the front. You can, however, still purchase a baby-doll T-shirt bedizened with the film’s title in rhinestones. And the heart-shaped locket by the jewelry designer J. Hannah, inspired by the one Priscilla wears in the movie, which was in turn inspired by one Priscilla Presley actually wore, is still available, in sterling silver ($400) or 14-karat gold ($1,280).

headline: ‘We Cannot Kill Our Way Out of This Endeavor’
abstract: The United States has leverage as Israel’s most important ally and diplomatic protector. It needs to use it to end this war.
lead_paragraph: With the Middle East spiraling in the wrong direction, with too many fresh graves in Israel and Palestine alike, with children maimed and killed in Gaza in staggering numbers, with anger and bigotry spinning away to poison hearts around the world, the last, best hope may be President Biden.

headline: Why Aren’t More People Marrying? Ask Women What Dating Is Like.
abstract: Harping on people to get married from up in the ivory tower fails to engage with reality in the dating trenches.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Camino had been in a relationship for two years when she found out she was pregnant. The father, whom she met while they were both working at a restaurant in Times Square, was initially excited. But he had been using drugs lately and had been fired from his last four jobs; when she ventured that she was scared she might wind up raising the child alone, he got defensive and walked out. She and her daughter now live in Florida with her parents, and he is not a part of their lives.

headline: Tough Decisions About Dementia and End-of-Life Care
abstract: Readers discuss Sandeep Jauhar’s guest essay about dementia and advance directives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Trump-Biden Rematch Is the Election We Need
abstract: How else are we going to resolve the questions that hang over our democracy?
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden versus Donald Trump is not the choice America wants. But it is the choice we need to face.

headline: Should Joe Manchin Run for President?
abstract: If current polling holds, it’s not running an alternative to Biden that seems most likely to put Trump back in the presidency.
lead_paragraph: In the emotional life of the liberal mediasphere, there was so little space between the release of the New York Times/Siena poll showing President Biden losing to Donald Trump handily across a range of swing states (doom! doom!) and the Democratic overperformance in Tuesday’s elections (sweet relief!) that one of the striking features of the polling passed with relatively little comment.

headline: Violence by West Bank Settlers Cannot Be Ignored
abstract: The Palestinians there whom I spoke to by telephone said people were aware of how terrible the consequences of an uprising would be.
lead_paragraph: After the well over 1,000 Israelis killed on Oct. 7, and the thousands more Palestinians in Gaza killed in the war against Hamas, it may appear unseemly to focus on the relatively small and sadly familiar clashes between settlers and Palestinians in the West Bank. But it would be a mistake to overlook the danger of the escalation in settler violence over the past month.

headline: Ivanka Trump, Witness for the Prosecution
abstract: While the country debates Donald Trump’s real net worth, should we also ask if his daughter was anything more than window dressing for him?
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost three years since, on Jan. 6, 2021, Ivanka Trump, swaddled in a black coat, stood beside her father inside a tent on the Ellipse in Washington, D.C. Until her walk up the steps of the New York State Supreme Courthouse on Wednesday, that was one of her last public family appearances in an official capacity.

headline: Drawings of a City Divided: New York Reacts to the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: To many New Yorkers, the war feels extremely close to home.
lead_paragraph: I started drawing New York over 30 years ago when I first arrived in the city as a visitor from London. Since then, I have witnessed the city as its architecture and population changed. I saw the city coping with loss and recorded scenes at ground zero in the months after the Sept. 11 attacks. And now I have seen the new trauma of a city divided.

headline: Parents Are People
abstract: What happens when you realize the people in charge don’t have the answers.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you realize the people in charge don’t have the answers.

headline: Russia Launches Missile at Kyiv for First Time in Weeks, Ukraine Says
abstract: The attack was part of an overnight barrage that suggested Moscow was testing air defenses before another potential winter campaign against Ukraine’s energy infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military said on Saturday that it had shot down a Russian ballistic missile hurtling toward Kyiv, the first such attack on the capital in weeks, while cities across the country were targeted by a Russian air barrage that damaged several buildings.

headline: Two Stories That Unfold Through Letters
abstract: An editor recommends “84, Charing Cross Road” and “The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society.”
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Could Get 100 Years in Prison. What Is Fair?
abstract: The founder of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange was found guilty of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: After a monthlong trial and about four hours of deliberation, a jury convicted the FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy last week. He had been accused of stealing billions of dollars from his cryptocurrency exchange’s customers and investors, funneling the money into his investments and extravagant spending.

headline: Texas Bishop Loudly Critical of the Pope Is Removed
abstract: Bishop Joseph Strickland was a highly prominent figure among traditionalist American Catholics who see Pope Francis as too liberal.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis fired on Saturday a bishop in Texas who was one of his loudest American critics within the Catholic Church, a highly rare dismissal that appeared to reflect the growing rift between the Vatican and a more conservative wing of the church.

headline: Wegovy Is Shown to Reduce Risk of Heart Attacks and Strokes in Some Patients
abstract: The results of a large clinical trial suggest the obesity medication could also change the landscape of cardiovascular care.
lead_paragraph: A pivotal new study suggests that the weight loss drug Wegovy cut the risk of heart attack, stroke or death from cardiovascular issues by 20 percent among overweight or obese people with heart disease — a striking benefit that could change the standard of care for these patients.

headline: Iran’s president visits Saudi Arabia for the first time since the two mended ties.
abstract: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit on the war in Gaza, his first visit since the regional rivals agreed early this year to restore diplomatic ties after years of hostility.
lead_paragraph: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit on the war in Gaza, his first visit since the regional rivals agreed early this year to restore diplomatic ties after years of hostility.

headline: ‘The Climate’s No Good’: The Hunt for White Truffles Gets Pricier
abstract: Climate change in Italy has come for one of the world’s most sought-after delicacies. Foodies will probably see the impact when the check comes.
lead_paragraph: Primo and Scilla led the way deeper into the woods near Amandola, in central Italy. Across a gurgling brook, up a muddy slope, over mossy tree limbs, through a tangle of brambles and vines, the dogs covered acres of terrain. For nearly three hours, their olfactory senses were on high alert for white truffles, a delicacy with soaring prices, in large part because they are under extreme threat by climate change.

headline: Peter S. Fischer, Who Helped Create ‘Murder, She Wrote,’ Dies at 88
abstract: He spent many years as a writer and producer of the hit mystery series starring Angela Lansbury. He later wrote his own mystery novels, set in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Peter S. Fischer, a creator, writer and producer of “Murder, She Wrote,” the long-running television series that starred Angela Lansbury as a mystery novelist and amateur sleuth, died on Oct. 30 in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 88.

headline: The Pies Are Here
abstract: Caramel apple pie, pumpkin pie with pepitas, pecan slab pie and lemon pudding pie with honey and ginger. Oh, and a cranberry cheesecake tart.
lead_paragraph: The pies are here! Four words, so much joy (and butter). This year’s batch of beauties from Claire Saffitz (above) is particularly lovely, both in the eating and the sharing: pumpkin pie with pepitas, lemon cream pie with honey and ginger, caramel apple pie, pecan slab pie and a cranberry cheesecake tart. She also has a clever new pie dough recipe, in case you can’t pull yourself or your family from one of our many other fantastic Thanksgiving pie recipes. Push up those sleeves, cube that butter and flour that bench: It’s pie time.

headline: David Ferry, Poet and Translator Who Won Acclaim Late in Life, Dies at 99
abstract: After nearly 40 years as a professor, he began a new career writing poems and translating classics. He won a National Book Award when he was 86.
lead_paragraph: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass. He was 99.

headline: Trump Asks Judge to Televise Federal Election Trial
abstract: The request to Judge Tanya Chutkan was short on legal arguments and long on bluster, and it faces an uphill battle as federal courts generally prohibit cameras.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have told a judge that she should permit his trial on federal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election to be televised live from the courtroom.

headline: Right-Wing Counterprotesters Clash With Police in London
abstract: Dozens were arrested after skirmishes broke out between far-right demonstrators and the London police near a pro-Palestinian march that coincided with Armistice Day.
lead_paragraph: Dozens were arrested after skirmishes broke out between far-right demonstrators and the London police near a pro-Palestinian march that coincided with Armistice Day.

headline: Icelandic Town Evacuated as Earthquakes Portend Volcanic Eruption
abstract: Officials said that “the likelihood of a volcanic eruption” in the near future was “considerable” in Grindavik, home to about 4,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Icelandic authorities declared a state of emergency and evacuated a town of about 4,000 people on Saturday after hundreds of earthquakes were detected overnight, signaling an increased likelihood of a volcano erupting in the country’s southwestern Reykjanes Peninsula.

headline: Hezbollah’s Leader Says Fighters Will Keep Up Pressure on Israel
abstract: As clashes continue along Israel’s volatile border with Lebanon, Hassan Nasrallah said his group was now trying to hit targets deeper inside Israel with newer and more advanced weapons.
lead_paragraph: The head of Lebanon’s powerful Hezbollah militia, Hassan Nasrallah, said on Saturday that his group intended to keep up pressure on Israel and claimed that it was striking deeper into Israeli territory with powerful new weapons.

headline: Iran and Saudi Arabia, Regional Rivals, Call for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: The leaders of both Islamic countries appeared to put aside their historical animosities at a summit to present a united stand against Israel’s bombardment of the strip after Hamas’s attack.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of Iran and Saudi Arabia, regional rivals who restored diplomatic ties this year, met in Riyadh on Saturday at a summit where they called for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza and unconditional delivery of humanitarian aid to the enclave, which Israeli forces have besieged since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.

headline: Karen Davis, Who Battled for the Rights of Birds, Dies at 79
abstract: A fierce campaigner, Ms. Davis expanded the reach of the animal rights movement by advocating for chickens, turkeys and other farmyard fowl.
lead_paragraph: Karen Davis, an animal-rights activist who led campaigns to recognize the dignity of chickens, turkeys and other farmyard fowl — and whose fervor was such that she compared the industrial slaughter of poultry to the Holocaust — died on Nov. 4 at her sanctuary for rescued chickens in Machipongo, Va. She was 79.

headline: The Lives Who Were Overlooked
abstract: The editor who created the “Overlooked” obituary series at The New York Times talks about the upcoming book compilation.
lead_paragraph: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]

headline: Gaza Hospitals Near Collapse as Fighting Rages Nearby
abstract: Facing power outages and shortages of food, water and medical supplies, hospitals are struggling just to keep patients alive, Gazan health authorities say.
lead_paragraph: Operations at Gaza’s main hospital were showing signs of collapse on Saturday, with its director and the Gazan Health Ministry describing power outages, shortages of water and medicine and a crisis in treating seriously wounded patients and vulnerable children, while battles between Israeli troops and Hamas fighters raged ever closer.

headline: A Pond in Hawaii Turned Pink, Raising an Environmental Red Flag
abstract: Dry conditions and high salt levels in the water allowed for halobacteria to thrive, turning a pond bubble-gum pink.
lead_paragraph: A pond in Hawaii became a social media spectacle this week after turning bubble-gum pink. However, experts said the new hue was not just a photo opportunity but an indicator of environmental stress.

headline: Right on the Money
abstract: Garrett Chalfin’s Sunday puzzle comes with a price.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Johnson Pitches Bill to Avert Government Shutdown That Faces an Uncertain Fate
abstract: The measure would extend funding for some agencies through late January, and for others until early February. It omits funding for Ukraine or Israel.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson on Saturday pitched House Republicans on a convoluted plan to avert a government shutdown at the end of next week, proposing a bill that would temporarily extend funding for some federal agencies until late January and for others through early February.

headline: In Veterans Day Speech, Trump Promises to ‘Root Out’ the Left
abstract: The former president said that threats from abroad were less concerning than liberal “threats from within” and that he was a “very proud election denier.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, on a day set aside to celebrate those who have defended the United States in uniform, promised to honor veterans in part by assailing what he portrayed as America’s greatest foe: the political left.

headline: About 300,000 People Participate in Pro-Palestinian March in London
abstract: Demonstrators marched in support of Palestine and demanded a cease-fire in Gaza in one of Britain’s largest protests in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators marched in support of Palestine and demanded a cease-fire in Gaza in one of Britain’s largest protests in recent years.

headline: Son of Former Hollywood Agent Is Charged in Woman’s Murder
abstract: The police believe the victim is the wife of the suspect, Samuel Haskell, the son of a veteran talent agent and film producer. Mr. Haskell’s in-laws were missing as of Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The son of a once prominent Hollywood agent and executive has been charged in the murder of a woman investigators believe to be his wife and whose remains were found bagged inside a dumpster in Los Angeles this week, the police said.

headline: Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.
abstract: The site was built for the military, but commercial sales are booming with little public accountability. Rounds have been bought by murderers, antigovernment groups and others.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Hixon, a 27-year veteran of the Navy who served in the Persian Gulf, trained with government ammunition that typically had a distinctive “LC” marking on its brass casings.

headline: Inside the Army Factory That Makes AR-15 Ammunition: 4 Takeaways
abstract: Commercial rounds are being manufactured on government property. Some have been used in violent crimes, including mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: The Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, built during World War II, has long been operated for the federal government by private contractors. Over the past decade, a New York Times investigation found, the site has increasingly produced rounds for the commercial market as military demand has diminished.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Proposal to Fix Housing That Already Inspired a Cult
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 12, 2023
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t any deep philosophical movement. I’m trying to cut taxes.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 12, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the U.S. Space Force misspelled the surname of a member of the U.S. Space Force. He is Lt. Col. Galen Thorp, not Thorpe.

headline: The Corner Lot Where All the World’s Vegemite Comes From
abstract: First concocted a century ago, the spread is widely adored by Australians — and loathed by almost everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Just off Australia’s largest container port lies a sickle-shaped neighborhood with a scent so distinctive that passing taxi drivers will sometimes roll down their windows for a whiff of the rich and unmistakably beery aroma.

headline: Toxic Air Is No Reason to Stay Inside for Delhi’s Joggers and Yoga Fans
abstract: In India’s capital, skipping exercise and the social routines that often come with it is seen as worse than going out and breathing poison.
lead_paragraph: A few steps into his early-morning run, Purushottam Sahu struggled to breathe. He started coughing. He felt as if he might vomit.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Offers Up Little Debate
abstract: Timothée Chalamet hosted an episode that presented former President Trump as an aggrieved forerunner. The musical guest was boygenius.
lead_paragraph: Come on, you didn’t really think that “Saturday Night Live” would begin this weekend with a parody of the third Republican presidential debate, did you?

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Bodily Indignities of the Space Life
abstract: The race is on to put hotels in space and neighborhoods on the moon. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
lead_paragraph: As an incubator of life, Earth has a lot going for it, something we often fail to appreciate fully from within its nurturing bounds. Merely sending probes and rovers to the moon and Mars won’t do. For various reasons — adventure! apocalypse! commerce! — we insist upon taking our corporeal selves off-world too. Multiple private companies have announced plans to put hotels in space soon. NASA is aiming to 3-D-print lunar neighborhoods within a couple of decades. And while it will probably take longer than that to build and populate an outpost on Mars, preparations are being made: This summer, four NASA crew members began a 378-day stay in simulated Martian housing at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: ‘The Driver Stayed in the Car With the Radio On and the Window Open’
