abstract: A sidewalk singalong, an eventful pedicab ride and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Should Your Ex-Boss Get a Say in Your New Job? Wall Street Says Yes.
abstract: Legislation in New York that would outlaw noncompete agreements, a staple at big banks, has led to frenzied lobbying to persuade Gov. Kathy Hochul to kill the effort.
lead_paragraph: For high-powered Wall Street and banking executives, one of the hallmarks of the job comes into play only at the end: a signed noncompete agreement.

headline: Is Remote Work the Answer to Women’s Prayers, or a New ‘Mommy Track’?
abstract: Post-pandemic work-from-home norms allowed more women to stay in the work force than ever before. Remote work could also make it harder to get ahead.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, the legal scholar Joan C. Williams published a theory for why professional women were “opting out” of their careers.

headline: The ‘Georgists’ Are Out There, and They Want to Tax Your Land
abstract: Amid a crisis in affordable housing, the century-old ideas of Henry George have gained a new currency.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Mike Duggan talks about his accomplishments in Detroit, the list is both impressive and sad. He had the streetlights turned back on, and reopened closed parks. In the decade since he took office, the city has demolished some 25,000 blighted homes whose rusty debris and incubation of crime drag down neighborhoods.

headline: The Undying Appeal of the Las Vegas Wedding
abstract: After 70 years as the “Wedding Capital of the World,” the glittering city that attracts thousands of couples seeking unconventional nuptials has grown beyond the drive-through wedding.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas has long been a stage where reality dissolves into fantasy. In the heart of the desert — a place where the Eiffel Tower, Egyptian pyramids and medieval castles all beam on one glamorous strip — the entertainment is virtually unlimited. It’s no wonder, then, that a city built on the promise of pleasure and escape has remained a popular destination for weddings.

headline: A Swift, Opinionated Portrait of Willa Cather (She Would Have Approved)
abstract: “Chasing Bright Medusas,” a new biography by Benjamin Taylor, aims not to uncover new facts but to provide a concise introduction to the novelist.
lead_paragraph: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together. What a good antidote to despair that was. Much of it was rereading, but I’d missed some stories and novels, and I’d never read them sequentially or with a clear sense of Cather’s life. That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.

headline: You Paid $1,000 for an iPhone, but Apple Still Controls It
abstract: The company codes its devices with software that complicates repairs by triggering safety warnings and malfunctions.
lead_paragraph: For a decade, it was easy to get help repairing an iPhone. Cracked screens could be replaced in minutes, and broken cameras could be exchanged without a hitch.

headline: Her Livelihood? Hunting Pythons in the Dead of Night.
abstract: Amy Siewe teaches people how to find and euthanize invasive Burmese pythons, which have been so successful at adapting to Florida that they appear here to stay.
lead_paragraph: An unexpected chill can fall over the Florida Everglades late at night. Stars speckle the sky. Frogs croak and croak, their mating calls echoing in the air.

headline: For Joan Armatrading, Classical Music Is Just Another Genre
abstract: The pioneering singer-songwriter is unveiling her first classical composition, Symphony No. 1, this month.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Chi-chi Nwanoku, the founder and artistic director of the Chineke! Orchestra, received an email out of the blue from the singer-songwriter Joan Armatrading. She, the message said, had finished composing her first classical composition.

headline: Why Vultures Might Just Be the Smartest Birds Above the Block
abstract: The birds are widely reviled for their carrion-eating ways. But an evolutionary history of scavenging has forged a creative, cunning and wide-ranging mind.
lead_paragraph: The two lappet-faced vultures had been together for just a few months, yet the massive birds, with their watchful, featherless gargoyle faces and their dark mottled body plumage so plush it looks like fur, had already mastered the avian version of monkey-see-monkey-do.

headline: The Occupied West Bank: Divided by Faith, United by Fear
abstract: As bloodshed surges around them, an Israeli settler and a Palestinian tour guide search for answers — and a shred of hope.
lead_paragraph: As Moish Feiglin pulls up to his settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, he points to an eight-foot-tall concrete slab blocking the middle of the road.

headline: How Ukraine, With No Warships, Is Thwarting Russia’s Navy
abstract: The commander of Ukraine’s Navy said in a rare interview that the Russian naval blockade of Odesa had been broken. He also described how the war is transforming naval tactics.
lead_paragraph: In a small, hidden office in the port city of Odesa, the commander of the Ukrainian Navy keeps two trophies representing successes in the Black Sea.

headline: When Ruthless Cultural Elitism Is Exactly the Job
abstract: “It tends to be true that the best publishers are people who read books,” says literary kingmaker Andrew Wylie.
lead_paragraph: “It tends to be true that the best publishers are people who read books,” says literary kingmaker Andrew Wylie.

headline: U.S. Bets on Small Nuclear Reactors to Help Fix a Huge Climate Problem
abstract: The dream of reviving nuclear power in the U.S. rests on a new generation of smaller reactors meant to be easier to build. But major obstacles loom.
lead_paragraph: The dream of reviving nuclear power in the U.S. rests on a new generation of smaller reactors meant to be easier to build. But major obstacles loom.

headline: Nepal Is Investigating New Airport Made by China
abstract: After a Times article about the cost and quality of Pokhara airport, which Chinese state-owned firms financed and built, Nepal’s anti-corruption agency said it was looking into the project.
lead_paragraph: As developing countries weigh the consequences of borrowing heavily from China for major infrastructure projects, anti-corruption officials in Nepal have begun an investigation into a flagship airport financed and built by Chinese state-owned companies.

headline: Kelly Johnson Embodies the Hard-Line Views She Shares With the Speaker
abstract: The wife of Mike Johnson, the new speaker, has rallied opposition to abortion rights and used her pastoral counseling business to condemn homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: As Speaker Mike Johnson likes to tell it, it was love at first sight when he first met Kelly Lary, the sunny, blonde former Kappa Delta who caught his eye in a red dress at the wedding of a mutual friend.

headline: Vermont May Be the Face of a Long-Term U.S. Labor Shortage
abstract: Employers are pulling out all the stops to attract workers as the state’s population grows older, offering a likely glimpse of the country’s future.
lead_paragraph: At Lake Champlain Chocolates, the owners take shifts stacking boxes in the warehouse. At Burlington Bagel Bakery, a sign in the window advertises wages starting at $25 an hour. Central Vermont Medical Center is training administrative employees to become nurses. Cabot Creamery is bringing workers from out of state to package its signature blocks of Cheddar cheese.

headline: In Texas, Vietnamese American Shrimpers Must Forge a New Path Again
abstract: They overcame the trauma of war, language barriers and prejudice to become successful shrimpers. But the decline of the industry in America is forcing them to consider other options.
lead_paragraph: The sun was still rising when Vinh Nguyen hauled in his first catch of the day.

headline: Barbra Streisand, in Her Own Words
abstract: The singer has released a 1,000-page memoir. Its heart is a story of perseverance.
lead_paragraph: This year’s memoirs have kept ravenous consumers of celebrity culture well fed.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 13, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: F.B.I. Examining Whether Adams Cleared Red Tape for Turkish Government
abstract: After winning the 2021 Democratic mayoral primary, Eric Adams successfully pressed city officials to allow the opening of a Manhattan high-rise housing the Turkish Consulate General.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are investigating whether Mayor Eric Adams, weeks before his election two years ago, pressured New York Fire Department officials to sign off on the Turkish government’s new high-rise consulate in Manhattan despite safety concerns with the building, three people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Measuring Israel by the Just-War Yardstick
abstract: The Netanyahu government falls short on most benchmarks of whether its actions in Gaza meet the standard.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s response to the horrifying Hamas attack on Oct. 7 has caused widespread protest among its critics and soul-searching among some of its supporters. The deaths of thousands of Palestinian civilians in a ferocious bombing campaign and an increasingly intense ground war in the Gaza Strip cry out for a careful examination of the moral basis for Israel’s actions.

headline: The New Republican Party Isn’t Ready for the Post-Roe World
abstract: With leaders like Trump, the pro-life movement can’t prevail.
lead_paragraph: Ohio is not a swing state, not any longer. Donald Trump won it by eight points, twice. It has a Republican governor, and while its senators are split between the parties, its U.S. House delegation is made up of 10 Republicans and five Democrats. And yet Ohio just passed an abortion-rights referendum by a margin of more than 13 points.

headline: The Conservative Supreme Court Vision That Means Inequality for Women
abstract: The Roberts court’s commitment to history and tradition leads to decisions that reflect a constitutional order made with men in mind.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court last week heard oral arguments in United States v. Rahimi, a challenge to a federal law that takes guns away from people subject to domestic violence restraining orders. From the moment the court agreed to hear the case, advocates hoped it would provide an opportunity for the court to limit the sweep of last year’s blockbuster decision expanding gun rights.

headline: The Legal Double Standard That’s Rarely Discussed
abstract: Every day prosecutors choose to keep former targets in the dark, never telling them that the case against them is dead.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors formally advised lawyers for former Vice President Mike Pence this past June that he would not be charged for retaining classified materials after leaving office. I expect that the special counsel Robert Hur will similarly soon announce that President Biden will not face charges for his own handling of classified documents. The merits of those determinations, no less than the one to indict Donald Trump for hoarding such documents in Mar-a-Lago’s bathrooms and ballrooms, are properly debated.

headline: What Happens When Palestinians Tell Their Stories Directly to the World?
abstract: Far too many civilians are dying in Gaza, but Palestinian voices are being heard like never before.
lead_paragraph: After the Israeli military killed his older brother in an airstrike in Gaza in 2014, Ahmed Alnaouq says, he almost lost his will to live. “I sank into a deep depression,” he told me in a recent phone call. But an American friend convinced him to write about his brother and channel his grief into something productive. Together, they founded We Are Not Numbers, a project that trains young writers in Gaza and publishes their personal essays in English.

headline: 3 Dead, 14 Injured in Brooklyn House Fire
abstract: All three floors of a rowhouse in Crown Heights were on fire when firefighters arrived. At least one firefighter was injured.
lead_paragraph: A fire in a Brooklyn rowhouse early Sunday morning left three people dead and 14 people injured, police officials said.

headline: A Perfect Lasagna
abstract: Serve for Sunday supper now, or parbake and freeze to feed the family later.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. At last, it’s oven weather where I stay. I set the thermostat low, put on a sweater under my apron and get to work: a Guinness pie, say, or a braised leg of lamb? Better yet, a perfect lasagna (above).

headline: At Salon Art + Design, Gold Bracelets and Lipstick-Red Monochromes
abstract: The 12th edition of the fair, dedicated to fine and decorative arts, offers a beguiling mix of paintings, jewelry and modern Brazilian design.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Salon Art + Design, the 12th edition of a fair dedicated to fine and decorative arts, transforms the Park Avenue Armory into a fabulous and eccentric collector’s house. Open through Monday, it brings together work on Masonite board by the artist Robert Mangold (Zeit Contemporary Art) and wooden sculpture by Louise Nevelson (Galerie Gmurzynska) alongside rare books (Potterton Books), chunky gold Tiffany bracelets (DK Farnum) and a shiny, surreal, curiously tooth-like chair made of solid bronze by Voukenas Petrides (Fumi Gallery).

headline: Over 100,000 March in France Against Antisemitism
abstract: The demonstrations in Paris and other cities came amid a rise in tensions in France over the Gaza war and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
lead_paragraph: More than 100,000 demonstrators in Paris and cities across France took to the streets on Sunday to show their solidarity with the country’s Jews and to deplore antisemitic acts that have multiplied across the nation since Hamas’s attack on Israel on Oct. 7.

headline: Peter Nygard, Former Fashion Mogul, Convicted of Sexual Assault
abstract: The verdict in Toronto concludes the first of Mr. Nygard’s criminal trials in Canada. The 82-year-old also faces charges in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A Toronto jury on Sunday found Peter Nygard, the high-profile executive behind a fallen fashion empire, guilty of four counts of sexual assault after just over three days of deliberation at the end of a six-week trial.

headline: What We Know About the Death Toll in Israel From the Hamas-Led Attacks
abstract: Israel’s ability to give an accurate count of how many died in Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack has been complicated by corpses that were mutilated and identifying foreign workers killed in the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Israel revised its official estimated death toll of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks, lowering the number to about 1,200 people, down from the more than 1,400 initially cited, a spokesman for the country’s Foreign Ministry said on Friday night.

headline: Marvel Flounders at the Box Office With ‘The Marvels’
abstract: “The Marvels” cost about $300 million to make and market and arrived to $47 million in domestic sales.
lead_paragraph: The once-superheroic Marvel Studios is now merely mortal.

headline: Major Freeway Near Downtown Los Angeles Is Closed Indefinitely After Fire
abstract: All lanes on a part of Interstate 10 remained closed a day after two nearby storage yards were engulfed in flames. Officials are investigating the cause of the fire.
lead_paragraph: Drivers in Los Angeles who use one of the busiest freeways in the area will need to change their travel plans for an indefinite period of time as authorities assess the damage from a fire early Saturday that shut down part of an interstate downtown.

headline: 5 U.S. Special Operations Troops Killed in Helicopter Crash in Mediterranean
abstract: The troops were on a refueling training mission when the aircraft crashed off the coast of Cyprus. The episode, which Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said was an accident, is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Five members of the U.S. Army Special Operations forces have died in a helicopter crash in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, American officials said on Sunday.

headline: Why Is the Democratic Base Eroding?
abstract: Readers react to a column by Pamela Paul criticizing the party’s direction. Also: Inequality and test scores; WIC funding.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 30 Horses Die in Arson Fire at Upstate Racetrack
abstract: Firefighters and horse owners rushed to the scene after the blaze started in a barn, but none of the horses could be saved.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of racehorses were killed last week when an arsonist set fire to a barn in upstate New York, leaving their owners devastated.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands Protest Spanish Prime Minister’s Deal With Separatists
abstract: The deal, which grants amnesty to secessionists, is meant to give Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez enough support to form a coalition to stay in power.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of incensed Spaniards responded to the call of conservative parties on Sunday and packed squares across the country to protest a deal that Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, a Socialist, reached with secessionists to grant them amnesties in exchange for the political support required for him to retain power.

headline: Monday Briefing: Conditions Worsen in Gazan Hospitals
abstract: Plus Vegemite’s 100th birthday.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Red Crescent said yesterday that Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City was “no longer operational,” as power outages and shortages of fuel continued to wreak havoc on Gaza’s health facilities. The Gazan aid group said that more than 14,000 displaced people had been sheltering there.

headline: New Gene Editing Treatment Cuts Dangerous Cholesterol in Small Study
abstract: The trial involved only 10 patients, but it suggests cholesterol can be permanently reduced with a single treatment for patients at risk of heart disease.
lead_paragraph: The handful of patients had severe heart disease that had caused chest pain and heart attacks. After trying available cholesterol-lowering medications, they could not get their cholesterol as low as cardiologists recommended.

headline: In Israel, Christie Says Trump Ducked Mideast Progress and Fueled Bigotry
abstract: The former New Jersey governor and chief G.O.P. antagonist to the former president cited Mr. Trump’s rhetoric of intolerance and faulted him for a lack of ambition on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who is challenging Donald J. Trump for the Republican presidential nomination, said Mr. Trump’s rhetoric of intolerance — as evident today as it was during his presidency — had fueled the surge of bigotry confronting Jews and Muslims after Hamas’s brutal Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the fierce Israeli response in Gaza.

headline: Hikers Rescued After Following Nonexistent Trail on Google Maps
abstract: A Canadian search-and-rescue group said it had conducted two missions recently after hikers “may have sought to follow” a nonexistent trail on Google Maps.
lead_paragraph: A search-and-rescue group in British Columbia advised hikers to use a paper map and compass instead of street map programs after it said two hikers had been rescued by helicopter after likely following a trail that did not exist but that appeared on Google Maps.

headline: Netanyahu Sees No Near-Term Role for Palestinian Authority in a Postwar Gaza
abstract: Differing from the U.S. view, the Israeli prime minister also said Israel must retain security control over Gaza so it can be “demilitarized” and “de-radicalized.”
lead_paragraph: Even as Israeli tanks and ground troops continued to battle Hamas militants in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday outlined a postwar vision for the territory, one that he said would not involve the Palestinian Authority in its current form.

headline: Israeli Forces Near a Struggling Hospital They Say Covers a Hamas Complex
abstract: Israeli officials say that Hamas has built a complex under Al Shifa, a major Gaza hospital. Hamas denies it is operating from beneath the hospital, whose patients face dire conditions amid power cuts.
lead_paragraph: With Israel consolidating its hold on northern Gaza, its forces are closing in on a sprawling medical center that for Israelis and Palestinians alike has emerged as a symbol of the other side’s inhumanity.

headline: Take a Break
abstract: Benjamin Fink makes a convincing puzzle in his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: U.S. Carries Out Another Round of Airstrikes on Targets Tied to Iran
abstract: Airstrikes hit two facilities in eastern Syria, most likely killing or injuring Iran-backed militia personnel. The United States has blamed such groups for recent attacks against its troops.
lead_paragraph: The United States conducted a new round of airstrikes against facilities used by Iran and its proxies in eastern Syria late Sunday in retaliation for a spate of recent attacks against American troops, Pentagon officials said on Sunday.

headline: A Mayor’s Suicide Leaves an Alabama City Seeking Answers
abstract: The mayor fatally shot himself after a news site published a photo of him in makeup and said he had written erotic fiction and posts using names and photos of local residents, including a minor.
lead_paragraph: F.L. Copeland Jr., a Baptist pastor and grocery store owner known as Bubba, once told a colleague that being mayor of Smiths Station, Ala., reminded him of a real-life version of the popular Sims computer game: building a community, then dealing with the complexities and crises that emerged along the way.

headline: New York Democrat Announces Early Departure From House, Citing G.O.P. Dysfunction
abstract: Representative Brian Higgins, Democrat of New York, said he would step down in February.
lead_paragraph: Representative Brian Higgins, Democrat of New York, said on Sunday that he would leave Congress in February.

headline: Tim Scott Suspends ’24 Campaign, as His Sunny Message Failed to Resonate
abstract: He entered the Republican presidential race as a rising star with substantial financial resources, but struggled to break out of the pack of Trump challengers.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, who tried carving out a space in the Republican presidential field with a hopeful message built on his life story — the son of a single mother, he rose from poverty to become the only Black Republican in the Senate — announced on Sunday that he was suspending his campaign.

headline: More Than 100,000 March in France Against Antisemitism
abstract: The demonstrations, called by the leaders of both chambers of the French Parliament, came amid a rise in tensions over the Israel-Gaza War and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
lead_paragraph: The demonstrations, called by the leaders of both chambers of the French Parliament, came amid a rise in tensions over the Israel-Gaza War and a surge in antisemitic incidents.

headline: Quotation of the Day: She’s Less Than Charming to Everglades Pythons
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I had a family that went hunting with me instead of going to Disney World.”

headline: Why Does This Bride Look So Mad?
abstract: An 1866 painting by Auguste Toulmouche is being repurposed online as a conduit for women’s anger.
lead_paragraph: How long could you maintain your most withering glare? A minute? An hour?

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The latest from the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Patients including babies at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza are dying because of a lack of power, medical staff said amid conflicting accounts from Israel and health authorities in Gaza over why a badly needed fuel delivery for the besieged and crumbling facility had been held up.

headline: Fighting to Govern Myanmar, From a Teeny Office in Washington
abstract: The National Unity Government of Myanmar, formed as an alternative to the junta that orchestrated a 2021 coup, has to battle global apathy and ignorance as it struggles for recognition.
lead_paragraph: Three blocks from the White House, at the end of a fluorescent-lit hallway on the sixth floor of a co-working space for “business nomads, freelancers and energetic entrepreneurs,” sits the American headquarters of the National Unity Government of Myanmar.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘BlackBerry’ and ‘Jay-Z and Gayle King: Brooklyn’s Own’
abstract: AMC airs its original program in three parts. And Gayle King interviews Jay-Z on CBS.
lead_paragraph: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 13-19. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: exhortation
abstract: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word exhortation has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 20 in “One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer” by Scott Miller:

headline: Behind Public Assurances, Xi Jinping Has Spread Grim Views on U.S.
abstract: Speeches by the Chinese leader show how he was bracing for an intensifying rivalry with the United States from early in his rule.
lead_paragraph: When President Xi Jinping of China made his first state visit to the United States in 2015, he wrapped his demands for respect in reassurances.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Says Family Properties Show His Father’s Brilliance
abstract: In his second appearance in court, Donald J. Trump’s eldest son testified that the company’s assets were extremely valuable. A judge has found their values were inflated.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s signature properties are at the heart of a sweeping civil fraud case accusing him of manipulating their values and his net worth. To hear the former president’s eldest son tell it, those properties prove something far rosier: the brilliance of the Trump family business.

headline: What We Know About the Criminal Investigation Into Eric Adams’s Campaign
abstract: Federal authorities are examining whether the mayor’s 2021 campaign accepted illegal donations, including from the Turkish government.
lead_paragraph: After federal authorities raided the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s chief fund-raiser on Nov. 2, a broad criminal inquiry into the fund-raising practices of Mr. Adams’s 2021 campaign spilled into public view.

headline: The Two-State Platitude
abstract: Once a hope for the future of Israel and Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
lead_paragraph: Once a hope for the future of Israel and Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.

headline: North American Birds Will No Longer Be Named for Racists — or Anybody Else
abstract: Ornithologists and amateur birders alike have long wrestled with the historical nature of bird names bestowed by early collectors.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 1, the American Ornithological Society announced that it would be renaming all the birds under its purview that are currently named for human beings. The birds’ new names will reflect the species’ appearance or habitat — some trait associated with the actual bird, in other words, and not with the colonial explorer who first identified it.

headline: Chile, Known for Its Wines and Piscos, Turns to Gin
abstract: Distilleries are popping up across the country as Chileans use the versatile spirit to showcase their country’s unique botanicals.
lead_paragraph: Last Hope Distillery is one of the only real cocktail bars in Puerto Natales, a horseshoe of a city that wraps around a windy inlet in Chilean Patagonia. To enter, visitors buzz, speakeasy-style, then hang up their coats and settle in at the bar. A server sets a glass down.

headline: A Pandemic Novel That Never Says ‘Pandemic’
abstract: Michael Cunningham’s “Day” peeks into the lives of a family on one specific April date across three years as life changes because of Covid and other challenges.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.

headline: I Sent My Doctor a Selfie. Intentionally.
abstract: Teledermatology companies are disrupting skin care, and a lot of consumers are OK with that.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, while skimming her Instagram feed, Fawzia Khan happened upon an ad for Dear Brightly, an online platform that sells prescription retinoids, a derivative of vitamin A that’s used topically to fight acne and aging skin, and available through doctors.

headline: ‘A Monster’: Super Meth and Other Drugs Push Crisis Beyond Opioids
abstract: Millions of U.S. drug users now are addicted to several substances, not just opioids like fentanyl and heroin. The shift is making treatment far more difficult.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nic Helmstetter crab-walked down a steep, rain-slicked trail into a grove of maple and cottonwood trees to his destination: a dozen tents in a clearing by the Kalamazoo River, surrounded by the detritus of lives perpetually on the move. Discarded red plastic cups. A wet sock flung over a bush. A carpet square. And scattered across the forest floor: orange vial caps and used syringes.

headline: Behind This Novel’s Cheery Facade Lies a Powerful Story of Immigration
abstract: In “Happy,” by Celina Baljeet Basra, a Punjabi farmer with big dreams finds more challenges than opportunity after he emigrates to Europe.
lead_paragraph: A friend recently told me he’d read an article in this paper describing the money to be made supplying migrants in their journey from South America to the United States. “Made me realize I don’t have any real understanding of the immigration situation,” my friend said.

headline: What to Know About the Flu Virus
abstract: What’s the difference between influenza A and influenza B, and does it matter which you catch?
lead_paragraph: Each fall, the flu emerges as a formidable force, spreading through the droplets produced when people cough, sneeze or talk, and sometimes hitching a ride to our noses by way of the infected surfaces that we touch. Influenza viruses cause tens of millions of illnesses and thousands of deaths in the United States each year.

headline: Can’t Think, Can’t Remember: More Americans Say They’re in a Cognitive Fog
abstract: Adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s are driving the trend. Researchers point to long Covid as a major cause.
lead_paragraph: There are more Americans who say they have serious cognitive problems — with remembering, concentrating or making decisions — than at any time in the last 15 years, data from the Census Bureau shows.

headline: This Photograph Demands an Answer
abstract: The news media doesn’t often publish graphic images of dead children. But this photograph must be seen.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t look too closely you might think the photograph is a dimly lit snapshot from a slumber party or a family camping trip. Six small children lie in a row, their heads poking out from the white sheet that is casually lying across their little chests. None appear to be older than 10, though it is hard to say for sure.

headline: Financial Fraudsters Have Escaped Justice for Far Too Long
abstract: The Justice Department has been losing ground in the fight against financial fraud for years.
lead_paragraph: From a prosecutorial perspective, the Justice Department’s aggressive pursuit of Sam Bankman-Fried for financial fraud has been brutally efficient. His conviction came a year to the day after the public learned that there could be serious problems with the finances at his cryptocurrency exchange FTX, and it generated a wave of public interest and positive press for the department.

headline: Polluting Industries Say the Cost of Cleaner Air Is Too High
abstract: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is about to announce new regulations governing soot — the particles that trucks, farms, factories, wildfires, power plants and dusty roads generate. By law, the agency isn’t supposed to consider the impact on polluting industries. In practice, it does — and those industries are warning of dire economic consequences.

headline: Where Is the Line Between Helping a Child Become More Resilient and Pushing Them Too Hard?
abstract: Has a parent ever challenged you to be more resilient? If so, were you grateful for the encouragement? Or did it go too far?
lead_paragraph: Has a parent, a teacher, a coach or some other caring adult ever pushed you to try something new? To persevere through a difficult situation? To do something that you thought you couldn’t do?

headline: With Diana’s Death, ‘The Crown’ Enters Its Most Evocative Era
abstract: The final season of Netflix’s royal drama opens in 1997, on the cusp of one of the most analyzed periods in recent British history.
lead_paragraph: The images are joltingly familiar, even after all these years.

headline: America Is Losing Control
abstract: President Biden shows he has not learned from past mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, President Biden has presented himself as a statesman humbled and enlightened by his own country’s missteps after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. “While you feel that rage,” he advised Israelis, “don’t be consumed by it.”

headline: The Two-State Platitude
abstract: Once a hope for the future of Israel and the Palestinians, “the two-state solution” can now feel like a hollow phrase.
lead_paragraph: In the decades-long effort to resolve the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, it has seemed to many like the least flawed among many imperfect ideas: the two-state solution. It would create an independent Palestinian state, made up of Gaza and the West Bank, that would exist alongside Israel. The goal has become official policy of most governments around the world and has been the basis for peace talks for years.

headline: Will the Tie Ever Make a Comeback?
abstract: A reader wonders whether men’s neckties are a relic of the past.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Guy Trebay, our men’s wear critic, said when I asked him about ties, “It never pays to sound the death knell in fashion since even the most seemingly defunct articles of clothing have a way of rising from the dead, and this is particularly so in men’s wear, where the repertoire is limited and largely based on centuries-old customs.”

headline: $1.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Victorian cottage in Little River, a three-bedroom bungalow with a guesthouse in Los Angeles and a renovated 1913 home in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: This house is perched above Van Damme State Beach, within walking distance of several popular trails and Spring Ranch Nature Preserve. It is less than five minutes from Little River Inn Golf and Tennis Club, which has a nine-hole golf course where players have spotted great horned owls, ospreys and bobcats.

headline: Maybe This Is Why Donald Trump Is Afraid to Debate Nikki Haley
abstract: That exchange at last week’s debate about high heels wasn’t a throwaway moment.
lead_paragraph: If Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis have the best shot at taking on Donald Trump for the Republican presidential nomination, there was an especially telling moment at Wednesday’s debate that shows why Ms. Haley might be better suited to endure and overcome Mr. Trump’s lines of attacks than Mr. DeSantis would be.

headline: What It Means to Be a Texan Is Changing in Surprising Ways
abstract: White people make up a declining minority in Texas, even among those born in the state. And all those people moving in? They’re as likely to be Black, Hispanic or Asian.
lead_paragraph: Silhouetted against the predawn light of the West Texas sky, a group of oil field workers got ready for the tough job ahead on a September day — cleaning up a spill on a rig outside of Odessa — speaking a mix of English and Spanish.

headline: How Hoboken Got Smart About Climate Change
abstract: The New Jersey city has been more forward-thinking than New York in preparing for big storms.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the contrasts between two flood-prone cities on the Hudson River — New York and Hoboken, N.J. — in an era when climate change is bringing us more intense storms.

headline: In Politics, There Are Worse Things Than Wishful Thinking
abstract: Does Nikki Haley’s rise suggest there might be life left in the Republican primary?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, my attention these past few weeks has been devoted almost entirely to outrages and tragedies in the Middle East. But I couldn’t help smiling for a second when Nikki Haley called Vivek Ramaswamy “scum” at last week’s G.O.P. debate, after he raised the subject of her daughter’s use of TikTok.

headline: Leila de Lima, Critic of Duterte’s Drug War, Is Released on Bail
abstract: Though she was never convicted, Ms. de Lima was detained for six years after she fiercely opposed the Philippine former president’s brutal war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: The Philippines released on bail its most famous political prisoner, Leila de Lima, whose six-year detention served as a stark warning to those who dared to question former President Rodrigo Duterte’s brutal drug war.

headline: At Tourist Hotels, Israeli Evacuees Plan for Long Stays to Escape Border Attacks
abstract: More than 125,000 Israeli evacuees have been resettled from their communities along the dangerous borders with Lebanon and Gaza in the largest internal displacement in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: A joyful clamor echoed in the ballroom of the Golden Crown Hotel. Kindergarten was in full swing for 30 children from Arab al-Aramshe, a village next to Israel’s border with Lebanon. Only this class was meeting 44 miles south, in Nazareth, where nearly 800 of the village’s residents have been living since mid-October, when they were evacuated because of the risk of attacks by the militant group Hezbollah.

headline: Crisis at Gaza’s Main Hospital, and More
abstract: Plus, Tim Scott suspends his campaign for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and a rise in reports of cognitive difficulties.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Doctors of Gaza
abstract: Doctors working inside the Gaza Strip tell their stories of survival.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of injuries and death.

headline: America’s Other Drug Problem
abstract: The crisis increasingly involves drugs besides opioids.
lead_paragraph: When political leaders talk about America’s current drug crisis, they are typically referring to opioids like painkillers, heroin and fentanyl. And when they have passed laws to deal with the problem in the past decade, those policies have centered on opioids. They have, for example, focused on boosting access to medications that treat only opioid addiction or reverse only opioid overdoses.

headline: Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital Is ‘No Longer Functioning,’ W.H.O. Says
abstract: The agency warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for those trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.
lead_paragraph: Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital is no longer functioning, according to the World Health Organization, which warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for hundreds of patients and displaced people trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.

headline: Opinion Today: When to Show War’s Horrors
abstract: On the difficult decision not to show the photograph at the center of a column published today.
lead_paragraph: Since the first use of photography to document battle in the Crimean War, there have been questions about the ethics of photojournalism in covering conflict and about how to regard the suffering of others depicted in that work.

headline: Attacks Intensify on Russian Forces in Occupied Regions of Ukraine
abstract: In the latest strike, Kyiv said three Russian officers were killed in a bombing in the southern city of Melitopol.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian partisans killed three Russian officers in a bomb attack over the weekend, military authorities said, in a sign that Kyiv is stepping up its harassment of Moscow’s forces in the absence of decisive territorial progress on the battlefield.

headline: The Improbable Comeback of David Cameron
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has presented himself as a change agent, chose a predecessor, Mr. Cameron, as his foreign secretary. But he comes with political baggage.
lead_paragraph: When David Cameron resigned as Britain’s prime minister after losing the Brexit vote in 2016, he offered members of Parliament a rueful valedictory: “I was the future once.” Few, perhaps including Mr. Cameron himself, expected to see him return.

headline: What’s at Stake in the Biden-Xi Meeting
abstract: President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, are set to meet on Wednesday, as the two seek to maintain ties despite trade tensions.
lead_paragraph: Nine months after the Chinese spy balloon controversy sent relations between Washington and Beijing to a new low, President Biden and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, will meet this week in San Francisco for face-to-face talks.

headline: As the Republican Field Narrows, Nikki Haley Makes a $10 Million Move
abstract: The former ambassador to the U.N. is reserving her first ads in Iowa and New Hampshire as she looks to outstrip Gov. Ron DeSantis in the race for second place.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign plans to reserve $10 million in television, radio and digital advertising in Iowa and New Hampshire starting in the first week of December — its first investment in advertising this cycle and a move meant to give the candidate a boost as the clock ticks for the field to make significant gains against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: N.Y. Area Amtrak Service Paused Over Problems With Garage Above Tracks
abstract: Service has been suspended for two days between New York City and Westchester because structural issues were found in a garage above the tracks in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Amtrak train service on the line between New York City and Albany remained disrupted for a second day on Monday after structural issues were discovered in a parking garage above the train tracks in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Hollywood Actors to Start Voting This Week on a New Contract
abstract: The tentative agreement would end the longest movie and television strike in SAG-AFTRA’s 90-year history.
lead_paragraph: For the past several months, production in Hollywood has been at a near standstill.

headline: Regents Exams May Become Optional for High School Graduation in New York
abstract: The tests had once been seen as a hallmark of academic rigor, but high-stakes graduation tests have fallen out of favor nationally.
lead_paragraph: New York could soon stop requiring many high school students to take Regents exams to earn a diploma, a major step in a sweeping overhaul of the state’s graduation system as it joins a national movement to rethink high-stakes exit exams.

headline: Chevron Restarts Gas Production on Platform Near Gaza Strip
abstract: The energy giant had halted operations at the offshore facility on request from Israel’s government shortly after the attacks by Hamas militants last month.
lead_paragraph: Chevron said Monday that it had resumed production of natural gas from a platform in Israeli waters on instructions from the government. Israel’s Ministry of Energy had ordered the U.S. energy giant to halt production at the Tamar platform, shortly after the Oct. 7 raids by militants from Hamas in Israel and the start of Israel’s bombardment of Gaza.

headline: Start-Ups With Laser Beams: The Companies Trying to Ignite Fusion Energy
abstract: Companies are looking to commercialize advances made by federally supported research labs in the quest for boundless energy.
lead_paragraph: Take a smidgen of hydrogen, then blast it with lasers to set off a small thermonuclear explosion. Do it right, and maybe you can solve the world’s energy needs.

headline: A Look at Suella Braverman’s Turbulent Time as Home Secretary.
abstract: Ms. Braverman, who is no stranger to controversy, has now been fired from the post of home secretary twice.
lead_paragraph: Suella Braverman has embraced controversy in her time as a senior member of the Conservative government.

headline: Here Is a List of the New U.K. Cabinet so Far
abstract: David Cameron, a former British prime minister, is taking over as foreign secretary.
lead_paragraph: British government reshuffles generally take place over a period of hours, with the pace of appointments sometimes halting or accelerating as politicians accept or decline new positions. Here’s what has been announced officially so far on Monday.

headline: Spanberger Announces Run for Governor in Virginia, Leaving House Seat in Play
abstract: The centrist Democrat helped deliver her party the House majority in 2018, and her decision to seek higher office could make it more difficult for Democrats to reclaim control in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Representative Abigail Spanberger, a prominent Virginia Democrat who was repeatedly able to win in a conservative-leaning district, announced on Monday that she would run for governor in 2025, leaving open a competitive seat that could be crucial to her party’s efforts to win back control of the House next year.

headline: Biden Strengthens Ties With Indonesia Despite Tensions Over the War in Gaza
abstract: Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, visited the White House and appealed to President Biden to call for a cease-fire. Mr. Biden focused instead on their new strategic partnership.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia met at the White House on Monday to announce a new strategic partnership, but their differing views on the conflict in Gaza came into view when Mr. Joko asked for the United States to “do more” to stop the war.

headline: Secret Service Agent Protecting Naomi Biden Fires Gun During Car Break-In
abstract: Three people were seen breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington late Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A Secret Service agent guarding one of President Biden’s granddaughters fired at three people seen breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle in Washington late Sunday but did not appear to have hit them, according to a senior law enforcement official.

headline: Do You Know These Fictional Places in Popular Novels?
abstract: Try this short quiz to see if you can identify the imaginary locations created by certain authors for their books.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz to see if you can identify the imaginary locations created by certain authors for their books.

headline: Exxon Mobil Plans to Produce Lithium in Arkansas
abstract: The move is the oil giant’s first foray in the production of a metal vital for electric vehicle batteries.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil said on Monday that it planned to set up a facility in Arkansas to produce lithium, a critical raw material for electric vehicles, which pose one of the biggest challenges to the company’s oil business.

headline: An Atmospheric River Will Bring Rain and Snow to California This Week
abstract: It’s still too early to know just how much, though.
lead_paragraph: A first of many.

headline: When a Seat in the Theater Means a Seat in the Salon
abstract: “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding” is a play where the Black women in the audience are the ones who feel most at home.
lead_paragraph: In a scene in Jocelyn Bioh’s “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,” a man rolls in a cart of items to sell to the clients and stylists at the titular salon. I recognized the character immediately and sat up, anticipating the joke. I wasn’t the only one: A small contingency of the audience at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater started snickering and laughing before he had even fully stepped onstage.

headline: Cameron’s Return Relies on a Procedure That’s Unusual, but Not Unprecedented
abstract: Ministers in Britain have to hold a seat in Parliament, but the government can create a place in the House of Lords to satisfy that requirement.
lead_paragraph: One distinctive feature of Britain’s political system is that ministers are required to hold a seat in Parliament to propose legislation and be held to account by fellow lawmakers.

headline: Nepal Is Banning TikTok Over Hate Content, Officials Say
abstract: The small Himalayan nation’s cabinet of ministers said the Chinese-owned app had neglected its repeated requests to curb content that affected “social harmony.”
lead_paragraph: The government in Nepal said on Monday that it was banning the popular social media app TikTok, saying the platform’s refusal to curb hate content was affecting “social harmony.”

headline: Maryanne Trump Barry, Retired Judge and Donald Trump Sister, Dies at 86
abstract: A former appellate federal judge in New Jersey, she supported her brother but, as audio recordings revealed in 2019, she could be scathingly critical of him.
lead_paragraph: Maryanne Trump Barry, a former federal judge who was an older sister of Donald J. Trump and served as both his protector and critic throughout their lives, has died. She was 86.

headline: Because the Sides Are Really the Star
abstract: Brown-butter mashed potatoes, roasted squash with hot honey and a fresh take on green bean casserole might outshine the turkey.
lead_paragraph: Are you Team Turkey, or Team Sides? My Thanksgiving happy place is all about gathering as many of my favorite side dishes as I can and throwing a big, buttery veg-and-carb-fest. It’s permission to eat both honey-roasted sweet potatoes and brown-butter mashed potatoes at the same meal without even a tinge of guilt. Thanksgiving comes but once a year; I believe in making the most of it.

headline: How Much Can Trees Fight Climate Change? Massively, but Not Alone, Study Finds.
abstract: The research, which comes with important caveats, was partly an effort to address the scientific uproar surrounding an earlier paper.
lead_paragraph: Restoring global forests where they occur naturally could potentially capture an additional 226 gigatons of planet-warming carbon, equivalent to about a third of the amount that humans have released since the beginning of the Industrial Era, according to a new study published on Monday in the journal Nature.

headline: Cracking the Green Bean Casserole Code
abstract: Eric Kim cooked 13 iterations of the midcentury Thanksgiving staple to create the ultimate recipe for today.
lead_paragraph: Dorcas Tarbell restocks her 97-year-old father’s fridge from a grocery list he gives her every week. One of the items that’s often on that list is a frozen TV dinner of green bean casserole.

headline: Russell Brand’s Alternate Reality
abstract: The British entertainer built an army of fans with his conspiracy-minded podcast. Now, amid sex-assault claims against him, they’ve become his whole world.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 12, four days before he was expected at the Troubadour Wembley Park Theater for another sold-out show, Russell Brand asked his fans for a favor. “I’ve always struggled with authority and being told what to do,” he wrote to ticketholders, attaching a questionnaire for a planned bit with his audience. “Even when it comes to something small like being offered a seat by a doctor, I’ll purposefully refuse rather than comply. Tell me about your relationship with authority — whether you tend to yield to authority or fight it.”

headline: MasterVoices Puts on a Starry Show With a Shoestring Budget
abstract: This essential organization gives fresh, entertaining life to music theater curiosities. What if it had more money?
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of Stephen Sondheim in New York at the moment: the premiere staging of his last musical, “Here We Are,” and star-studded revivals of “Merrily We Roll Along” and “Sweeney Todd” on Broadway.

headline: ‘1989 (Taylor’s Version)’ Repeats at No. 1
abstract: Jung Kook of BTS’s solo album “Golden” debuts at No. 2 in another dominant week on the charts for Taylor Swift.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift holds the top of the Billboard 200 album chart with her latest remake, while Jung Kook of BTS opens at No. 2 and a posthumous release by Jimmy Buffett lands in the Top 10.

headline: Who Is James Cleverly, Britain’s New Home Secretary?
abstract: Cleverly is generally seen as less ideological and more of a team player than his predecessor in the Home Office, Suella Braverman.
lead_paragraph: James Cleverly, who will move from his position leading the Foreign Office to become Britain’s home secretary, is generally seen as less ideological and more of a team player than his predecessor in the Home Office, Suella Braverman.

headline: Speech and Antisemitism on Campus
abstract: Responses to articles about the tensions on college campuses. Also: Joe Manchin’s possible candidacy, and Jill Stein’s definite one; private art collections.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Case on Outdoor Exercise for Prisoner in Solitary
abstract: The court’s three liberal justices dissented, saying that the prisoner, Michael Johnson, should be able to challenge prolonged denial of fresh air.
lead_paragraph: Over a forceful dissent from its three liberal members, the Supreme Court on Monday turned down an appeal from a prisoner in Illinois held in solitary confinement who said that prolonged denial of outdoor exercise was cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: ‘The Lady Bird Diaries’ Review: A 1960s First Lady Speaks
abstract: Lady Bird Johnson proves an engrossing narrator to her own story and that of a roiling nation.
lead_paragraph: “The Lady Bird Diaries” opens with images of a drizzly November day in Fort Worth, and the voice of Claudia Alta Johnson. Lady Bird Johnson — a nickname she acquired as child growing up in Texas — is recounting the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: ‘A Murder at the End of the World’ Review: P.I. Meets A.I.
abstract: The story of death at a mogul’s retreat (no, not “Glass Onion”) has a few interesting ideas about tech within a familiar mystery scenario.
lead_paragraph: An eccentric tech billionaire invites a slew of notables to a private retreat, where a detective must solve a mysterious death. If the premise of “A Murder at the End of the World” jumps out at you, it may be because you not so long ago encountered it as the premise of Rian Johnson’s “Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery.”

headline: Splinter Is Coming for These ‘Game of Thrones’ Trees
abstract: Six of the Dark Hedges beech trees, a tourist destination in Northern Ireland for fans of the HBO fantasy series, will be cut down because they are in poor condition, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Six trees with long branches that twist up to the sky that were made famous by the series “Game of Thrones” will be cut down in the coming weeks, officials in Northern Ireland said on Monday.

headline: Fake Reviews Are Rampant Online. Can a Crackdown End Them?
abstract: A wave of regulation and industry action has placed the flourishing fake review business on notice. But experts say the problem may be insurmountable.
lead_paragraph: After Dr. Mark J. Mohrmann completed a successful orthopedic procedure in 2019, his patient turned to Yelp, the review website, to share his appreciation.

headline: Gospel Grammy Nominee Is Nearly Kicked Off Flight for Singing
abstract: In a widely shared video, a Delta flight attendant told the gospel singer Bobbi Storm that she would be removed if she would not listen to his instructions to be quiet.
lead_paragraph: A gospel singer was threatened with being removed from a Delta Air Lines flight after she refused to stop singing on the plane because, she said, she was “doing what the Lord” told her to do.

headline: Kevin Wynn, Choreographer of Complex Movement, Dies at 67
abstract: He became known for his “layered movement dialogue” and was an uncommonly dedicated teacher who mentored students over decades.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Wynn, a choreographer of complex maelstroms that moved at lightning speed and an uncommonly dedicated teacher who influenced generations of dancers, died on Oct. 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: Rashida Tlaib, Censured by the House, Is Praised and Condemned at Home
abstract: The Democratic congresswoman from the Detroit area and the only Palestinian American in the House faces a complicated landscape in her district.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month, the suburbs of Detroit have played host to vigils where victims of the war between Israel and Hamas are commemorated with prayers, candles and tearful speeches.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Liberia?
abstract: Can you find Liberia on a map? What else do you know about this West African nation with 5.5 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Liberia on a map? What else do you know about this West African nation with 5.5 million people?

headline: CBS Says New Scripted Shows Will Return in February
abstract: The announcement is the first from a network about its plans since a tentative agreement was reached last week to end Hollywood’s strikes.
lead_paragraph: The lights are turning on again in Hollywood.

headline: Turkey Potpie, Guinea Fowl and a Hybrid Turnip for the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: Aprons for a good cause, a roasting pan for the holiday bird and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Not enough Thanksgiving guests for a 12 to 16 pounder? There are other avian options to bronze in the oven and present with panache. There’s guinea fowl (above), a pasture-raised bird with luscious dark meat that’s not gamy, which is as easy to roast as a chicken. Season the interior with salt and pepper, tuck in a bunch of fresh herbs, rub the outside with butter, oil or duck fat, set it on a rack at 375 degrees and roast a large one, four pounds or so to serve six, for an hour and 20 minutes. You’ll only need about an hour for a 2- to 3-pounder serving two to four. Heritage Foods has 4- to 4.5-pound guinea hens raised by the Good Shepherd Poultry Ranch Network based in Kansas. D’Artagnan sells 2 to 3 pound hens from California.

headline: Under Pressure, Columbia Pledges $100 Million to Patients Doctor Abused
abstract: The institution said it “failed these survivors” in a letter on Monday apologizing for its role in the decades-long abuse by the gynecologist, Robert Hadden.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four months after a former Columbia University gynecologist was sentenced to 20 years in prison for abusing patients, the university on Monday apologized to victims and announced a “multipronged” response plan.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Object to Trump Request for Broadcast of Election Trial
abstract: The office of the special counsel said that televising the proceeding would create a “carnival atmosphere” and allow the former president to divert attention from the charges he faces.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Monday accused former President Donald J. Trump of trying to turn his trial on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election into “a media event” with a “carnival atmosphere” by backing calls to have it broadcast live on television.

headline: Supreme Court Adopts Ethics Code After Reports of Undisclosed Gifts and Travel
abstract: The code does not specify how the rules would be enforced or by whom.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court issued an ethics code on Monday after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the justices to adopt one.

headline: Democratic Aides in Congress Break With Their Bosses on Israel-Hamas War
abstract: A wave of current and former staff members, mostly of a younger generation, are agitating for a cease-fire and speaking out against their bosses’ positions.
lead_paragraph: The carnations arrived by the wheelbarrow. Blood-red, pink, orange and yellow, more than 10,000 stems were laid on the steps at the base of the Capitol against a clear blue sky.

headline: Indianapolis Museum Leader, Hired After Racism Outcry, Leaves Her Role
abstract: Colette Pierce Burnette was appointed last year by Newfields, whose campus includes the Indianapolis Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Colette Pierce Burnette, who was hired to lead the Newfields campus that includes the Indianapolis Museum of Art after a controversy about a racially insensitive job posting, has left the organization after 15 months on the job and shortly after the arrival of a new museum director.

headline: Hysteria or Healing? Examining the Power of the Shaking Body
abstract: The artist Liz Magic Laser considers quaking as both a symptom and a cure for psychological distress in “Convulsive States” at Pioneer Works.
lead_paragraph: As the choreographer and dancer Wendy Osserman, 81, began to contort her body at a recent performance in Queens, her hands shook. Her fingers flapped back and forth. She threw one arm away from the other — tossing and releasing, flailing and returning — and hopped into one-leg kicks before sticking her tongue out and coiling it into a tunnel.

headline: Priest Impersonator Targeted Texas Churches, Officials Say
abstract: A man calling himself Father Martin stole $500 from a Houston church and visited six Dallas parishes, officials said. The man has also been spotted in two other states and Ontario.
lead_paragraph: A man impersonating a priest who calls himself Father Martin stole $500 from a church in Houston and showed up at six other parishes in Dallas last month, prompting security warnings among dioceses in Texas, church officials said.

headline: Hamas has held some Israeli hostages since long before Oct. 7.
abstract: Two Israeli citizens taken nearly a decade ago are believed to still be alive. Families are also fighting for the return of the remains of two soldiers killed in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The plight of families desperately seeking the return of their loved ones abducted from Israel on Oct. 7 is painfully familiar to Aviram Shaul.

headline: Under Pressure, Britain’s Leader Tries Another Reset With a Swerve to Center
abstract: After more than a year as prime minister, Rishi Sunak, a Conservative, has failed to close a yawning gap in the polls. On Monday he did something new.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain fired one of his most senior and divisive ministers on Monday, in a reshuffle of his top team that unexpectedly brought a centrist predecessor, David Cameron, back into government.

headline: America Needs a Serious Talk About How to Shrink Its Deficits
abstract: Interest rates are making U.S. debt a bigger burden. A bipartisan commission could find solutions.
lead_paragraph: You need to put politics aside to shrink government budget deficits — or that’s the conventional wisdom, anyway. Heidi Heitkamp disagrees. Heitkamp, who served one term in the U.S. Senate as a Democrat from the red state North Dakota, argues that it’s impossible to cut deficits and restrain the growth of the national debt without politics.

headline: Read the Supreme Court’s Ethics Rules
abstract: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it had issued an ethics code for the justices after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the court to adopt one. Here are the ethics rules.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it had issued an ethics code for the justices after a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts intensified pressure on the court to adopt one. Here are the ethics rules.

headline: Los túneles de Gaza
