abstract: A younger generation of Israeli and Palestinian peacemakers want to be part of the dialogue about the “day after” the war, when Israelis and Palestinians must grapple again with how to live side by side.
lead_paragraph: Though only 9 at the time, May Pundak knew that when her father was often away in the early 1990s, he was involved in some kind of mission for Israel, one so secret that she could not breathe a word about it to friends at school.

headline: Seizing Darfur Region, Paramilitary Forces Are Accused of Atrocities
abstract: Seven months into Sudan’s civil war, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces and its allies are ransacking and capturing the Darfur region. An aid worker said, “People are dying like insects.”
lead_paragraph: Bodies littered the road out of El Geneina, a town in western Sudan, as Dr. Rodwan Mustafa and his family sped down a bumpy road that led to the border with Chad and, they hoped, safety.

headline: U.N. Security Council Calls for Dayslong Humanitarian Pauses in Gaza
abstract: After weeks of division, the Council adopted a resolution that stopped short of calling for a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution on Wednesday calling for immediate and urgent dayslong humanitarian pauses in the Israel-Hamas war to allow desperately needed aid to reach civilians in Gaza.

headline: For Jonathan Lyndon Chase, Hair Is Rooted in Pride
abstract: The Philadelphia artist’s show at Artists Space considers how hair cutting, grooming and caregiving help create a Black queer community.
lead_paragraph: Black hair has been a rousing topic for politicians, comedians and artists for decades. Malcolm X argued that straightening Black hair to conform to white beauty standards was a form of racist brainwashing. Regina Kimbell made a documentary with the brilliant title “My Nappy Roots: A Journey Through Black Hair-itage” (2010) and the comedian Chris Rock made a similar documentary, “Good Hair” (2009), about the Black hair industry (and, of course, got in trouble at the Oscars for mentioning a Black actress’s lack of hair). Now a Broadway play, “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,” written by Jocelyn Bioh, celebrates the “masterpieces” created by West African immigrants on women’s heads in a Harlem braiding shop.

headline: In Britain, Reality Is Cleaving in Two
abstract: The country’s leading politicians support the war in Gaza. Much of its public does not.
lead_paragraph: In Britain, Armistice Day is usually an understated affair, marked only by two minutes of silence at 11 a.m. This year was considerably more eventful, as two very different protests descended on London.

headline: Madagascar Votes Amid Violence and Calls for Boycott
abstract: Tensions are high on the island nation off the coast of southeastern Africa, as opposition presidential candidates complain of a rigged election and abuses by security forces.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of political violence, voters on the island nation of Madagascar went to the polls on Thursday to elect a president, even though 10 of the 13 candidates called for a boycott, accusing the man they are vying to replace of unfairly tilting the process in his favor.

headline: Word of the Day: palatable
abstract: This word has appeared in 121 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word palatable has appeared in 121 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 14 in “Bring Fans and Skip the Sights: Vacationing in Scorching Hot Europe” by Ceylan Yeginsu:

headline: Fleets of Force
abstract: How China strong-armed its way into dominating the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: How China strong-armed its way into dominating the South China Sea.

headline: Stephen Colbert Sums Up Biden’s Meeting with China’s President: ‘He Said, Xi Said’
abstract: Colbert said President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, had a lot to catch up on: “trade tensions, global flash points, who got hot over the summer.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Brick Wall
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Grace Wales Bonner Has Set Her Sights Beyond Fashion
abstract: The designer has made waves with fashion that infuses European heritage with Afro-Atlantic spirit. Now she has curated an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Grace Wales Bonner’s approach to fashion can sometimes feel more like that of an academic rather than a designer.

headline: Branding the Good Life
abstract: Erik Torstensson, co-founder and creative director of Frame, creator of Mr Porter and an investor in Skims, knows a lot about how to have fun working in fashion.
lead_paragraph: Erik Torstensson wanted to talk about Frame, the “model-off-duty” denim brand that he started with his business partner, Jens Grede. As Frame rounds its 10th anniversary, Mr. Torstensson has been on a store-opening spree — Marylebone in London in October, Madison Avenue in December — intent on injecting Frame with new energy (the implication being it needed some). Sales were approximately $170 million in 2022.

headline: A New Getty Family Business
abstract: The fashion designer Rosetta Getty may have a rule-breaking heir in her daughter Violet.
lead_paragraph: Once, more than a decade ago, Rosetta Getty was asked by her daughter’s elementary schoolteacher, “Are we going to discuss the elephant in the room?”

headline: Office Building Fire in Northern China Kills at Least 26
abstract: The fire, at a coal company’s offices in the province of Shanxi, also left at least 38 people hospitalized, the state-run news media reported. The cause was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: At least 26 people were killed and 38 others were hospitalized when a fire broke out in a coal company’s office building in a provincial city southwest of Beijing on Thursday, China’s state-run news media reported.

headline: After Days Trapped in a Tunnel, Workers Wait for a Rescue’s Plan B
abstract: The Indian authorities are trying a second drilling technique to reach 40 men who are getting by on water and food sent in through a pipe.
lead_paragraph: Four days after 40 workers became trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the Indian authorities were still trying on Thursday to find a way through debris and rescue them, as anguished family members and colleagues protested outside to demand faster action.

headline: Rental Cars: Know the Pitfalls
abstract: What you need to know about renting a car, from reservations to return.
lead_paragraph: From getting a good deal to figuring out insurance requirements, renting a car can be a complicated, pitfall-prone experience. Here are some best practices to follow, from reservations through returns.

headline: Tracy K. Smith Collects Books About the Supernatural
abstract: “I have a lot of books on near-death experiences, psychic phenomena and past-life regression on my shelves,” says the two-time poet laureate, whose new book is the memoir “To Free the Captives.” “These kinds of books nudge me to remember our world is but one facet of an enormous continuity.”
lead_paragraph: What’s the last great book you read?

headline: An Interview With Kamala Harris on What’s at Stake in 2024
abstract: The vice president believes democracy is on the line. Are Democrats ready for that fight?
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is crucial to the Biden campaign’s strategy for winning over a skeptical Democratic base.

headline: Charles Dickens: the Man, the Myth, the Brand
abstract: In “The Life and Lies of Charles Dickens,” Helena Kelly revisits the image the author crafted so carefully in his lifetime.
lead_paragraph: The specter of biography has long struck fear in the hearts of living legends. Martha Washington, Henry James and Somerset Maugham tried to thwart would-be chroniclers by pitching private papers into the fire — heartbreaking acts of futile resistance. Trusted correspondents did not, as James instructed, “burn, burn, burn.”

headline: He Says He’s Doing Good. This Author Strongly Disagrees.
abstract: In “The Bill Gates Problem,” Tim Schwab excoriates the billionaire philanthropist and his foundation.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century ago, Bill Gates became an international symbol of greed, arrogance and hubris for his no-holds-barred leadership of Microsoft.

headline: Why Georgia Republicans Are Protecting the D.A. Who Indicted Trump
abstract: G.O.P. leaders, including Gov. Brian Kemp, are shielding Fani T. Willis from political threats, not so much to protect her, as to protect the image of the state.
lead_paragraph: Colton Moore, a 30-year-old auctioneer from rural Dade County, Ga., enjoys rare bragging rights for a freshman state senator. Donald J. Trump, the leading candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, recently singled him out by name as a man of “courage and conviction.”

headline: 36 Hours in Acadiana, Louisiana
abstract: Explore Cajun Country, a region where French, Creole, Native American and African traditions come together in a cultural gumbo.
lead_paragraph: Explore Cajun Country, a region where French, Creole, Native American and African traditions come together in a cultural gumbo.

headline: Do Safe Injection Sites Increase Crime? There’s Finally an Answer.
abstract: Communities don’t have to choose between saving lives and stopping crime. The data is proof.
lead_paragraph: Over 100,000 Americans now die from drug overdoses annually. To combat this crisis in New York City and save lives, Mayor Bill de Blasio decided to support an initiative rife with controversy: In November 2021, his government allowed OnPoint, a nonprofit, to open two overdose prevention centers, where people with addictions can inject or smoke drugs like opioids and stimulants under medical supervision to reduce the risk of overdose death. Upon taking office, Mayor Eric Adams, Mr. de Blasio’s successor, has continued to support the sites’ work.

headline: Barbara Kingsolver Takes Stock
abstract: One Pulitzer Prize, two book tours, 54 weeks on the best-seller list and many admiring messages later, the author reflects on “Demon Copperhead.”
lead_paragraph: Now that “Demon Copperhead” has been in the world for almost 14 months — and a stalwart on the hardcover fiction list for 54 weeks — Barbara Kingsolver finally has a moment to reflect on the gratifying hubbub of the past year. She won a Pulitzer Prize. She’s been on two book tours. She’s received notes, emails and direct messages — “every possible way you can get a message,” she said in a phone interview — from readers letting her know how the novel resonated with them. Kingsolver even received a fan letter from Tom Hanks. She said, “Do you remember mailgrams? The really big paper that you fold up? I’d forgotten how to open one so I slit right through the middle of the page, unfortunately. Otherwise, it would have been suitable for framing.”

headline: 679 Paintings. Sculptures. A Sword. The Met Moved Them All.
abstract: The museum’s European galleries open today after a $150 million renovation that will allow art to be seen through a new lens.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll get a look at some of the most popular galleries in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which are about to reopen after a five-year renovation project. We’ll also find out what the chairman of the House Ethics Committee said about its investigation of Representative George Santos.

headline: How R.F.K. Jr. Has Turned His Public Crusades Into a Private Windfall
abstract: The causes Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has championed have brought him admiration, criticism — and tens of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. earned more than $500,000 as the chairman and top lawyer at Children’s Health Defense, the nonprofit organization that he has helped build into a leading spreader of anti-vaccine falsehoods and a platform for launching his independent bid for the White House.

headline: Every Star Wants a Documentary Now. But Is It Just P.R.?
abstract: “The Last Dance” — the Michael Jordan-backed documentary about, well, him — has inspired several celebrities to commission their own biographical films.
lead_paragraph: When the director Fisher Stevens was shooting “Beckham,” the four-part docuseries about the British footballer David Beckham, he walked into his subject’s kitchen and saw Beckham cleaning up. Stevens immediately grabbed his camera, thinking that this was a revealing moment — the famous multimillionaire scrupulously washing his own dishes. But as soon as he saw the camera, Beckham stopped.

headline: A Homeless Man Attacked Him. But Was There More to the Story?
abstract: An altercation in San Francisco has raised fears about the city’s future — but also questions about what really happened.
lead_paragraph: Responding to 911 calls about a street fight in the Marina district, the police found Don Carmignani, 53, standing on the sidewalk with blood streaming down his face. It was 7:20 p.m. on April 5 — twilight — and multiple witnesses had gotten a clean view of Carmignani’s attacker: a young homeless man who was a familiar presence in the neighborhood. The police arrested him two minutes later, right down the block. An ambulance took Carmignani to Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital.

headline: The Bush-Obama Blueprint That Gives Biden Hope for ’24
abstract: President Biden isn’t the first incumbent to face grim polling a year out from Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Well before Election Day in 2004, President George W. Bush was warned by strategists that he would face a tough campaign battle because of voter distress over the war in Iraq and over the economy — two issues he had once hoped to ride to a second term.

headline: Starbucks Workers Walk Out on Red Cup Giveaway Day
abstract: Unionized employees say promotional events like the one on Thursday exacerbate staffing and scheduling problems at the chain’s stores.
lead_paragraph: Unionized Starbucks workers walked off the job on Thursday to press their demands for contract negotiations and spotlight their complaints over staffing and scheduling issues.

headline: Bidenomics Has a Mortal Enemy, and It Isn’t Trump
abstract: Yawning inequality in the American economy is causing Bidenomics to fall flat with voters.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 26, the Department of Commerce announced that gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter. This growth rate ran well above even optimistic forecasts, leading to what can only be called triumphalism from a White House dead set on making Bidenomics a key to its 2024 presidential campaign. President Biden issued a self-congratulatory statement, and the White House echoed it over and over — and Donald Trump’s relative popularity increased.

headline: Do You Trust Online Reviews?
abstract: Do you ever use online reviews to help you make decisions about movies, books, stores or music? How do you know they aren’t fake?
lead_paragraph: Thumbs up.Five stars.You’ll love it.It’s very easy to use.It will never break!

headline: Meet the African Artists Driving a Cultural Renaissance
abstract: As digital connections bring the African diaspora together, these 12 creatives are at the center of a global shift.
lead_paragraph: As digital connections bring the African diaspora together, these 12 creatives are at the center of a global shift.

headline: She Wanted a New House in a New City. What Would $400,000 Buy in Colorado?
abstract: After the pandemic derailed her plans for a life in New Mexico, a retired schoolteacher ‘was ready to go back home’ to Colorado. But Denver and Boulder were too expensive.
lead_paragraph: After the pandemic derailed her plans for a life in New Mexico, a retired schoolteacher ‘was ready to go back home’ to Colorado. But Denver and Boulder were too expensive.

headline: These Are the Fights That Many House Republicans Really Want
abstract: The House agreed to keep the government open for a few weeks. But don’t expect the good sense to last long.
lead_paragraph: The lights are going to stay on in federal government offices, and also in the suite of the House speaker, Mike Johnson, at least for a few more weeks. Up to now, it hadn’t been clear that both could happen at the same time.

headline: Progressives Aren’t Liberal
abstract: The divide on the left is getting wider.
lead_paragraph: Remember when “liberal” was a dirty word? In the 1980s, Ronald Reagan, who often prefaced it with a damning “tax and spend,” may have been the most effective of bashers. But the most blatant attack was in the early ’90s, after Newt Gingrich’s political organization GOPAC sent out a memo, “Language: A Key Mechanism of Control,” urging fellow Republicans to use the word as a slur.

headline: Los Angeles Will Offer More Energy Incentives to Low-Income Residents
abstract: A new study by the city’s utility and other researchers found that lower-income residents cannot afford electric vehicles and clean energy.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles said on Thursday that it would build electric vehicle chargers and offer bigger rebates for the purchase of battery-powered cars in response to a new report that concluded that low-income people were being left behind in the transition to clean energy.

headline: T’s Holiday Gift Guide: Chile Flakes, Cookie Candles and More
abstract: What T Magazine editors are eyeing for our friends and family — and what we’re coveting for ourselves.
lead_paragraph: No Hanukkah party is complete without some light gambling. When I was young, after my family and I inevitably ate our entire supply of gelt by the first night, we would play dreidel using whatever tokens were left around the house — M&Ms, chocolate chips, even Cheerios if things got dire. Thankfully, if you’re stocking up on chocolate coins for your own gathering, there are now much more elevated options to throw in the pot. Veruca Chocolates in Chicago makes dark chocolate sea salt gelt without the usual foil wrapping, each piece instead dusted with a gold finish and molded to replicate ancient Judean coins. Fortnum & Mason stashes its milk chocolate coins inside a festive tin that resembles the storefront of its Piccadilly headquarters in London. And Li-Lac Chocolates, one of the oldest confectioneries in New York, offers milk and dark chocolate dreidels — though be prepared to bring an extra dreidel of your own, since you’ll want to eventually break into these ones to reach the gelt within.

headline: Film Club: ‘Madeleine’
abstract: A filmmaker’s animated ode to her 107-year-old friend. What can we learn from their remarkable friendship?
lead_paragraph: “Madeleine” is a 15-minute Op-Doc film that touches on themes of mortality, hope and the power of friendship. Every week Raquel, the filmmaker, visits Madeleine, 67 years her senior, in a retirement home. Madeleine refuses to go outside, but Raquel finds a way to bring her on a road trip. Blending reality with fiction and stop-action animation, the film creates a whimsical but moving portrait of Madeline — and their unlikely but inspiring friendship.

headline: They Trudge From Russia Into Ukraine, Fleeing Life Under Occupation
abstract: About 100 Ukrainians a day travel back into Ukraine at an unofficial border crossing, bringing tales of repression and fear about life in Russian-controlled territories.
lead_paragraph: The Russian soldiers turned up at her home close to midnight with an ominous message.

headline: Israel and Hamas Near a Hostage Deal, and More
abstract: Plus, scant progress in Biden-Xi talks and opposition to the deal between G.M. and the autoworkers’ union.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Biden’s Electric Car Problem
abstract: Examining the real effect of a law meant to supercharge the production and sale of electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, at President Biden’s urging, congressional democrats passed a sweeping plan to supercharge the production and sale of electric vehicles.

headline: In Talks With Biden, Xi Seeks to Assure and Assert at the Same Time
abstract: China’s depiction of Xi Jinping’s U.S. visit reflected his sometimes-contradictory priorities: to project both strength and a willingness to engage with Washington.
lead_paragraph: Meeting with President Biden for the first time in a year, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, reiterated his determination to unify with Taiwan, but stopped short of mentioning the potential use of force. He denounced what he called futile American efforts at containing China, but also acknowledged that U.S. tech restrictions had taken a toll.

headline: Some U.K. Labour Lawmakers Rebel Against Leader on Gaza Policy
abstract: More than a quarter of Labour lawmakers in Parliament backed a motion calling for a cease-fire amid growing concern over casualties in Gaza and rising pressure on European politicians.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s main opposition Labour Party has suffered a significant rebellion in Parliament over its policy on Gaza, in a sign of the hardening of opinion in Western Europe against Israel’s military action in the enclave.

headline: A Surprising Shift in Economics
abstract: Economic thinking has become more progressive in recent years.
lead_paragraph: A then-obscure think tank named the Roosevelt Institute released a report in 2015 that called for a new approach to economic policy. It was unabashedly progressive, befitting the history of the institute, which was created by trusts honoring Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt.

headline: ‘Trolls Band Together’ Review: This Must Be Pop
abstract: The third installment of the “Trolls” franchise reunites ’N Sync in this entertaining boy band fever dream.
lead_paragraph: When DreamWorks kicked off the “Trolls” franchise in 2016, one could practically hear the squeals of joy from studio execs: a tentpole blockbuster that took the name-brand dolls and reimagined them as colorful singing creatures doing renditions of seemingly every pop hit of the last half century. It was built for mass appeal toddler fixation. The movies also could be charming and even take their premise in interesting directions.

headline: ‘Thanksgiving’ Review: Gobble, Gobble, Gasp
abstract: From a fake genre trailer comes a full horror meal, courtesy of Eli Roth.
lead_paragraph: The origin of this seasonal slasher is in an ersatz trailer the horror filmmaker Eli Roth made for the portmanteau movie “Grindhouse” in 2007. The two lurid features directed by Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino were separated by a series of teasers for imaginary movies concocted by like-minded pals of the filmmakers, also including Rob Zombie and Edgar Wright. Believe it or not, Roth’s feature-length version of “Thanksgiving” is the third such trailer to get its Pinocchio-esque real-movie wish.

headline: ‘Next Goal Wins’ Review: Offside
abstract: Michael Fassbender plays a bitter soccer coach in this sloppy underdog comedy from Taika Waititi.
lead_paragraph: Bland photography and perfunctory writing are the very least of my issues with “Next Goal Wins,” a movie-shaped stain on the class of entertainment known as the sports-underdog comedy.

headline: ‘The Stones and Brian Jones’ Review: Sympathy for a Founding Rocker
abstract: A new documentary looks back at Jones’s rise and fall, but also underlines his crucial strand in the Rolling Stones’ DNA.
lead_paragraph: There’s a particular indignity to being dropped from the band you founded.

headline: ‘JFK: What the Doctors Saw’ Review: A Clinical Take
abstract: Barbara Shearer’s documentary unpacks the medical opinions of physicians who treated John F. Kennedy in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Amid a climate of invigorated interest in the assassination of John F. Kennedy — stoked by the media capitalizing on the 60th anniversary of his death to reignite familiar debates — Barbara Shearer’s “JFK: What the Doctors Saw” contributes some clarity to the conspiratorial noise by centering on a tiny piece of the puzzle: the professional opinions of the physicians present in the president’s Parkland Memorial Hospital emergency room.

headline: ‘The Disappearance of Shere Hite’ Review: The Feminist Mystique
abstract: Nicole Newnham’s documentary charts the life and times of the feminist Shere Hite, whose pioneering research on women’s sexuality earned her both fame and notoriety.
lead_paragraph: “The Disappearance of Shere Hite” opens with a 1976 TV interview with Shere Hite about her pioneering study, “The Hite Report: A Nationwide Study of Female Sexuality.” As she talks about the revelations of her research — that women masturbate, and most men don’t know how to please them — the interviewer tells a crew member to stop snickering.

headline: ‘Black God, White Devil’: Holy War in Brazil’s Backlands
abstract: Glauber Rocha’s allegorical epic unfolds in a desolate, arid region of Brazil known for its rebellions, outlaws and self-anointed saints.
lead_paragraph: Replete with religious cults, righteous outlaws, starving peasants and the music of Heitor Villa-Lobos, Glauber Rocha’s stark, violent “Black God, White Devil” introduced the world to Brazilian cinema novo. It also split the jury at the 1964 Cannes Film Festival, which compromised by awarding the Palme d’Or to “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.”

headline: New York Will Give a ‘Clean Slate’ to Formerly Incarcerated People
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul signed legislation that could make as many as two million people eligible to have their criminal records sealed.
lead_paragraph: Roughly two million people convicted of crimes in New York may be eligible to have their records sealed as part of a broad criminal justice initiative that was signed into law on Thursday by Gov. Kathy Hochul.

headline: ‘Best. Christmas. Ever!’ Review: Frenemies Rejoice
abstract: Heather Graham and Brandy play old friends who have a surprise reunion.
lead_paragraph: Holiday cheer stokes an old source of envy in “Best. Christmas. Ever!,” the latest Netflix holiday film from the director Mary Lambert (“Under the Cherry Moon,” “Pet Sematary”).

headline: City to Pay Record $17.5 Million Settlement After Wrongful Conviction
abstract: George Bell was sentenced to life in 1999 for a murder in Queens that he did not commit. He was exonerated two years ago.
lead_paragraph: A man  exonerated after spending over two decades in prison for murders in Queens that he did not commit will receive a $17.5 million settlement from New York City, an apparent record, according to his lawyer and city data.

headline: Pandas, Ping-Pong and Profits: Chinese Leader Woos U.S. C.E.O.s
abstract: Amid frosty U.S.-China relations, Xi Jinping emphasized friendship in an address to executives from Apple, Boeing, Nike and others.
lead_paragraph: The streets outside the San Francisco hotel where the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, addressed a crowd of American business executives Wednesday night were chaotic, echoing with police sirens and the chants of protesters. A woman had strapped herself to a pole 25 feet in the air in front of the hotel, yelling “Free Tibet!” as a cold rain fell.

headline: Israel’s Opposition Leader Says Netanyahu ‘Must Go Now’
abstract: Yair Lapid says that he would join a coalition without Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Where Are the Country’s Hottest Rental Markets?
abstract: With higher interest rates keeping potential buyers in the rental market, Queens and the Bronx are seeing more rental activity.
lead_paragraph: What are the hottest rental markets in New York these days? The answers may come as a surprise: According to a new national study by RentCafe, as of October, Queens, N.Y., had the highest level of renter activity among the 150 largest metropolitan markets in the United States. The Bronx ranked sixth. But the real dark horse was Buffalo, which came in at No. 9 — the highest-ranking new entry on the list.

headline: What the Biden-Xi Talks Accomplished (and Didn't)
abstract: Wednesday’s four-hour meeting in San Francisco resulted in few breakthroughs. But C.E.O.s gave the Chinese leader a standing ovation at a banquet afterward.
lead_paragraph: The mood music was upbeat but pragmatic after the first face-to-face meeting in a year between President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping. There was no joint communiqué after Wednesday’s talks, but both sides issued positive statements trumpeting where they found common ground, including on tackling climate change and improving communications.

headline: David Cameron Visits Kyiv Aiming to Show That U.K. Hasn’t Forgotten Ukraine
abstract: With much global attention turned to the war in Gaza, President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that his country cannot afford a “frozen conflict” with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Former Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, in his new role as foreign secretary, vowed on a surprise visit to Ukraine that his country would maintain military support for Kyiv “however long it takes,” an effort to offer reassurance amid fears that Ukraine is being forgotten as much of the world’s attention focuses on the war in Gaza.

headline: Finland Will Close 4 Border Crossings With Russia to Stem Migrants
abstract: Officials accused Moscow of loosening migration controls. Relations between the countries deteriorated after Finland joined NATO following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Finland said on Thursday that it was closing part of its border with Russia after a dramatic increase in migrant crossings that it blamed on Moscow, the latest sign of deteriorating relations between the neighbors since the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): What Is Going on With the Grammy Nominations?
abstract: Dissecting the contenders for the 2024 Grammy Awards, including top nods for SZA, Olivia Rodrigo, boygenius, Miley Cyrus, Taylor Swift and Jon Batiste.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Chappaqua, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Cliffside Park, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 5,000-square-foot, three-story house from 2009, with a two-story entryway with a curved staircase, a large family room with a gas fireplace, an adjoining galley kitchen, a formal dining room, a lower-level in-law suite with a second kitchen, an elevator, a three-car attached garage, a partially covered patio and outdoor kitchen, on a 0.12-acre corner lot one block from the cliffs of the Palisades. Elina Policastro, Sotheby’s International Realty, 201-424-8213, legacysir.com

headline: Will Shortz’s Life as a ‘Professional Puzzle Maker’
abstract: The New York Times Crossword editor celebrates his 30th year in a job many would love to have.
lead_paragraph: Crossword Challenge: We’ve republished the Nov. 21 crossword of every year Will Shortz has been editor. These puzzles will be available for free until Nov. 30. Solve by difficulty level after this article.

headline: APEC Thrusts San Francisco Into the Spotlight
abstract: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference with President Biden and other world leaders is expected to draw as many as 30,000 people.
lead_paragraph: The spotlight is on San Francisco this week as it hosts the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, a high-profile summit of 21 Pacific Rim countries that is expected to bring as many as 30,000 people to the Bay Area.

headline: Haley Tussles With DeSantis, Aiming to Prove Herself in Iowa
abstract: Nikki Haley is vying for a matchup with Donald Trump in her home state. The calculus is similar for Ron DeSantis, who has stepped up his attacks on his rival for second place.
lead_paragraph: For most of the 2024 presidential cycle, Nikki Haley has ceded ground in Iowa to Donald J. Trump, who dominates its polls, and to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who has made the state central to his hopes of besting the Republican front-runner.

headline: Xi Jinping’s U.S. Visit Unites Protesters
abstract: With Xi Jinping visiting the U.S. for the first time in more than six years, protesters seized a rare chance to speak out together on issues that cannot be openly discussed in China.
lead_paragraph: With Xi Jinping visiting the U.S. for the first time in more than six years, protesters seized a rare chance to speak out together on issues that cannot be openly discussed in China.

headline: Biden Met With Xi, in an Effort to Lower the Heat
abstract: Also, salty drinking water threatens lower Louisiana. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met today with Xi Jinping, the president of China, on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in California. It was their first conversation in a year, and both leaders framed the meeting as a step toward easing tensions that had dramatically worsened in recent years. “Planet Earth is big enough” for both superpowers, Xi said, adding that their countries should be “fully capable of rising above differences.”

headline: Largely Ignored by the Western World, Africa’s Medieval Treasures Shine at the Met
abstract: North Africa’s influences radiated throughout Byzantium,  helping to create a Golden Age. These objects are high on the beauty and rarity scale.
lead_paragraph: We like to keep history as we’ve learned it in a headlock, to make sure it doesn’t shift or change. Standard maps are useful aids in imposing paralysis. They turn the world into a fixed field of safe-spots and blanks, an us-them weave of gates and fences.

headline: Elite Runner Who Rode in a Car During a Race Is Banned for a Year
abstract: The ultramarathoner Joasia Zakrzewski acknowledged that she got a lift for two and a half miles of a 50-mile race in April.
lead_paragraph: A top ultramarathoner who got a lift for part of a race has been banned for a year from competing or coaching in Britain.

headline: Retailers Wary of Squeeze on Shoppers Ahead of Key Holiday Season
abstract: Consumers have bucked expectations despite high inflation and interest rates, but retailers worry whether they can keep it up through the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Days ahead of the start of the holiday shopping season, several major retailers expressed caution about consumers during the busiest selling period of the year.

headline: Cryptocurrency Prices Surge, Driven by a Potential Bitcoin Fund
abstract: Investors anticipate regulatory approval of an exchange traded fund linked directly to Bitcoin, which they hope will encourage more people to invest in the digital asset.
lead_paragraph: In a Manhattan courtroom this month, the cryptocurrency industry faced a reckoning as its onetime star, Sam Bankman-Fried, was convicted of fraud in a trial that put the industry’s excesses on vivid display.

headline: Pedro Sánchez Secures New Term to Lead a Divided Spain
abstract: The Socialist prime minister won a parliamentary vote only after promising amnesty to Catalan separatists, enraging conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Sánchez, the Spanish progressive leader, secured a second term as prime minister on Thursday after a polarizing agreement granting amnesty to Catalan separatists gave him enough support in Parliament to govern with a fragile coalition over an increasingly divided nation.

headline: Santos Won’t Seek Re-election After House Panel Finds Evidence of Crimes
abstract: The findings, which were referred to prosecutors, are likely to prompt another attempt to expel the embattled congressman from the House.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee on Thursday found “substantial evidence” that Representative George Santos violated federal law, setting the stage for another push to expel the embattled first-term Republican from New York and prompting him to declare that he would not seek re-election.

headline: Israel Blocks Palestinian Americans From Entering From West Bank
abstract: The move is an apparent violation of a recent agreement that says citizens from the United States and Israel can travel to the other nation without a visa.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: When Your Significant Other Has Four Legs and Fur
abstract: For singles who have grown weary of dating, pet ownership helps fill the relationship void.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Clayton has been single for two years, giving her ample time to reach a conclusion about dating: It’s not really her thing, at least for now.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in Manhattan Valley and in Cobble Hill.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 800-square-foot co-op unit with a windowed galley kitchen, a sunken living and dining area, and a large bedroom with a windowed en suite bath and a walk-in closet, on the 10th floor of a 19-story prewar doorman building with a live-in super, shared laundry and extra storage. Linda Reiner and Lisa Tarnopol Deslauriers, 917-273-5860, Coldwell Banker Warburg; cbwarburg.com

headline: We Talked to Some Kamala-but-Not-Joe Voters. Here’s What They Said.
abstract: A slice of voters would vote for Vice President Harris but not President Biden, reflecting his challenges and opportunities.
lead_paragraph: In our recent poll of voters in battleground states, we asked how people would vote if Kamala Harris were running for president. Though Donald J. Trump still led in this hypothetical matchup, Vice President Harris performed slightly better than President Biden.

headline: How One Family’s Pursuit of Tennis Success Ended in Heartache
abstract: The death of one daughter and the struggles of another have left a prominent New Zealand tennis family questioning their choices and their relationship with the game they once loved.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, David Lewis received a phone call from the coroner’s office in Washington, D.C. His oldest daughter, Carolina, a former college tennis player, had been found dead in a hotel room. She was 23.

headline: Man Exonerated in Malcolm X’s Murder Sues U.S. Over His Conviction
abstract: Muhammad A. Aziz and the estate of Khalil Islam are seeking answers about why the F.B.I. withheld evidence that later cleared both men.
lead_paragraph: A former member of the Nation of Islam who was exonerated in the assassination of Malcolm X filed a federal lawsuit on Thursday in a case that could shed new light on the F.B.I.’s role in one of the most notorious murders of the civil rights era.

headline: An Old Watch Gets a Face-Lift Orchestrated by John Mayer
abstract: The musician enlisted Online Ceramics, a brand known for its idiosyncratic T-shirts, to remake Casio’s G-Shock.
lead_paragraph: It’s not uncommon to see clocks or hourglasses alongside the snails, skeletons, scarecrows and other imagery on Online Ceramics T-shirts. The label’s founders, Elijah Funk and Alix Ross, said the passage of time has been a theme they’ve explored since they started designing clothing several years ago in Los Angeles.

headline: The Eclectic Inspirations for Alan Wake 2’s Surreal Tale
abstract: Yes, there is a Stephen King influence. But the video game’s metanarrative was inspired by unorthodox novels, films and plays such as “House of Leaves” and “Fight Club.”
lead_paragraph: A gritty crime thriller with a dreamlike tone and dense postmodern flourishes, the survival horror video game Alan Wake 2 is often weird and always unpredictable, veering off from its small-town murder-mystery setting to follow surreal and mind-bending digressions. It has few, if any, video game precedents.

headline: ‘Rustin’ Review: A Crucial Civil Rights Activist Gets His Due
abstract: Colman Domingo carries this biopic of a March on Washington organizer, the first narrative feature from Michelle and Barack Obama’s production company.
lead_paragraph: Every so often an actor so dominates a movie that its success largely hinges on his every word and gesture. That’s the case with Colman Domingo’s galvanic title performance in “Rustin,” which runs like a current through this portrait of the gay civil-rights activist, a close adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Pacifist, ex-con, singer, lutist, socialist — Bayard Rustin had many lives, but he remains best known as the main organizer of the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. It was Rustin who read the march’s demands from the podium, remaining near King’s side as he delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech.

headline: How International Law Views Military Action at a Hospital
abstract: Human rights laws prohibit harming or interfering with a hospital like Gaza’s Al-Shifa, with very narrow exceptions, or using it as a human shield. Attacking one can be a war crime.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military has seized the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital, Al-Shifa. Israel says it needed to capture the hospital, in Gaza City, to destroy a Hamas command center and underground facilities that it says are there. Hamas and doctors at Al-Shifa deny Israeli allegations of Hamas fighters using the hospital as a base.

headline: Test Your Protein Knowledge
abstract: How much do you need, and where should you get it? See how much you really know about this essential nutrient with our quiz.
lead_paragraph: How much do you need, and where should you get it? See how much you really know about this essential nutrient with our quiz.

headline: SpaceX Shifts the 2nd Launch of Its Starship Rocket to Saturday
abstract: Elon Musk’s private space company is hoping for a better performance of the giant rocket, which is the most powerful ever to fly.
lead_paragraph: Follow updates from the second Starship test launch here.

headline: Union Workers Back Contract Deals at 3 Big Automakers
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union hopes the agreements with General Motors, Ford and Stellantis will help it make inroads at other companies.
lead_paragraph: Members of the United Automobile Workers union have given their backing to new contracts with the three big U.S. automakers, agreements that deliver hefty wage increases and other gains that had eluded the union for more than 20 years.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Death of Jewish Protester After California Altercation
abstract: The local prosecutor said he would charge the man with involuntary manslaughter and battery causing serious injury, in the death of a 69-year-old Jewish protester in Thousand Oaks this month.
lead_paragraph: It was, at first, the usual kind of interaction that takes place at dueling rallies. An argument between two opposing protesters, each firm in his beliefs.

headline: In Mumbai, an Intimate Diwali Dinner Party
abstract: Aditi Dugar, the owner of the restaurant Masque, celebrated the festival of lights with a modern Indian tasting menu prepared by the chef Varun Totlani.
lead_paragraph: During the Hindu festival of Diwali, intricate neon-hued sand decorations called rangoli embellish the entrances of homes across India and the diaspora, their presence intended to ward off evil and usher in good fortune. At a recent Diwali dinner party at the Mumbai restaurant Masque, its owner, Aditi Dugar, 40, and chef, Varun Totlani, 31, paid homage to this tradition by welcoming their guests with an edible play on rangoli: slices of cured barramundi from the Andaman Islands, in the northeastern Indian Ocean, topped with colorful garnishes like yellow fennel flowers, radish microgreens and red pomegranate arils.

headline: Park Avenue Armory Will Host ‘Illinoise’ and ‘Indra’s Net’ in 2024
abstract: The Armory’s upcoming season also includes the North American premiere of ‘Inside Light.’
lead_paragraph: The Park Avenue Armory announced its 2024 season on Thursday, including the New York City arrival of “Illinoise,” a dance-theater work based on a Sufjan Stevens album and staged by Justin Peck, and the North American premiere of “Indra’s Net,” an immersive installation performance inspired by a Buddhist story and created by the interdisciplinary artist Meredith Monk.

headline: The Mysterious Injuries Among U.S. Troops
abstract: Responses to an article about soldiers who have brain damage from firing heavy weapons. Also: Mike Johnson; Capitol fighting; climate change; preventing falls.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 29, 2023
abstract: The Colorado River is shrinking. What’s using all the water?
lead_paragraph: Note: Comments are open for student responses. Live moderated discussion of this graph will take place on Wednesday, Nov. 29.

headline: House Republicans, Stalled on Spending, Weaponize the Power of the Purse
abstract: As Congress struggles to do the bare minimum of keeping the government funded, House Republicans are using the annual federal spending bills to try to punish the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: Just before hard-right House Republicans staged a floor mutiny over spending on Wednesday that sent lawmakers home early for their Thanksgiving break, they managed one final vote, on a measure to reduce the salary of an obscure Biden administration official to $1.

headline: Sally Darr, Formidable Chef of ’80s-Era French Bistro, Dies at 100
abstract: A skilled and self-taught cook of homey French fare, she drew fans (including Julia Child) to her Greenwich Village restaurant for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Sally Darr, the exacting chef and owner of La Tulipe, a tiny 1980s-era French bistro in downtown Manhattan renowned for its exquisite yet homey French cooking — and often agonizing delays — resulting from her infamous perfectionism, died on Nov. 7 at her home in the West Village. She was 100.

headline: Muslim Runner Says She Was Cut From Lululemon Campaign Over Religious Identity
abstract: Amena Saad participated in a photo shoot ahead of the New York City Marathon, but later discovered she was cropped out. Lululemon said it was a mistake.
lead_paragraph: An Arab-American runner who competed in the New York City Marathon said she was cropped out of a Lululemon media campaign because of her identity and support for Palestinians in the Israel-Gaza war.

headline: Gaza Is Plunged Into a Communications Blackout Amid a Severe Fuel Shortage
abstract: Major Palestinian networks said “all telecom services” in the Gaza Strip were down, leaving most in the enclave cut off from the outside world amid an escalating Israeli operation.
lead_paragraph: The Gaza Strip was in a communications blackout on Thursday, leaving most of the more than two million people in the enclave cut off from the outside world amid an escalating Israeli ground operation and relentless bombardment.

headline: Why Some Seniors Are Choosing Pot Over Pills
abstract: Older people are using cannabis more than ever. Here’s what to know about its potential medicinal benefits and side effects as we age.
lead_paragraph: Seniors are one of the fastest-growing populations of cannabis users in the United States. While some older adults have used pot for decades, studies suggest that others are turning to the drug for the first time to help them sleep better, dampen pain or treat anxiety — especially when prescription drugs, which often come with unwanted side effects, don’t work as intended.In 2007, only about 0.4 percent of people age 65 and older in the United States had reported using cannabis in the past year, according to the National Survey on Drug Use and Health. That number rose to almost 3 percent by 2016. As of 2022, it was at more than 8 percent.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends dancing dogs, Shakespeare scholars and an animated adaptation.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Secret Life of Dancing Dogs’

headline: Measles Cases Climb Across the Globe
abstract: The virus sickened an estimated nine million people worldwide in 2022, most of them children.
lead_paragraph: Measles cases worldwide rose 18 percent and deaths increased by more than 40 percent from 2021 to 2022 as countries struggled to get routine vaccinations back on track after the pandemic, according to a new report from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: ‘Fallen Leaves’ Review: Love (and Laughs) Among the Ruins
abstract: In the latest from the Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki, two lonely people find each other with tenderness, karaoke and deadpan comedy.
lead_paragraph: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise. In between, there are lonely nights, fleeting joys, ordinary degradations, laborious work, karaoke reveries, many cigarettes and more drinks. A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs. Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.

headline: Day After Xi Meeting, Biden Says U.S. Has ‘Real Differences’ With China
abstract: Mr. Biden won applause when he noted that he and Mr. Xi had agreed to resume military-to-military communication to “reduce the risk of miscalculation.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden said Thursday that the United States has “real differences with Beijing,” one day after he held an hourslong meeting with President Xi Jinping of China at a moment of deep tension between the two countries.

headline: ‘Monarch: Legacy of Monsters’ Review: Godzilla vs. Kurt Russell
abstract: The MonsterVerse franchise adds a series on Apple TV+ and brings a classic leading man back to the small screen.
lead_paragraph: Among entertainment series based on extra-powerful intellectual property, Legendary Pictures’ so-called MonsterVerse is a latecomer and a lightweight. Beginning with “Godzilla” in 2014, it has generated four films, unexceptional beyond their special effects (and middling performers at the box office, by franchise standards), and an animated Netflix series. Not exactly a rampage.

headline: For Thanksgiving, 20 Wines Under $20
abstract: These lively, versatile bottles are perfect for a crowd. Don’t worry about pairing, these will go with anything.
lead_paragraph: By now, your Thanksgiving preparations may nearly be set. You are on top of the menu, who’s cooking what, seating, tasks for the children. But what about the wine?

headline: Hunter College Pulls Screening of Film Critical of Israel
abstract: The cancellation of a showing this week of the documentary “Israelism” caused a backlash from the college’s Senate, which called it a violation of academic freedom.
lead_paragraph: Hunter College this week abruptly pulled a screening of a documentary film critical of Israel, creating a backlash from faculty members and students who have charged the New York school’s administration with undermining academic freedom.

headline: Panda Diplomacy Might Not Be Dead Just Yet
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China said his country may keep sending giant pandas to the United States. The National Zoo in Washington sent three of them back to China last week.
lead_paragraph: The fur balls might be coming back to Washington and San Diego.

headline: ‘Saltburn’ Review: A Promising Young Man Takes a Seedy Turn
abstract: In the new film from Emerald Fennell, Barry Keoghan plays an Oxford student drawn into a world of lust and envy at a classmate’s estate.
lead_paragraph: “Saltburn” is the sort of embarrassment you’ll put up with for 75 minutes. But not for 127. It’s too desperate, too confused, too pleased with its petty shocks to rile anything you’d recognize as genuine excitement. This thing was written and directed by Emerald Fennell, whose previous movie was “Promising Young Woman,” a horror flick about rape that was also a revenge comedy. So believe me: She wants you riled. Fennell’s seen the erotic thrillers, studied her Hitchcock and possibly read her Patricia Highsmith, and gets that if you name your main character Oliver Quick he’s obligated to do something at least arguably Dickensian. The question here, amid all the lying, lazing about and (eventually, inevitably) dying, is to what end?

headline: What Students Are Saying About Waking Up in the Morning
abstract: “Mornings have always been a battleground, a relentless struggle between my cozy bed and the demanding alarm clock.”
lead_paragraph: How hard is it to wake up in the morning?

headline: Philip Glass’s Piano Etudes: A Diary of an Influential Life
abstract: Begun to improve his own technique, piano exercises that Glass wrote over decades are the subject this month of a new book, a concert and dances.
lead_paragraph: Philip Glass wanted to become a better pianist.

headline: Showstopping Mains for a Vegetarian Thanksgiving
abstract: Think roasted carrots on a plush bed of ricotta and feta, or a vegetable biryani studded with cashews and pomegranate seeds.
lead_paragraph: To be clear: There is nothing wrong with assembling a vegetarian Thanksgiving feast out of your favorite vegetable sides. A tray of scalloped potatoes with cider-glazed brussels sprouts and roasted mushrooms would be a very fine meal. But given that Thanksgiving is essentially the Food Super Bowl, you might want a showstopping star, something big and grand to anchor the table both in importance and heft.

headline: Scientists Find First Evidence That Groups of Apes Cooperate
abstract: Some bonobos are challenging the notion that humans are the only primates capable of group-to-group alliances.
lead_paragraph: If a troop of baboons encounters another troop on the savanna, they may keep a respectful distance or they may get into a fight. But human groups often do something else: They cooperate.

headline: 2 Israeli Hostages’ Bodies Were Recovered Near Al-Shifa Hospital, Army Says
abstract: Israeli officials say the hospital complex hosts major Hamas facilities, some in underground bunkers, a claim that Hamas and hospital officials reject.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers have recovered the bodies of two hostages kidnapped during the Hamas-led attack on Israel last month from buildings near the Al-Shifa Hospital complex in Gaza City, the Israeli military has said.

headline: Trump and Bolsonaro Claimed Fraud. Now an Argentine Candidate Is, Too.
abstract: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian economist, could be elected Argentina’s president on Sunday. If he is not, he has already pointed to fraud.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s claims of election fraud already helped inspire one South American leader, former president Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, to sow doubt about the security of his nation’s elections, leading to a riot in Brazil’s capital this year.

headline: Jewish Celebrities and Influencers Confront TikTok Executives in Private Call
abstract: TikTok faces escalating accusations that it promotes pro-Palestinian, anti-Israel content. “Shame on you,” Sacha Baron Cohen said on the call.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen Jewish TikTok creators and celebrities confronted TikTok executives and other employees in a private meeting on Wednesday night, urging them to do more to address a surge of antisemitism and harassment on the popular video service.

headline: Man Obsessed With Online Conspiracy Theories Convicted in Paul Pelosi Attack
abstract: San Francisco jurors convicted David DePape, 43, of federal crimes for breaking into the home of Nancy Pelosi and striking her husband with a hammer.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Thursday convicted David DePape of federal crimes for breaking into the San Francisco home of Representative Nancy Pelosi and beating her husband with a hammer in an attack that raised fears of political violence ahead of the 2022 midterm elections.

headline: It’s Always Fire Season Now
abstract: The world has always experienced fire year-round, but these are a lot harder to ignore.
lead_paragraph: It’s the end of fire season in the Amazon, where I am, and I can smell the smoke from burning trees. So can millions of people in Indonesia, India and the United States.

headline: Nov. 18: SpaceX may attempt a second flight of its Starship rocket.
abstract: On April 20, SpaceX conducted the first full flight test of its Starship vehicle that is to one day carry astronauts to the moon and perhaps colonists to Mars. The brief flight was a learning experience that ended in the tumbling rocket being ordered to self-destruct, and with a torn-up launch site. On Saturday as early as 8 a.m. Eastern time, the company will attempt a second test flight from its launch site in Boca Chica, Texas. The launch had been planned for Friday but was postponed one day to replace a part on the rocket.
lead_paragraph: On April 20, SpaceX conducted the first full flight test of its Starship vehicle that is to one day carry astronauts to the moon and perhaps colonists to Mars. The brief flight was a learning experience that ended in the tumbling rocket being ordered to self-destruct, and with a torn-up launch site. On Saturday as early as 8 a.m. Eastern time, the company will attempt a second test flight from its launch site in Boca Chica, Texas. The launch had been planned for Friday but was postponed one day to replace a part on the rocket.

headline: Dozens Are Injured in Chicago Train Crash
abstract: Of 38 people who were injured when a Yellow Line train struck a plow on the tracks, nearly two dozen were taken to hospitals in conditions ranging from serious to fair, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were injured on Thursday morning when a Chicago Transit Authority train struck a plow on the tracks on Chicago’s North Side, the authorities said.

headline: A Taste of Florida on the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: While it is popular all year long, Key lime pie sales surge for the holiday, and many bakeries in Florida are preparing.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving, Carey McKearnan and her family typically squeeze more than 20 firm Key limes for the juice her mother, Sherin McKearnan, uses to make Key lime pie.

headline: Protesters Demanding Gaza Cease-Fire Shut Down Bay Bridge
abstract: Westbound traffic into San Francisco was blocked, causing enormous traffic jams on highways in the East Bay. At least 50 people were arrested.
lead_paragraph: Protesters demanding a cease-fire in Gaza shut down westbound traffic on the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Thursday morning, interrupting Bay Area commuter traffic into San Francisco.

headline: Congress Prevented a Shutdown, but the Spending Fight Is Far From Over
abstract: Lawmakers bought time for talks, but heading off another shutdown threat early next year will be difficult. And a separate funding measure for Israel, Ukraine and the border remains unaddressed.
lead_paragraph: The stopgap spending bill Congress sent to President Biden late Wednesday prevented the federal government from shutting down as of 12:01 a.m. Saturday. But it is only a temporary reprieve, and lawmakers have considerable work to do before federal agencies again face the threat of running out of money beginning Jan. 19.

headline: Talks on Surveillance Law Simmer as Its Expiration Date Looms
abstract: If congressional inaction lets Section 702 lapse on New Year’s Eve, officials believe the program could lawfully operate into April.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations in Congress over a warrantless surveillance law are intensifying as it nears its expiration date. The debate has come during what national security officials say is a surge in threats fueled by the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: How Santos Spent Donors’ Money: Ferragamo, OnlyFans and Botox
abstract: House ethics investigators found that Representative George Santos used campaign money on personal spending splurges in the Hamptons and Atlantic City.
lead_paragraph: George Santos was utterly triumphant. He had just flipped a Long Island congressional seat, improbably helping deliver Republicans a House majority. It was time for a post-election shopping spree.

headline: Eric Adams Slashes Budgets for Police, Libraries and Schools
abstract: Mr. Adams said the migrant crisis made the deep budget cuts necessary. Progressive Democrats called the reductions dangerous and unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams announced painful budget cuts to New York City services on Thursday that would freeze police hiring and close libraries on Sunday and warned that more cuts would be necessary without additional federal funding to manage the migrant crisis.

headline: Friday Briefing: Israel Continues to Search Al-Shifa
abstract: Plus accusations of atrocities in Darfur.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers yesterday were still combing Al-Shifa Hospital, which the Israeli military has said concealed a secret Hamas base. The Gaza health ministry said that thousands of people remained inside the Al-Shifa Hospital compound with little food and water.

headline: Trump’s Truth Social Platform Could Struggle to Survive Without New Cash
abstract: Truth Social, the online platform at the core of Trump Media, has had challenges attracting advertising revenue.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company is running on fumes and could be at risk of folding if it doesn’t find new funds in a hurry.

headline: Videos About Bin Laden’s Criticism of U.S. Surge in Popularity on TikTok
abstract: The videos discuss a letter the former Al Qaeda leader wrote in 2002 in which he defended the Sept. 11 attacks and said Americans had become “servants” to Jews.
lead_paragraph: Videos on TikTok supporting a decades-old letter by Osama bin Laden criticizing the United States and its support of Israel surged in popularity this week, adding to accusations that the company is fueling the spread of antisemitic content. The White House condemned the resurfacing of the letter.

headline: How to Skip the Turkey
abstract: And dairy-free desserts, mushroom-free gravy and a kabocha casserole. It’s Thanksgiving Recipe Matchmaker.
lead_paragraph: We’re one week out from Thanksgiving, and you need showstopping sides (read to the very end for rapid-fire recipes) and meatless mains and dairy-free desserts, and you need them stat. So let’s not waste a moment of time. This … is Recipe Matchmaker.

headline: Sean Combs Is Accused by Cassie of Rape and Years of Abuse in Lawsuit
abstract: In the suit, the singer says Mr. Combs, known as Puff Daddy or Diddy, subjected her to a pattern of control and abuse over about a decade. Mr. Combs “vehemently” denied the allegations.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the producer and music mogul who has been one of the most famous names in hip-hop for decades, was sued in federal court on Thursday by Cassie, an R&B singer once signed to his label, who accused Mr. Combs of rape, and of repeated physical abuse over about a decade.

headline: Kaitlin Armstrong Found Guilty in Murder of the Cyclist Moriah Wilson
abstract: Ms. Armstrong fled the United States and went to Costa Rica after she was named as a suspect in the killing of Ms. Wilson, a 25-year-old professional cyclist.
lead_paragraph: Kaitlin Armstrong was found guilty of first-degree murder on Thursday in the death of Moriah Wilson, a professional cyclist who had briefly dated Ms. Armstrong’s boyfriend and was killed while visiting Austin, Texas, for a bike race 18 months ago.

headline: John Morris, Who Brought Rock Legends to the Stage, Dies at 84
abstract: As a coordinator of the Woodstock festival and the hallowed New York venue Fillmore East, he helped showcase the likes of Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin.
lead_paragraph: John Morris, who brought an element of spectacle to the rock explosion of the 1960s as a coordinator and M.C. for the era-defining Woodstock festival, and who also helped run the storied rock venues Fillmore East in New York City and the Rainbow theater in London, died on Friday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84.

headline: Supreme Court Refuses to Revive Florida Law Restricting Drag Shows
abstract: A federal judge in Orlando ruled that the law violated the First Amendment, saying it was “specifically designed to suppress the speech of drag queen performers.”
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court refused on Thursday to revive a Florida law that banned children from “adult live performances” such as drag shows.

headline: For Biden, a Subtle Shift in the Power Balance With China’s Xi Jinping
abstract: For the first time in years, a Chinese leader desperately needed a few things from the United States.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden met President Xi Jinping on Wednesday on the edges of Silicon Valley, there was a subtle but noticeable shift in the power dynamic between two countries that have spent most of the past few years denouncing, undercutting and imposing sanctions on each other.

headline: Robert Battle, Artistic Director of Alvin Ailey Company, Resigns
abstract: Battle is stepping away after running the company for 12 years, citing health concerns.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater announced on Thursday that Robert Battle, its artistic director since 2011, is resigning from the position, citing health concerns.

headline: Blame Shifting, Attacks and Legal Gaslighting
abstract: The former president’s defense strategy is taking shape.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s defenses in his federal election interference case are coming into focus: a mix of blame shifting, political attacks and a kind of legal gaslighting.

headline: A Bronx Island With a Million Graves Is Now a Park
abstract: Hart Island, which has served as New York City's potter's field since the 1800s, will open for limited public tours.
lead_paragraph: Hart Island, which has served as New York City's potter's field since the 1800s, will open for limited public tours.

headline: Canada Convicts White Supremacist in Killing of Four Muslims
abstract: A judge is expected to rule on whether Nathaniel Veltman, 22, also committed terrorism when he rammed his pickup truck into a Muslim family in June 2021.
lead_paragraph: For four seconds, Nathaniel Veltman floored the gas pedal, hurtling his pickup truck toward a Muslim family of five out for an evening walk in London, Ontario, killing four of them. The lone survivor was a 9-year-old boy.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: At the National Book Awards last night, the nonfiction chair Ada Ferrer explained what she and her fellow judges had been looking for as they narrowed the field from hundreds of submissions to five finalists and finally one winner (Ned Blackhawk’s “The Rediscovery of America”): They wanted books that somehow made a difference, in any of the many ways that books can do that, and that were well written, in any of the many ways that books can meet that definition.

headline: Tracking Potential Tropical Cyclone Twenty-Two
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times.

headline: Sickle-Cell Treatment Created With Gene Editing Wins U.K. Approval
abstract: The first treatment that relies on CRISPR is expected to receive U.S. approval next month. But it may cost millions of dollars per patient.
lead_paragraph: Regulators in Britain on Thursday approved the first treatment derived from CRISPR, the revolutionary gene-editing method. Called Casgevy, the treatment is intended to cure sickle-cell disease and a related condition, beta thalassemia.

headline: Jury Deadlocks on Officer Charged With Violating Breonna Taylor’s Rights
abstract: Brett Hankison, a former police detective, would have been the second Louisville officer to be convicted on federal charges related to the fatal police raid on Ms. Taylor’s home in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution of Brett Hankison, the former police detective who fired 10 bullets through Breonna Taylor’s apartment during a fatal 2020 raid in Louisville, Ky., ended in a mistrial on Thursday after the jury said it could not reach a unanimous verdict on federal civil rights charges.

headline: Listen: Hamas’s Bloody Philosophy, Questions for Kamala Harris, Barbra Streisand’s Tell-All Memoir
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Trump and Aides Immediately Attack Clerk After Gag Order Is Paused
abstract: Allison Greenfield has become a lightning rod for the former president and his allies, who say a civil fraud case against him is political persecution.
lead_paragraph: A New York appeals court judge on Thursday paused gag orders on Donald J. Trump and his lawyers that had prevented them from commenting on court staff in the civil fraud trial of the former president.

headline: A.C.L.U. Sues DeSantis Over Crackdown on Pro-Palestinian Campus Group
abstract: Florida education officials moved to ban chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine, but critics say it’s a clear cut violation of the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union and Palestine Legal filed a federal lawsuit Thursday claiming that Gov. Ron DeSantis and Florida education officials violated the First Amendment when they ordered the removal of support for Students for Justice in Palestine, a campus activist group.

headline: Swifties Delight, Then Recoil, From Travis Kelce’s Old Tweets
abstract: Taylor Swift fans were delighted to discover Travis Kelce’s old posts about Olive Garden and squirrels. Then comments about “ugly girls” and “fat people” resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: For celebrities riding a wave of fame, it may well be a rite of passage: new scrutiny to old social media posts. This week, it was Travis Kelce’s turn, as fans of Taylor Swift took delight in mundane tweets by her apparent boyfriend from his early 20s.

headline: Pressure Mounts as Israel Combs Through Gaza Hospital for Hamas’s Presence
abstract: The Israeli military said troops had uncovered a Hamas tunnel shaft underneath the Al-Shifa Hospital complex, as well as a vehicle on the hospital grounds packed with weapons.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: F.B.I. Raided Homes of Second Adams Aide and Ex-Turkish Airline Official
abstract: On the same day the federal authorities raided the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s chief fund-raiser, they also searched the residences of two people with ties to Turkey.
lead_paragraph: As F.B.I. agents searched the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s chief fund-raiser earlier this month for evidence his campaign conspired with Turkey, separate teams executed warrants at the residences of two others with ties to the mayor and that country, several people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Johnny Green, Jumpin’ Knicks All-Star, Dies at 89
abstract: An All-Star forward — and an all-American at Michigan State — he was known as Jumpin’ Johnny, able to soar over taller opponents for 14 seasons in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Green, an All-Star forward for the Knicks in the 1960s who gained acclaim for his leaping ability and rebounding prowess through 14 National Basketball Association seasons, died on Thursday in Huntington, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 89.

headline: Israeli Troops Scoured a Gaza Hospital for Signs of Hamas
abstract: Also, George Santos won’t seek re-election. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: As night fell in the Gaza Strip today, Israeli troops were still searching the territory’s largest hospital, Al-Shifa, which Israel has said concealed a secret Hamas base.

headline: X Races to Contain Damage After Elon Musk Endorses Antisemitic Post
abstract: IBM, a major advertiser on X, has pulled its spending from the social media platform, whose employees are grappling with what to tell its other advertisers, according to internal messages.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after Elon Musk endorsed an antisemitic post on X as “the actual truth” of what Jewish people were doing, IBM paused its advertising on the social media platform as X’s chief executive, Linda Yaccarino, and others at the company scrambled on Thursday to contain the fallout.

headline: There Should Be More Public Pressure on Hamas
abstract: Legal accountability depends on political resolve.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2008, I helped raid a hospital. As I’ve written before, I was deployed as a JAG officer (an Army lawyer) with the Third Armored Cavalry Regiment in Diyala Province, Iraq. Diyala was in the midst of a wave of suicide bombings, many of them carried out by women, that was brutal beyond words. And the vast majority in our area of operations weren’t aimed at American troops. We could be quite hard to hit. Instead, suicide bombers blew up cafes, medical clinics and weddings. Sometimes they’d “double tap.” One bomber would detonate, then as medical help arrived, a second bomber would kill aid workers and desperate family members who were searching for survivors.

headline: Writing Prompts About Food, Family and Culture
abstract: Here are some questions to help students reflect on the food traditions and memories that are most meaningful to them.
lead_paragraph: When you think of your cultural or familial traditions, do you think of food? The meals that are part of your holiday celebrations? The special dishes your parents or grandparents have prepared for you? The flavors that remind you of who you are and where you’re from?

headline: Tiffany Haddish, Misty Copeland and Martha Stewart Party in New York City
abstract: The Shed hosted a benefit in the Hudson Yards neighborhood of Manhattan, and the Central Park Conservancy held a gala in the park.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, about 500 people gathered in the Hudson Yards neighborhood of Manhattan for the fourth-annual gala for the Shed, the $475 million arts center that opened in 2019. It has since hosted a concert series by the director Steve McQueen and Quincy Jones and is currently staging Stephen Sondheim’s final musical, “Here We Are.”

headline: Universities Are Failing at Inclusion
abstract: Instead of being places where students learn other points of view, American universities have become ideological war zones.
lead_paragraph: Over the past five weeks, Jewish students on America’s campuses have found themselves confronted with those who celebrate a terrorist operation that featured the mass murder and reportedly the rape of fellow Jews. They see images of people tearing down posters of kidnapped Jewish children. At M.I.T., Jewish students report that they were told by some faculty members to avoid the university’s main lobby — which had been the site of a pro-Palestinian protest — for their own safety. At Cooper Union, Jewish students were barricaded in the library by a protest that started out as a pro-Palestinian demonstration and quickly became, one student reported, “pure anti-Jew.”

headline: American Musicians Are Doing Something Profound in Beijing Right Now
abstract: While Chinese and American leaders meet in a contentious moment, the musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra and their Chinese counterparts find harmony.
lead_paragraph: While presidents Joe Biden and Xi Jinping were drawing the world’s attention for their talks in San Francisco this week, a different kind of summitry is happening in China. There, representatives from their two countries are speaking through violins, cellos, oboes and clarinets.

headline: International Court Orders Syria to Stop Torture of Political Opponents
abstract: Human rights experts have estimated that some 14,000 people died from torture or were killed in the prisons run by military intelligence and security forces during Syria’s long civil war.
lead_paragraph: Judges at the U.N.’s highest court on Thursday ordered Syria’s government to stop torturing its imprisoned opponents, seeking to end the abuses that have become a notorious hallmark of the country’s long civil war that has left hundreds of thousands dead.

headline: ‘Spamalot’ Review: You’ll Laugh in Its General Direction
abstract: In the first Broadway revival of the Monty Python musical, the old bits are verbatim but the clowns are running the circus.
lead_paragraph: Even the coconuts get entrance applause.

headline: Car Talk and Birthday Wishes Punctuate Biden’s ‘Trust but Verify’ Diplomacy
abstract: Despite simmering tensions, President Biden and President Xi Jinping exchanged the kind of pleasantries that adversarial leaders deploy when they are trying to make nice.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, President Xi Jinping of China is largely considered a mysterious autocrat who has long harbored a fatalistic view of his country’s relationship with the United States.

headline: Ohio Man Who Attacked Officers on Jan. 6 Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison
abstract: Kenneth Joseph Owen Thomas has failed to express remorse for his actions that day and turned his notoriety as a rioter into a brand, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio man who assaulted law enforcement officers during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and who the Justice Department said became a “one-man misinformation machine” as he spread lies online about what occurred that day, was sentenced on Thursday to four years and 10 months in prison.

headline: Just for Kicks
abstract: Hemant Mehta’s puzzle is a challenging start to the solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: They Started Playing Football as Young as 6. They Died in Their Teens and Twenties With C.T.E.
abstract: They started playing football as kids, began to suffer mentally and died before 30. Researchers found they had C.T.E., the brain disease linked to hits to the head. If their families could go back, would they still let them play?
lead_paragraph: They started playing football as kids, began to suffer mentally and died before 30. Researchers found they had C.T.E., the brain disease linked to hits to the head. If their families could go back, would they still let them play?

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart are here to cast a spell on us (and not a curse, let’s hope!).
