lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — There is something especially suspenseful about solving an acrostic puzzle that turns out to be about a great discovery; in this case, it’s one that has captured the world’s imagination and led to the notion of an ancient curse, disseminated by the writers Marie Corelli and Arthur Conan Doyle, that still persists.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Mystique in the Mountains Where a College Dynasty Grows
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “My job is to be a runner. Plain and simple, I felt like I was going to be able to do it the best here.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 17, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about paramilitary forces accused of committing atrocities while seizing territory in the Darfur region misstated the time period in which more than 800 people were killed as Rapid Support Forces and allied Arab fighters overran the army garrison in El Geneina. It was earlier this month as well as last week, not only last week.

headline: Nothing Could Stop Their Relationship From Heating Up
abstract: Jamie Kalman needed a fire performer for an event she was producing and was about to hire Aubrey DePew, but then the pandemic happened.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Leigh Kalman was looking for someone who could eat and breathe fire for an upcoming event she was producing in Pensacola, Fla. So she reached out to Aubrey Nicole DePew, who had precisely those skills, on Instagram.

headline: Her Cheese Was So Good That We Had to Break Up
abstract: Small gestures can build relationships — and also tear them down.
lead_paragraph: She offered to bring fancy cheese, the kind that costs $35 per pound. I said a couple of supermarket slabs would be fine, for one-fourth the price.

headline: On the Road to Healing, Finding Love After Loss
abstract: When Trevor Bates and Shahnaz Singh-Kandah met at church, both were overcoming personal challenges and neither was looking for love. But through divine intervention, they had a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Jovan Bates knew Shahnaz Singh-Kandah would be his wife even before he asked her out. “I heard the Holy Spirit say Shahnaz is your wife, and I heard it very clearly,” he said.

headline: After a Rough Start, a Strong Connection
abstract: After a first date, Bruce Patrick made a bold move that alarmed Travis London, who blocked him. They soon fell in love anyway.
lead_paragraph: Before Travis Kenneth London fell in love with Bruce Douglas Patrick, he had blocked his number.

headline: Making Sweet, and Bittersweet, Music Together
abstract: A bite of bruschetta helped lay the foundation for the relationship between the conductor Michael Repper and Vanessa Moody. That honesty served them well when she was diagnosed with a brain tumor.
lead_paragraph: Michael Eric Repper’s history of unflagging devotion to a narrow set of passions dates back to the early 1990s when, as a 3-year-old, he snapped to attention the moment the orchestra kicked in at a classical music concert. By the time he had reached his early 20s, another of his select few passions was consuming him: his relationship with his girlfriend, Vanessa Rodrigues Moody.

headline: Israeli and Palestinian Activists Ask Americans to Take Side of Peace
abstract: Sally Abed, a Palestinian citizen of Israel, and Alon-Lee Green, a Jewish Israeli, found polarization in America over the war in Gaza. They also found longing for a new approach.
lead_paragraph: When Sally Abed and Alon-Lee Green flew from Israel to New York last week, they found a version of the United States they’d never seen before: split by the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis, with fractures tearing at the worlds of art, business, books, academia and even food.

headline: What’s Left When a Long War Suddenly Ends
abstract: While the conflict over the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh concluded with an Azerbaijani victory, resentments simmer on both sides, creating fertile ground for new violence.
lead_paragraph: The commander of the victorious army watched on in triumph as his troops goose-stepped in columns through the central square of the former breakaway capital they had captured in a brazen attack just weeks before.

headline: Surprise! Los Angeles Freeway to Reopen Next Week, Newsom Says.
abstract: After California officials initially feared that a crucial section of Interstate 10 might close for months, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that it would reopen by Tuesday at the latest.
lead_paragraph: A major section of a freeway in Los Angeles that was shut down because of fire damage is expected to reopen no later than Tuesday — far earlier than officials had originally estimated and before the full onslaught of holiday traffic.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Israel’s search of a major hospital in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Two days into its search of the Al-Shifa Hospital complex in Gaza, the Israeli military offered video of weapons it said it had found there and what it described as a tunnel entrance. The images could not be independently verified and have not proved the existence of the sprawling Hamas base that the Israeli military said the hospital had concealed, and which Hamas and the hospital leadership have denied.

headline: Amtrak Train Derails in Michigan After Striking Vehicle on Tracks
abstract: The accident occurred near Lake Michigan an hour east of Chicago. The engineer and about 10 passengers were treated for injuries, the local authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An Amtrak passenger train carrying more than 200 passengers derailed in Michigan on Thursday night after striking a vehicle on the tracks, injuring 11 people, the local authorities said.

headline: Biden Signs Spending Bill, Staving Off a Government Shutdown
abstract: The bill sidesteps an immediate crisis, but the path to a longer-term agreement on government spending is unclear.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed a short-term government funding bill on Thursday, narrowly averting a government shutdown but leaving a larger spending clash for Congress early next year.

headline: Seth Meyers Skewers George Santos for Botox and OnlyFans Expenditures
abstract: The “Late Night” host joked that Santos’s campaign fund-supported spending looks like “the shopping list of a 98-year-old oil tycoon’s 20-year-old wife.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: obfuscation
abstract: This word has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word obfuscation has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 27 in “At Larry Kramer’s Memorial, a Gathering of Friends and Enemies” by Jacob Bernstein:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Dog TV
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: A Reporter Doesn’t Ask for Trust, but Tries to Earn It
abstract: Jan Hoffman, who recently wrote about the lives of people struggling with addiction, approaches her sources with empathy, candor and zero expectations.
lead_paragraph: This fall, Jan Hoffman, who covers addiction for The New York Times, traveled to wooded encampments in Kalamazoo, Mich., where syringes littered the forest floor. She was there to report on the rise of “polysubstance use,” the simultaneous use of multiple drugs. Often, people who are addicted to one illicit substance, like methamphetamine, become dependent on another, such as fentanyl, after taking a laced drug. As one doctor told Ms. Hoffman, polysubstance use is yet another prong of the “addiction crisis” in the United States.

headline: If Your Child Is Addicted to TikTok, This May Be the Cure
abstract: Children are suffering under the weight of social media. New York lawmakers believe they have a strategy to halt the damage.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, hundreds of families and school districts around the country have sued big tech companies on the grounds that the hypnotic properties of social media popular with children have left too many of them unwell. Citing the promotion of the “corpse bride” diet, for example, and other practices around dangerous forms of weight loss, Seattle Public Schools filed a complaint in January arguing that platforms like TikTok and Snapchat have been so unsparing in their delivery of harmful material to students that the resulting anxiety, depression and suicidal ideation were interfering with the school system’s primary mission of educating children.

headline: The N.Y.C. Neighborhood Where Families Are Filling Up Empty Offices
abstract: Five financial district buildings are being turned into housing, including the country’s largest such conversion. Will it work elsewhere in Manhattan?
lead_paragraph: For all the talk about converting New York City’s languishing office buildings into housing, just one neighborhood has done it on a large scale: the financial district.

headline: A Masterpiece About a Masterpiece, for All Ages
abstract: An enchanting work by Italy’s foremost living children’s author is finally available in English.
lead_paragraph: Once in a great while a book comes along that’s equally enthralling for children and the people they call grown-ups — a book playful and accessible enough to hold a young person’s attention yet sufficiently resonant and complex to keep a seasoned reader turning its pages, sometimes even while fighting back tears. We label these works children’s classics, but really they’re a literary wake-up call, as books like Carlo Collodi’s “The Adventures of Pinocchio” and E.B. White’s “Charlotte’s Web” reveal their brilliance at every stage of one’s reading journey.

headline: Something Wonderful Is Happening in American Prisons. Really.
abstract: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation.
lead_paragraph: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation — good that will extend far beyond the realm of criminal justice. With a 2020 law finally taking full effect, people who are incarcerated can for the first time in decades get Pell Grants, the federal tuition aid for low-income students. The grants are small, but they are critical to rebuilding one of the most important tools we have to reduce crime and mitigate the harms of mass incarceration: college education.

headline: A Dying Anticorruption Crusader Considers His Life’s Own Misdeeds
abstract: Chuwit Kamolvisit has enthralled Thailand for decades with revelations of police and political corruption. But his own compromised past, including time as a “super pimp,” clouds his legacy.
lead_paragraph: His anticorruption crusade has made him a household name in Thailand, but Chuwit Kamolvisit would be the first to tell you that his own life has been neither admirable nor one others should emulate.

headline: An Extreme D.I.Y. Project Outside Seoul
abstract: The South Korean ceramist Hun-Chung Lee taught himself design and construction, creating a collection of small buildings as impressive as his artwork.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean ceramist Hun-Chung Lee taught himself design and construction, creating a collection of small buildings as impressive as his artwork.

headline: When the Best Gift Costs Nothing at All
abstract: In a season of high spirits and spirited spending, experts say focusing on sentiment over receipts is more likely to bring holiday cheer.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family. But when she tore open the wrapping on his gift for her, she was disheartened to discover what lay inside: a car-window scraper. Sure, she lived in a frosty place, but she didn’t own a car. Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.

headline: His Architect Said the Site Was No Good, So He Built the Project Himself
abstract: The South Korean ceramist Hun-Chung Lee taught himself design and construction, creating a collection of small buildings as impressive as his artwork.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has an urge to design a house but lacks architectural training should take courage from Hun-Chung Lee.

headline: Type All Day, Toast All Night: The Rise of Remote-Work Weddings
abstract: Weekend nuptials are stretching out well into the workweek as guests with hybrid schedules pack their laptops and stick around for a few extra days.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of wedding guests are bringing a new kind of plus-one to the festivities: their remote jobs.

headline: After a Landmark Verdict, Realtors Ask, ‘What’s Next?’
abstract: A recent ruling has the potential to transform the way Americans buy and sell homes — and many real estate agents are feeling a sense of foreboding.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny November weekend, plenty of people showed up to see the three-bedroom house with a view of San Francisco Bay, nestled in the hills of Berkeley, Calif., and listed for shy of $1 million. As the inquiries rolled in the following week, Deidre Joyner, the listing agent, received one that stunned her.

headline: Downtowns Are Full of Empty Buildings. Universities Are Moving In.
abstract: The stylish new Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg Center took over a former museum in Washington. It’s got potential to become a community hub.
lead_paragraph: On a conspicuous corner of Pennsylvania Avenue, in a once gaudy building that used to house the Newseum, the 10-story, $650 million Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg Center has just opened in Washington. I’ll say straight off: It’s not architecture for the ages, but it’s an interesting, high-end model of an urban quad and a good example of how struggling downtowns are finding a glimmer of hope as satellite campuses.

headline: Kerry James Marshall’s Prints Throw Blackness Into Relief
abstract: A new art book collects the painter’s printmaking oeuvre over almost half a century.
lead_paragraph: “I am not one who goes in much for magical thinking,” the painter Kerry James Marshall wrote in 2018. “Material reality has spirit enough for me.” From the first scrapbook his kindergarten teacher showed him to his career blurring the lines between large-scale painting, lithography, photography and sculpture, KERRY JAMES MARSHALL: The Complete Prints: 1976-2022 (Ludion/D.A.P., $125) traces a lifelong reverence for the materiality of all visual art.

headline: I Knew U.S. Military Aid Would Kill Civilians and Undermine Israeli Security. So I Quit.
abstract: Military aid to Israel without accountability has endangered both Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 18, I resigned from the State Department because I could not support the provision of U.S. weapons into the conflict in Gaza, where I knew that they would be used to kill thousands of civilians. I saw no willingness to re-evaluate a long-term policy that has not led to peace and has actually undermined both regional stability and Israeli security.

headline: Remembering Bayard Rustin in Life and Onscreen
abstract: The civil rights leader and organizer of the March on Washington is the focus of a new biopic. Here’s how it stacks up against archival images.
lead_paragraph: As an adolescent, Bayard Rustin had many virtues. He was smart: He served as his high school valedictorian. He was respectful: After tackling opponents as an offensive lineman on his high school team, he would help them up and recite a line of poetry. And he was brave: While playing football, he organized a strike demanding equal accommodations for Black players who were forced to stay in substandard hotels on road trips.

headline: A Newspaper Chain Hired a Dedicated Taylor Swift Reporter. Is It OK if He’s a Swiftie?
abstract: Do you think a fan can be impartial? On the other hand, would someone who isn’t a fan have the expertise to do the job well?
lead_paragraph: Think about the task of reporting on all things Taylor Swift: her music; her business enterprises such as tours, movies and merchandise; her life and the media coverage it receives; and the effect she has on her fans’ lives and on pop culture itself.

headline: Jezebel, the Oral History: ‘There Was This Riotous Sense of Fun’
abstract: The site defined an era of feminism for millions of readers. According to its editors and writers, it was also an exhilarating place to work.
lead_paragraph: The name “Jezebel” was chosen in 2007 by Gawker Media’s co-founder and chief operating officer, Gaby Darbyshire. Over several months, she and the site’s founder, Anna Holmes, had brainstormed names everywhere from the Gawker office on Crosby Street to Balthazar, where they jotted down notes on a paper tablecloth.

headline: Santos Was a Big Spender at Sephora and Spas
abstract: A report by the House Ethics Committee detailed some of the ways the Long Island congressman spent donors’ money.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at details of Representative George Santos’s spending that were laid out by the House Ethics Committee. We’ll also look at what Mayor Eric Adams’s budget cuts will mean for municipal services.

headline: Owner of Chelsea Piers Lists His Upper West Side Townhouse
abstract: Roland W. Betts and his wife, Lois Betts, are asking $9.5 million for their home on West 102nd Street, where Eleanor Roosevelt’s father once lived.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1972, the townhouse at 313 West 102nd Street, where Eleanor Roosevelt’s father once lived, had lingered on the market for a year despite its historical lineage, when the developer Roland W. Betts agreed to pay the $150,000 asking price.

headline: ‘The Crown’: The History Behind Season 6 on Netflix
abstract: The final season of the royal drama series opens in 1997, just weeks before Princess Diana’s death. Here’s how The Times covered the fatal car accident and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Since its premiere in 2016, Netflix’s “The Crown” has followed the reign of Queen Elizabeth II, blending fact and fiction as each season inches closer to the present day. Last year, after complaints about the show’s historical inaccuracies, Netflix added a disclaimer that “The Crown” is a “fictional dramatization.”

headline: Goodbye, Feminist Blogs. Hello, Gen Z Content Creators?
abstract: Young women are more feminist than ever, as are big brands and Hollywood franchises. But what happened to the online community blogs and zines once offered?
lead_paragraph: Rayne Fisher-Quann grew up with no shortage of feminist influences. There was her mother, who brought home a book about the problems with Barbie and banned the actual dolls. There were websites transmitting the wise and world-weary voices of fired-up millennial thinkers — the women’s blog Jezebel, the teen site Rookie. Now that Ms. Fisher-Quann is establishing herself as an independent writer focused on girlhood and identity, she wonders how her career might unfold if there were a more cohesive online community for Gen Z feminists like herself.

headline: In These Short Stories, Characters Young and Old Struggle to Connect
abstract: In new collections by Yiyun Li, Claire Keegan, Alexandra Chang and Lore Segal, interpersonal bonds are created and destroyed.
lead_paragraph: The short-story writer “can’t create compassion with compassion, or emotion with emotion, or thought with thought,” Flannery O'Connor wrote. “When you can state the theme of a story, when you can separate it from the story itself, then you can be sure the story is not a very good one.” By this metric, Claire Keegan’s SO LATE IN THE DAY: Stories of Women and Men (Grove, 119 pp., $20), a collection of one novella and two short stories all exploring misogyny through the eyes of women who react to it and men who blister with it, is nothing short of a masterpiece. Through narratives of a canceled wedding, a writer’s interrupted residency and a woman’s dangerous infidelity with a stranger, Keegan’s delicate hand directs the reader away from obvious moralizing to the banality of bigotry.

headline: Just What the (Urgent Care) Doctor Ordered
abstract: Urgent care centers are on every corner: “You’re never more than three minutes away from pizza, a deli or a doctor willing to help.”

headline: ‘Get a Job, Get Married, Have Kids’: A Debate Over Youth Politics
abstract: In Professor Lozada’s classroom, an argument over kids today and their formative political experiences.
lead_paragraph: What’s your earliest political memory? That’s the question Professor Carlos Lozada puts to his co-hosts this week on “Matter of Opinion.” The hosts discuss the coups and presidential pinings of their youths before debating what political events may be shaping the attitudes of younger voters today.

headline: This Is What’s Become of the House
abstract: The attention that the budget process brings can breed dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: Compared to a Republican representative allegedly receiving “a clean shot to the kidneys” from another representative this week, the House passing a plan to avert a government shutdown and keep federal funding flowing into early 2024 seemed almost anti-climactic.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: Alone Together
abstract: In some ways Whitney and Asher are a team, though in others they are distant from one another.
lead_paragraph: There are multiple moments in the second episode of “The Curse” when the camera lingers on the desperation behind a character’s eyes. While last week’s premiere established that these people are often despicable, the follow up plunges deeper into their loneliness and sadness.

headline: The Sermons I Needed to Hear Right Now
abstract: A tender conversation with Rabbi Sharon Brous about Jewishness and the Jewish state.
lead_paragraph: This is a conversation about the relationship between Jewishness and the Jewish State. About believing some aspects of Israel have become indefensible and also believing that Israel itself must be defended. About what it means when a religion built on the lessons of exile creates a state that inflicts exile on others. About the ugly, recurrent reality of antisemitism.

headline: This Thanksgiving, Full Planes to Go With Full Plates
abstract: With about 30 million travelers expected to jam U.S. airports this year and storms in the forecast, you may want to take an extra helping of patience, too.
lead_paragraph: A government shutdown won’t be disrupting travel plans this Thanksgiving after Congress agreed on Wednesday to a funding package that lasts through early next year. But clouds and crowds might make your trip a slog anyway.

headline: The War in Gaza Is Splintering the Democratic Party
abstract: A clash over the future of the Squad threatens the progressive coalition.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jamaal Bowman, whose district encompasses several affluent Westchester County suburbs as well as a small part of the Bronx, last week planned a “healing breakfast” with Jewish constituents pained by his pro-Palestinian politics. A member of the informal alliance of a half-dozen or so young Black and brown left-wing representatives known as the Squad, Bowman won a primary against the district’s staunchly pro-Israel incumbent in 2020, fueled largely by the energy of that summer’s racial justice protests. But now, with the conflict in the Middle East inflaming American politics, he seemed likely to face his own primary challenge in June, one that will test the coalition between liberal Jews and people of color that is key to the progressive movement both in his district and in the country more broadly.

headline: China Wants to Bulldoze Old Neighborhoods to Revive the Economy
abstract: The halting revitalization of one “urban village” in Shenzhen shows the challenges of fixing a national property crisis after years of overborrowing.
lead_paragraph: In Shenzhen, a metropolis born of China’s economic prosperity, Paibang Village is a reminder of the city’s modest past and the challenges ahead for reviving the country’s property sector.

headline: Students Are Missing School at an Alarming Rate
abstract: Schools reopened after the pandemic, but student attendance has not bounced back.
lead_paragraph: The academic achievement of millions of American students faltered during the pandemic — and in many cases, has not recovered three years later. The latest data on student attendance offers one explanation: Far more students are missing many days of school compared with before the pandemic.

headline: An A.I. Pin Drops + YouTube’s Take on Deepfakes + a Lab-Grown Thanksgiving
abstract: The companies changing our phones, our media and our meat.
lead_paragraph: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing. Might this be the device that replaces the iPhone? It’s the question on Silicon Valley’s mind. The pin allows users to take phone calls, catch up on messages and get answers to questions, all without ever looking at a screen.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the Netflix biopic on the civil right activist Bayard Rustin.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the Netflix biopic on the civil right activist Bayard Rustin.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 17, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 4 Ways to Avoid Awkward Moments This Thanksgiving
abstract: Setting boundaries can defuse tension, experts say. Here’s how they do it.
lead_paragraph: For some of us, Thanksgiving dinner can include a cornucopia of intrusive, inappropriate and anxiety-producing comments from loved ones. (“No plus one this year, huh?” “Wow, your hair went fully gray!” “Are you still unemployed?”)

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Haruki Murakami, Dipo Faloyin, Beverly Gage and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Haruki Murakami, Dipo Faloyin, Beverly Gage and more.

headline: A’s Will Finally Turn Out the Lights on Pro Sports in Oakland
abstract: With baseball owners approving the Athletics’ move to Las Vegas, some see the departure as the death of the working-class sports fan.
lead_paragraph: One by one, they have left Oakland.

headline: When It Comes to Disdain for Democracy, Trump Has Company
abstract: Antidemocratic attitudes run deep within the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: It makes perfect sense to treat Donald Trump as the most immediate threat to the future of American democracy. He has an ambitious plan to turn the office of the presidency into an instrument of “revenge” against his political enemies and other supposedly undesirable groups.

headline: Israeli Army Escorts Journalists to Gaza Hospital, and More
abstract: Plus, George Santos won’t seek re-election and Sean Combs is accused of rape in a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Our Critic’s Favorite Grammy-Nominated Songs
abstract: Bad Bunny, bluegrass and more.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The New York Times, brings you a playlist of songs from down-ballot Grammy nominees:

headline: Two Superpowers Walk Into a Garden
abstract: President Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, met at a moment of tension between their two countries. Here’s how it went.
lead_paragraph: One of the most highly anticipated diplomatic events of the year took place this week in a mansion outside San Francisco. President Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, met to repair their countries’ relations, which had sunk to one of their lowest points in decades.

headline: ‘The Crown’: Behind the Photo of an Embrace That Changed Princess Diana’s Life
abstract: In the show, Mohamed al-Fayed sends the photographer Mario Brenna to capture shots of Diana and al-Fayed’s son, Dodi, on vacation. The portrayal is inaccurate, Brenna says.
lead_paragraph: It’s summer 1997, and Princess Diana is flirting with Dodi Fayed, a globe-trotting playboy, on the Jonikal, a yacht floating on sparkling Mediterranean waters.

headline: Football’s Young Victims
abstract: Figuring out how to make the sport safer remains an urgent matter of public health.
lead_paragraph: I want to make clear that the subject of today’s newsletter is especially difficult.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games’ Is Back. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: With the prequel, “The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes,” now in theaters, here are answers to questions you may have about the franchise.
lead_paragraph: Arriving eight years after the most recent film in the franchise, “The Hunger Games” is back with a new installment: “The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes.” Adapted from a 2020 novel by Suzanne Collins, the author who created the “Hunger Games,” this film serves as a prequel, taking place 64 years before the events of the first film.

headline: Arab American Comedy Festival Goes On Amid Troubled Times
abstract: On its 20th anniversary, organizers look back on a tradition that has frequently coincided with painful news events.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, with the Iraq War underway and a wave of anti-Arab sentiment spreading across the country, Dean Obeidallah and Maysoon Zayid did what they do best: They went onstage and cracked some jokes.

headline: Eli Roth Takes a Stab at Thanksgiving Horror
abstract: Ever since he was a boy, the director has wanted to make a gory movie about the holiday. “Thanksgiving” is adapted from his 2007 faux trailer.
lead_paragraph: For almost every holiday, there’s a horror movie, from “My Bloody Valentine” to “Black Christmas.” Thanksgiving, too. But the turkeys-beware holiday gets its own namesake movie with Eli Roth’s “Thanksgiving,” featuring an ensemble cast that includes Addison Rae, Patrick Dempsey and Gina Gershon.

headline: Russia Sentences Activist to Penal Colony for Antiwar Notes on Price Tags
abstract: A court sentenced Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko to seven years in a penal colony, in one of the most prominent cases of Russia’s crackdown on wartime dissent.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court has sentenced a pacifist artist to seven years in a penal colony for leaving price tags with small antiwar messages in a supermarket, the latest example of the Kremlin’s resolve to stamp out opposition to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Roger Kastel, ‘Jaws’ Poster Artist, Dies at 92
abstract: A prolific illustrator, he was most closely associated with the image that made the “Jaws” paperback a runaway best seller, and the blockbuster film it inspired an enduring classic.
lead_paragraph: Roger Kastel, an artist whose painting for the “Jaws” poster — of a menacing shark with bared teeth looming below an insouciant skinny dipper — became one of the most enduring images in modern pop culture, died on Nov. 8 in Worcester County, Mass. He was 92.

headline: Celebrity Campaign Shines Spotlight on New Zealand Bird Contest
abstract: An endorsement from the comedian John Oliver led to a spike in votes for the eventual winner, the pūteketeke.
lead_paragraph: Like so many modern elections, the poll to decide New Zealand’s favorite bird has, in past years, been beset by accusations of vote rigging, foreign influence and debates about candidates’ eligibility.

headline: Iceland Is in a Holding Pattern as It Awaits a Volcanic Eruption
abstract: As the country prepares for a possible volcanic eruption, it’s working to protect a power plant that serves 30,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Iceland is fortifying a power plant that supplies electricity and hot water to about 30,000 people and is continuing to allow the residents of the evacuated town most at risk to go in one by one and gather personal belongings as the country waits for a possible volcanic eruption.

headline: A Crowd Pleasing Casserole? It’s in the Bag (of Frozen Hash Browns)
abstract: It freezes nicely, so serve it on Thanksgiving or keep it on hand as a last-minute rescue breakfast in the days following the feast.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I figure you’ve got your turkey recipe sorted by now. (You oughta. Thanksgiving is in less than a week!) Kim Severson’s recipe for dry-brined turkey is the choice for nine out of 10 sharpies I’ve spoken with, though if you’d like something new, I’d still love to make the argument for this marvelous recipe for a Jamaican-spiced bird or this recipe for a New England-style one.

headline: Advertisers Push Back at Social Media Firms over Antisemitism
abstract: Companies, celebrities and influencers have taken TikTok and X  — and Elon Musk himself — to task for the rise of hate speech on their platforms since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel.
lead_paragraph: The rise in antisemitism since the outbreak of war in the Middle East has ignited a clash between Wall Street donors and universities, and divided some workplaces. Now, the pressure is building on social media platforms, particularly Elon Musk’s X and TikTok, with advertisers, celebrities and influencers pulling spending and confronting executives about the proliferation of hate speech.

headline: Everton Docked 10 Points, a Premier League Record, in Financial Case
abstract: The penalty adds to the problems of a team operating under a mountain of debt. It vowed to appeal.
lead_paragraph: Everton, a founding member of England’s Premier League that has fallen into financial crisis, faced yet more pain on Friday after it was given a 10-point penalty for breaching the league’s economic rules. The punishment, the largest points deduction in the league’s history, sent Everton to the bottom of the standings and left it facing the threat of relegation from England’s top division at the end of the season.

headline: Tip a Self-Service Kiosk? How to Deal With the Many Requests for Tips.
abstract: Since the pandemic, they seem to be everywhere. And with inflation, the gratuity on a pricier meal feels like a big outlay.
lead_paragraph: If you feel that you’re being asked to tip more often, you’re not alone.

headline: The Fed’s Decisions Now Could Alter the 2024 Elections
abstract: The state of the economy will affect voting next November, and the Federal Reserve may find itself in a delicate position, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: What’s happening in the economy now will have a big effect — perhaps, a decisive one — on the presidential election and control of Congress in 2024.

headline: Tammy Faye Bakker Is Broadway Bound. As a Musical.
abstract: A show about the televangelist, with songs by Elton John and Jake Shears, had a run in London last year and plans to open in New York next season.
lead_paragraph: A new musical about Tammy Faye Bakker, the singing televangelist whose colorful life and collapsed ministry have repeatedly been dramatized for stage and screen, is pledging to open on Broadway next season.

headline: ‘Please Don’t Destroy: The Treasure of Foggy Mountain’ Review: Fools’ Gold
abstract: The “S.N.L.” troupe, known for digital shorts, makes its feature debut with this goofy, episodic adventure farce.
lead_paragraph: The 20-something comedians Ben Marshall, John Higgins and Martin Herlihy, who produce digital shorts for “Saturday Night Live” under the group name Please Don’t Destroy, owe a lot to their “S.N.L.” forebears Andy Samberg, Jorma Taccone and Akiva Schaffer, whose troupe The Lonely Island laid the groundwork for Please Don’t Destroy’s distinctive style of two- to four-minute video skits that relish in juvenile absurdity.

headline: Great Places to Enjoy Art in California
abstract: Readers recommend their favorite museums and art destinations, including several hidden gems.
lead_paragraph: If the weather forecast holds, much of California is supposed to be rainy this weekend, making it a perfect time to visit a museum.

headline: Is America Beholding ‘Immaculate Disinflation’?
abstract: The term, which is roughly synonymous with "soft landing," is meant to imply that getting price increases down without a big pop in unemployment would be nearly miraculous.
lead_paragraph: The term, which is roughly synonymous with "soft landing," is meant to imply that getting price increases down without a big pop in unemployment would be nearly miraculous.

headline: With Her Dad, Ben Vereen, by Her Side, Karon Davis Turns to Dance
abstract: The focus of her art is on realities that Black dancers face in the world of ballet. First she sculpted real dancers; then she brought in a familiar face to help bring them to life.
lead_paragraph: “I come from show people,” the sculptor and installation artist Karon Davis said in an interview on Wednesday. “The minute I was born, I was handed tap shoes, ballet shoes.” She’s only half joking: her mother, Nancy Bruner, was a ballerina; her sister, Naja, who died at the age of 16, was an aspiring ballerina; and her father is the Tony- and Emmy-award-winning actor, dancer and singer Ben Vereen.

headline: Michael Lewis Tells His Own Story of Sam Bankman-Fried
abstract: “Going Infinite” may have missed the big takeaway, but it offers at least one undeniable pleasure: deep access.
lead_paragraph: If Michael Lewis’s chief talent is explaining how a misunderstood outsider’s penetrating insights allow him to win at a complex game, then Sam Bankman-Fried stretches that literary muscle in a different, less comfortable direction. Bankman-Fried — who was briefly the world’s richest person under 30, until the abrupt collapse of his cryptocurrency exchange FTX in late 2022 — is an outsider, in some sense, but it’s not clear that he had a penetrating insight, or that he won a game in any way that we should respect.

headline: Watch the Leonids Meteor Shower Reach Its Peak This Weekend
abstract: Fireballs that come from the wake of comet 55P/Tempel-Tuttle may be visible while the moon is a quarter full.
lead_paragraph: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.

headline: A.S. Byatt, Scholar Who Found Literary Fame With Fiction, Dies at 87
abstract: One of Britain’s most ambitious and intellectual novelists, she won the Booker Prize with “Possession,” her 1990 tale of illicit love spanning two centuries.
lead_paragraph: A.S. Byatt, one of the most ambitious writers of her generation, whose dazzling 1990 novel, “Possession,” won the Booker Prize and brought her international fame as a novelist and unapologetic intellectual, died on Thursday at her home in London. She was 87.

headline: Fall Fashion in Tokyo
abstract: Photographer Simbarashe Cha documents transitional style in the Japanese capital for The New York Times.

headline: ‘We’ll Never Get Out of Hell’: One American Family’s Escape From Gaza
abstract: Lena Beseiso was visiting family with her children and grandson when the war broke out and thrust them into a fight for survival.
lead_paragraph: Lena Beseiso pulled her blanket closer as she lay on the cold tile floor, and waited for the bombs to fall.

headline: The Days Are Getting Shorter. At These Restaurants, Time Stands Still.
abstract: A tavern, a pub and a beer hall for hunkering down with sausages and other cold-weather classics.
lead_paragraph: First, an announcement: In a few weeks, I’ll devote Where to Eat to answering questions from readers, especially those of you who will be visiting New York City in December. Want a good spot to refuel along Fifth Avenue in Midtown, which will be off-limits to cars the first three Sundays in December? How about a place to eat before or after embarking on a Santa Safari through the Christmas lights of Dyker Heights, Brooklyn?

headline: Israel, Hamas and the Rules of War
abstract: Readers discuss two guest essays addressing the moral issues. Also: Congressional aides’ protests; college rankings; rich in New York; fake reviews.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Santos Faces New Expulsion Push Led by His Own Party After Damning Report
abstract: The resolution from Representative Michael Guest, a Republican, sets the stage for a vote shortly after Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: The Republican chairman of the bipartisan House Ethics Committee introduced a resolution on Friday to expel Representative George Santos of New York from Congress, citing the committee’s damning new report documenting violations of House rules and evidence of pervasive campaign fraud.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sharon Brous
abstract: The Nov. 17, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sharon Brous. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: It was another busy week of news, giving the late night hosts plenty of fodder, including revelations that Representative George Santos spent campaign funds on OnlyFans, Botox and other personal items. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: It was another busy week of news, giving the late night hosts plenty of fodder, including revelations that Representative George Santos spent campaign funds on OnlyFans, Botox and other personal items. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Review: ‘Florencia’ Brings Spanish Back to the Met Opera
abstract: Starring Ailyn Pérez, Daniel Catán’s heavily perfumed “Florencia en el Amazonas,” from 1996, is the company’s first work by a Latin American composer.
lead_paragraph: Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, had stepped onto the podium on Thursday evening to begin the performance. The theater was hushed before his downbeat when a voice rang out from a balcony.

headline: In Spain, the Latin Grammys Recognize Powerful Women
abstract: Karol G, Shakira and Natalia Lafourcade took the top prizes at the awards’ first ceremony outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: Spain tried to share the cultural clout of its former colonies at the 24th annual Latin Grammy Awards, which were broadcast worldwide on Thursday night from the Fibes convention center in Seville. It was the first Latin Grammy ceremony to take place outside the United States.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include an intimate documentary about Latin American immigrants in Canada, a Turkish psychological thriller, a Chilean ghost story and more.
lead_paragraph: The camera tilts up the glassy facade of a skyscraper and roves across a wall mural featuring voluptuous pinup models, while, on the soundtrack, a woman recalls her early experiences as an immigrant: ordering food in tentative English, taking the bus, learning to dress for winter. Lina Rodriguez’s intimate, inventive documentary ties together the aural testimonies of three women about the (often violent) journeys that brought them from various parts of Latin America to Canada, and the everyday struggles of living, working and raising a family in an unfamiliar world.

headline: Ukraine Says It Has Seized Small Dnipro Foothold After Months of Raids
abstract: The Ukrainian military said it had taken a sliver of Russian-controlled land, a move that might offer some hope but was unlikely to lead to a rapid breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: For months, Ukrainian forces have been carrying out stealth raids into Russian-held territory on the eastern bank of the Dnipro River near the southern city of Kherson, Ukraine. The operations have been shrouded in secrecy, with small groups of Ukrainian soldiers crossing the river at night to avoid Russian drones, and officials remaining tight-lipped about the fierce fighting.

headline: Want to Know What’s Bedeviling Biden? TikTok Economics May Hold Clues.
abstract: Economic despair dominates social media as young people fret about the cost of living. It offers a snapshot of the challenges facing Democrats ahead of the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Look at economic data, and you’d think that young voters would be riding high right now. Unemployment remains low. Job opportunities are plentiful. Inequality is down, wage growth is finally beating inflation, and the economy has expanded rapidly this year.

headline: The Big Number: 18%
abstract: Surveys this month found that domestic flight prices for holiday travel were substantially down from a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Surveys this month found that domestic flight prices for holiday travel were substantially down from a year ago.

headline: Xabi Alonso Isn’t Coming to Save Your Team. Not Yet.
abstract: The patience of Alonso, the Bayer Leverkusen manager, says a lot about him, and just as much about a sport perpetually chasing the next big thing.
lead_paragraph: Xabi Alonso has always done things at his own speed. As a player, it was his coolness, his control, his capacity to wait until precisely the right moment that made him one of the finest midfielders of his generation. As he contemplated the idea of becoming a coach, he saw no reason to change. He would continue to treat patience as a virtue.

headline: André 3000’s 17-Minute Reverie, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Julia Holter, Dua Lipa, Danny Brown and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Qui Nguyen Was Done Writing Plays. His Family Pulled Him Back In.
abstract: With “Poor Yella Rednecks,” the writer continues to tell his Vietnamese American family’s immigrant story. Maybe one day his parents will even see the shows.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Qui Nguyen was at a low point. “I decided that my writing life had not amounted to much, and I felt I needed to concentrate on my family and my kids,” he said during a recent video conversation. “I was going to hang it up.” The new play he was working on, he added, was “a sort of swan song.”

headline: Review: A ‘Jungle Book’ With the Climate Crisis on Its Mind
abstract: The choreographer and director Akram Khan’s reimagining of Kipling’s fable updates the message but leaves out the fun.
lead_paragraph: The waters are rising. News reports tell of rationing, curfews, economic collapse. One announcer goes so far as to speculate about the extinction of human beings and even — the horror! — the end of Google search.

headline: Taylor and Travis Might Save Romance, but Posh and Becks Were Here All Along
abstract: Why a throwback celebrity couple could be the model for reviving marriage.
lead_paragraph: Tell me if this tale sounds familiar: A handsome football star sets his cap for one of the world’s leading female pop stars when she’s at the peak of her global fame. He tells people that he fancies her, he manages to meet her, and soon she’s appearing at his games while he roves near and far to visit her while she’s on tour. Their combined brand — singing and sports, beauty and the baller — makes them a cultural sensation, a media obsession, a romance made in tabloid heaven.

headline: Cassie’s Suit Against Sean Combs May Cast Her Career in a New Light
abstract: The R&B singer was poised for a big breakout after her 2006 hit song “Me & U.” But her second album never arrived.
lead_paragraph: Cassie, the singer, model and actress who is suing the music mogul Sean Combs for physical and sexual abuse, was supposed to be the next Britney Spears or Janet Jackson.

headline: George Tscherny, Whose Graphic Designs Defined an Era, Is Dead at 99
abstract: With a bevy of corporate and institutional clients, he helped shape the visual language of the postwar American economy.
lead_paragraph: George Tscherny, a leading figure in postwar graphic design whose work unified the crisp, clean lines of European modern art with an American commercial pop sensibility, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

headline: ‘Beyond the Aggressives: 25 Years Later’ Review: Trailblazers Revisited
abstract: This documentary from Daniel Peddle offers an update on the transmasculine people of color who participated in ballroom culture in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: The 2005 documentary “The Aggressives” provided a novel view of ballroom culture, or the underground pageant scene which emerged as a haven for queer Black and Latino youths in the 1980s and ’90s. The subjects of the 2005 film are people who identified themselves as “aggressives” — they were assigned female at birth, but they competed in ballroom categories highlighting their masculinity. They walked the catwalk dressed in construction gear and basketball jerseys. The original film followed its stars for five years, as they carried their gender performance out of the ballroom and into the streets, into their relationships and family lives.

headline: Unions in Sweden Expand Blockade Against Tesla
abstract: In sympathy with striking mechanics, unions representing dockworkers, electricians and others in the country are refusing to do work for the electric carmaker.
lead_paragraph: Electricians and dockworkers across Sweden on Friday joined a widening effort by unions in the country to pressure Tesla to sign a collective bargaining agreement with its mechanics.

headline: At the Philharmonic, Violin Concertos as Alike as They Are Different
abstract: In back-to-back programs, the orchestra presented concertos by Beethoven and Benjamin Britten.
lead_paragraph: The violin concertos by Beethoven and Benjamin Britten are as alike as they are different, and over the past week, the New York Philharmonic presented them in back-to-back programs that gestured at their beauties without digging into them.

headline: Macy’s Parade Shuns Boycott Demands From Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Group
abstract: A right-wing group that has been designated a hate group is planning to protest the Thanksgiving parade because of the inclusion of two nonbinary performers.
lead_paragraph: An anti-L.G.B.T.Q. group is organizing a boycott of Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade over performances by nonbinary Broadway actors, in the latest attempt to force companies to reverse course on social issues that some far-right groups consider too liberal.

headline: Resignations Roil Documenta Show as War in Gaza Polarizes Art World
abstract: The entire team in charge of selecting the leading avant-garde exhibition’s next curator has now resigned, putting the future of the 2027 edition in question.
lead_paragraph: Documenta, the German contemporary art exhibition considered one of the most prestigious in the world, fell into crisis this week after the entire team tasked with finding its next artistic director resigned after a series of disputes with administrators related to the Israel-Hamas War.

headline: Nikki Haley Renews Call for TikTok Ban After Bin Laden Letter Circulates
abstract: The presidential candidate has argued that social media platforms should better police certain users and content, prompting backlash from some Republican rivals.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her calls this week for the U.S. government to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, after some users, weighing in on the war between Israel and Hamas, promoted “Letter to America,” a text written by Osama bin Laden after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: A Simple Way to Save Premature Babies
abstract: Waiting two minutes to sever the umbilical cord after birth raises the chances that a premature infant will survive, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after a baby is born, doctors clamp the umbilical cord linking the infant to the placenta, which is still inside the mother’s uterus, and then cut it. New research shows that if doctors wait at least two minutes after the birth to clamp the cord, they significantly improve in-hospital survival rates for premature infants.

headline: An Exhibition of Orcs and Elves Has Rome Abuzz, and Bewildered
abstract: Italy’s Culture Ministry has opened a curious show dedicated to the life and works of J.R.R. Tolkien — and perhaps a new front in the culture wars. It’s “beautiful.” Just ask the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: On the opening night of Rome’s most talked-about new exhibition this week, top government ministers in sharp suits hobnobbed with Roman socialites in fur coats, and eccentric art lovers rubbed shoulders with hard-right youth group members.

headline: 7 Great André 3000 Guest Verses
abstract: He isn’t rapping on his new LP. But he showed his skills on these tracks.
lead_paragraph: After announcing a new album just a few days ago, André 3000 has released his solo debut, “New Blue Sun.” Coming nearly two decades into his rap duo Outkast’s long hiatus, the album’s mere existence is surprising enough. But here’s an understatement: It is not what most people were expecting from the man behind hits as disparately brilliant as “Ms. Jackson,” “B.O.B.” and “Hey Ya!,” who is arguably one of the most skilled and beloved rappers of his generation. It’s actually not a rap album at all. It is, in fact, an 88-minute instrumental album of ambient woodwind compositions.

headline: White House Condemns Elon Musk for Spreading ‘Antisemitic and Racist Hate’
abstract: The tech entrepreneur had endorsed a social media post that echoed the conspiracy theory that had fueled the Tree of Life synagogue killer in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Friday denounced Elon Musk for boosting an anti-Jewish conspiracy theory on his social media platform X, calling the actions of Mr. Musk, the world’s richest person, an “abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate.”

headline: Inside the Pro-Palestinian Group Protesting Across College Campuses
abstract: Students for Justice in Palestine, which was founded at Berkeley, has fueled activism, and, critics say, intimidation and antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: After last month’s attack on Israel by Hamas, Students for Justice in Palestine promoted a “tool kit” for activists that proclaimed “glory to our resistance.” The group has been banned or suspended by Brandeis, Columbia and George Washington University. And it was recently the target of thundering speeches on Capitol Hill and blistered during a Republican presidential debate.

headline: How Bad Is Antisemitism Online? It’s Increasingly Hard to Know.
abstract: People who study social media say the conflict between Israel and Hamas has underscored the need for better data transparency from platforms.
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war flooded social media with violent content, false information and a seemingly limitless swell of opinions, lawmakers and users have accused platforms like TikTok and Facebook of promoting biased posts.

headline: Red-Crowned Parrots Are Beloved in L.A. County. Who’s Trapping Them?
abstract: The bird, a nonnative species whose population ballooned in the 1970s and 80s, became emblematic of Temple City, Calif.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the residents of Temple City, Calif., had learned to love their shrill avian neighbors — expecting to be woken by a cacophony of squawks, and anticipating their return at dusk to roost in the trees.

headline: Judge Rejects Trump Motion to Strike Jan. 6 Mentions From Federal Election Case
abstract: The ruling was a step toward allowing prosecutors to introduce evidence at trial that members of the mob that stormed the Capitol believed they were acting at Donald Trump’s instruction.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election rejected on Friday a request by Mr. Trump’s lawyers to remove language from his indictment describing the role he played in the violence that erupted at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Weeks Before Election as Speaker, Johnson Lamented ‘Dark and Depraved’ Culture
abstract: Mike Johnson’s comments on a prayer call in October, during which he talked about church attendance and L.G.B.T.Q. youth, offered an up-to-date distillation of his views.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks before he was elected speaker, Mike Johnson joined a prayer call where he lamented that American culture was “so dark and depraved it almost seems irredeemable,” claiming as evidence that attendance at church had reached an all-time low and that 25 percent of high school students identified as “something other than straight.”

headline: A Journey Into Northern Gaza: Ruins, Wreckage and Darkness
abstract: New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of conditions in wartime Gaza. They saw houses flattened like playing cards and a city utterly disfigured.
lead_paragraph: When a group of international journalists arrived at the southern fringe of Gaza City early Friday morning, riding in the back of an Israeli army jeep, we struggled to orient ourselves amid the ruins, the wreckage and the darkness.

headline: Big Apple Circus Review: A Show That Bends Over Backward for You
abstract: The extraordinary within the everyday: A holiday season rite returns with aerialists, trapeze acts, funny clowns (really!) and cotton candy too.
lead_paragraph: If confetti supplies have plummeted, if a spangle shortage now afflicts Manhattan, blame a tent at the southwestern corner of Lincoln Center. Yes, the Big Apple Circus has returned and for a little over a month New York will glimmer more brightly.

headline: To Become a World-Class Chipmaker, the United States Might Need Help
abstract: American workers can’t build a state-of-the-art chip industry alone, a policy group argues.
lead_paragraph: In President Biden’s vision for the U.S. economy, technological supremacy goes arm in arm with high-paying jobs for American workers. But what happens when those two objectives don’t line up perfectly? What has to give?

headline: What to See, Eat and Buy in Guadalajara, Mexico’s City of Makers
abstract: Steeped in cultural heritage, the capital of Jalisco is drawing a new wave of artists.
lead_paragraph: For much of the 20th century, the image of Mexico popularized abroad through film, music, art and literature was, more accurately, a portrayal of Jalisco state and especially its capital, Guadalajara. Mariachi and tequila both originated here as did some of Mexico’s most famous singers and actors. The writer Juan Rulfo, whose 1955 novel, “Pedro Páramo,” still stands as the central monument of modern Mexican literature, grew up in Jalisco and vividly depicted its arid, sun-blasted landscapes in his writing, while the architect Luis Barragán, who moved from Guadalajara to Mexico City in the 1930s, carried with him an appreciation for his home state’s cloisters, haciendas and humble country buildings, which he translated in his own work as austere, inscrutable volumes of stucco. “Jalisco,” as a popular saying goes, “is Mexico.”

headline: Orlando Museum’s Ex-Leader Countersues, Insisting ‘Basquiats’ Are Real
abstract: The Orlando Museum of Art previously accused its former director, Aaron De Groft, of using the institution to try to legitimize fake works for personal profit.
lead_paragraph: The former leader of the Orlando Museum of Art has countersued the institution that fired him, insisting in court documents filed this week that the roughly two dozen works shown by the museum under his care were as advertised: newly discovered works by the celebrated artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.

headline: My Mom Opposes Abortion. I’ve Had 2. Should I Tell Her?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the kinds of disclosures we owe those close to us.
lead_paragraph: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level. She has been anti-abortion my entire life. We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year. When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral. She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret). I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially. Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren. I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her. But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices. What do I owe her?— Name Withheld

headline: N.Y.C. Council Member Who Toted Gun at Rally Will Not Face Charges
abstract: Brooklyn prosecutors said that the pistol the council member, Inna Vernikov, had in her waistband was inoperable. She had come to the pro-Palestinian demonstration to livestream her opposition.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn councilwoman who was arrested last month after carrying a pistol to a pro-Palestinian rally at Brooklyn College has had charges dismissed against her after it was found that the weapon was unloaded and inoperable.

headline: Trump Attends His Sister’s Funeral, but Does Not Speak
abstract: The former president went unmentioned during the memorial service for Maryanne Trump Barry, seemingly in accordance with her wishes.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 mourners streamed into the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan on Friday morning for the memorial service of Maryanne Trump Barry, a longtime federal judge and an older sister of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Often Dismissed, Sideline Reporters Now Deal With Fabrication Fallout
abstract: Charissa Thompson’s statement that she had made up reports during N.F.L. games on Fox left many of her counterparts aghast.
lead_paragraph: Since Thursday afternoon, those in the sports media industry, particularly women, have been talking about one thing: that the prominent broadcaster Charissa Thompson had casually volunteered in an interview that she had made up reports while working as a sideline reporter.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: McDonald’s is getting into fashion. Plus, we take a look at fake online reviews and Russell Brand’s alternate reality.

headline: ‘Arcadia’ Review: Artistic Ambition Gets Thrown Into Chaos
abstract: Bedlam’s revival of Tom Stoppard’s time-traveling mind-bender of a play is a meditation on uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: If even commonplace matters of everyday life — weather, traffic, disease — can defy scientific expectations, what hope could there be in predicting human behavior? With “Arcadia,” his 1993 play, Tom Stoppard set out to explore the science of this uncertainty and how it can disrupt our understanding of history. A new staging presented by Bedlam makes a valiant effort to adapt Stoppard’s cerebral probes into chaos theory, Newtonian law, thermodynamics and metaphysics for a 2023 audience, but the result is a muddled one. And that may just demonstrate Stoppard’s frustrating but brilliant point.

headline: Nikki Haley Says She Doesn’t Agree With Trump Calling Political Opponents ‘Vermin’
abstract: Her reaction, which came six days after the former president first made the remarks, came in response to a question from one of her supporters while campaigning in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations who is rising in the polls in the Republican presidential race, criticized former President Donald J. Trump for vowing to root out his political opponents like “vermin.”

headline: OpenAI’s Board Pushes Out Sam Altman, Its High-Profile C.E.O.
abstract: Mira Murati, who previously served as chief technology officer, has been named interim chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman, the high-profile chief executive of OpenAI, who became the face of the tech industry’s artificial intelligence boom, was pushed out of the company by its board of directors, OpenAI said in a blog post on Friday afternoon.

headline: Former Obama and Biden Officials Sign Letter Defending U.S.’s Israel Stance
abstract: The letter drew 137 signatures, fewer than an earlier letter of dissent from Biden administration officials. Organizers say the new letter should carry more weight because it is not anonymous.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 former members of the Obama and Biden administrations have sent a letter to the White House praising President Biden’s “moral clarity, courageous leadership and staunch support of Israel,” in an effort to defend Mr. Biden’s policies amid roiling dissent within the administration.

headline: Auctions in New York Reflect a Dip in the Market
abstract: While some risk was offloaded to third-party guarantors at the November series, and sales hit estimates, Sotheby’s saw a loss on a Rothko and seemingly the Fisher Landau collection.
lead_paragraph: A dip, or a trough, or just a blip? Traders and collectors were left asking this question after two weeks of sales in New York stress-tested the top end of the auction market for modern and contemporary art.

headline: Sean Combs’s Hip-Hop Career Through the Years
abstract: The music mogul, who was accused of sexual abuse by a former romantic partner, fueled the commercial success of rap over a 30-year career dotted by allegations of violence.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the hitmaking hip-hop mogul also known as Puff Daddy or Diddy, was sued this week in federal court by Cassie, an R&B singer who was once signed to his label and who had been his romantic partner. She accused Mr. Combs, 54, of rape, and of physical abuse over about a decade. A lawyer for Mr. Combs said he “vehemently denies these offensive and outrageous allegations.” One day after the suit was filed, the two parties reached a settlement. A key driver of hip-hop’s takeover of mainstream pop, Mr. Combs has had a career in music, fashion and TV for more than 30 years that has been periodically interrupted by run-ins with the law.

headline: Israel Displays Tunnel Shaft at Gaza Hospital and Says It Will Let In Some Fuel
abstract: The discovery at Al-Shifa Hospital did not seem to settle the question of whether Hamas has been using the complex to hide weapons and command centers, as Israel has said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces on Friday probed further into civilian infrastructure in northern Gaza for signs of a Hamas presence, announcing that they had found weapons at a school and guiding international reporters to a tunnel shaft on the grounds of the territory’s largest hospital.

headline: Rosalynn Carter, 96, Enters Hospice Care at Home in Georgia
abstract: The former first lady, who recently announced that she has dementia, joined her husband, former President Jimmy Carter, who has been in hospice care since February.
lead_paragraph: Rosalynn Carter, the former first lady, has entered hospice care at her home in Georgia alongside her husband, former President Jimmy Carter, who has been in hospice since February, the family announced on Friday.

headline: After ‘Saltburn,’ Watch These Five Country House Movies
abstract: From upstairs to downstairs and the challenging moments in between, a walk through a particular subgenre of films ripe for dramatic tension.
lead_paragraph: If “Promising Young Woman” was Emerald Fennell’s darkly comic take on the rape-revenge thriller — one that rode a zeitgeisty wave of discourse onto a best original screenplay Oscar in 2021 — “Saltburn” is the writer-director’s entry in the country house canon. The film (in theaters) is the latest in a subgenre ripe for dramatic tension: upstairs versus downstairs; invited versus interloped; public versus private. Away from prying eyes, characters in these tales tend to revel in their idyllic surroundings as unseen, often sinister, forces work against them, resulting in an unforgettable stay.

headline: U.S. Offers Tapes From Bugged Guantánamo Prison Yard as Evidence in 9/11 Case
abstract: An undisclosed government agency declassified the secret intelligence program as the prosecution pushes to defend F.B.I. interrogations after C.I.A. torture.
lead_paragraph: The government has declassified a secret intelligence program that clandestinely recorded prison yard conversations of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of being the mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, as prosecutors seek to supply evidence that could be used at an eventual trial.

headline: A Rare Opportunity to See China’s Leader Up Close and (Sort of) Personal
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China is one of the most self-contained Chinese leaders in decades, who reveals next to nothing about his personal life.
lead_paragraph: As the most powerful Chinese leader in generations, Xi Jinping rarely bothers to glad-hand or to try charming a crowd. His public appearances in China are carefully crafted, with fawning cadres and adoring fans positioned around him.

headline: White House Condemns G.O.P. Demands in Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The White House said in a letter to House Republicans that their recent subpoenas and demands for interviews were irresponsible.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Friday condemned House Republicans’ wide-ranging impeachment inquiry into President Biden, saying that there was no legitimacy to the investigation and that recent subpoenas and demands for congressional testimony from the former White House counsel, White House aides and Biden family members were “irresponsible.”

headline: U.S. Investigates Colleges for Antisemitism and Islamophobia Complaints
abstract: Columbia, Cooper Union, Cornell and University of Pennsylvania were among half a dozen universities under investigation for harassment complaints on campus.
lead_paragraph: The federal government opened discrimination investigations this week into half a dozen universities, including Columbia, Cooper Union and Cornell in New York, following complaints about antisemitic and anti-Muslim harassment after the Israel-Hamas war broke out.

headline: What’s Causing ‘Bad Vibes’ in the Economy?
abstract: Look at recent economic data, and you would think that young voters would be riding high. Unemployment remains low and job opportunities are plentiful. But look at TikTok, and you get a very different impression.
lead_paragraph: Look at recent economic data, and you would think that young voters would be riding high. Unemployment remains low and job opportunities are plentiful. But look at TikTok, and you get a very different impression.

headline: Gunman Fatally Shoots One at Hospital and Is Killed by Trooper, Officials Say
abstract: State officials said the situation at New Hampshire Hospital, a state psychiatric facility in Concord, had been “contained.” The motive for the shooting remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: A gunman fatally shot a security officer inside the lobby of a state psychiatric hospital in Concord, N.H., on Friday afternoon and then was killed shortly afterward by a state trooper patrolling the campus, state officials said.

headline: Judge Denies Trump’s Request for a Mistrial in Fraud Case
abstract: The judge, Arthur F. Engoron, used the denial as an opportunity to defend his handling of the case. The former president’s allies have accused him of political bias.
lead_paragraph: The New York state judge presiding over Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial defended his work on Friday as he rejected a mistrial bid from the former president’s lawyers in which they had accused him of political bias.

headline: Times Reporters Got a Rare Glimpse of Gaza’s Largest Hospital
abstract: Also, OpenAI pushed out its high-profile C.E.O. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Early this morning, three of my colleagues visited Al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical complex, which has become central to the war between Israel and Hamas.

headline: George Brown, Drummer With Kool & the Gang, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Brown kept time for a group that combined funk, disco, R&B and jazz to create some of the most memorable pop songs of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: George Brown, who as the drummer of the group Kool & the Gang played on funk, disco and pop hits that featured prominently in movies and have been sampled numerous times, died on Thursday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Advertisers Flee X as Outcry Over Musk’s Endorsement of Antisemitic Post Grows
abstract: Disney, Apple, Paramount and Lionsgate halted marketing on X, formerly Twitter, as Elon Musk faced a furor over antisemitic abuse on his social media platform.
lead_paragraph: The blowback over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X gathered steam on Friday, as several major advertisers on his social media platform cut off their spending after his comments.

headline: Alex Murdaugh Pleads Guilty to Spate of Financial Crimes
abstract: Financial Crimes
lead_paragraph: Alex Murdaugh, the former lawyer who was convicted this year of murdering his wife and son, pleaded guilty on Friday to a spate of money laundering and other financial crimes, fortifying the prospect that he will spend decades in prison even as he seeks a retrial in his murder case.

headline: Brendan Sexton, a Pioneer of Recycling, Is Dead at 78
abstract: As New York City’s sanitation commissioner, he began the mandatory program to separate garbage. He also hired the department’s first uniformed women.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Sexton, who as New York City’s sanitation commissioner initiated what at the time was the nation’s most ambitious mandatory garbage recycling program and hired the first women as uniformed workers in the department’s 105-year history, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Ex-Sheriff’s Deputy Pleads Guilty to Failing to Intervene in Fatal Shooting
abstract: Six other Colorado law enforcement officers were also charged with failure to intervene in connection to the death of Christian Glass, 22, who called 911 for roadside help.
lead_paragraph: A former Colorado sheriff’s deputy pleaded guilty this week to failure to intervene in connection with the fatal shooting last year of a man who had called 911 for roadside assistance, prosecutors said on Friday. Six other law enforcement officers who responded to the 911 call were also charged in the case.

headline: Meet Mira Murati, the Engineer Now Leading OpenAI
abstract: The company’s interim C.E.O. has been managing the development and distribution of ChatGPT and DALL-E for years.
lead_paragraph: For years, Mira Murati has worked behind the scenes at OpenAI, overseeing the development and delivery of revolutionary products such as ChatGPT and DALL-E. Now, she is stepping into the limelight as its interim chief executive.

headline: Israel Says Hospital Held Hamas Command Center: How Long Could It Take for Proof?
abstract: Military experts say it could take days, weeks or months for Israel to make a definitive case. Or it might never come.
lead_paragraph: Israel is trying to produce solid evidence for its assertion that Hamas has been using tunnels under Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza as a command center. But an Israeli military-led tour of the hospital grounds with journalists Thursday night showed directly only a shaft in the ground with a staircase, which did not settle the issue.

headline: Montauketts’ Bid for N.Y. State Recognition Is Vetoed for the 5th Time
abstract: The tribe on Eastern Long Island, which lost state recognition more than a century ago, has won over the State Legislature, but not the governor.
lead_paragraph: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.

headline: Colorado Judge Keeps Trump on Ballot but Finds He ‘Engaged in Insurrection’
abstract: A district court judge ruled that former President Donald J. Trump “engaged in insurrection” but said the disqualification clause of the 14th Amendment did not apply to him.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado judge ruled on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump could remain on the primary ballot in the state, rejecting the argument that the 14th Amendment prevents him from holding office again — but doing so on relatively narrow grounds that lawyers for the voters seeking to disqualify him said they would appeal.

headline: Liberia’s President Concedes Election Defeat in a Knife-Edge Vote
abstract: President George Weah, a former soccer star whose administration had weathered accusations of corruption, announced that he had lost his bid for re-election to Joseph Boakai, a 78-year-old former vice president.
lead_paragraph: Liberia’s president, George Weah, conceded defeat on Friday night in his bid for a second term, after a tight runoff against Joseph Boakai, a 78-year-old political veteran, in an election that was considered a test of democracy in the West African nation.

headline: Satellite imagery shows a water plant in Gaza City burned down amid a dire water shortage.
abstract: It was not clear what caused the fire, or how recently the plant had been operating.
lead_paragraph: Fire has gutted a water treatment plant on the outskirts of Gaza City, satellite images captured on Thursday and Friday show — the latest evidence of damage to water infrastructure amid an increasingly dire shortage of clean water.

headline: Thousands Gather in Pro-Palestinian Protests Across New York City
abstract: In Brooklyn and in Manhattan, multiple rallies drew large crowds calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people took to the streets on Friday evening in the latest instance of what has become near daily protests in New York City over the Israel-Hamas war. This time, pro-Palestinian demonstrators held banners and signs demanding a cease-fire in the bombardment of Gaza.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, November 19, 2023
