abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events? The Silk Road, “The Hesitant Fiancée”, and the Clean Air Act.
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events? The Silk Road, “The Hesitant Fiancée”, and the Clean Air Act.

headline: Writer With Good Taste?
abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu serves up a themeless for puzzle gourmets.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — ’Tis the season for holiday puzzle entries, and this grid by Hoang-Kim Vu debuts a great one. There are also a lot of references to festivities and foods, some of them subtle — give your finished solve a once-over and you’ll see what I mean.

headline: Cassie Settles Lawsuit Accusing Sean Combs of Rape and Abuse
abstract: The R&B singer Casandra Ventura and the music mogul did not disclose terms of the settlement, which came one day after Ms. Ventura filed an explosive complaint.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs and the singer Cassie have reached a settlement just one day after she filed an explosive lawsuit accusing the hip-hop mogul of rape and numerous instances of physical abuse.

headline: Nikki Haley Says She Would Have Signed Six-Week Abortion Ban as Governor
abstract: The former governor of South Carolina, who has tried to thread the needle on abortion in the G.O.P. race, made a gesture of support for stricter limits on the procedure.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina has tried to carve a more moderate path on the contentious issue of abortion than many of her rivals for the Republican nomination for president.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 18, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new biopic on the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin misstates the middle initial of an author. He is Michael G. Long, not Michael C. Long.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Dying Anticorruption Crusader Considers His Life’s Own Misdeeds
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 18, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “When everybody’s quiet, you just whisper and everybody can hear you.”

headline: The Bloody, 76-Hour Battle on a Tiny Atoll That Helped End World War II
abstract: The Battle of Tarawa, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, took a heavy toll on American forces and led to outrage at home.
lead_paragraph: Over three days of intense fighting, thousands of soldiers perished on beaches and in the ocean for a prize — a strategic speck of coral sand and its critical air strip, in the middle of the Pacific — that would help decide the outcome of World War II.

headline: Powerful Quake Shakes Southern Philippines, Killing at Least 7
abstract: The 6.7-magnitude earthquake struck near General Santos City, where hundreds were injured, and schools and shopping malls were closed.
lead_paragraph: A powerful underwater earthquake shook the southern Philippines on Friday, killing several people, damaging a school, shopping malls and dozens of homes, and knocking out power across villages, officials said.

headline: Emergency Pod: Sam Altman is Out at Open AI
abstract: “Probably the most shocking tech story of the year.”
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman, the chief executive of Open AI, was pushed out of the company by its board of directors on Friday. The news was a complete shock to much of the company’s employee base and to its largest corporate partner, Microsoft. Silicon Valley insiders are scrambling to get answers on exactly what happened and why the board’s decision seemed so abrupt. We rundown what we know and the many things we still don’t.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: In a Six-Point Star, a Multitude of Meanings
abstract: Wearing Star of David necklaces and other Judaica has become a way for some Jewish people to declare their heritage amid a rise in antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: About four years ago, after the deadly shooting at a synagogue in Poway, Calif., in April 2019, Abby Adams and Sammy Gabbai started an Instagram account to share stories of Jewish solidarity. The account, Why I Wear My Star, featured posts containing people’s reasons for wearing Star of David jewelry and other Judaica.

headline: Robert Moses Put Monkeys in a Park in Harlem. They’re Finally Gone.
abstract: The iron monkeys with shackled wrists were mentioned in “The Power Broker,” which was published nearly 50 years ago, but had remained mounted in a Riverside Park playground until recently.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the metal trellis adorning a public bathroom in a playground in Riverside Park may have appeared innocuous. It was made up of four posts, each decorated with a long-tailed iron monkey.

headline: Why Revel Shut Down Its Moped Service in New York
abstract: Revel’s ridership has declined steeply amid safety concerns and growing competition from Citi Bike and personal e-bikes and mopeds.
lead_paragraph: When Revel brought 68 electric mopeds to a Brooklyn storefront in 2018, it set out to show New Yorkers that getting around the city could be fun.

headline: How a Political Insider Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Tricia Shimamura keeps busy by welcoming immigrants, helping women get into politics and chasing around her two young children on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Tricia Shimamura spends her days crisscrossing the city as the director of community affairs for Mark Levine, the Manhattan borough president. She helps with everything from street fairs to welcoming new immigrants.

headline: But How Does the Book Sound?
abstract: In August, The Times began publishing regular reviews of audiobooks, a booming segment of the publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: For about a decade, Elena Sheppard has reviewed books, mostly fiction, including several novels for The New York Times. It’s safe to say she knows the art well. But in June, an unexpected request landed in her email inbox.

headline: F1 in Las Vegas: A Roaring Spectacle for Fans, but a Huge Headache for Locals
abstract: The flashy adult playground shrouds itself in black tarp to block views of the racing spectacle from prying (unticketed) eyes. Its transformation has become a long-term, costly nuisance for locals.
lead_paragraph: Rajine Jones has a front-row seat to the Las Vegas Grand Prix, one of the most audacious events to roar into a city built on spectacle. Not that she will be able to see it.

headline: ‘Subway Mania’ Brings the Cartoonish World of Pro Wrestling to Commuters
abstract: The wrestling superfan, Tim Rivera, leads a troupe of performers that cosplay as their childhood heroes in front of unsuspecting subway riders.
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, the city’s subways are the performance spaces they encounter most often. Everyday, dancers and musicians put on a subterranean revue that uses mass transit as a stage.

headline: ‘It’s Like I Am Blind’: Waiting for Asylum in a British Hotel
abstract: With the contentious Rwanda plan in disarray, experts say the U.K. government should focus on a huge backlog of asylum cases, including 50,000 people in hotels.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Mohammed Al Muhandes wakes up in a hotel in Leeds, England, and wonders how to pass the day.

headline: How to Keep Your Bank From Closing All Your Accounts
abstract: Banks have suddenly shut down the accounts of scores of customers. Here’s how you can avoid becoming one of them.
lead_paragraph: Having a checking account is a privilege, not a right, but most people forget this until they lose access to their accounts.

headline: Why Is the College Board Pushing to Expand Advanced Placement?
abstract: This year, taxpayers paid the nonprofit at least $90 million for A.P. tests that many students failed.
lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, the College Board has moved aggressively to expand the number of high school students taking Advanced Placement courses and tests — in part by pitching the program to low-income students and the schools that serve them.

headline: Chapter 5: An Unlikely Escape Route
abstract: Here was the paradox of being a woman in modern India. Sometimes a path from the oppression of patriarchy was marriage to a man willing to help challenge that system.
lead_paragraph: For Nasreen, getting to New Delhi after she ran away from her family and the betrothal they had arranged for her was a daring feat. But surviving there tested her determination.

headline: Dubai’s Costly Water World
abstract: The city has spent billions of dollars to provide fresh water to its residents and tourist attractions, but experts say the efforts are straining the Persian Gulf’s natural resources.
lead_paragraph: For a desert city, Dubai appears like a water wonderland. Visitors can scuba dive in the world’s deepest pool or ski inside a megamall where penguins play in freshly made snow. A fountain — billed as the world’s largest — sprays more than 22,000 gallons of water into the air, synchronized to music from surrounding speakers.

headline: The Bergdorf Blonde Moves to Park Avenue
abstract: The location has changed, but clients such as Hillary Clinton and Martha Stewart remain loyal to Parvin Klein, a colorist who perfected an iconic hair color.
lead_paragraph: The Bergdorf blonde is now taking meetings at the Regency Hotel.

headline: Sex Workers Have Been Shunned by Banks, Even When Their Work Is Legal
abstract: Financial service companies often avoid what they deem high-risk industries like adult entertainment. When workers lose their accounts, they are left with few options.
lead_paragraph: Bella Cummins has run Bella’s Hacienda Ranch, her Nevada brothel, for nearly four decades — and for four decades, she’s been shunned by much of the banking industry.

headline: Crushing It
abstract: The minivan life takes a turn when the kids are old enough to drive.
lead_paragraph: My life is pretty relaxing right now, but there’s a chilling period each day that derails all of my sleekest and sturdiest emotional trains, and that’s the dark corridor between 8:30 and 8:42 a.m., when my two daughters leave for high school.

headline: Excuse Me While I Do My Holiday Preset
abstract: Some people are pulling back — in socializing, spending, eating — not to avoid Covid, but to bolster their mental health.
lead_paragraph: Right after Halloween, Ashley Guerra started being inundated with invitations — for Friendsgiving, for holiday parties and for New Year’s Eve.

headline: Sea Creatures From the Deep, Captured in Glass, Rise at Mystic Seaport
abstract: A new show of marine invertebrates, modeled in Germany nearly 150 years ago, helps tell a story about the Connecticut coast today.
lead_paragraph: An enterprising father and son in Dresden, Germany, Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka, found success in the 19th century hand-blowing glass models of marine invertebrates and selling them to universities and natural history museums around the world, from New England to Tokyo. Harvard and Cornell bought around a thousand, in total, by mail order in the 1870s and 1880s.

headline: Where the 9/11 Dead Are Not Forgotten at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Victims’ relatives leave memory stones and messages at a site that is walking distance from the court where the four men accused of conspiring in the plot have yet to be tried.
lead_paragraph: Stones and seashells for people killed in the Sept. 11 attacks began appearing at a signpost at Guantánamo Bay a few years ago, not far from the courtroom for war crimes cases.

headline: How Do I Make My Building Turn on the Heat (or Turn It Up)?
abstract: New York City requires building owners to provide heat between Oct. 1 and May 31.
lead_paragraph: Q: Our co-op building near Gramercy Park is not following New York City heating laws. There’s been no heat after 10 p.m. so far this year, and there was rarely heat at night last year. There is no heat at 6 a.m. — it comes on at 7 a.m. The windows are drafty and need to be replaced, which makes the problem worse. A vote by co-op shareholders on replacing the windows did not pass. Several of us have offered to pay to replace the windows ourselves, but we were told we cannot do this. What can we do to make sure the building is properly heated?

headline: In Hurricane’s Sudden Fury, Acapulco’s Yacht Crews Went Down With Their Ships
abstract: Hurricane Otis left a trail of destruction and death but inflicted its worst blow on the yacht crews and other boat workers who are a pillar of the tourism industry.
lead_paragraph: On the night Hurricane Otis barreled into Acapulco, Mexico, Saúl Parra Morales received a video that only hours before would have seemed unbelievable.

headline: Black Thought Is Here for ‘The Gilded Age’ and ‘1883’
abstract: Tariq Trotter, the Roots frontman and author of the new book “The Upcycled Self,” loves a period drama when it’s done right.
lead_paragraph: Despite earning worldwide acclaim as the frontman of the Roots and achieving a degree of ubiquity when they became the house band for “The Tonight Show,” Tariq Trotter, also known as Black Thought, is an introvert and a bit of an enigma. There’s a good chance that fans who know every Roots verse still know little about the man behind them.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Nov. 11-17
abstract: “Quit” is easy, but being a word scholar is hard.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: The Critics Scoffed. Nora Roberts Just Kept Writing.
abstract: At 73, a titan of the romance world talks about how she redefined a genre that was all too easy to dismiss.
lead_paragraph: It’s no exaggeration to say that the writer Nora Roberts has shaped how generations of people, especially women, think about relationships and sex — not to mention, what makes a great story. Before Roberts, the romance genre was dominated by tepid and virginal women who were overpowered by brooding men. Roberts changed all that by thrusting romance into the modern era.

headline: Europe Moves to Fill Weapons Gap Amid Doubts About U.S. Commitment to Ukraine
abstract: Germany, Norway, Britain and others are increasing weapons production to help Kyiv. But the aid may be coming too late as winter looms and Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia stalls.
lead_paragraph: Faced with growing American reluctance to send more military aid to Ukraine, European leaders are moving to fill the gap, vowing new support for Kyiv as it battles Russia in a war in Europe’s backyard.

headline: Bedbug Anxiety Has Come for Asia, and the Pest Killers Are Here for It
abstract: Outbreaks in France and South Korea have people across Asia on high alert for bedbugs. Exterminators in the region say business is booming.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good time to be a professional bug killer in Asia.

headline: Here is what to know about Saturday’s SpaceX launch.
abstract: SpaceX’s Starship, the most powerful rocket ever built, lifted off for a second test flight on Saturday and reached an altitude of about 90 miles above Earth before engineers lost contact with it.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX’s Starship, the most powerful rocket ever built, lifted off for a second test flight on Saturday and reached an altitude of about 90 miles above Earth before engineers lost contact with it.

headline: Single-Use Plastics Ban Overturned by Canadian Court
abstract: Steven Guilbeault, Canada’s environment minister, said the government was “strongly considering” an appeal of the federal court’s ruling.
lead_paragraph: Plastic bags have been disappearing from the checkout lines of Canadian retailers after the federal government banned them last year, along with a handful of other single-use plastic items such as straws and disposable takeout cutlery. But just as businesses and consumers were adapting, a court ruling upended the policy, a key part of Canada’s effort to be among the “world leaders in fighting plastic pollution.”

headline: A Thanksgiving Road Map
abstract: We have a plan to help you prepare for the holiday — and stay sane.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, just as a jubilant Santa Claus was making his way across 34th Street on TV, I noticed something alarming in the kitchen of my childhood home. The oven I had preheated for my stuffing had not, in fact, heated.

headline: How I Learned to Shave
abstract: Things our dads taught us, whether they intended to or not.
lead_paragraph: Things our dads taught us, whether they intended to or not.

headline: I’m a Climate Scientist. I’m Not Screaming Into the Void Anymore.
abstract: Something has changed in the United States, and not just the climate.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half years ago, when I was asked to help write the most authoritative report on climate change in the United States, I hesitated. Did we really need another warning of the dire consequences of climate change in this country? The answer, legally, was yes: Congress mandates that the National Climate Assessment be updated every four years or so. But after four previous assessments and six United Nations reports since 1990, I was skeptical that what we needed to address climate change was yet another report.

headline: The Startling Evidence on Learning Loss Is In
abstract: The effects of the pandemic on children are persistent and require urgent attention.
lead_paragraph: In the thick of the Covid-19 pandemic, Congress sent $190 billion in aid to schools, stipulating that 20 percent of the funds had to be used for reversing learning setbacks. At the time, educators knew that the impact on how children learn would be significant, but the extent was not yet known.

headline: Postpone Social Security for the Sake of the Young?
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay that said older Americans need to rethink their retirement expectations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why We Have to Reckon With the Real Malcolm X
abstract: Malcolm X still looms over our current moment. But the version of the man that we meet now is much more human, relatable, problematic and inspirational, for all his flaws.
lead_paragraph: When Anthony Davis’s opera “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,” which is currently being revived at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, premiered in the mid-1980s, it seemed like a radical act of elevation: The opera lent grand pathos to the story of Malcolm X by giving his life the arc of a tragic hero. And at that moment, Malcolm X was a hero, achieving a grandeur on the world stage in death beyond what he had achieved in life.

headline: For the Holidays, These May Be the Best Gifts
abstract: For my annual giving guide, these three nonprofits are the top reader favorites.
lead_paragraph: Wondering what to give friends and relatives this holiday season? Here are ideas for gifts that change lives.

headline: Can Nikki Haley Beat Trump?
abstract: Imagining the unlikely scenario in which she actually wins the nomination.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to admit that I underestimated Nikki Haley.

headline: The Axe Is Sharp
abstract: Biden should aim more barbs at Trump, not at fellow Democrats.
lead_paragraph: David Axelrod is not a prick.

headline: George Santos Is More Dangerous Than You Know
abstract: Mr. Santos has exposed just how much craziness the Republican Party is willing to tolerate in pursuit of narrow partisan gains.
lead_paragraph: By now, you probably know a lot about George Santos, the congressman who scammed with abandon and made up almost everything. His college diploma. His grandparents who “survived” the Holocaust. Many of his most egregious untruths were unveiled by The New York Times last December. This week, the House Ethics Committee went even further, reporting that he had used campaign money for Atlantic City trips and things marked “Botox.”

headline: Two Books for a Happier Thanksgiving
abstract: A glamorous family memoir; a fictional dinner party.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Cybersecurity Lawsuit That Boards Are Talking About
abstract: An S.E.C. lawsuit against a software company hacked by Russian state actors in 2020 could affect how companies handle cybersecurity risks.
lead_paragraph: For the last month, an under-the-radar lawsuit has privately been a hot topic of conversation in Fortune 500 boardrooms and corporate security departments.

headline: Congress Isn’t a Schoolyard. Time to Deal With Toxic Immaturity.
abstract: Young men need to look for role models outside the attention economy.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Senator Markwayne Mullin, Republican of Oklahoma, decided to settle a social media beef in the middle of a Senate hearing labeled Standing Up Against Corporate Greed. Mullin read from a months-old post by Sean O’Brien, the president of the Teamsters, in which O’Brien called Mullin “a clown & fraud,” mocked the senator with an unflattering photo and the hashtag #LittleManSyndrome and challenged the senator to a fight: “Anyplace, Anytime cowboy,” O’Brien boasted.

headline: Don Walsh, Record-Breaking Deep Sea Explorer, Dies at 92
abstract: In 1960, aboard the submersible Trieste, he and a scientist made a historic dive of nearly seven miles into the ocean’s deepest spot.
lead_paragraph: Don Walsh, a pioneering U.S. Navy explorer who, along with the scientist Jacques Piccard, broke the record for human deep submergence by descending nearly seven miles to the ocean’s deepest spot, died on Nov. 12 at his home in Myrtle Point, Ore. He was 92.

headline: Colombia to Sterilize Pablo Escobar’s ‘Cocaine Hippos’
abstract: The drug kingpin brought four hippos to his estate in the 1980s. Officials estimate that about 170 now roam Colombia, and say the population must be controlled to protect the country’s ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: When the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar was killed in 1993, most of the animals he had imported as pets — zebras, giraffes, kangaroos and rhinoceroses — died or were transferred to zoos.

headline: This Is Not the Way to Help Depressed Teenagers
abstract: Large-scale, “light touch” interventions have backfired.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the pandemic, when rates of teenage suicide, anxiety and depression spiked, policymakers around the world have pushed to make mental health resources more broadly available to young people through programming in schools and on social media platforms.

headline: The War Turns Gaza Into a ‘Graveyard’ for Children
abstract: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
lead_paragraph: Barefoot and weeping, Khaled Joudeh, 9, hurried toward the dozens of bodies wrapped in white burial shrouds, blankets and rugs outside the overcrowded morgue.

headline: How to Become a Cricket Expert for the Cricket World Cup Final
abstract: The world’s top cricket teams have spent the past weeks battling to determine which is the best at the Cricket World Cup, one of the most popular sporting events in the world. But in some countries, including the U.S., cricket barely hits sports fans’ radars — which is a shame! With the World Cup final set for Sunday, here’s what you need to know to understand a game that has captivated fans for centuries.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top cricket teams have spent the past weeks battling to determine which is the best at the Cricket World Cup, one of the most popular sporting events in the world. But in some countries, including the U.S., cricket barely hits sports fans’ radars — which is a shame! With the World Cup final set for Sunday, here’s what you need to know to understand a game that has captivated fans for centuries.

headline: French Senator Accused of Drugging Fellow Lawmaker
abstract: Joël Guerriau, a centrist representing a region of western France, is under investigation over suspicion that he spiked a colleague’s drink with the intention of sexually assaulting her.
lead_paragraph: A French senator is under investigation on accusations that he spiked the drink of a fellow lawmaker with drugs this past week with an intent to sexually assault her, the Paris prosecutor’s office said on Saturday.

headline: What happened during SpaceX’s Starship test flight.
abstract: Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas just after 7 a.m. Central time on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas just after 7 a.m. Central time on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.

headline: Is Israel’s Military Strategy to Eradicate Hamas Working?
abstract: Israel is making progress in ground control of Gaza, but it has not vanquished Hamas or freed most of the hostages. And international condemnation of civilian casualties is growing.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military’s seizure of Al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical complex, is central to the military strategy at the heart of the ground invasion: Eradicate Hamas and free roughly 240 hostages taken during the Oct. 7 surprise attack.

headline: They survived Hamas’s attack on a trance party. An ad hoc center with art and music is helping them heal.
abstract: For some who had taken psychedelics at the event, the traumatic effects may have been compounded. A group of caregivers joined together to help.
lead_paragraph: The gunning down of hundreds of partygoers at Tribe of Nova, a trance party in Re’im, Israel, in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 terrorist attacks has wrought an outpouring of grief for those killed or taken hostage. Yet while the several thousand attendees who survived may feel lucky to be alive, many are still grappling with the aftermath of the horrifying experience.

headline: Many Details of Sam Altman’s Ouster Are Murky. But Some Things Are Clear.
abstract: Everything seemed to be going his way. Then his time at OpenAI was over.
lead_paragraph: All over Silicon Valley, phones lit up on Friday with the same question: What the heck happened to Sam Altman?

headline: This Chocolate Chess Pie Is a Dessert Checkmate
abstract: It’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
lead_paragraph: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt. Those ingredients make up Vaughn Vreeland’s new chocolate chess pie (above), a veritable litany of all the baking stuffs we want when the weather turns cold and the yule log turns warm. Made with a store-bought pie crust (or a half-recipe of this foolproof pie dough), it’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.

headline: Rumbles in the Senate and the Supreme Court — and the Movie You’ll Never See
abstract: Here’s what caught my eye this week.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of news this week, and I could not write a column about every event. Instead, here are some quick thoughts on a few events that caught my eye. You can think of this as something like a lightning round.

headline: Ohio Priest Who Sexually Abused Boys Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
abstract: The priest, Michael Zacharias, had enabled the victims’ drug addictions by paying them money in exchange for sexual acts, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio priest who coerced three boys into engaging in sexual acts as children and abused their addiction to opioids as teenagers and adults, paying them money that funded their drug habits in exchange for sex, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday, the Justice Department said.

headline: SpaceX Makes Progress in 2nd Launch of Giant Moon and Mars Rocket
abstract: The journeys of Starship’s two parts ended in separate explosions. But the engineers at Elon Musk’s spaceflight company overcame problems that marred the rocket’s first flight in April.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX, Elon Musk's spaceflight company, launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.

headline: Fan Dies at Taylor Swift Concert in Rio’s Extreme Heat
abstract: Many fans fell sick at the show, where temperatures broke records and concertgoers complained of a lack of water. The pop star postponed Saturday’s show.
lead_paragraph: One fan died and many others fainted at Taylor Swift’s concert on Friday in Rio de Janeiro, where temperatures felt like nearly 140 degrees Fahrenheit, a record for the city, and fans said they struggled to get water.

headline: Apple Says It Will Improve the Green vs. Blue Texting Experience
abstract: Longstanding texting problems between Android and Apple owners will ease next year. Among other changes, users will be able to send better-quality videos and photos.
lead_paragraph: Starting next year, it should be less frustrating for iPhone and Android users to text one another.

headline: Federal Prosecutor Asks Judge to Strip New York of Control Over Rikers
abstract: Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor joined the Legal Aid Society and other lawyers representing people detained in the jail complex in calling for a takeover.
lead_paragraph: The federal government on Friday formally joined an effort to strip Mayor Eric Adams’s administration of control over Rikers Island, asking a judge to hand oversight of the troubled jail complex to an outside authority.

headline: Pardon Recipients Seek to Sell Trump on His Own Sentencing Law
abstract: The Republican front-runner has a history of making racist statements, but some advisers think highlighting his signature law could help increase support among Black voters and potentially swing the election.
lead_paragraph: In early July, former President Donald J. Trump received a somewhat unlikely visitor at his golf club and estate in Bedminster, N.J.: Michael Harris, the founder of Death Row Records, who had been imprisoned for drug trafficking and attempted murder, came to meet privately with the man who had pardoned him.

headline: More Advertisers Halt Spending on X in Growing Backlash Against Musk
abstract: Warner Bros. Discovery and Sony have joined other companies in pausing spending on X, formerly Twitter, over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic post.
lead_paragraph: More major advertisers have paused their spending on X, the social media service formerly known as Twitter, as the backlash continued over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X.

headline: Patients and Workers Leave Gaza Hospital Days After Israeli Raid
abstract: Some said they were ordered to evacuate Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. The military said it had agreed to a request by the hospital director to help people leave safely.
lead_paragraph: Wounded patients, medical workers and hundreds of displaced Palestinians left the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital complex on Saturday, a witness and a hospital doctor said, days after Israeli troops stormed the complex in search of Hamas command centers.

headline: The Fear and Tension That Led to Sam Altman’s Ouster at OpenAI
abstract: The departure of the high-profile boss of the San Francisco company drew attention to a philosophical rift among the people building new A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, Sam Altman led OpenAI to the adult table of the technology industry. Thanks to its hugely popular ChatGPT chatbot, the San Francisco start-up was at the center of an artificial intelligence boom, and Mr. Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, had become one of the most recognizable people in tech.

headline: Viktor Belenko, Who Defected to the West in a Jet Fighter, Dies at 76
abstract: Among the highest-profile figures to flee the Soviet Union, he brought with him a secret weapon and firsthand experience behind the Iron Curtain.
lead_paragraph: On a clear late summer day in 1976, a plane popped up on the radar just off the coast of the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It had been flying a mere 100 feet off the water, low enough to avoid detection. Now, suddenly, it climbed up to 20,000 feet. Clearly, the pilot wanted to be seen.

headline: Ousted OpenAI C.E.O. Makes Plans for New Artificial Intelligence Company
abstract: Sam Altman, who was forced out of his company on Friday afternoon, was quickly moving to create another company with another OpenAI executive who quit on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman, the tech entrepreneur who was removed as chief executive of OpenAI on Friday by its board of directors, is in the process of pitching a new artificial intelligence start-up to investors, according to three people familiar with his plans.

headline: Thanksgiving Meal Prep
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein and Rachel Fabi’s puzzle brings everything you could possibly need to the table.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: David Del Tredici, Who Set ‘Alice’ to Music, Dies at 86
abstract: A Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, he was an experimentalist who redefined himself, becoming identified with a lush style called the New Romanticism.
lead_paragraph: David Del Tredici, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer who began as an experimentalist but became best known for a midcareer shift toward a style that came to be called the New Romanticism, which yielded a series of rich-hued, tuneful pieces based on Lewis Carroll’s “Alice” stories, died on Saturday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 86.

headline: Sam Altman Is Said to Be Discussing Return to OpenAI With Company’s Board
abstract: Mr. Altman was forced out of the artificial intelligence start-up on Friday, leading to an outcry from his supporters and the company’s investors.
lead_paragraph: Sam Altman and Greg Brockman, two top executives at OpenAI who left the company after a dramatic board meeting on Friday, are talking again with board members about returning to the artificial intelligence start-up, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Louisiana General Election Results
abstract: See all results and maps from the Louisiana general election.
lead_paragraph: See all results and maps from the Louisiana general election.

headline: Trump Focuses on Iowa as He Looks to Close Out the Republican Race
abstract: The former president has made Iowa his priority, hoping to thin the field and turn his attention to a campaign against President Biden.
lead_paragraph: With just under two months until the Iowa caucuses, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday returned to the state and made explicit a campaign strategy that he had only hinted at for months.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Smoldering Gaza Becomes a Graveyard for Children
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The children’s bodies come to us broken and in pieces. It’s chilling.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new biopic on the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin misstates the middle initial of an author. He is Michael G. Long, not Michael C. Long.

headline: The Invisible War in Ukraine Being Fought Over Radio Waves
abstract: Using electromagnetic waves to flummox and follow smarter weapons has become a critical part of the cat-and-mouse game between Ukraine and Russia. The United States, China and others have taken note.
lead_paragraph: The drones began crashing on Ukraine’s front lines, with little explanation.

headline: A Jan. 6 Defendant Pleads His Case to the Son Who Turned Him In
abstract: The Capitol attacks ruptured their mutual trust. In the weeks before Brian Mock’s sentencing, could he mend the divide with his son A.J.?
lead_paragraph: The trial was over and the verdict was in, but Brian Mock, 44, kept going back through the evidence, trying to make his case to the one person whose opinion he valued most. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Wisconsin next to his son, 21-year-old A.J. Mock, and opened a video on his laptop. He leaned into the screen and traced his finger over the image of the U.S. Capitol building, looked through clouds of tear gas and smoke and then pointed toward the center of a riotous crowd.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: What Endures After a Climate Activist’s Suicide: Grief, Anger and Hope
abstract: Five years ago, David Buckel violently ended his life in a public park in Brooklyn. People who knew him were shocked and angry. Yet they refused to give up.
lead_paragraph: They were walking up Ninth Street in Park Slope as they often did after work, each man a movie unto himself: one a crusading L.G.B.T.Q. rights attorney who quit the law to shovel dirt, the other a young man from the projects who became his most brilliant protégé.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Is Upgrading Its Radios. The Public Won’t Be Able to Tune In.
abstract: The New York Police Department is spending $500 million on a new radio system it calls more reliable and secure. But the public will no longer be able to monitor what officers are doing minute to minute.
lead_paragraph: John Roca cruised through Midtown Manhattan on a recent night just as the streetlights flicked on, his camera in the back seat of his sedan.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: In Hitler’s Birthplace, Soul-Searching Over a Poisonous Past
abstract: The Austrian government is turning the house where Hitler was born into a police station. But many think it should be used instead to teach essential lessons about history.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian town of Braunau am Inn, sitting just at the border with Germany, has a 15th-century church tower, cobblestone streets and cluttered rows of charming, colorful houses, some in green, pink and blue.

headline: From Vegetation to Prevarication, Hedge’s Meaning Has Grown
abstract: As a verb, “hedge” first meant to create a border with shrubbery. But it’s not just land that can be hedged: so too can bets, investments and words.
lead_paragraph: In June, Debra Kamin, who covers real estate, wrote about the hedges that hid the homes of Hollywood’s rich and famous: “From the street, a passer-by would have no idea that an alternate universe exists just beyond their leafy green walls.”

headline: New Tool for Building and Fixing Roads and Bridges: Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In Pennsylvania and elsewhere, A.I. is being applied to the nation’s aging infrastructure. Is that wise?
lead_paragraph: In Pennsylvania, where 13 percent of the bridges have been classified as structurally deficient, engineers are using artificial intelligence to create lighter concrete blocks for new construction. Another project is using A.I. to develop a highway wall that can absorb noise from cars — and some of the greenhouse gas emissions that traffic releases as well.

headline: ‘The Cashier’s Expression Saved Me From Having to Ask the Obvious’
abstract: A second life for a lunch receipt, a late summer storm and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: As Morocco Tries to Rebuild After Quake, Tradition Is Top of Many Minds
abstract: Experts say the government should preserve cultural and architectural heritage, while also building disaster-resistant homes. In the meantime, residents are living in tents and in limbo.
lead_paragraph: Boujemaa Kouti still remembers the screams of his neighbors trapped under the rubble of their houses, calling for help that horrific night 63 years ago.

headline: Swedish Soccer Prioritized Fans Over Finances. Now, Business Is Booming.
abstract: While most of Europe’s leagues engage in a Sisyphean quest to source as much money as possible, Sweden has chosen a different model. But its rewards come with risk.
lead_paragraph: The warning sounded over and over, first in Swedish and then in English. A fire had been detected. Please evacuate the stadium. The players left the field. Outside, fire crews were arriving. But in the stands, as a thick cloud of smoke wreathed and coiled in the floodlights, nobody moved. The fans were going to make the game happen by sheer force of will.

headline: F.B.I. Faulted Agents for Shooting at a Fleeing Suspect and Killing a Family Dog
abstract: Agents rarely get in trouble for intentionally firing their guns at people or animals. The two “bad shoot” incidents were not previously known.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. faulted agents in 2019 for misusing their guns in two separate shootings, each an exceedingly rare internal finding of violations of its lethal force policy, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.

headline: How Targeted Weight Loss Ads Can Haunt Future Brides
abstract: When women post about their engagements and upcoming weddings on social media, an unexpected, potentially damaging specter arrives: targeted weight loss ads.
lead_paragraph: After Lauren Aitchison became engaged in March 2022, she began seeing targeted ads for wedding content everywhere, with marketing phrases like “shredding for the wedding” and “bridal boot camp.”

headline: What to Know About Assisted Living
abstract: The facilities can look like luxury apartments or modest group homes, and can vary in pricing structures. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: Are you confused about what an assisted-living facility is, and how it differs from a nursing home? And what you can expect to pay? Here’s a guide to this type of housing for older people.

headline: A Trip to the French Countryside, and Through Time
abstract: Mathias Énard’s new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” considers the jumble of life in a variety of stories and styles.
lead_paragraph: To fully appreciate what Mathias Énard is up to in his new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” it helps to know about the 16th-century French literary genius François Rabelais and his bawdy five-volume masterpiece, “Gargantua and Pantagruel.” A tale of giants who roam the French countryside having drunken adventures and upsetting social norms, Rabelais’s work has been a wellspring of laughter through much of Western literary history, inspiring writers for centuries, though these days he is probably more referred to than read.

headline: It’s Thanksgiving. Will Ozempic Make It Better or Worse?
abstract: The weight-loss drugs that have swept into the cultural conversation crash into a holiday that’s all about food.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gabie Caballero got a call from her brother inviting her to his home in Houston for a Thanksgiving feast. “As soon as he mentioned food and Thanksgiving, I felt overwhelmed,” Ms. Caballero, 46, said.

headline: Extra Fees Drive Assisted-Living Profits
abstract: The add-ons pile up: $93 for medications, $50 for cable TV. Prices soar as the industry leaves no service unbilled. The housing option is out of reach for many families.
lead_paragraph: Assisted-living centers have become an appealing retirement option for hundreds of thousands of boomers who can no longer live independently, promising a cheerful alternative to the institutional feel of a nursing home.

headline: Surviving War in Gaza, One Text Message at a Time
abstract: Every morning, Ahmed Mansour, a Palestinian filmmaker in the U.S., texts his family in Gaza to check if they are still alive. Israel’s siege of the territory has caused widespread communication blackouts, making it difficult for him to reach his parents and siblings.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Ahmed Mansour, a Palestinian filmmaker in the U.S., texts his family in Gaza to check if they are still alive. Israel’s siege of the territory has caused widespread communication blackouts, making it difficult for him to reach his parents and siblings.

headline: ‘Murder’s Easy. We Did Something Much Worse.’
abstract: Our crime columnist recommends four newly published books.
lead_paragraph: There’s a mordant theme to this month’s column; in three of the four books, dark humor undercuts despair and sardonic wit compensates for failure. Nowhere are these traits more on display than in DEATH OF THE RED RIDER (Pushkin Vertigo, 396 pp., paperback, $16.95), the second appearance of Yulia Yakovleva’s Stalin-era detective, Vasily Zaitsev, who goes about the ordinary business of solving murders while communities around him in 1930s Russia are purged and exiled en masse.

headline: Why Do Evil and Suffering Exist? Religion Has One Answer, Literature Another.
abstract: In the third installment of an essay series on literature and faith, Ayana Mathis explores how writers have grappled with one of theology’s oldest conundrums.
lead_paragraph: In the church of my childhood, we believed God’s angels battled demons in a war for our souls. This was not a metaphor. We were Pentecostals, though not strictly and not always. We weren’t picky about denomination; what mattered was belief in the redeeming blood of Christ, in the Bible literally interpreted and in God’s endless love. And evil. We believed in evil.

headline: Mick Herron Has Made a Blockbuster Career Writing About Foul-Ups and Has-Beens
abstract: The author of the “Slow Horses” series says he relates more with failures. With millions of books sold and the third season of the series airing next month, he may have to wrap his head around success.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Mick Herron’s rickety literary career looked to be falling apart. None of his novels had sold more than a few hundred copies, and “Slow Horses,” the first book in his acidly funny series about a band of misfits in the British intelligence services, had performed so badly that its sequel, “Dead Lions,” could not find a British publisher.

headline: A 30-Year Trap: The Problem With America’s Weird Mortgages
abstract: One big reason the U.S. housing market is broken: Owners don’t want to give up their cushy old loans.
lead_paragraph: Buying a home was hard before the pandemic. Somehow, it keeps getting harder.

headline: Derek Hough, America’s Ballroom Ambassador, Hits the Road
abstract: A judge on “Dancing with the Stars,” Hough has become one of the country’s most visible dancers. Now his “Symphony of Dance” is touring to 60 cities.
lead_paragraph: In one week this fall, Derek Hough visited five states as part of his 60-city concert tour “Symphony of Dance.” After a show in Cincinnati, and a post-show ice bath, he flew to Los Angeles for 48 hours to appear on Jennifer Hudson’s talk show, rehearse an upcoming Disney holiday special and film an episode of “Dancing With the Stars,” the hit television ballroom and Latin dance competition that helped start his career 16 years ago. Then he flew to Michigan for the next show.

headline: For Years, Two Men Shuttled Messages Between Israel and Hamas. No Longer.
abstract: Since 2006, Gershon Baskin, an Israeli peace activist, and Ghazi Hamad, a Hamas official, maintained a secret back channel between Gaza and Israel. Then Oct. 7 happened.
lead_paragraph: For 17 years, on and off, two men maintained a secret line of communication between Israel and Hamas, the armed Palestinian group that opposes Israel’s existence.

headline: A Mother’s Search for Her Son Leads to a Pauper’s Grave and More Questions
abstract: Bettersten Wade spent months calling the police for help finding her son, without being told that an off-duty officer driving an S.U.V. had fatally struck him on the same day she last saw him.
lead_paragraph: For months, Bettersten Wade called the police in Jackson, Miss., desperate for any update or sign that detectives were making progress in tracking down Dexter, her 37-year-old son who left their home one day in March and vanished.

headline: What to Know as Argentina Votes in a Pivotal Election
abstract: On Sunday, voters will choose whether to elect a far-right libertarian, Javier Milei, or the center-left economy minister, Sergio Massa.
lead_paragraph: For months, Argentina has been consumed by a single question.

headline: Future Designs the First Lanvin Lab Collection
abstract: The collaboration between the fashion house and the entertainer is the latest example of the growing union between the two industries.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the French fashion house Lanvin will release its inaugural Lanvin Lab collection with Future, the rapper and producer. Earlier this year, Future was brought on, temporarily, to help design the collection for Lanvin Lab, the brand’s new design arm that will focus on rotating collaborations. More pieces from the unisex ready-to-wear collection, all designed by Future, will debut next year.

headline: DeSantis’s Two-Pronged Approach in Iowa: Hit Trump on Abortion, and Get Personal
abstract: The Florida governor is courting white evangelicals by using Donald J. Trump’s criticisms of hard-line abortion restrictions against him.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida paused, looked down and then told a banquet hall filled with conservative Iowa Christians something that he had never before said in public: His wife, Casey DeSantis, experienced a miscarriage several years ago during her first pregnancy.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What Does the U.S. Space Force Actually Do?’
abstract: Inside the highly secretive military branch responsible for protecting American interests in a vulnerable new domain.
lead_paragraph: The Space Force, the sixth and newest branch of the U.S. military, was authorized by Congress and signed into law by President Donald Trump in December 2019. The initiative had been shaped within the armed forces and Congress over the previous 25 years, based on the premise that as satellite and space technologies evolved, America’s military organizations had to change as well.

headline: The Tyranny of Hotness
abstract: Why beauty always commandeers the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: A beautiful person is so often a confrontation. Even in silence, symmetrical features announce their presence and elicit a reaction: desire, admiration, curiosity, resentment, belittlement, rage or envy. The response is rarely neutral.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 27, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Mocks George Santos and Welcomes a Sassy Panda
abstract: Jason Momoa hosted an episode that also poked fun at President Biden’s meeting with Xi Jinping and Thanksgiving travel.
lead_paragraph: Making his second appearance in the role of President Biden, Mikey Day was quickly overshadowed by a sassy panda played by Bowen Yang in a “Saturday Night Live” sketch that parodied a presidential news conference from earlier this week.

headline: What Happens When the Superrich Are This Selfish? (It Isn’t Pretty.)
abstract: In a break from the past, the Western world’s wealthiest people no longer try to support the societies they live in.
lead_paragraph: Throughout much of the Western world’s history, the wealthiest have been viewed in their communities as a potentially harmful presence, and they have attempted to allay this sentiment by using their riches to support their societies in times of crises like plagues, famines and wars.

headline: The Sneaky Sticker Shock of Subscription Culture
abstract: Silicon Valley has immersed us in an expensive, pervasive and perennially annoying type of automated capitalism.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending. As I’ve subscribed to more apps and streaming platforms, significant sums of my money tend to drift away each month without my ever thinking about it. It’s as if it were a tax being taken out of my paycheck, one spent on something silly or indulgent like a subscription box of international snacks instead of — I don’t know — basic public infrastructure.

headline: An Old Hate Cracks Open on the New Right
abstract: Antisemitism breaks loose on the populist right wing.
lead_paragraph: A dam burst last week on the right, and a wave of grotesque antisemitism poured out all over the internet.

headline: The Empty Seat at Our Thanksgiving Table
abstract: After my daughter’s death, I have been approaching this holiday with trepidation.
lead_paragraph: Grieving parents like me are told to gird themselves for anniversaries and holidays, for birthdays and religious events. We’re advised to plan for days associated with joy. We consider exit strategies. We talk about how the markers of civil religion and religious observance are harder for us, now that we no longer exist exactly inside society, but run alongside it, observing. Each holiday centered on family is now barbed.

headline: A Cancer Patient’s Last Wish: To Pay Off the Medical Debt of Others
abstract: Casey McIntyre organized a campaign that has raised nearly $220,000 since she died a week ago. The funds are expected to pay off more than $20 million in debt, an official said.
lead_paragraph: A 38-year-old woman with ovarian cancer who started a campaign to help people pay off their medical debt has raised more than $200,000 in the week since she died.

headline: Man Suspected of Killing 4 in Memphis Is Found Dead After Hourslong Manhunt
abstract: The shootings across three locations killed three women and one 13-year-old girl, and critically injured one 15-year-old, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of fatally shooting three women and a 13-year-old girl in Memphis was found dead early Sunday with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said, ending an hourslong manhunt.

headline: When Students’ Cellphones ‘Colonize Their Minds’
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul and a news story about a Florida school district’s ban. Also: The “catastrophists”; an example of compassion.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You’ve Planned Your Play. Now Play Your Plan.
abstract: Cheesy Hasselback potato gratin for Sunday (and Thursday); tofu and green beans with chile crisp for Monday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. For those of us who take Thanksgiving seriously, who plan and plan and cook and cook, this last Sunday before the feast marks the real start of the holiday. I’m cleaning out my fridge and freezer to make room for an epic trip to the supermarket, cataloging serving platters and cooking vessels, making sure I have enough mismatched knives and forks to serve (checks notes) 32 people. (Yikes! I’m short two dozen chairs!)

headline: Yemen’s Houthis hijacked a ship in the Red Sea.
abstract: Only hours earlier, the Iran-backed militia issued a statement threatening to target Israeli-flagged, -owned and -operated ships. Israel said the vessel was not an Israeli ship.
lead_paragraph: Yemen’s Houthi militia hijacked a ship in the Red Sea on Sunday, in what the Iran-backed group said was a demonstration of support for “the oppressed Palestinian people.”

headline: At Least 24 Killed in Strike on Gaza School Run by the U.N.
abstract: Nearly 7,000 people were sheltering at the school, according to the United Nations. Another school had been struck on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A strike this weekend on a school run by the United Nations that was being used for shelter by thousands of displaced people in northern Gaza killed at least 24 people, a U.N. official said Sunday.

headline: Premature Babies Are Evacuated From Embattled Hospital in Gaza
abstract: The 31 babies will be taken to Egypt for treatment, officials say. Israel’s push to seize Al-Shifa Hospital and a lack of power led doctors to warn that the infants were at particular risk.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and taken to another hospital in the enclave’s south, the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization said on social media.

headline: ‘Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,’ Almost
abstract: Not quite a reboot or a sequel, this anime series brings back the cast of the beloved “Scott Pilgrim” movie but lands without the same charm.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that at some point in the ’90s there were two separate, very different Sonic the Hedgehog TV series running simultaneously? “And the same guy played Sonic in both shows,” Scott Pilgrim, the doofy 23-year-old layabout of “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,” shares, unprompted, to his love interest, Ramona Flowers. “Isn’t that wild? The same guy playing two different versions of the same guy??”

headline: Off the Court and Field, Top Athletes Become Players in the Art Market
abstract: Sports figures are increasingly becoming serious collectors, helping drive interest in contemporary art and particularly in artists of color.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony, the 10-time N.B.A. All-Star who announced his retirement in May, said that when he was starting out as a professional basketball player he did not understand art, but grew to appreciate it and began collecting as he matured. Now paintings by major Black artists including Nelson Makamo, Swoon, Rashid Johnson and Kehinde Wiley line the walls of his Westchester home.

headline: I-10 Freeway in Los Angeles to Fully Reopen Monday After Fire Repairs
abstract: Officials had feared that Interstate 10, a crucial artery for drivers, might have been closed for months after a fire on Nov. 11 severely damaged a section of it.
lead_paragraph: Interstate 10 in Los Angeles will fully reopen on Monday, more than a week after a fire severely damaged a section of the freeway, officials announced on Sunday.

headline: Karel Schwarzenberg, Renegade Czech Prince and Politician, Dies at 85
abstract: Popular with the Czech public for quietly subverting the aristocracy, he served twice as foreign minister and ran for president in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Karel Schwarzenberg, a Czech prince who twice served as his country’s foreign minister, played a key role in the Velvet Revolution and quietly subverted aristocratic expectations, died shortly after midnight on Nov. 12 in Vienna. He was 85.

headline: What Happened in the World of Artificial Intelligence?
abstract: Sam Altman’s abrupt ouster from OpenAI highlighted deep divisions in the A.I. world and culminated in his surprise return to the start-up he founded.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt ouster of Sam Altman on Friday as chief executive of OpenAI, one of the world’s most prominent A.I. companies and  the maker of ChatGPT, set off a head-spinning series of twists  that culminated late Tuesday with Mr. Altman’s reinstatement at the company he founded and pledges to overhaul the way OpenAI is run.

headline: After Eras Tour Triumphs, Taylor Swift Finds Trouble in Brazil
abstract: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour broke records in North America, but has faced tragedy and mishaps during a three-day stretch of concerts in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift was welcomed to Brazil on Thursday by a projection that made the world-famous Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro appear as if it were clad in a T-shirt similar to the one she wore in her “You Belong With Me” music video and was decorated with the names of Brazilian states and symbols from her songs.

headline: The White House May Condemn Musk, but the Government Is Addicted to Him
abstract: Rarely has the U.S. government so depended on the technology provided by a single technologist with views that it has so publicly declared repugnant.
lead_paragraph: The White House denounced Elon Musk on Friday for “abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate,” for his endorsement of what an administration spokesman called a “hideous lie” about Jews.

headline: Rosalynn Carter, First Lady and a Political Partner, Dies at 96
abstract: She helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Sunday in Plains, Ga. She was 96.

headline: It Seemed to Have It All: 9 Dancers, 5 Guitars, 5 Amps
abstract: But “takemehome,” a look at isolation by Dimitri Chamblas in collaboration with the musician Kim Gordon, fades into its own shadows at NYU Skirball.
lead_paragraph: The dance started — or seemed to start — with people walking onto the stage before finding a spot and lying down. The bright, blisteringly white lights made the view murky, yet through the haze random bodies were stretched out on backs and sides, utterly limp. Above them was a suspended zeppelin: Imagine a giant balloon of a baked potato floating over 34th Street in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: Bobby Ussery, Jockey Who Saw Triumph and Dismay, Dies at 88
abstract: In amassing 3,611 victories, he rode a long shot, Proud Clarion, to victory in the 1967 Kentucky Derby. The next year at Churchill Downs, he saw victory nullified.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Ussery, a Hall of Fame jockey whose 3,611 victories included the 1960 Preakness Stakes and the 1967 Kentucky Derby, but who saw victory at Churchill Downs snatched away the next year when his horse was disqualified after the race, died on Thursday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 88.

headline: Premature Babies Are Treated After Evacuation From Al-Shifa Hospital
abstract: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.

headline: Monday Briefing: Babies Evacuated From Al-Shifa
abstract: Plus: A woman’s unconventional escape in India.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four days after the Israeli military stormed the biggest hospital in the Gaza Strip, the World Health Organization described the complex as a “death zone” where several patients had died because medical services had been shut down.

headline: Texas Governor Endorses Trump, Lauding His Border Policies
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott threw his support behind the former president in the Republican presidential primary at an event near the southern border.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday in an appearance near the southern border, echoing Mr. Trump’s talk about an existential crisis of illegal immigration.

headline: Talks to Bring Sam Altman Back to OpenAI Stretch Through Weekend
abstract: Disagreements over the board’s makeup appear to have muddled negotiations. Mr. Altman was forced out as chief executive by the company’s board on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Talks at OpenAI to bring back Sam Altman, the artificial intelligence start-up’s recently ousted chief executive, continued into Sunday evening but there were disagreements over the makeup of the company’s board of directors, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

headline: London Police Question Russell Brand About Past Allegations
abstract: The British news media reported on Sunday that he was questioned in connection with three sex offenses.
lead_paragraph: The British police questioned Russell Brand, the comedian, actor and YouTuber, in relation to three allegations that he had committed sexual offenses, according to British news reports.

headline: The Shape of a Rainbow
abstract: Sam Ezersky leaves us in a state of disarray.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: For an Aging President, a Birthday With a Bite
abstract: President Biden has no plans for a lavish public celebration when he turns 81 on Monday, even as Democrats search for a strategy to assuage voters’ concerns about his age by next year’s election.
lead_paragraph: For many of a certain age, there comes a point when marking yet another birthday, taking note of yet another passage of the calendar, is not greeted with the same enthusiasm it once was. And that’s for people who are not even running for president.

headline: Argentina Elects Javier Milei in Victory for Far Right
abstract: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Argentines on Sunday chose Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who has drawn comparisons to Donald J. Trump, as their next president, a lurch to the right for a nation struggling under an economic crisis and a sign of the enduring strength of the global far right.

headline: Infants Moved From ‘Death Zone’ Hospital That Israel Says Was Hamas Hideout
abstract: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Four days after it was seized by Israeli troops, the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital has become a “death zone,” the World Health Organization said, as 31 premature babies in extremely precarious health there were evacuated on Sunday.

headline: ‘A Beautiful Place That Has a Dragon’: Where Hurricane Risk Meets Booming Growth
abstract: The combined threat of climate change and development in risky areas is making it a big challenge to keep coastal Carolina residents safe.
lead_paragraph: The combined threat of climate change and development in risky areas is making it a big challenge to keep coastal Carolina residents safe.

headline: ‘Hell’s Kitchen’ Review: How Alicia Keys Got Her Groove
abstract: A promising Off Broadway jukebox musical features hits by the R&B star (including “Fallin’,” “If I Ain’t Got You” and “No One”) and a story much like her own.
lead_paragraph: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease. “Second act trouble” presented in many ways: unmoored songs, desperate cutting, illogical crises, hasty workarounds. Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.

headline: Cruise’s C.E.O. Quits as the Driverless Carmaker Aims to Rebuild Trust
abstract: Kyle Vogt, a founder of Cruise, resigned from the company on Sunday, weeks after it suspended all of its self-driving operations.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Vogt, a founder and chief executive of Cruise, the driverless car subsidiary of General Motors, resigned on Sunday, less than a month after Cruise suspended all autonomous operations after a series of traffic mishaps.

headline: Rosalynn Carter Lauded for Humanitarian Work, Mental Health Advocacy
abstract: Politicians from both sides of the aisle and other notable figures paid tribute to the former first lady, who died on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Rosalynn Carter, the former first lady, died on Sunday, politicians from both sides of the aisle commended her work in that public role and the strides she made for women’s rights, mental health and many other causes.

headline: A Big Year for India on the Global Stage Ends in Cricket Heartbreak
abstract: A dominant World Cup run closes with a loss to Australia in the final, a symbol of how far India has come and how far it still has to go.
lead_paragraph: The stage was amply set: an acrobatic air show by Indian military planes, performances by star Bollywood singers, a light display, lots of fireworks and — talked about as the highlight — an appearance by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the vast stadium that bears his name.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The latest from the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: On the fifth day of its operation inside the Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City, the Israeli military released video of what it said was a 55-meter (180-foot) section of a fortified tunnel running 10 meters beneath the complex, seeking to bolster its allegations that Hamas has used it as a base for its military operations.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 20, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Viktor Belenko, Who Defected to the West in a Jet Fighter, Dies at 76
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Nov. 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “If my regiment could see five minutes of what I saw today, there would be a revolution.”

headline: Behind 94 Acts of Shocking Violence, Years of Glaring Mistakes
abstract: New York officials have escaped scrutiny for repeated failures to help homeless mentally ill people, a New York Times investigation has found.
lead_paragraph: The last breakdown of Marcus Gomez began in full view of the people whose job it was to stop it.

headline: Microsoft Hires Sam Altman Hours After OpenAI Rejects His Return
abstract: The announcement capped a tumultuous weekend for OpenAI, after Mr. Altman made a push to reclaim his job as C.E.O. of the artificial intelligence company.
lead_paragraph: The board of directors of OpenAI, the high-flying artificial intelligence start-up, said in a note to employees on Sunday night that its former chief, Sam Altman, would not be returning to his job, while naming his second interim replacement in two days.

headline: ‘It Was Terrible’: Taylor Swift Fans in Brazil Bear Heat and Dismay
abstract: Thousands of fans had already traveled to the stadium in Rio de Janeiro by the time the show on Saturday was called off because of safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of fans had already traveled to the stadium in Rio de Janeiro by the time the show on Saturday was called off because of safety concerns.

headline: The Best True Crime to Stream: Family Matters
abstract: Four picks from television, films and podcasts that show blood is not always thicker than water.
lead_paragraph: Family secrets, tumult and trauma are at the heart of so many — if not most — true crime stories, and breed some of the most bizarre betrayals. Here are four picks including podcasts, television and films that explore unforgettable crimes involving families, all of whom prided themselves on presenting a perfect image until the truth came crashing through the facade.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Thanksgiving Specials and Holiday Movies
abstract: The Macy’s Day Parade, an annual dog show and a Friends marathon air on Thanksgiving. And Christmas movies are here, including “Love Actually” and “The Holiday.”
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 20-Nov. 26. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: quackery
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word quackery has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 15 in the book review “A Reason to Cheer for Cells and the Viruses That Feed on Them” by Alex Johnson:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Clothes that Conjure the Holiday Spirit
abstract: Keith Nielsen, who oversaw costumes for four Hallmark Christmas movies out this year, shares his approach to dressing festively. (It does not involve ugly sweaters.)
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Keith Nielsen was feeling less than cheerful when a friend told him about an internship opportunity with the costume department of the TV series “Mozart in the Jungle.”

headline: Helmets Off, Mics Up: N.F.L. Players Discover the Power of Podcasts
abstract: The N.F.L. tends to suppress individuality, but podcasts from stars like the Kelce brothers, Micah Parsons and Tyreek Hill are popping up as valuable portals to fans.
lead_paragraph: Hours after winning a playoff game with the Kansas City Chiefs in 2020, tight end Travis Kelce chatted with his older brother, Philadelphia Eagles center Jason Kelce, about the intricacies of blocking defensive linemen while the siblings devoured dinner at a steakhouse.

headline: An Ex-Detective’s Overturned Murder Cases Have Cost New York $110 Million
abstract: Louis N. Scarcella, a former N.Y.P.D. detective, was accused of framing dozens of people for murder. The city and state have paid a steep price to settle claims over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: A single New York City police detective accused of trying to close murder cases by concocting false witness testimony and coercing confessions has cost taxpayers $110 million in settlements to more than a dozen people whose convictions were overturned after some had spent decades in prison.

headline: How to Watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: Stepping off a half-hour earlier than usual, this year’s parade will include 31 floats, 25 balloons and performances by Jon Batiste and Cher.
lead_paragraph: The 97th annual Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade will take place on Thursday, with over three million spectators expected to brave the early-morning cold for a view of the procession’s many floats, balloons and celebrity performers.

headline: What to Know About Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial
abstract: The short Thanksgiving week will see the parade of expert witnesses continue as the defense argues that the valuations of assets were within normal boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s defense lawyers this week will offer a look into his business operations and continue the parade of expert witnesses testifying on his behalf in a Manhattan courtroom.

headline: In Death Valley, a Rare Lake Comes Alive
abstract: Visitors normally flock to Death Valley National Park to feel the searing heat and take in the barren landscape. This fall, they’ve been drawn by a different natural feature: water.
lead_paragraph: Furnace Creek and Stovepipe Wells are among the roadside outposts inside Death Valley National Park, while Dante’s View draws tourists at sunset and Hell’s Gate greets visitors arriving from the east.

headline: How Electricity Is Changing, Country by Country
abstract: Renewable electricity is rising quickly, but the world’s power mix remains fossil fuel-heavy — for now.
lead_paragraph: Renewable electricity is rising quickly, but the world’s power mix remains fossil fuel-heavy — for now.

headline: They Thought They’d Found the Perfect New York Loft. It Was Illegal.
abstract: Tenants of a Bronx building have been displaced since the city ordered them to vacate. They want the landlord to make repairs and for their loft apartments to be legalized.
lead_paragraph: The painter found out about the Bronx building for creative types on Craigslist. So did the fashion stylist and the air quality technician who calls himself “a wannabe artist.”

headline: How to Avoid Family Drama This Holiday Season
abstract: Sidestep old grudges and political disagreements, and give yourself the gift of peace.
lead_paragraph: For some families, tension around the holidays is quiet — all clenched teeth and subtle jabs. For others, it is big, loud and boozy.

headline: To These Writers, Video Games Are Not Just Entertainment, but Art
abstract: In the anthology “Critical Hits,” gamers like Hanif Abdurraqib, Alexander Chee and Larissa Pham explain what the medium means to them.
lead_paragraph: At their best, video games can offer a path through difficulty, in both reality and fiction. In Ka Vang’s short story “Ms. Pac-Man Ruined My Gang Life,” a Hmong teenager escapes domestic trouble in an arcade; in Jamil Jan Kochai’s “Playing Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain,” an Afghan American boy grows “oddly immune” to the dissonance of shooting video-game targets who resemble his father; in Raven Leilani’s novel “Luster,” Edie and Akila break bread in Overcooked after the police attempt to break their spirits.

headline: Why I Am a Liberal
abstract: Perhaps more than ever, there is an urgent need for a clear understanding of liberalism.
lead_paragraph: More than at any other time since World War II, liberalism is under siege. On the left, some people insist that liberalism is exhausted and dying and unable to handle the problems posed by entrenched inequalities, corporate power and environmental degradation. On the right, some people think that liberalism is responsible for the collapse of traditional values, rampant criminality, disrespect for authority and widespread immorality.

headline: Why Cold Symptoms Are Worse at Night
abstract: We asked experts why we cough and sniffle more when we head to bed, and what to do for better sleep.
lead_paragraph: It’s cold and flu season. That means you’re very likely surrounded by a symphony of coughs and sniffling noses — if you’re not actively coughing yourself.

headline: ‘Lost Time for No Reason’: How Driverless Taxis Are Stressing Cities
abstract: In San Francisco and Austin, Texas, where passengers can hail self-driving vehicles, the cars have added to the workloads of city employees.
lead_paragraph: Around 2 a.m. on March 19, Adam Wood, a San Francisco firefighter on duty, received a 911 call and raced to the city’s Mission neighborhood to help a male who was having a medical emergency.
