Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.

headline: Can the Palestinian Authority Really Govern Gaza After the War?
abstract: Considered authoritarian and corrupt, the Palestinian Authority is still Washington’s choice to run the enclave. But many believe it can be credible now only if it includes Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Lanky and lightly bearded, Jihad Imtoor is the proud son of a fighter killed in the first intifada, or uprising, against Israel. His father was a member of Fatah, the political faction that controls the Palestinian Authority. But he has had enough of its rule in the West Bank.

headline: Could Haley Really Beat Trump? Big Donors Are Daring to Dream.
abstract: Powerful players in the business world have gravitated toward Nikki Haley, aware that she remains an underdog but beginning to believe she has a chance.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Nikki Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, got an unexpected call from Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase. Mr. Dimon said he was impressed by Ms. Haley’s knowledge of policy details and her open-minded approach to complex issues raised in the Republican presidential race, according to a person familiar with what they discussed. Keep it up, he told her.

headline: The Art of Being a Super Begins at Dawn
abstract: A harried super at a five-building co-op in Westchester County carves out some time in the morning to return to his easel and oil paints.
lead_paragraph: Like all superintendents, Peter Rutkowski has a to-do list: tend to the boilers, renovate the laundry room, check a water leak. It goes on and on; it’s endless. But most importantly, he must paint. Every day.

headline: For Russia’s Pop Star Exiles, a Moral Stand and a Creative Climb
abstract: Monetochka was one of Russia’s most discussed pop stars. Now, like other antiwar acts in exile, she’s having to retool her career.
lead_paragraph: Before Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, Monetochka was on her way to becoming a superstar in Russia.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “Maestro,” Bradley Cooper’s biopic on Leonard Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “Maestro,” Bradley Cooper’s biopic on Leonard Bernstein.

headline: How to Make Envy Work for You
abstract: Most of us have faced the green-eyed monster before, but the feeling has benefits, experts say.
lead_paragraph: I have an acquaintance whom I’ve followed for years on social media — even though most of her posts fill me with envy. She always seems to be on a different tropical vacation. How many beaches can a person visit?

headline: What’s It Like to Work With Hayao Miyazaki? Go Behind the Scenes.
abstract: The anime master is a creature of habit who talks every day with his longtime producer, and keeps it more hands off with his regular composer.
lead_paragraph: News of Hayao Miyazaki’s retirement can’t ever be trusted.

headline: In Country Where Houses Are Bought in $100 Bills, Plans for Sweeping Change
abstract: Years of economic quagmire created an upside-down economy in Argentina. Javier Milei, a far-right populist, won the presidency this week by promising to blow it all up.
lead_paragraph: Marcelo Capobianco was inspecting the calf carcass he had just hung from a hook in his small butcher shop outside Buenos Aires on Tuesday when he admitted that the premium-grade beef would hardly earn him anything.

headline: 700 Paintings, 45 Galleries: A Guide to the Met’s New European Wing
abstract: After a five-year renovation, some of the museum’s grandest galleries have reopened. Our critic frames six artworks you cannot miss.
lead_paragraph: Let the light in. Five years after the Metropolitan Museum of Art set off on a major renovation of its galleries for European painting, the super-prime real estate at the top of its grand staircase is open again. Up in the attic, the architects Beyer Blinder Belle have replaced 30,000 square feet of skylights for the first time since the Truman administration. Down in the galleries, the Met’s designers have widened the rooms, rearranged the sightlines, shellacked the walls purple and blue. The curators have reassembled the whole painting collection for the first time since 2018, shuffled across 45 new galleries and bathed in beautifully tempered light.

headline: Past Israel-Hamas Cease-Fires Have Proved Fragile
abstract: In 2014, nine truces came and went during a 51-day conflict and more than 2,000 people were killed before there was a lasting agreement to halt the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas have agreed to a four-day truce — but if the past is any indication, there is no guarantee that the pause in fighting will hold, much less lead to lasting peace.

headline: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Athlete Convicted of Murder, to Be Paroled
abstract: The South African sprinter, who garnered global headlines after killing his girlfriend in 2013, will be released in January after meeting the requirements for parole.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius, a once-inspirational figure who gained international fame as an Olympic sprinter for South Africa before he was convicted of murdering his girlfriend, will be released on parole, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: A Different Approach to Climate Action
abstract: What if we actually succeed in addressing the crisis?
lead_paragraph: There’s no shortage of reasons to be alarmed by climate change these days. This year is almost certain to be the hottest in recorded history. Extreme weather is wreaking havoc around the globe. Fossil fuel production and emissions are still rising, and world leaders are not moving fast enough.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: Missing Chicken
abstract: This week, Asher and Whitney inflict their chaos upon people who never asked for their charity but are now reliant on it.
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of this week’s episode of “The Curse,” a scene opens in an elementary school classroom. At the center of the frame is a boy we have never seen before. He is white and attentive, and the camera zooms in on him. He raises his hand, and gets permission to seemingly go to the bathroom.

headline: Taiwan Opposition Cracks Apart, and Invites the Cameras In
abstract: The split over a proposed joint ticket bolsters the governing party candidate’s chances in the coming presidential election. That won’t please Beijing.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Taiwan’s two main opposition parties were edging toward a coalition, in a bid to unseat the island democracy’s governing party in the coming presidential election, an outcome that Beijing would welcome. The election, one elder statesman from Taiwan’s opposition said, was a choice between war and peace.

headline: ‘It Snowballed’: How a Knife Attack in Dublin Led to a Riot
abstract: The violence in Ireland’s capital on Thursday night was fueled by far-right agitators who spread rumors online about an attack on three children earlier that day.
lead_paragraph: Soon after three children and a woman were wounded in a knife attack outside a Dublin school on Thursday, rumors about the perpetrator’s nationality began to proliferate online.

headline: Let’s Talk Leftovers
abstract: Specifically: turkey soup, turkey pho and Kenji López-Alt’s Thanksgiving Hot Pockets.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How’d it go? I’m hoping really well, for the lot of us: beautifully cooked turkeys and plentiful side dishes, everyone reasonably happy, excellent pies. I hope no one got weird.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The British sci-fi show is celebrating its 60th anniversary with three specials featuring some familiar faces.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for a television show to celebrate its 60th anniversary. It’s even rarer for a show to be entering a new era on its 60th anniversary.

headline: Nissan Will Build More Electric Cars in England
abstract: The company said it would build three electric models at its plant in northeast England, bolstering the future of Britain’s auto industry.
lead_paragraph: Nissan said Friday that it would invest an additional 1.1 billion pounds (about $1.4 billion) to make three new electric models at its plant in Sunderland in northeast England.

headline: Volcano’s Eruption Threat Is Ebbing, but Iceland Continues to Wait
abstract: A fishing town that was evacuated this month will probably be spared, but residents can’t return until all danger has passed.
lead_paragraph: The likelihood that a volcanic eruption will engulf the fishing town of Grindavik, Iceland, is decreasing by the day, officials said on Friday, even as they continued to warn that an eruption could still occur.

headline: Why You Love (or Love to Hate) Christmas Music
abstract: Like the holiday season itself, the nostalgia that Christmas music evokes can be emotionally charged.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a little over one year since the Backstreet Boys released their Christmas album, “A Very Backstreet Christmas,” and Francine Biondo has had it on repeat ever since.

headline: In the Stock Market, Don’t Buy and Sell. Just Hold.
abstract: There’s new evidence that market timing doesn’t work. Your odds of success are better if you just hang on and aim for average returns, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Selling all of your stock just before the market falls, and buying shares just before the market rises, is a brilliant strategy.

headline: Disney Rejected Her a Few Times. The ‘Wish’ Director Just Kept Trying.
abstract: After she was finally hired by the studio, Fawn Veerasunthorn worked her way up the ranks, and has applied that lesson of perseverance to her new film.
lead_paragraph: At the turn of the century, a young medical student in Thailand mailed a handwritten letter to a Disney animator in Florida.

headline: The History of the Cuban Sandwich
abstract: An illustrated look at how the pressed sandwich became storied in Tampa, Fla., Miami and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Follow New York Times Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and Pinterest. Get regular updates from New York Times Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.

headline: How 1.2 Million Marijuana Arrests Will Shape New York’s Legal Market
abstract: A new map illustrating 42 years of marijuana arrests documents the way that New York disproportionately targeted working-class, Black and Hispanic people for decades.
lead_paragraph: For young Black men like Justin Sullivan, growing up in Harlem in the 2000s came with regular harassment from the police, making it risky to use marijuana. But when he started making white friends who also smoked weed, he learned that they were not under the same scrutiny.

headline: Chicken and Potatoes Everyone Will Love
abstract: This easy braise has a little heat and a lot to rave about, especially when paired with a simple avocado salad and a cozy rice pudding in this David Tanis menu.
lead_paragraph: For a cool-weather meal that feeds a crowd, consider a braise. Slow simmered and deeply flavored, it has a number of attractive qualities. For one thing, it benefits from steeping in its own juices; cooking it several hours ahead of serving, even a day before, is ideal. The flavors intensify, mature, strengthen.

headline: Georgia’s Liberal Organizers Warn of a Cash Crunch and Apathy
abstract: Cost-conscious shifts in strategy and a changed political landscape have stoked fears about the groups’ ability to keep delivering victories for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Since 2020, Democratic strategists and activists have fixated on how to expand their gains in Georgia, once a Republican stronghold and now a true battleground.

headline: High-Speed Police Chases Rise Near Texas Border, Leaving Locals on Edge
abstract: Many law enforcement agencies have curbed pursuits because of their inherent danger. But some Texas authorities see them as necessary for border security.
lead_paragraph: Jairo Lerma and several of his relatives placed a wooden cross in the dry grass along a Texas highway where his parents, on their way from Georgia to Mexico, died suddenly in a fiery crash with an oncoming car that was carrying migrants and fleeing a sheriff’s deputy.

headline: France Scoffs at an Englishman’s ‘Napoleon’
abstract: French critics considered Ridley Scott’s new biopic lazy, pointless, boring, migraine-inducing, too short and historically inaccurate. And that’s just to start.
lead_paragraph: The French do not like an Englishman’s rendition of Napoleon.

headline: Growing Numbers of Chinese Migrants Are Crossing the Southern Border
abstract: More than 24,000 Chinese citizens have been apprehended crossing into the United States from Mexico in the past year. That is more than in the preceding 10 years combined.
lead_paragraph: The surge of migrants entering the United States across the southern border increasingly includes people from a surprising place: China.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: A rom-com in space, a coming-of-age quest and a high-tech birthing plan are among the films worth checking out this month.
lead_paragraph: After three years of buddy banter and watching the same movies over and over, astronauts Adam and Jane, marooned on a busted ship, accept the fact that they won’t get back to Earth and finally give in to their mutual attraction. Of course that’s when their navigation system starts working again, enabling them to return home — where their spouses are waiting. Uh-oh. Does it count as cheating if you thought you were doomed?

headline: Powerful Forces Are Fracking Our Attention. We Can Fight Back.
abstract: Attention education is the most powerful thing we can do for ourselves, for one another, for democracy.
lead_paragraph: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention. But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions. High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.

headline: Relax, Electric Vehicles Really Are the Best Choice for the Climate
abstract: Electric vehicles really are better for the environment than hybrid vehicles that have both gas and electric motors.
lead_paragraph: It has been a bumpy few weeks for carmakers who sell electric vehicles, which are moving more slowly off the lot than they were earlier this year. What’s going on? It seems that American drivers may be more hesitant about E.V.s than automakers expected.

headline: There Are Better Ways to Talk With Your Kids About Santa
abstract: New psychological studies shed light on the matter.
lead_paragraph: As the holiday season approaches, many parents find themselves facing a tricky problem: how to talk about Santa Claus with their young children, especially as those children begin to develop doubts about Santa’s existence. When does a fun, fanciful tradition risk becoming harmful deception? How can parents — who typically play a large and active role in fostering a belief in Santa Claus — ease the transition to disbelief?

headline: The Very Good Reason People Like George Santos Lie About Nonsense
abstract: If you’re laughing, it’s working.
lead_paragraph: All politicians lie. So many people consider that idea self-evident that I’ve heard it deployed as both a defense of lying and a reason to disengage from our democratic system entirely.

headline: What Am I Thankful for This Year? Amazing Scientific Discoveries.
abstract: They could lead to fewer hospital-acquired infections, more kidneys available for transplantation and fewer greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: I’ll wager that the event of 2023 that will change our lives the most in coming years is not the sighting of a Chinese spy balloon, the failure of Silicon Valley Bank, the fall of Kevin McCarthy’s speakership or any of the other eruptions that transfixed us this year.

headline: New York’s Era of Overspending Ends With a Shudder
abstract: Fiscal reality is finally hitting the city. Will Mayor Adams make the right choices when cutting the budget?
lead_paragraph: After years of heady spending, the budget cuts announced by Mayor Eric Adams last week hit New York City like a punch to the gut: Most libraries would be closed on Sundays. The expansion of the city’s signature prekindergarten program would be delayed. So would efforts to improve New York’s notoriously dirty streets and keep rats at bay. The city’s police force would be pared down in coming years.

headline: This Easy Pantry Meal Puts Dreamy Pasta and Beans Front and Center
abstract: These two hardworking ingredients are at their best in this weeknight meal, laden with chile, lemon and garlic.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I decide to cook straight from the pantry, one of two things usually results: pasta or beans.

headline: Debates Over Words Amid War: ‘Antisemitism,’ ‘Anti-Zionism,’ ‘Apartheid’
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Charles M. Blow. Also: Expanding Advanced Placement classes; election lessons; America’s love of outlaws.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: As Cease-Fire Takes Hold, Some Gazans Attempt a Treacherous Return Home
abstract: Israel had warned Gazans not to move from the south to the north during the cessation of hostilities, feeding their fears of permanent displacement.
lead_paragraph: When the cease-fire in Gaza took effect early Friday morning, Palestinians across the Gaza Strip prepared to go back to the homes they fled to see if they were still intact, to check on relatives left behind and in some cases, to finally bury their dead.

headline: The Big Number: $985
abstract: Consumer spending has been strong this year, but retailers worry about shoppers' mood this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending has been strong this year, but retailers worry about shoppers' mood this holiday season.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 24, 2023
abstract: No corrections  appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 24, 2023.

headline: The Best Black Cake, a West Indian Delight, Starts at Home
abstract: For many in the Caribbean diaspora, there is no substitute for this deeply flavorful fruitcake.
lead_paragraph: By Thanksgiving week, every surface of Marva Adams-Miller’s Brooklyn home is crowded with bags of flour and brown sugar, bottles of spices and dried fruits soaking in buckets of liquor. Ms. Adams-Miller is one of an elite group baking Caribbean black cake in late fall and the Christmas holiday season and turning cultural need into entrepreneurial opportunity. From the end of October to Christmas week, Ms. Adams-Miller normally bakes black cakes eight to 10 hours daily, outside of her full-time job working with city youth.

headline: Turkey Raises Interest Rates to 40 Percent to Tame Runaway Inflation
abstract: The country’s central bank increased rates by 5 percentage points in an attempt to deal with the soaring cost of household necessities and the devaluing of the lira.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s central bank has raised interest rates to 40 percent, its highest level in nearly two decades, in a significant move to tame the country’s runaway inflation after the country’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, had previously defied economic convention by cutting rates to slow price increases.

headline: The Premier League Needs a Commissioner
abstract: Allowing clubs to block rule changes and money to delay punishments feeds the perception that the same rules do not apply to everyone.
lead_paragraph: Pete Rozelle’s immediate reaction could not accurately be described as unbridled enthusiasm. He was 33. He had, for the last three years, been the general manager of the Los Angeles Rams. He was suave, charming and well liked. But he was nevertheless starting to wonder whether running an N.F.L. football team was really the job for him.

headline: Audrey Salkeld, Pioneering Historian of Everest, Dies at 87
abstract: She trawled 56 boxes of forgotten archives, bringing to life mysterious figures from early expeditions on the world’s highest peak.
lead_paragraph: Audrey Salkeld, a pioneering historian of Mount Everest who herself made it to within 8,000 feet of the summit, died on Oct. 11 in Bristol, England. She was 87.

headline: Here’s what we know about the released Israeli hostages.
abstract: The first group of 13 Israeli hostages — all women and children — were handed over to Israeli officials on Friday, joining five others released or rescued earlier in the fighting.
lead_paragraph: After nearly seven weeks in captivity, 13 Israeli hostages abducted by Hamas and other groups during the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel were released on Friday as part of a deal that paused the fighting in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Bentley in Border Bridge Crash Was a Luxury Car Packed With Power
abstract: The 2022 Flying Spur could reach 60 miles per hour in four seconds. The couple who died inside were business owners from a town near Niagara Falls, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The car that exploded this week at a border bridge in Niagara Falls, N.Y., was a 2022 Bentley Flying Spur, the authorities said on Friday, an ultraluxury model capable of reaching a speed of 60 miles per hour in four seconds.

headline: Sean Combs Accused of Sexual Assault by a Second Woman
abstract: The rap mogul denied a rape accusation made in a new lawsuit that was filed days after Mr. Combs settled another suit in which the R&B artist Cassie had accused him of abuse.
lead_paragraph: The producer and music mogul Sean Combs was accused of sexually assaulting a woman in 1991 in a lawsuit she filed on Thursday, a week after he settled a suit that accused him of raping and physically abusing Cassie, an R&B singer once signed to his label.

headline: Can I Skip My 100-Year-Old Father’s Wedding? He’s Making a Big Mistake.
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to show up for loved ones, even when we don’t agree with their choices.
lead_paragraph: My 100-year-old father is about to marry a 75-year-old woman who is a three-time widow. He met her in church, and after one month I believe she pressured him to get married. My siblings and I are all against the wedding. I’ve spent more time with our father than my siblings have over the past five months, during their courtship, and I’ve seen firsthand many red flags. For example, my father loves tennis (he played on his 100th birthday), but now, because his girlfriend is jealous of him playing with other women, he’s stopped doing so, and is beginning to show signs of decline. We’ve discussed the potential problems associated with a 25-year age difference, but he doesn’t believe that his girlfriend would do anything to harm him because she is religious.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Faces Sex Abuse Suit From Ex-Aide Who Says He Groped Her
abstract: The aide, Brittany Commisso, is bringing the case under the Adult Survivors Act, which permits people who say they were abused long ago to seek redress. Mr. Cuomo denied wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Brittany Commisso, a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York who accused him of groping her in late 2020, is suing him under the state’s Adult Survivors Act for what she described as “pervasive abusive conduct,” according to court papers.

headline: Biden says ‘the chances are real’ that the pause could open the door to a longer cease-fire.
abstract: Asked if he trusts Hamas to uphold its end of the deal, Mr. Biden said, “I don’t trust Hamas to do anything right. I only trust Hamas to respond to pressure.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden called the release of 24 hostages by Hamas on Friday “only a start, but so far it’s gone well.”

headline: Terry Taylor, First Woman Named Sports Editor of The A.P., Dies at 71
abstract: She brought a relentless management style to the wire service’s sports department for 21 years, supervising its coverage of sports around the world.
lead_paragraph: Terry Taylor, who as the first — and only — woman to be named the sports editor of The Associated Press brought a tireless management style to covering the Olympics, the World Cup and leagues and teams worldwide, died on Nov. 14 at her home in Paoli, Pa. She was 71.

headline: For Tiny Village Near Gaza, Some Hostages Return, but More Are Still Missing
abstract: Of the 13 Israeli hostages released from Gaza on Friday night, 12 were from a single farming village: Kibbutz Nir Oz.
lead_paragraph: All but one of the 13 Israeli hostages released on Friday were abducted from Kibbutz Nir Oz, an Israeli village close to the Gaza border where Hamas militants took more than 70 people on Oct. 7.

headline: X May Lose Up to $75 Million in Revenue as More Advertisers Pull Out
abstract: Internal documents show companies like Airbnb, Coca-Cola and Microsoft have halted ads, or may do so, after Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory.
lead_paragraph: X, the social media company formerly known as Twitter, could lose as much as $75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year as dozens of major brands pause their marketing campaigns after its owner, Elon Musk, endorsed an antisemitic conspiracy theory this month.

headline: First Group of Hostages Released by Hamas Is ‘Only a Start,’ Biden Says
abstract: President Biden expressed hope that the four-day truce between Israel and Hamas could open the door to a longer cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: President Biden expressed hope that the four-day truce between Israel and Hamas could open the door to a longer cease-fire.

headline: William Casey, Who Uncovered Police Corruption, Is Dead at 78
abstract: He was the unsung investigator whose dogged undercover probe exposed the “Dirty 30” scandal in a Harlem precinct.
lead_paragraph: William M. Casey, a former New York City deputy police chief who was the unheralded hero of the “Dirty 30” corruption investigation, which ensnared one-sixth of the officers assigned to a West Harlem precinct, died on Nov. 9 at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y. He was 78.

headline: L.A. Pays Stylish Tribute to Born X Raised Founder
abstract: At the brand’s annual Sadie Hawkins Winter Formal, guests and entertainers paid tribute to Chris Printup, who died this year.
lead_paragraph: “I was inspired by Miami and Sour Patch Kids Watermelon,” said Cliftun, a musician and artist who was in a vibrant pink and green ensemble with some elegant fur. He added, “Spanto always commented on how I always came with crazy fur, so this is for my guy.”

headline: In West Bank, Cheers and Worries After Prisoners Are Released
abstract: Families that waited outside a prison for the release of people detained by Israel said the conflict in Gaza and the rising death toll had cast a pall over any celebration.
lead_paragraph: It was the moment the crowd outside the gates of Ofer prison just outside the West Bank city of Ramallah had awaited for hours: A large white bus carrying Palestinian prisoners and detainees exited the prison gates and made its way through the crowd around 8 p.m. Friday.

headline: In a Poignant Moment, Israelis Welcome Some Hostages Home
abstract: The return of 13 Israeli hostages out of more than 200 provided a glimmer of hope for a nation still traumatized by the Hamas assault of Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: Israelis waited all day Friday in nervous anticipation for a piece of good news and ray of light after seven weeks of collective mourning and trauma.

headline: First Captives Freed in Tense Gaza Truce Between Israel and Hamas
abstract: Hamas freed two dozen hostages, Israel released 39 imprisoned Palestinians, and more than 130 aid trucks reached Gaza over the first day of a tense, temporary truce after seven weeks of war.
lead_paragraph: Hamas freed two dozen hostages held in Gaza and Israel released nearly 40 imprisoned Palestinians on Friday, completing the first exchange in a tense, temporary truce that halted the fighting after seven weeks of war.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Detains 34 Pro-Palestinian Protesters at Macy’s Parade
abstract: The demonstrators, who briefly disrupted the Thanksgiving Day parade, were protesting Israel’s killing of civilians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department detained 34 demonstrators at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade who were protesting Israel’s killings of civilians in Gaza, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Waiting and Worrying Continue for Families of American Hostages
abstract: No Americans were released in the first day of the temporary cease-fire, but officials and families were hopeful they would be freed in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: Families of the Americans being held hostage by Hamas must wait longer to find out if their relatives will be among those released.

headline: Says Who?
abstract: Jeff Stillman makes a flashy Saturday debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a gorgeous grid from Jeff Stillman, who has constructed Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles for The Times but never a weekend or themeless crossword. Four lively span entries make a frame for the rest of the fill, which also somehow winds around the center of the puzzle.

headline: Betty Rollin, Who Wrote Candidly About Her Breast Cancer, Dies at 87
abstract: Coping with illness was the subject of a popular memoir, “First, You Cry.” In “Last Wish,” a best seller, she wrote about helping her mother end her life. She chose to end her own life as well.
lead_paragraph: Betty Rollin, a network news correspondent who described intensely personal life passages in two memoirs — “First, You Cry,” about being diagnosed with breast cancer and having a mastectomy, and “Last Wish,” in which she revealed that she had helped her pain-ravaged mother end her life — died on Nov. 7 in Basel, Switzerland. She was 87.

headline: Dean Phillips, Democrat Challenging Biden, Won’t Seek Re-election
abstract: Mr. Phillips, 54, a congressman from Minnesota, has called for a new generation of leadership in Washington as he mounts a long-shot bid against his party’s incumbent president.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, a Democrat who began a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden last month, said on Friday that he would not run for re-election next year.

headline: Surviving Winter in a Decimated Ukrainian Village
abstract: Winter in Ukraine’s eastern steppe brings an inescapable cold. The wind blowing through damaged homes, the shattered windows, the chill in your bones — it feels as if it will be permanent.
lead_paragraph: Winter in Ukraine’s eastern steppe brings an inescapable cold. The wind blowing through damaged homes, the shattered windows, the chill in your bones — it feels as if it will be permanent.

headline: Derek Chauvin Is Stabbed in Federal Prison, Minnesota Attorney General Says
abstract: Mr. Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted of murdering George Floyd during a 2020 arrest, was serving a sentence of more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted of murdering George Floyd during a 2020 arrest that set off a wave of protests, was stabbed at a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., on Friday, according to the office of Keith Ellison, the Minnesota attorney general.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Chinese Join Migrant Crush on U.S. Border
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “If you make it to the U.S., then you’re more likely than not to be able to stay. So it’s absolutely worth the chance of taking that risk.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 25, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 25, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 9 this weekend about a new reality competition show on Netflix misidentifies one of the producing studios of “Squid Game: The Challenge.” It is Studio Lambert, not Lambert Studios.

headline: Cockroaches and Mountains of Trash Plague Acapulco After Hurricane
abstract: Residents complain of rashes and stomach ailments as 666,000 tons of garbage overwhelm the city. Uncollected waste after natural disasters can lead to illnesses, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Below the shattered windows of the high-rise hotels in downtown Acapulco, people walk alongside towering hills of garbage bags filled with rotting food and debris, from mattresses to Christmas decorations. Volunteer firefighters from distant states clear the waste, wiping away swarms of cockroaches from their arms.

headline: Watching People Watch a Game. With 100,000 Friends.
abstract: Soccer fans are tuning out broadcasts in favor of watchalongs: streaming parties where you hear what you want to hear and see everything except the game.
lead_paragraph: With the lights adjusted and the cameras rolling, the production team gives Joe Smith his cue. In five seconds, he will be broadcasting live to a couple thousand people. Mr. Smith’s mind, though, is elsewhere. “Slate is definitely the best way to build a roof,” he mutters to his co-host, Jay Mottershead, as the countdown hits three. “All these years on, they haven’t topped it.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Can Divorce Be Affordable? Yes, but Only if Spouses Want It to Be.
abstract: There are ways to reduce the stress and expense of ending a marriage, but they require both parties to want to end the relationship civilly.
lead_paragraph: If there is an easy point of agreement in the emotional upheaval of divorce, it is that endless legal battles can break the bank.

headline: A Pop Star Filmed a Music Video in a Church. The Priest Was Punished.
abstract: The singer Sabrina Carpenter danced through Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Church. The Diocese of Brooklyn said it was “appalled.”
lead_paragraph: On Halloween, the pop star Sabrina Carpenter uploaded a music video to YouTube for her new song “Feather.” That was a Tuesday. By the end of the week, a Catholic priest had been stripped of his administrative duties because of it.

headline: Would You Pay $175,000 for a Luxury Bunker at the U.S. Open?
abstract: A new poll sent to previous luxury suite attendees tests the appetite for even more luxury options at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open has long catered to tennis fans of all stripes, from hedge fund moguls and celebrities eating rock shrimp in luxury suites to boozy subway-riding fanatics screaming from the top rows past midnight. The future may see that gap widen even more.

headline: How Tamron Hall Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Hall, the talk show host and author, has a lot on her plate: TV, fiction writing and her family. Somehow she still has time for her parrot, too.
lead_paragraph: Tamron Hall has a highly organized life — it’s how she manages to put on the “Tamron Hall” talk show five days a week while being present for her family and writing the occasional novel.

headline: ‘Rust’ Killing Forces Hollywood to Make Choices on Guns
abstract: Real guns or replicas? Blank fire or special effects? The killing of a cinematographer on a film set has some in the industry rethinking their approach to firearms.
lead_paragraph: Scott Reeder, the head of props on “Walker,” the TV revival about a gun-toting Texas Ranger, was planning for a scene in which a woman points a revolver at a captive when a new set of orders arrived: real guns would no longer be used in the production.

headline: Chapter 6: Struggle and Hope
abstract: Arti passed every test for her government job but still faced disappointment and a new set of challenges.
lead_paragraph: There are moments in life that stick in memory as a fulcrum between before and after.

headline: Magic Man: The Story of the Greatest Point Guard in N.B.A. History
abstract: Roland Lazenby’s big biography of Magic Johnson gives us a wealth of detail, a huge cast of characters and, in a way, the tapestry of our time.
lead_paragraph: MAGIC: The Life of Earvin “Magic” Johnson, by Roland Lazenby

headline: Despite Bans, Disabled Women Are Still Being Sterilized in Europe
abstract: Governments have declared the practice a human rights violation. But they have made exceptions that are divisive among parents, doctors and social workers.
lead_paragraph: Anita cannot speak or comprehend complex information. At 28, she communicates mostly with facial expressions and baby-like sounds. When excited, she washes her hands. When her periods cause cramping and pain, she moans and agitates, unable to understand.

headline: In This Atlanta Suburb, Teens Taste Freedom at 10 M.P.H.
abstract: In Peachtree City, Ga., golf carts are everywhere, giving young people in particular an early chance to take life by the wheel.
lead_paragraph: A regular golf cart has no turn signals, no radio, no protection from the elements other than a thin roof and rain flaps. Press the pedal to the floor and it can maybe — maybe — accelerate to 15 miles per hour.

headline: Gaza Civilians, Under Israeli Barrage, Are Being Killed at Historic Pace
abstract: Even a conservative assessment of the reported Gaza casualty figures shows that the rate of death during Israel’s assault has few precedents in this century, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Israel has cast the deaths of civilians in the Gaza Strip as a regrettable but unavoidable part of modern conflict, pointing to the heavy human toll from military campaigns the United States itself once waged in Iraq and Syria.

headline: My Elderly Neighbors Need Help, but There’s Only So Much We Can Do
abstract: When serious health issues, including dementia, make sharing an apartment building difficult, there are resources available to consider.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side. There is a rent-stabilized apartment on my floor occupied by an older couple who have lived here for 50 years and have serious health issues. This morning, one of the occupants, who has advanced dementia, opened my apartment door, which was briefly unlocked, and was standing in my living room! I was able to gently escort her back to her apartment. Building management said that they have spoken to the city’s adult protective services, which has investigated and declined to act. This is a terrible situation — there are no interested family members, and the couple is often unbathed and walking the halls. What can we do?

headline: Who Would Donald Trump Choose as His Running Mate?
abstract: While voting has yet to begin for the G.O.P. primary, Donald Trump has casually weighed the pros and cons of some contenders.
lead_paragraph: While voting has yet to begin for the G.O.P. primary, Donald Trump has casually weighed the pros and cons of some contenders.

headline: Sebastian Maniscalco’s Toughest Audience Is His Kids
abstract: “When they laugh, it blows away the feeling of 20,000 people,” says the comedian, who stars in the new Max series “Bookie.”
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Maniscalco sells out theaters riffing on his tight-knit Italian American family. Earlier this year, in the movie “About My Father,” Robert De Niro played his hairstylist dad — who tutored the actor in the art of applying highlights. He even pitched a series centered on his life to the sitcom creator Chuck Lorre.

headline: South Korea’s City of Books
abstract: With some 900 book-related businesses, Paju Book City, northwest of Seoul, is an intentional and euphoric celebration of books and the bookmaking process.
lead_paragraph: A satellite city 22 miles northwest of Seoul, South Korea, Paju is small, with a population of around half a million. The streets are quieter than those of the bustling capital, the air cleaner and the pace of life half a beat slower.

headline: Pina Bausch’s ‘Rite of Spring’ Takes Root in Africa
abstract: A company of dancers from across Africa perform Bausch’s canonical work around the world. “I’ve always felt that this was an African dance,” said Germaine Acogny.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Pina Bausch’s “Rite of Spring,” a woman in a wispy white shift walks up to a man and hands him a red dress, a look of terror in her eye. The woman has elected her destiny: To be the “chosen one,” the sacrificial victim who ensures the survival of the collective. But that doesn’t make the outcome any less brutal.

headline: It’s Holiday Window Season in NYC. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: In time for the December shopping season, Manhattan department stores have unveiled ornate displays.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s light it up!” the actress Jennifer Lawrence said on Monday night as she helped to reveal the holiday windows and kick off the annual lights show at Saks Fifth Avenue.

headline: DeSantis Faces Critical Decision on Cruise Ships in Key West
abstract: A campaign donor to Gov. Ron DeSantis wants to expand cruise ship operations in Key West, where voters have tried to restrict them.
lead_paragraph: Since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, when cruise ships filled with sickened passengers were blocked from U.S. ports, residents in Key West, Fla., have been trying to limit the size and number of vacation vessels on the tiny island, using the momentum created during the pandemic to argue for continuing restrictions on cruise vessels.

headline: When the Neighbors Are All Older, Too
abstract: Some seniors prefer age-restricted communities, while others want intergenerational living. There is little research to show which option is healthier.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Fitts loved her roomy house in suburban Atlanta. But after her children moved out, and the pandemic exacerbated the isolation she often felt as a divorced woman, she left for Latitude Margaritaville, a Jimmy Buffett-themed housing development in Daytona Beach, Fla., for those “55 and better.”

headline: Russia Bombards Kyiv With ‘Record’ Drone Assault, Ukraine Says
abstract: The aerial assault began early Saturday and continued past sunrise. Ukraine said its air defense teams had shot down nearly all of the explosive-laden attack drones.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a huge drone attack at Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, before dawn on Saturday, sending wave after wave of crewless aircraft packed with explosives toward a city that is home to around three million people.

headline: A Mayor Whose Past Informs His Approach to Homelessness and Addiction
abstract: Dan Carter, the mayor of Oshawa, Ontario, was a homeless addict from his teens until he was 31. Now he’s helping people who face those issues in his adopted city.
lead_paragraph: In Dan Carter, whom I profiled this week, Oshawa, Ontario, has a mayor with an unusual background. But the city faces a situation that is confronting many, perhaps most, Canadian municipalities: a growing population of homeless people, many with addiction and mental health issues.

headline: Shopping Mall Fire Kills at Least 10 in Pakistan
abstract: Fire safety is a persistent problem in Karachi, where construction has outpaced firefighting infrastructure and building code enforcement is lax.
lead_paragraph: A devastating fire engulfed a multistory shopping center in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Saturday, killing at least 10 people and injuring dozens more, officials said. The disaster drew attention to the continuing fire risks in a densely populated city where building codes are often ignored.

headline: Poultry Slam
abstract: A “This American Life” tradition: stories of fowl, real and imagined, and their mysterious hold over us.
lead_paragraph: During the highest turkey consumption period of the year, we bring you a “This American Life” tradition: stories of turkeys, chickens, geese, ducks, fowl of all kinds — real and imagined — and their mysterious hold over us.

headline: Behind the Book Review’s Best Books List
abstract: A conversation with the editors about the painstaking process of selecting the 10 Best Books of the year.
lead_paragraph: This past week, The New York Times Book Review published its list of 100 Notable Books of 2023. On Tuesday, a handful of those titles will be named the Review’s 10 Best Books of the year. The list is a closely guarded secret, the product of many months of passionate closed-door debate presided over by Gilbert Cruz, the editor of the Book Review, and Tina Jordan, his deputy.

headline: Why the Next Seven Weeks Are So Critical in the Race for President
abstract: The downward slide of once-mighty presidential candidates usually starts after Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is upon us. Which means that while Americans are recovering from an orgy of overeating and Black Friday shopping, the political world is easing into the next phase of the presidential election: primary crunchtime.

headline: Stephen Sondheim Doesn’t Want to Be Your Savior
abstract: Sondheim has been canonized, with revivals and revues everywhere. It’s a development he might have greeted with deep ambivalence.
lead_paragraph: It was on a late summer’s night in 2022, about eight months after his death, that I confirmed that Stephen Sondheim had turned into a holy ghost.

headline: ‘The Golden Bachelor’ Is a Fantasy. Aging in America Isn’t.
abstract: Why we’re captivated by the septuagenarian spectacle.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Nov. 30, the first “Golden Bachelor” will give out his final rose, and with it he’ll crown one lucky baby boomer as the winner of his heart.

headline: Who Was the Real ‘Shaved Woman of Chartres’?
abstract: An infamous victim of the postwar purges turned out to be a committed collaborator.
lead_paragraph: In August 1944, in a city near Paris, Robert Capa took a photograph of a woman cradling a baby in the middle of a jeering crowd, her head shaved and her forehead marked with a swastika.

headline: It’s OK to Never ‘Get Over’ Your Grief
abstract: Traditional mourning practices preserve a place for the dead among the living.
lead_paragraph: Queen Victoria wore black for the remaining four decades of her life after her beloved husband, Prince Albert, died in 1861. This mourning practice was still commonplace during the first decades of the 20th century but almost nonexistent by its end. My great-grandmother, who died in 1999, was the only person I knew who wore mourning black until her own death.

headline: The Only Way Forward
abstract: Coexistence for Israelis and Palestinians is possible and is the only alternative to violence.
lead_paragraph: It is said that wars end when both sides conclude they have nothing more to gain by fighting. By that logic, Israel and the Palestinians should have long ago agreed to the only solution that makes sense: separate states side by side. They’ve tried, again and again, but in this cauldron of religious passion and competing grievances, peace has always lost out. Is there any chance that things will be different when the guns fall silent this time?

headline: Two Novels by Renegade Women
abstract: Leah Greenblatt recommends “Meg,” by Theodora Keogh, and “The Glass Cell,” by Patricia Highsmith.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Americans Under 30 Don’t Trust Religion — or Anything Else
abstract: Why the shift away from organized faith seems a little different for young adults.
lead_paragraph: This is an addendum to a series about Americans moving away from religion. Read part one, part two, part three, part four and part five.

headline: Not Everything Has to Be Meaningful
abstract: Sometimes painful experiences are just painful. And that’s OK, too.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, I was blindsided by the sudden onset of obsessive-compulsive disorder and secondary depression. For the better part of a year, my days were consumed by intrusive thoughts and feelings of angst, dread and despair. It was a terrifying and disorienting ordeal.

headline: Cantaloupes Linked to Deadly Salmonella Outbreak, U.S. Says
abstract: Two deaths were reported in Minnesota, and the number of people sickened by salmonella has doubled since the outbreak was announced last week, federal officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two people have died in a salmonella outbreak linked to cantaloupes as cases have more than doubled since the outbreak was first announced last week, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.

headline: The Israeli hostages freed on Friday begin to reunite with their families.
abstract: The return to a normal life will be a long process, doctors say.
lead_paragraph: The 13 Israeli hostages freed on Friday after being abducted in the Hamas-led surprise attack last month have begun reuniting with their families, ending nearly seven weeks of uncertainty and fear over their fates in Gaza.

headline: A Doctor Who Left Russia Remembers the Pain of Antisemitism
abstract: Donations to The New York Times Communities Fund may be made online or with a check.
lead_paragraph: It was rare for Jewish women to practice radiology in post-Stalinist Russia, but that’s what Diana Amastis, now 95, did for most of her life in St. Petersburg in the 1950s and ’60s.

headline: Remains of World War II Tank Commander Identified After 79 Years
abstract: Second Lt. Gene F. Walker was killed in Germany in 1944, nearly three months after his daughter was born. She learned in July that his remains had been identified.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 79 years, Anne Walker Collingwood knew little about her father, an American soldier who died about three months after she was born while fighting near Hücheln, Germany, during World War II.

headline: Donors Give Over €300,000 for Immigrant Who Intervened in Dublin Stabbing
abstract: A Brazilian man stopped a stabbing that prompted one of the worst anti-immigrant riots in recent history. Many people in Ireland and beyond are saying thanks by buying him a proverbial pint.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of a knife attack in Dublin this past week that sparked Ireland’s worst anti-immigrant violence in recent memory, people in the country and beyond are celebrating a Brazilian immigrant who intervened to end the assault.

headline: André 3000’s Experiments With Flutes and Fame
abstract: The acclaimed rapper’s first solo album contains no rapping. What does this sharp creative turn reveal about its maker?
lead_paragraph: This month, André 3000 — half of Outkast, and one of the most innovative rappers of all time — made a tentative return to music with the release of his first solo album, “New Blue Sun.” It is … not a hip-hop album. Instead, André, who has regularly been spotted out and about playing one of several flutes, has released an LP of contemplative experimental music, in which he is a supporting character, not the star.

headline: It’s the Saturday After Thanksgiving. It’s Cookie Time.
abstract: Bookmark our collection of easy holiday cookies for fantastic gifts and gleeful snacking.
lead_paragraph: Hello, and happy Saturday After Thanksgiving! By now you’ve probably exhausted our collection of excellent Thanksgiving leftovers recipes, shredding the remaining white meat for a turkey potpie or, for something lighter yet fully restorative, Melissa Clark’s new turkey, farro and chickpea soup. So it’s time to turn our attention to the best part of the winter holidays. It’s time to make some cookies.

headline: Behind Johnson’s Rise, a G.O.P. Consumed by the Far Right
abstract: After their party was decimated in the 2008 elections, mainstream Republican leaders believed they could harness rising far-right populist forces. Instead, they were overrun by them.
lead_paragraph: The roots of the Republican crackup this fall that paralyzed the House, fueled the unexpected rise of Speaker Mike Johnson and now threatens to force a government shutdown crisis early next year lie in a fateful choice the party made more than a decade ago that has come back to haunt its leaders.

headline: No U.S. hostages are expected to be released in the next round, an official says.
abstract: American hostages are not likely to be among the second group of women and children freed by Hamas, an American official said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: American hostages are not likely to be among the second group of women and children freed by Hamas, an American official said on Saturday.

headline: Everybody Knows Flo From Progressive. Who Is Stephanie Courtney?
abstract: A polo shirt, a white apron and a retro hairdo changed an actor’s life forever.
lead_paragraph: One needn’t eat Tostitos Hint of Lime Flavored Triangles to survive; advertising’s object is to muddle this truth. Of course, Hint of Lime Flavored Triangles have the advantage of being food, which humans do need to survive. Many commodities necessitated by modern life lack this selling point. Insurance, for example, is not only inedible but intangible. It is a resource that customers hope never to need, a product that functions somewhat like a tax on fear. The average person cannot identify which qualities, if any, distinguish one company’s insurance from another’s. For these reasons and more, selling insurance is tricksy business.

headline: The Stabbing of Derek Chauvin: What We Know
abstract: The attack in an Arizona prison was the latest violent episode involving a high-profile inmate at a federal correctional facility.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted of murdering George Floyd during a 2020 arrest, was stabbed at a federal prison in Arizona on Friday, according to the office of Keith Ellison, the Minnesota attorney general.

headline: At Meta, Millions of Underage Users Were an ‘Open Secret,’ States Say
abstract: Meta “routinely documented” children under 13 on Instagram and collected their data, according to a newly unsealed complaint.
lead_paragraph: Meta has received more than 1.1 million reports of users under the age of 13 on its Instagram platform since early 2019 yet it “disabled only a fraction” of those accounts, according to a newly unsealed legal complaint against the company brought by the attorneys general of 33 states.

headline: Stabbing of Derek Chauvin Raises Questions About Inmate Safety
abstract: The former police officer was being held in a specialized federal facility for high-profile inmates. He is said to be likely to survive.
lead_paragraph: The stabbing on Friday of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd in 2020, at a special unit inside a Tucson, Ariz., prison is the latest in a series of attacks against high-profile inmates in the troubled, short-staffed federal Bureau of Prisons.

headline: Unvaccinated and Vulnerable: Children Drive Surge in Deadly Outbreaks
abstract: About 60 million “zero-dose children” have not received any vaccines and have aged out of routine immunization programs. Protecting them will require a costly vaccination blitz.
lead_paragraph: Large outbreaks of diseases that primarily kill children are spreading around the world, a grim legacy of disruptions to health systems during the Covid-19 pandemic that have left more than 60 million children without a single dose of standard childhood vaccines.

headline: Here’s what we know about the Israeli hostages released on Saturday.
abstract: A second group of 13 included six members of an extended family.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released a second group of 13 Israeli hostages on Saturday as part of a cease-fire deal, a day after it released another 13.

headline: Growth Spurts
abstract: Adam Wagner and Michael Lieberman’s collaboration invites solvers to take a mile.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Catherine Christer Hennix, Spiritual Drone Musician, Dies at 75
abstract: She fused her mathematical knowledge with minimalist sounds and global spiritual traditions, most notably in her 1976 composition “The Electric Harpsichord.”
lead_paragraph: Catherine Christer Hennix, a Swedish experimental musician and artist who fused minimalist drones, mathematical logic and global spiritual traditions into an approach she called “infinitary composition,” died on Sunday at her home in Istanbul. She was 75.

headline: Marty Krofft, 86, Dies: Created Fantastical TV Shows With Brother
abstract: With Sid Krofft, he produced children’s shows, like “H.R. Pufnstuf,” and prime time programs, including “Donny & Marie.”
lead_paragraph: Marty Krofft, who, with his brother Sid, created a string of television shows that captured audiences from Saturday morning to prime time, including fantastical children’s fare, like “H.R. Pufnstuf” and “Land of the Lost,” and variety shows, like “Donny and Marie,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 26, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 9 this weekend about a new reality competition show on Netflix misidentifies one of the producing studios of “Squid Game: The Challenge.” It is Studio Lambert, not Lambert Studios.

headline: What’s Your Dream Office Setup?
abstract: Offices look very different than they did a century ago, reflecting evolving workplace norms. What’s the best setup for you? Take our quiz to find out what your ideal office looks like.
lead_paragraph: Offices look very different than they did a century ago, reflecting evolving workplace norms. What’s the best setup for you? Take our quiz to find out what your ideal office looks like.

headline: Fire Season in Australia Starts, Early and Ominous
abstract: Though experts do not think that this season will be the worst yet, they also warn that the past is no longer a reliable guide to the future.
lead_paragraph: The warmest winter on record, followed by an unusually warm and dry spring. Hundreds of fires along Australia’s east coast, including one that razed 53 homes in Queensland. And last week, on the west coast, a raging blaze just over a dozen miles from the Perth city center was fueled by an unseasonably early heat wave and strong winds.

headline: The pause in fighting enters a third day.
abstract: Halfway through a four-day pause in fighting that so far has brought two swaps of hostages and prisoners, Israeli leaders faced a dilemma over whether to restart the war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip once the truce ends on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through a four-day pause in fighting that so far has brought two swaps of hostages and prisoners, Israeli leaders faced a dilemma over whether to restart the war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip once the truce ends on Tuesday morning.

headline: A Thai mother rejoices at learning her son is alive.
abstract: Watsana Yojampa spoke to her son after he was released by Hamas. There are at least 18 Thai citizens still being held hostage in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Watsana Yojampa had been waiting by the telephone for nearly two months, wondering whether she would get good news — or the worst possible message that a mother could hear.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: What Today’s Migrant Crisis Looks Like to a Holocaust Refugee
abstract: A firsthand account of arriving to New York City as one of the 140,000 Jewish refugees who fled postwar Europe.
lead_paragraph: Even with New York’s complicated history as a port for new arrivals, the photographs this summer of more than a hundred migrants sleeping shoulder to shoulder on the sidewalk outside the once-elegant Roosevelt Hotel in Midtown Manhattan were shocking. So were scenes of young migrants idling on sidewalks, stoops and park benches, desperate to work but legally prohibited from doing so.

headline: Girls Thrive in Many Sports. Now They’re Coming for Football, Too.
abstract: Last year, New York became one of eight states across the country that offer girls’ varsity flag football. The sport’s popularity has only grown.
lead_paragraph: Honesty Butler was not planning to go to college, let alone leave her home state of New York. She loved art class, but hated math and history. Art school was too expensive, so she began to give up on the idea of higher education entirely.

headline: From an Early Age, a Passion for Late-Night TV
abstract: Trish Bendix, who writes the Best of Late Night column, reflects on years of watching and covering talk shows that air after dark.
lead_paragraph: My earliest memories of late-night television shows are of the guests, not the hosts. In the late ’80s and early ’90s, before the omnipresence of the internet, celebrities could promote their movies or sitcoms on talk shows with wild, unfiltered antics. It was an era of late-night TV where anything could happen — and often did.

headline: ‘I Carried Him, Screaming, Through the Night Streets of the Village’
abstract: Crying on the train, an encounter with the wrong celebrity and more reader tales from this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Survivor
abstract: For 25 years, Maria Cornejo has been designing things her way. But independence has a cost.
lead_paragraph: Maria Cornejo, the Chilean American designer, got the call in June. She was at home in her sort of messy little white house in Brooklyn, she said, with her 18-year-old cat, Ziggy, and some very large ficus plants.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: 3 Takeaways From the Investigation Into Trump’s Pardon of Jonathan Braun
abstract: Mr. Braun was still under investigation by the Justice Department at the time of his pardon. Here are some key points about the case.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Donald J. Trump left the White House, The New York Times published a story about how one of his last acts as president had been to commute the 10-year sentence of Jonathan Braun, a marijuana smuggler who had ongoing legal problems and a reputation for making violent threats.

headline: An Exclusive Look at a Dictator’s End
abstract: After Benito Mussolini was executed by Italian partisans, a Times reporter in Europe raced to send proof to New York.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, boy, have I got something special,” Daniel T. Brigham (1909-1990), a New York Times reporter in Bern, Switzerland, shouted into a radiophone when he reached The Times’s headquarters on the evening of Sunday, April 29, 1945.

headline: A Troubling Trump Pardon and a Link to the Kushners
abstract: A commutation for a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun had broader implications than previously known. It puts new focus on how Donald Trump would use his clemency powers in a second term.
lead_paragraph: Even amid the uproar over President Donald J. Trump’s freewheeling use of his pardon powers at the end of his term, one commutation stood out.

headline: Members of Congress Head for the Exits, Many Citing Dysfunction
abstract: More than three dozen incumbents have announced they will not seek re-election next year. Some are running for other offices, while others intend to leave Congress altogether.
lead_paragraph: Eleven are running for the Senate. Five for state or local office. One for president of the United States. Another is resigning to become a university president. And more and more say they are hanging up their hats in public office altogether.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Why Some Love Carols, Others Like Silent Night
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “For some of us, that’s an inspiring message. For others of us, it just draws in stark relief how far we are from achieving that.”

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ Film: 4 Takeaways From the Premiere
abstract: The star skipped the red carpet and slipped into the celebrity-filled screening on Saturday night. But the movie pulls back the curtain — a little.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of her new concert documentary, “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé,” Beyoncé states that she’s tired of being a “serial people-pleaser.” Since she was a child, she says, she has been striving for stardom, but now that she’s on top of the world and two years into her revelatory 40s, it’s time to recalibrate.

headline: Another Battle Royale in the Windsor War
abstract: In “Endgame,” Harry and Meghan’s sympathetic biographer, Omid Scobie, takes on the in-laws — and takes no prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Early on in “Endgame,” the journalist and royal commentator Omid Scobie makes an enticing promise.

headline: To Beat Trump, Nikki Haley Is Trying to Speak to All Sides of a Fractured G.O.P.
abstract: Her campaign will test what political strategists and observers of her rise in politics have said is among her greatest political skills: an ability to massage her message to the moment.
lead_paragraph: To beat former President Donald J. Trump in the coming months, Nikki Haley, his former ambassador to the United Nations, must stitch together a coalition of Republicans: Mr. Trump’s most faithful supporters, voters who like his policies but who have grown weary of him personally, and the smaller but still vocal contingent who abhor him entirely.

headline: The Envy Office: Can Instagrammable Design Lure Young Workers Back?
abstract: If your feed makes the corporate life look stylish, it’s just another evolution in the long history of the American workplace.
lead_paragraph: Inside the “blueberry muffin” conference room, the walls are, naturally, painted blue. Not just any blue — it’s the calming color you might find a baby’s bedroom, what the paint can refers to as “sea to shining sea.” Anchoring the room is a table, red and oblong, adorned with fake succulents in purple pots.

headline: Need Therapy? In West Africa, Hairdressers Can Help.
abstract: An initiative to train hairdressers in mental health counseling is providing relief to hundreds of clients in a region with the world’s least access to therapy.
lead_paragraph: Joseline de Lima was wandering the dusty alleys of her working-class neighborhood in the capital of Togo one day last year, when a disturbing thought crossed her mind: Who would take care of her two boys if her depression worsened and she were no longer around to look after them?

headline: Can Taiwan Continue to Fight Off Chinese Disinformation?
abstract: Ahead of a presidential election in January, Taiwanese fact checkers and watchdogs say they are ready for Beijing. But they are still worried.
lead_paragraph: Suspicious videos that began circulating in Taiwan this month seemed to show the country’s leader advertising cryptocurrency investments.

headline: Battle for Influence Rages in Heart of Wagner’s Operations in Africa
abstract: The death of the mercenary group’s leader has created a window of opportunity in the Central African Republic for Western powers to offer an alternative.
lead_paragraph: In palmier times, the leader of the Wagner group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, appeared at a Russian cultural center in the capital of the Central African Republic, sitting with schoolchildren and promising them free laptops.

headline: U.S. Troops Still Train on Weapons With Known Risk of Brain Injury
abstract: Pentagon researchers say weapons like shoulder-fired rockets expose troops who fire them to blast waves far above safety limits, but they remain in wide use.
lead_paragraph: A blast shattered the stillness of a meadow in the Ozark Mountains on an autumn afternoon. Then another, and another, and another, until the whole meadow was in flames.

headline: For New Music, There’s No Quartet Like JACK
abstract: Its stylistic range, precision and passion have made the group one of contemporary music’s indispensable ensembles.
lead_paragraph: “Can your hiccups be even bigger?” the composer Natacha Diels asked the JACK Quartet on a recent morning.

headline: Finding a Moral Center in This Era of War
abstract: “The idea that we must close our eyes to suffering that is not ideologically useful is morally degrading,” says the acclaimed author and military veteran Phil Klay.
lead_paragraph: “The idea that we must close our eyes to suffering that is not ideologically useful is morally degrading,” says the acclaimed author and military veteran Phil Klay.

headline: Antonia Bennett Used to Sing With Tony. Now She’s Carrying On Solo.
abstract: The crooner’s daughter is ramping up her music career once again, and plotting a new album. On Thursday, she’ll perform two sets at Dizzy’s Club in New York.
lead_paragraph: Antonia Bennett’s childhood had some unique charms. There were the parties, where the likes of Rosemary Clooney, Ella Fitzgerald and Mel Tormé would gather around the piano and sing. There were the times Bennett’s father, Tony, took her to work, beginning when she was about 5, and gave her an early taste of the spotlight.

headline: ‘We Went Back to the Stone Age’
abstract: Life in besieged Gaza revolves around a daily struggle to find food and water. With practically no fuel or coal, families are burning doors and window frames to cook what they can scrounge.
lead_paragraph: Nazmi Mwafi, 23, has one job, day in and day out: find water for his family.

headline: Here Are the Members of Congress Giving Up Their Seats, Setting Up a 2024 Fight
abstract: The fight for control of Congress could be heavily influenced by the already large number of members retiring or seeking higher office.
lead_paragraph: More than three dozen members of Congress have already said they are planning to leave their seats, setting the stage for major turnover in the 2024 election.

headline: Can a Rom-Com Make Sense in Dark Times? Yes, When It’s From This Master.
abstract: Aki Kaurismaki’s “Fallen Leaves” is both magical and despairing, born of what the Finnish auteur’s stars say is an unusual shooting approach.
lead_paragraph: There’s a detail in Aki Kaurismaki’s brilliant new gem of a comedy, “Fallen Leaves,” that I didn’t notice — even after two viewings — until one of its stars pointed it out to me. When the heroine goes to work as a dishwasher at a dingy Helsinki bar, there’s a shot of an oversize calendar. The year is 2024. “This is actually, you know, like a sci-fi film,” the actor Jussi Vatanen told me in a video call.

headline: Leaders of Attack on Sierra Leone Armory Arrested, President Says
abstract: President Julius Maada Bio said there had been “a breach of security” at a key military barracks in the capital, Freetown.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Sierra Leone said on Sunday that they had arrested most of the leaders of a thwarted effort to break into one of the West African country’s key military armories and barracks, hours after they had declared a nationwide, open-ended curfew in response to the overnight attacks.

headline: A Crossword Anniversary
abstract: A chat with Will Shortz, who has been editing The Times’s puzzle for 30 years.
lead_paragraph: Will Shortz celebrated his 30th anniversary as The Times’s Crossword editor this week. He is one of only four Crossword editors since 1942, when the paper began publishing puzzles as a way to offer relief to readers overwhelmed by war news. “It is possible there will now be bleak blackout hours — or if not that then certainly a need for relaxation of some kind or other,” Lester Markel, the paper’s Sunday editor, wrote to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, the publisher, two weeks after the attack on Pearl Harbor.

headline: Hamas Says Commander of Its Northern Gaza Brigade Is Dead
abstract: The group’s military wing, the Qassam Brigades, announced that Abu Anas al-Ghandour and three others had been killed. It did not say when.
lead_paragraph: Hamas, the armed group that controls Gaza, said on Sunday that one of its top commanders had been killed in its war with Israel there.

headline: How New Motherhood Changed Me as a Doctor
abstract: A silly story about sweet potato fries connected me to a patient’s family in a new way.
lead_paragraph: When I was pregnant and working in the intensive care unit, I disguised my growing abdomen with the largest fleece jacket I could find. It wasn’t just about my discomfort with my changing shape. There was something that felt incongruous — disrespectful, almost — about displaying the promise of unsullied new life amid all the tragedy.

headline: I Can Help Rebuild Gaza. First I Need to Survive Today.
abstract: I just fled Gaza after 50 days of war. But I know I’ll be back one day, to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: I was a young child, living in the Jabaliya area, in the north of Gaza, when I first saw an Israeli soldier up close. The Israel Defense Forces invaded the camp and our home. They stayed for three days. After that, I was afraid of Israelis. I always thought that they were coming to kill or kidnap me.

headline: Young Chinese Women Are Defying the Communist Party
abstract: Refusing to be pushed into traditional child-rearing roles, young women in China are quietly posing a challenge for its male-dominated government.
lead_paragraph: The pressure to marry began when Amiee was in her early 20s.

headline: Why Napoleon, Once Larger Than Life, Now Feels So Small
abstract: Napoleon’s story hasn’t changed. But in an age when many people feel buffeted by forces beyond their control, the notion of the Great Man struggles to inspire us.
lead_paragraph: “History,” the essayist Thomas Carlyle wrote in 1840, “is the biography of great men” — and of these Napoleon, whom Carlyle described as “our chief contemporary wonder,” was considered by many to be the greatest. The “Little Corporal” who became a general and then emperor, the revolutionary who toppled a dynasty only to found his own, turned rapidly after his death in 1821 into an international legend, admired and reviled in equal measure. The ambitious dreamed of emulating him; inmates of lunatic asylums believed they were him. And now we find him, some 200 years later, larger than life once again, on IMAX screens and in multiplexes in Ridley Scott’s new epic “Napoleon.”

headline: A Powerful Tool for Fighting Corruption Is Going Extinct
abstract: Local newspapers are failing. That’s a threat to democracy.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when road trips I took invariably included picking up local papers. I’d read from Page 1 through to the editorials and sports. They offered a screenshot of a small but real world — an ongoing scandal on the school board, a winning season at the high school, the death of a beloved teacher.

headline: Ukrainian Attack Cuts Power to Some Russian-Occupied Areas
abstract: The assault on energy infrastructure, a significant theater in the war, followed a large-scale Russian drone attack on Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian strike on a power station in Russian-held territory in eastern Ukraine overnight cut power to towns and cities, the pro-Russian authorities there said on Sunday, less than a day after Moscow launched a record number of attack drones toward Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.

headline: The New Face of a City of 50,000 People
abstract: Nadia Mohamed, the 27-year-old mayor-elect of St. Louis Park, Minn., says her win is just the first chapter.

headline: U.S. Hostage Might Be Released on Sunday, Top Biden Adviser Says
abstract: Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, said there was “reason to believe” an American would be among the next Hamas captives freed in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: At least one American citizen could be among the group of hostages Hamas is set to release on Sunday, Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, said on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Freed Israeli Hostages Share Details of Captivity, Relatives Say
abstract: Two days after the first batch of hostages was released, relatives who have spoken or met with them said they seemed to have been totally cut off from the outside world.
lead_paragraph: A mother released from captivity in Gaza with her young son told relatives that they had slept on chairs pushed together. An 85-year-old grandmother from a different family described counting the days to keep track of time.

headline: An Oratorio About Shanghai’s Jews Opens in China at a Difficult Time
abstract: “Émigré,” about Jews who fled Nazi Germany, debuts amid U.S.-China tensions and cultural rifts over the Israel-Hamas war. It comes to New York in February.
lead_paragraph: “Émigré,” a new oratorio about Jewish refugees who fled Nazi Germany for Shanghai in the late 1930s, begins with a song by two brothers, Josef and Otto, as their steamship approaches a Chinese harbor.

headline: What to Cook After You’ve Cooked Everything
abstract: Ginger-scallion steamed fish, squash and mushroom curry and lemony chicken breasts revive the palate, and are quick in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The guests are gone, let’s hope, and the house brought back to order after Thursday’s feast and a couple more epic meals behind it. You’ve consumed enough butter, starch and sugar to consider bearlike hibernation for the next week. This is not a day for fricassee.

headline: Should Biden Bow Out, as David Axelrod Urged?
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Maureen Dowd. Also: Speaker Mike Johnson’s lament; drive-through downsides; New Orleans drinking water.
