headline: American Girl Among Hostages Released on Sunday, Biden Says
abstract: “Thank God she’s home,” the president told reporters as he vowed to press for the release of more captives and an extension of the pause in fighting.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Sunday hailed the release of Avigail Idan, who turned 4 years old during her seven weeks in Hamas captivity and was the first American citizen to be freed by the group in recent days. The president vowed to keep working to secure freedom for others in captivity and extend the pause in the fighting.

headline: Prime Minister Netanyahu Visits Israeli Troops in Gaza
abstract: On the third day of a pause in fighting that was expected to continue until Tuesday, Mr. Netanyahu vowed to fight on “until victory.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel visited his country’s troops in the Gaza Strip on Sunday, three days into a pause in fighting there, and vowed that “we are continuing until the end — until victory.”

headline: Meet Charles Melton, the Breakout Star of ‘May December’
abstract: The ex-“Riverdale” star transformed himself for Todd Haynes’s new drama. As an actor, he’s caught between wanting to be seen and wanting to disappear.
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit it took me a while to notice the blood, which was wet and daubed onto his right cheekbone like a birthmark. In my defense, Charles Melton hadn’t noticed it either, even though the blood happened to be his.

headline: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Sunday
abstract: The group included several children, including a 4-year-old Israeli-American girl, and a Russian-Israeli who is the first man to be released.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released another 14 Israeli hostages on Sunday during the four-day pause in fighting with Israel, according to the Israeli government. The move came after an initial release of 13 Israelis on Friday followed by 13 additional Israelis late on Saturday.

headline: Millions Under Weather Alerts During Post-Thanksgiving Travel
abstract: Winter storm warnings were in effect for parts of Michigan on Sunday, while weather advisories were in effect for parts of the Midwest and Great Lakes region.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 14 million people were under various winter weather alerts on Sunday as a post-Thanksgiving snowstorm moved over the Rockies and Central Plains and travelers trekked home after the holiday, forecasters said.

headline: After 4-Year-Old Hostage Is Freed, Her Family Breathes a Sigh of Relief
abstract: Avigail Idan, a dual citizen of Israel and the United States, spent her fourth birthday as a captive after her parents were murdered in the Oct. 7 attack.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, she witnessed her parents’ murder, before being abducted. On Friday, nearly seven weeks later, she spent her fourth birthday while under captivity. And on Sunday, she was finally freed, as one of the hostages Hamas released under a deal with Israel.

headline: Monday Briefing: A 3rd Hamas-Israel Exchange
abstract: Plus an unusual mental health plan in Africa.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released 17 more hostages yesterday, including one American — Avigail Idan, who turned 4 on Friday, nearly seven weeks after her parents were killed in the Oct. 7 cross-border assault on southern Israel.

headline: Father Welcomes His Imprisoned Son Back Home in West Bank
abstract: A Palestinian prisoner freed on Sunday was paraded around his neighborhood in a 15-car motorcade after reuniting with relatives.
lead_paragraph: The father was glued to his television screen for days, anxiously watching the news to see if his 17-year-old son would be among those released from an Israeli prison as part of the deal struck between the Israeli government and Hamas last week.

headline: Biden to Skip U.N. Climate Summit, White House Official Says

headline: Portland Teachers’ Strike Ends After More Than Three Weeks
abstract: Portland students have struggled with absenteeism since the pandemic,
lead_paragraph: The union representing teachers, counselors and other school employees in Portland, Ore., reached a tentative deal with the city's public school district on Sunday, ending a strike that has kept nearly 45,000 students out of classes for more than three weeks in Oregon’s largest district.

headline: U.S. Navy Rescues Ship From Somali Pirate Attack
abstract: The United States says the episode is unrelated to regional tensions, though it is still investigating the firing of two missiles at the Navy ship involved in the rescue.
lead_paragraph: The five gunmen who attacked a chemical tanker in the Gulf of Aden on Sunday and were later captured by the U.S. Navy were Somali pirates, American officials said Monday.

headline: Female Rangers ‘Don’t Go All Alpha Like the Men’ to Protect a Forest
abstract: Rather than take a confrontational approach with trespassers looking to farm or log in a tropical rainforest in Indonesia, teams of women rangers try dialogue first.
lead_paragraph: Riding her motorbike while balancing a backpack, a wok and a sharp cleaver, Asmia expertly maneuvered her way up a dangerous cliffside: a three-mile trip along a precipitous dirt path, barely 40 inches wide, to reach the mouth of the forest.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: A third day of hostage exchanges in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Hamas, the armed group that controls Gaza, released 17 more hostages, including a 4-year-old girl, and said it would seek to extend a temporary cease-fire with Israel. The current four-day pause is scheduled to end today. An additional 39 Palestinians in custody were freed on Sunday, according to Israel’s prison service.

headline: Trapped in a Tunnel for 15 Days, With No End in Sight
abstract: The effort to rescue 41 construction workers in India has faced repeated setbacks. Now the authorities are trying to drill vertically through a mountain.
lead_paragraph: Over the two weeks that dozens of Indian construction workers have been trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the authorities have reported meter-by-meter progress toward reaching them and offered hopeful timelines for their rescue. Each time a breakthrough has appeared imminent, politicians have rushed to the scene.

headline: Car Crash Victims Seek Justice in a New Way: Talking to the Drivers
abstract: Circles for Safe Streets encourages New York drivers who hit people to take responsibility. Those who were injured can speak directly to those at fault.
lead_paragraph: Bill Penny was the center of attention in a tense room. It had been about nine months since he drove the wrong way down a one-way road in Brooklyn, hitting and critically injuring a woman who was crossing.

headline: Huge Turbines Will Soon Bring First Offshore Wind Power to New Yorkers
abstract: New York’s best bet for entering the era of offshore wind power is stacked up at the water’s edge in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: The pier on the Connecticut coast is filled with so many massive oddities that it could be mistaken for the set of a sci-fi movie. Sword-shaped blades as long as a football field lie stacked along one edge, while towering yellow and green cranes hoist giant steel cylinders to stand like rockets on a launchpad.

headline: A Final Wave of Sex-Abuse Lawsuits as One-Year Window Closes in New York
abstract: Since the Adult Survivors Act was passed, more than 3,000 civil suits have been filed, some aimed at politicians and others at institutions including hospitals and jails.
lead_paragraph: In the year since a one-time window opened in New York State allowing people to file sex-abuse lawsuits even after the statute of limitations had expired, more than 3,000 civil suits have been filed.

headline: When They Were Going Through Hell, They Kept a Record
abstract: Lauren Grodstein’s new novel takes place in the Warsaw ghetto, where a secret group of archivists made sure the truth survived.
lead_paragraph: Two decades before World War II, Lauren Grodstein’s great-grandparents fled Poland’s capital city and the antisemitism that was already ascendant there. “In all likelihood,” she writes in the afterword to this accomplished sixth book, “I would not be here had they stayed.” A chilling what-if, an idea for a book. More than a century after those ancestors escaped to safety, Grodstein gives voice to the doomed denizens they might have become.

headline: An Ancient Solution to Our Current Crisis of Disconnection
abstract: Rhetorical training is tantamount to installing the operating system for adult social life.
lead_paragraph: At the risk of sounding mawkishly positive, I think I’ve discovered a cheap, simple fix for our fraying social, emotional and political health.

headline: ‘My Patient Did Not Have to Die the Way She Did’
abstract: We need to create a gold standard of care to treat patients with peripheral artery disease.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2021, a soft-spoken woman in her 60s came to the emergency room where I worked, complaining of pain in her foot. When I examined her, I could see that I would need to amputate the infected leg immediately, or she risked sepsis and death. I amputated her leg that night. She died 14 months later.

headline: Round and Round We Go: Circular Strolls Near London
abstract: A handy guidebook outlines 27 bucolic walks outside the British capital that begin and end at train stations. We tried some out.
lead_paragraph: When is walking in circles a good thing? When following a trail through villages, forests and fields using open-access paths that begin and end at the same train station.

headline: Can Certain Foods Really Reduce Your Cancer Risk?
abstract: You won’t find a silver bullet in a single food, experts say, but there are some that may help you build the best defense.
lead_paragraph: On average, more than one in three people in the United States will develop cancer at some point in their lifetime, according to the American Cancer Society. And many of those cases, they say, can potentially be prevented, including by making changes to your diet.

headline: At the Montauk Lighthouse, a Restored Beacon Shines Again
abstract: A lens made in 1902 has been returned to the lantern room atop the lighthouse, which was commissioned by George Washington.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll find out why a crucial component in the oldest lighthouse in New York State has just been replaced with one manufactured in 1902.

headline: Russian Women Get a Fresh Warning About Their Rights
abstract: Expressing feminist views in Russia is now an increasingly dangerous thing to do.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than six months since the Russian playwright Svetlana Petriychuk and the theater director Zhenya Berkovich were arrested and jailed for their work on “Finist, the Bright Falcon,” an acclaimed play sympathetic to women recruited by ISIS.

headline: Is There Such a Thing as a ‘Useless’ College Major?
abstract: Would you consider pursuing a degree in a field you love even if it wouldn’t necessarily lead to a well-paying job?
lead_paragraph: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

headline: How Cave Canem Has Nurtured Generations of Black Poets
abstract: The poets’ fellowship, which was founded in 1996, has worked with poets who have gone on to win many of the genre’s most important accolades.
lead_paragraph: The poet Cornelius Eady took out his phone the other day and clicked to a black-and-white group photo that was taken 43 summers ago when he was a fellow at Bread Loaf, the famous writers’ retreat held each year in Vermont. Eady is easy to spot — he is the only Black person in the picture.

headline: Mars Needs Insects
abstract: If humans are ever going to live on the red planet, they’re going to have to bring bugs with them.
lead_paragraph: At first it was just one flower, but Emmanuel Mendoza, an undergraduate student at Texas A&M University, had worked hard to help it bloom. When this five-petaled thing burst forth from his English pea plant collection in late October, and then more flowers and even pea pods followed, he could also see, a little better, the future it might foretell on another world millions of miles from Earth.

headline: How the Biden Administration Took the Pen Away From Meta, Google and Amazon
abstract: The administration isn’t letting the tech giants write the rules of global trade. Good.
lead_paragraph: One reason that the idea of free trade has fallen out of fashion in recent years is the perception that trade agreements reflect the wishes of big American corporations, at everybody else’s expense.

headline: The Ceramists Putting a Fresh Spin on Traditional Korean Techniques
abstract: In reinvigorating the craft’s rich history, a group of female Korean and Korean American artists are creating a body of wholly distinct work.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based ceramic artist Eun-Ha Paek’s pieces are defined by their renegade spirit. A recent work, a foot-high stoneware form, resembles a child’s stick-figure drawing, but with a Surrealist bent: Instead of a head, it has a blue-and-white delftware-style dinner plate; instead of eyes, there are painted butterflies. “I like combining serve ware with food shapes, as if elements of a meal had come together and were having a dinner party,” says Paek, who builds her works’ hollow extremities, including legs that look like hot dogs, with a machine called an extruder and molds other parts by hand before coating the finished forms with cobalt and iron oxide washes and glazes. The pieces reflect Paek’s training in animation, film and video at the Rhode Island School of Design — now in New York, she teaches ceramics at Doclay and at Greenwich House, and illustration at the Parsons School of Design — as well as her upbringing. Born in Seoul, she immigrated to Los Angeles with her family when she was 9 and was dazzled by the new culture she encountered there. “The first place we went was to a drive-through for hamburgers,” she says. “I think my parents saw it as a symbol of having made it, to live in a country where food was brought to your car.”

headline: Introducing: ‘DealBook Summit’
abstract: This new podcast features a selection of interviews from the 2023 DealBook Summit event, hosted by Andrew Ross Sorkin.
lead_paragraph: “DealBook Summit” includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

headline: Trump Has a Master Plan for Destroying the ‘Deep State’
abstract: We should all be paying careful attention to the former president’s plans for a second term.
lead_paragraph: I study government bureaucracies. This is not normally a key political issue. Right now, it is, and everyone should be paying attention.

headline: Jesse Armstrong Still Has ‘a Lot of Sympathy’ for the Roys
abstract: In an interview, the “Succession” creator looked back on the end of the show and discussed Marxism, extreme wealth and whether any of his characters were remotely likable.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Armstrong didn’t always know how “Succession” would end. But he knew how that ending would feel. “It was always a bit about human mortality and the mortality of these kinds of media operations,” he said. As early as the pilot, he added, “I knew what the tone of the ending would be.”

headline: Let’s Talk About Biden, Trump and … Taylor Swift
abstract: Do any of them deserve to be Time’s person of the year?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, Gail. Peggy Noonan had a terrific column last week in The Wall Street Journal, making the case for why Taylor Swift should be Time’s person of the year. Aside from the fact that her Eras tour transformed the economy of many of the cities in which she played, she also spoke to the hearts and souls of millions of Swifties — including my two daughters — and spread joy, romance and glamour across the fair land.

headline: In Countdown to Iowa, Trump Is Coasting, as DeSantis and Haley Clash
abstract: The former president’s chief rivals are running low on time to make a statement in Iowa’s caucuses, which could determine whether the Republicans’ nominating contest is seriously contested at all.
lead_paragraph: Negative mailers are overstuffing Iowa mailboxes. Attack ads are cluttering the airwaves. And door knockers are fanning out from Des Moines to Dubuque and everywhere in between.

headline: Why Biden’s Weakness Among Young Voters Should Be Taken Seriously

After arriving in Brooklyn, they slept on a leaky air mattress in an apartment they shared with Khosrovian’s family.

headline: Nom Nom Nom. What’s the Deal With Cookie Monster’s Cookies?

headline: Storm Batters Southern Ukraine, Spreading Misery for Civilians and Soldiers
abstract: Violent waves stirred by hurricane-force winds threatened to tear maritime mines from their moorings in the Sea of Azov and the Black Sea.

The storm, which Ukrainian meteorologists said was among the most intense in decades, snarled supply routes for both countries’ armies and deepened the misery of tens of thousands of soldiers huddled in shallow trenches across the sprawling front line.

headline: Could Biden’s Clean Energy Push Be a Victim of Its Success?
abstract: Thanks to the president’s signature legislation, solar energy manufacturing is booming in Georgia, a key state in the 2024 election. But the industry now worries that it could be too much and too fast.
lead_paragraph: Dalton, Ga., was once known as the carpet capital of the country. Economic diversification meant branching out from wall-to-wall to hardwood flooring. Now, at Qcells, a solar panel company, robots patrol acres of shop floor where delicate solar cells are packaged, laminated and boxed into sophisticated panels — almost 30,000 a day at peak production — in a highly automated production line.

headline: Trial Starts in France for Teenagers Accused of Helping Teacher’s Killer

headline: X Has Become a ‘Global Sewer,’ Mayor of Paris Says

lead_paragraph: Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris, announced Monday on X, formerly Twitter, that she was quitting the social media site because it had devolved into a “gigantic global sewer” for disinformation, hatred, anti-Semitism and racism, and a “tool for destroying our democracies.”

headline: Emma Corrin Has a Mystery to Solve
abstract: The actor has worked steadily since breaking out as a young Princess Diana in “The Crown.” Corrin’s latest role is as an amateur sleuth in “A Murder at the End of the World.”
lead_paragraph: “I have no idea what I like,” Emma Corrin said.

headline: Former Coal Towns Get Money for Clean-Energy Factories
abstract: An Energy Department program designed to create jobs and manufacturing in communities reliant on fossil fuels is backing projects in West Virginia, Colorado and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.

headline: Vermont Man Charged With Attempted Murder for Shootings of Palestinian Students
abstract: Jason J. Eaton, 48, of Burlington, was charged with shooting three college students of Palestinian descent on Saturday outside the building where the police said he lives.
lead_paragraph: A 48-year-old Vermont man was charged on Monday with three counts of attempted second-degree murder in the weekend shooting of three young men of Palestinian descent on a Burlington street, a violent episode that stunned the small city.

headline: Young Thug’s YSL RICO Trial: What to Know
abstract: Hip-hop collective or street gang? In a blockbuster case against the famed Atlanta rap crew YSL, headed by Young Thug, prosecutors say it is both.
lead_paragraph: When the racketeering and gang conspiracy trial of Jeffery Williams, best known as the chart-topping rapper Young Thug, began on Monday in Atlanta, the star defendant had been in jail for 567 days.

headline: On a Single Day, Two Men Are Cleared in Decades-Old Manhattan Murders
abstract: Jabar Walker and Wayne Gardine were convicted in an era of crime and corruption that has created a wave of exonerations years later.
lead_paragraph: The killings happened eight blocks apart within nine months, near the height of New York City’s crack wars, in a Harlem precinct that was becoming synonymous with police corruption.

headline: Eurostar to Suspend Amsterdam to London Service for 6 Months
abstract: The no-transfer rail connection from the Dutch capital to London will close starting in June. A new terminal for Eurostar passengers is set to open at Amsterdam’s main rail station in 2025.
lead_paragraph: Direct train service from Amsterdam to London on the Eurostar, the sleek, fast train that connects Britain to northwestern Europe, will be suspended for six months next year, the train company said.

headline: On the Border, the Perfect Burrito Is a Thin, Foil-Wrapped Treasure
abstract: Despite a culinary rivalry, the sister cities El Paso and Ciudad Juárez can agree that a simple burrito is the best burrito.
lead_paragraph: One bite of a chile verde con papas burrito at Burritos Sarita in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, has the power to shatter whatever preconceived notions you have about burritos. In it, a pillowy-soft flour tortilla, with hints of smoke from the griddle, swaddles a fragrant mix of tender potatoes, caramelized onions and fire-roasted chile verde that is coated in a salty and tangy thick crema.

headline: Heavy Snow Blankets Western and Northern New York
abstract: The storm was bringing nearly two feet of snow in some areas.
lead_paragraph: Heavy snow coated parts of northern and western New York on Tuesday as a lake-effect snowstorm continued to wallop the region, causing hazardous travel conditions and closing schools.

headline: Profiles of Change: For 7 Women, a Heartfelt Cause Became a Mission
abstract: Leaders from around the world explained how they took their passions and concerns and turned them into action.
lead_paragraph: A financial administrator with deteriorating sight seeks help at an advocacy organization for visually impaired people and rises to become its chief executive. A former government spokeswoman with a love of cooking starts a restaurant to train refugees in culinary skills. A Lao weaver hoping to preserve a traditional craft creates a way to support it. Seven women from around the world explain how they took their passions and concerns and turned them into action. The interviews were edited and condensed.

headline: Arizona Legislators Must Testify About Voting Laws, Supreme Court Rules
abstract: Two Republican lawmakers had argued that they could not be questioned about their motives for supporting the laws, which require proof of citizenship to vote in federal elections.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that two Arizona lawmakers must testify about their reasons for supporting state laws requiring proof of citizenship for voting in federal elections.

headline: Stephen Colbert Cancels ‘Late Show’ Episodes After Rupturing Appendix
abstract: Colbert posted on social media that he was recovering from surgery and unable to host this week.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert canceled his “Late Show” episodes for the week as he recovers from surgery for a ruptured appendix, he announced on Monday.

headline: We Know War Is Awful, So Why Is It Making a Comeback?
abstract: Leaders can’t always avoid war, but being rational helps.
lead_paragraph: The two bloodiest wars of the past two years have been results of tragic miscalculations. A third war, which has dominated the news lately, might also have been set in motion by a costly mistake, as I’ll explain. To economists, this raises a question: If wars are so awful, why do we keep blundering into them?

headline: Justices Search for Middle Ground on Mandatory Sentences for Gun Crimes
abstract: A federal law imposes a mandatory 15-year sentence for possessing a gun after committing three serious drug offenses. But which offenses count?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday over which drug offenses trigger mandatory 15-year sentences under the Armed Career Criminal Act, which is a kind of federal three-strikes law.

headline: Biden Campaign Aims to Weaponize Trump’s Threat to Obamacare
abstract: The president’s aides quickly jumped on a statement by Donald Trump that he was “seriously looking at alternatives” to the health law.
lead_paragraph: Very few events bring aides on President Biden’s re-election campaign more joy than when former President Donald J. Trump threatens to repeal popular Democratic policies.

headline: The Good Old Days of Book Publishing, Martinis and All
abstract: “Among Friends” is a history of an industry transformed by consolidation and shifting tastes.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most stressed-out young people in the United States, if movies can be believed, work in publishing. IMDb, the online database, yokes these films together as a genre.

headline: N.Y. Cannabis Board Settles Suits, Paving Way for Dispensaries to Open
abstract: Regulators agreed to a settlement that would save 436 retailers from losing their licenses.
lead_paragraph: The New York State cannabis board voted Monday to approve a settlement that would resolve two lawsuits and end a three-month-long freeze on recreational dispensary openings across the state.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 27, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 27, 2023.

headline: Feed a Crowd With This Rich Ube Babka Wreath
abstract: Hanukkah cookies, free hot chocolate and other sweet food news.
lead_paragraph: A glazed, sugared round of twisted babka becomes a dazzling holiday wreath by Kora, a Filipino bakery in Long Island City, Queens. The filling woven throughout the brioche dough is the rich deep violet of puréed ube, the Filipino purple sweet potatoes. The babka is made in collaboration with Umamicart, an online Asian supermarket based in Brooklyn, which sells it and ships nationally. The plump wreath, 10 inches across, will serve at least 12. Just have some whipped cream or ice cream alongside or accompany it with leche flan.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: A Deal to Extend the Gaza Truce

lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas agreed yesterday to extend their fragile truce for two more days, according to officials in Qatar who helped negotiate the initial cease-fire.

headline: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Monday

headline: Biden’s Absence at Climate Summit Highlights His Fossil Fuel Conundrum
abstract: The president is facing some pressure to focus on oil drilling and gas prices at home, while boosting climate ambition on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed the country’s first major climate law and is overseeing record federal investment in clean energy. In each of the past two years, he attended the annual United Nations climate summit, asserting American leadership in the fight against global warming.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Military Is Slow to Act on Risky Arms
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 27, 2023.

headline: A Palestinian Activist, Ahed Tamimi, Faces Indefinite Detention
abstract: She is one of the highest-profile Palestinians arrested by Israel in its post-Oct. 7 crackdown. The military has moved to keep her jailed without charge, though she could also be freed in a hostage swap.
lead_paragraph: It was around 4 a.m. when Nariman Tamimi’s daughter, Ahed, roused her from sleep and told her that Israeli soldiers had surrounded their home in the occupied West Bank.

headline: 5-Year-Old Boy and Parents Are Stabbed to Death in Bronx Building
abstract: The child and his mother were found in their apartment, and the boy’s father lay dead in a hallway. Police investigators were questioning a relative.
lead_paragraph: A 5-year-old boy and his mother were found fatally stabbed in their Bronx apartment on Sunday, and the boy’s father was found stabbed to death in the hallway.

headline: Hamas and Israel Extend Cease-Fire for 2 Days, Qatar Says
abstract: The extension, and another exchange of hostages and prisoners, raised hopes that more people would be set free and more humanitarian aid would reach people in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas agreed on Monday to extend by two days a cease-fire that has brought a measure of calm to the Gaza Strip after seven weeks of intense warfare, the Qatari government said. The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and allow more aid into the beleaguered territory.

headline: Israel and Hamas Agreed to Extend Their Truce, Qatar Says
abstract: Also, Biden plans to skip the U.N. climate summit. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas agreed today to extend by two days a cease-fire that has brought a measure of calm to the Gaza Strip after seven weeks of intense warfare, according to officials in Qatar who were involved in the negotiations. The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and allow more aid into Gaza.

headline: Amid Parthenon Dispute, Sunak Cancels Meeting With Greek Prime Minister
abstract: After Kyriakos Mitsotakis called for the British Museum to return the Parthenon marbles, his British counterpart abruptly called off their meeting.
lead_paragraph: For the past two years, Greece’s government has conducted delicate negotiations with the British Museum hoping to secure the return of the Parthenon marbles, the ancient Greek antiquities brought to Britain in the early 19th century by Lord Elgin.

headline: Nikki Haley Is Coming for Your Retirement
abstract: Wall Street’s new favorite is far from a populist.
lead_paragraph: It feels like years ago, but actually only a few months have passed since many big Republican donors seemed to believe that Ron DeSantis could effectively challenge Donald Trump for the Republican nomination. It has been an edifying spectacle — an object lesson in the reality that great wealth need not be associated with good judgment, about politics or anything else.

headline: After Students Target Pro-Israel Teacher, Officials Try to Quell Outrage

lead_paragraph: New York City officials are investigating after hundreds of Queens high school students protested against a pro-Israel teacher, who was moved to another part of the building during the demonstration, the schools chancellor said Monday.

abstract: The plan would put Yellow back on the road with thousands of unionized drivers, but would force the government to wait longer for a loan repayment.

abstract: Effective drugs that have made the disease curable have yet to reach most  of the region.

headline: Tesla Sues Swedish Transport Agency in Dispute Over License Plates
abstract: The electric carmaker sued the agency to deliver license plates for its cars, the latest escalation as a labor fight enters its second month.
lead_paragraph: Tesla sued Sweden’s Transport Agency on Monday over a strike by postal workers that has blocked delivery of license plates for Tesla cars, the latest escalation of a widening battle between Sweden’s labor unions and the U.S. manufacturer of electric vehicles.

headline: In New Zealand’s Crackdown on Crime, What Part Can Maori Wardens Play?
abstract: The strategies used by the Indigenous community policing alternative are in stark contrast to more muscular tactics pitched by the incoming government.
lead_paragraph: As tempers flared on a recent evening in a nightlife district in Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, Joanne Paikea sensed an altercation — or even an arrest — brewing.

headline: Could a Drug Give Your Pet More Dog Years?
abstract: Longevity drugs for our canine companions are moving closer to reality. They also raise questions about what it might mean to succeed.
lead_paragraph: The life of a pet dog follows a predictable trajectory. Over time, the floppy-eared puppy that keeps falling asleep in his food bowl will become a lanky-legged adolescent with an insatiable interest in squirrels — before eventually settling into adulthood as a canine creature of habit, with a carefully chosen napping location and a well-rehearsed greeting ritual.

headline: Gold Bars and Tokyo Apartments: How Money Is Flowing Out of China.
abstract: Chinese families are sending money overseas, a sign of worry about the country’s economic and political future. But a cheaper currency is also helping exports.
lead_paragraph: Affluent Chinese have moved hundreds of billions of dollars out of the country this year, seizing on the end of Covid precautions that had almost completely sealed China’s borders for nearly three years.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and to allow more aid into the beleaguered area.

headline: How Geert Wilders Won
abstract: The Netherlands, where rural areas are losing physicians, bus stops and schools while urban areas thrive, is fertile ground for a demagogue.
lead_paragraph: A country where depopulating rural areas are losing physicians, bus stops and elementary schools while urban areas thrive is fertile ground for a demagogue — say, a politician who crusades against Islam, immigrants and the forces of globalization.

headline: New Zealand’s New Government Says It Will Scrap Smoking Ban
abstract: The law, celebrated as a model for other countries, would have eventually made tobacco illegal.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand’s new right-wing government has said it will repeal a law that would have gradually banned all cigarette sales in the country over the course of several decades.

headline: Giving Tuesday
abstract: How can you give back this year?
lead_paragraph: Nov. 28 this year is known as Giving Tuesday, a day when you are invited to take a break from buying things, and, instead, show generosity to others.

headline: Will Dyeing the Connecticut River Help Keep It Alive?
abstract: Hydrilla, a rapidly spreading invasive plant, is choking New England’s longest river. Government scientists are fighting back.
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut River faces a crisis: An aggressive invasive plant that grows in thick underwater mats is spreading swiftly.

headline: Even Most Biden Voters Don’t See a Thriving Economy
abstract: A majority of those who backed President Biden in 2020 say today’s economy is fair or poor, ordinarily a bad omen for incumbents seeking re-election.
lead_paragraph: Presidents seeking a second term have often found the public’s perception of the economy a pivotal issue. It was a boon to Ronald Reagan; it helped usher Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush out of the White House.

headline: Wife of Gilgo Beach Suspect Gets a Documentary Deal
abstract: Rex Heuermann is accused of killing three women. Where some saw depravity, others saw a chance to make a show.
lead_paragraph: After Rex Heuermann was arrested in July and accused of slaughtering women found bound in burlap and buried along a desolate stretch of Gilgo Beach, his family was left reeling and destitute.

headline: Ramboy
abstract: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.
lead_paragraph: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.

headline: ‘We Don’t Want to Let It Go’: A Family Farm in Ireland Prevails
abstract: On Achill Island in Ireland, Cian hopes to spend the summer playing soccer with his friends. But his grandfather thinks it’s about time to pass down a family tradition.
lead_paragraph: Ever since we were children, we’ve been fascinated by pastoralism. We both come from families with farming roots but grew up in the city. This enthusiasm brought us to Achill Island, off the west coast of Ireland, where sheep graze over the grassland.

headline: Now, What Was I Looking For?
abstract: Why your short-term memory falters, and how to make it better.
lead_paragraph: Q: Some thoughts vanish from my brain as soon as I think of them. Why can’t I remember things I just knew? And how can I improve my short-term memory?

headline: A French Thriller About a Kidfluencer Gone Missing
abstract: Delphine de Vigan’s “Kids Run the Show” skewers the phenomenon of parents exposing their children to the world for personal gain.
lead_paragraph: “You have to see it to believe it,” a police officer says of a mom vlogger’s YouTube channel in Delphine de Vigan’s agenda-setting literary thriller, which shines a light on the murky ethics of putting your family on social media. “Seriously, do people even know this exists?” It’s a pertinent question, because unless you have children, and carefully monitor their digital consumption, this billion-dollar industry could easily fly under your radar.

headline: The T Predictor: What We’ll Be Obsessing Over in 2024
abstract: We asked 46 artists, filmmakers, chefs and other creative people to forecast next year’s cultural trends. (Spoiler: We’re all going to be wearing a lot of brown.)
lead_paragraph: “Brown — the more ‘off,’ the better. It’s subtle and confrontational: Not a lot of colors have that versatility.” — Thebe Magugu, 30, fashion designer

headline: Where the Flavors of the Amazon Rainforest Delight
abstract: In the food-obsessed port city of Belém, sweet, savory and sometimes addictive dishes are made with fresh ingredients that are tough to come by in Rio de Janeiro, let alone outside Brazil.
lead_paragraph: A foreign visitor walking through Praça Brasil, a leafy square in the Amazonian port city of Belém, might think that the whirring blenders at a dozen nearby food carts were creating the most authentic açaí bowls on earth.

headline: They Fled Climate Chaos. Asylum Law Made Decades Ago Might Not Help
abstract: “We need protection,” one migrant at the U.S. border said. But the legal system for refugees never envisioned the millions displaced by global warming.
lead_paragraph: First came the hurricanes — two storms, two weeks apart in 2020 — that devastated Honduras and left the country’s most vulnerable in dire need. In distant villages inhabited by Indigenous people known as the Miskito, homes were leveled and growing fields were ravaged.

headline: A Giant Inland Sea Is Now a Desert, and a Warning for Humanity
abstract: The Aral Sea’s demise matters to us all.
lead_paragraph: Walking toward the shrinking remnants of what used to be the Aral Sea in Uzbekistan was like entering hell.

headline: A Piano With a Curved Keyboard Will Star at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The unusual piano, made in Belgium, will make its debut in Manhattan tonight. It’s more than a foot longer than a Steinway grand.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about the unusual-looking piano that will make its Carnegie Hall debut tonight. We’ll also find out about a poll that went to big spenders, as the United States Tennis Association considers whether to build suites costing $175,000 per person at the U.S. Open.

headline: Why Judges in the Trump Jan. 6 Trial Need a Rocket Docket
abstract: Voters could go to the polls in 2024 without knowing whether one of the candidates is criminally responsible for trying to overturn the last one.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for president in 2024, it’s now clear he will likely still have criminal indictments hanging over his head on Election Day. It’s possible that his criminal liability for the events leading up to the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol will remain unresolved.

headline: We Are Squandering One of the Most Important Medical Advances of the 21st Century
abstract: Congress has a chance to eliminate hepatitis C in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A little over a decade ago, I watched my brother in-law Rick Boterf die of complications from infection with the hepatitis C virus that took his health, his vibrant energy and ultimately his life.

headline: Americans Love Avocados. It’s Killing Mexico’s Forests.
abstract: Illegal deforestation for avocado crops points to a blood-soaked trade with the United States involving threats, abductions and killings.
lead_paragraph: First the trucks arrived, carrying armed men toward the mist-shrouded mountaintop. Then the flames appeared, sweeping across a forest of towering pines and oaks.

headline: What Role Does Humor Play in Your Life?
abstract: What makes you laugh these days?
lead_paragraph: It is often said that laughter is the best medicine. Do you agree? Why or why not?

headline: Vietnam Relied on Environmentalists to Secure Billions. Then It Jailed Them.
abstract: The government is preparing to present its energy transition plan at the U.N. climate talks as it intensifies a crackdown on environmental advocates.
lead_paragraph: When Vietnam was awarded a multibillion-dollar deal by a group of nine wealthy nations last year to work on reducing its use of coal, it agreed to regularly consult with nongovernmental organizations.

headline: Kids’ Books That Don’t Ignore the Dark Side of Life
abstract: It would be tempting to allow my son to believe in a world that will never betray him, but I want him to know better.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, I lost my heart to a peevish storybook turtle. This turtle — genderless, though for the sake of ease I’ll use “he” pronouns — might be forgiven for his mood. His days are riddled with mortal peril. In the watercolor milieu where he abides, boulders have a habit of plummeting from the sky, and a time-traveling Cyclopian monster roams the land.

headline: Can U.S.-China Student Exchanges Survive Geopolitics?
abstract: The flow of students between the countries has been a mainstay of their relationship, even when ties have soured. Now these exchanges, too, are under threat.
lead_paragraph: On a cool Saturday morning, in a hotel basement in Beijing, throngs of young Chinese gathered to do what millions had done before them: dream of an American education.

headline: At the Chicago Architecture Biennial, Artists Run Free
abstract: The directors, who are part of an art collective, wind up stretching architecture’s net in so many directions that it begins to fray.
lead_paragraph: Faheem Majeed, a member of the art collective the Floating Museum and one of the artistic directors of this year’s Chicago Architecture Biennial, was standing on a patch of soil on the South Side on a brisk, sunny afternoon last month. Next to him was the artist Erika Allen, a founder and the chief executive of Urban Growers Collective.

headline: U.S. Has Warned Israel to Fight More Surgically in Gaza, Officials Say
abstract: American officials have told the Israelis that a major bombardment risks sparking a humanitarian crisis that overwhelms the world’s capacity to respond.
lead_paragraph: The United States has warned Israel that it must fight more surgically and avoid further mass displacement of Palestinians in its war against Hamas to avoid a humanitarian crisis that overwhelms the world’s ability to respond, according to senior Biden administration officials.

headline: I Wanna Be Curated: Can You Really Put Punk in a Museum?
abstract: In Las Vegas, the answer is a resounding yes — and why not throw in a wedding chapel and a bar, too?
lead_paragraph: Fat Mike likes to be on time — to “put the punk in punctual,” as he says. So he was mildly distressed to be a few minutes late meeting me at the new Punk Rock Museum in Las Vegas, of which he is a founder and the public face. I had pleasantly cooled my heels at the museum’s bar, the Triple Down. At the Triple Down, you can order a Fletcher, a double rum and Coke served in an emptied Pringles can, named for Fletcher Dragge, guitarist for the band Pennywise and a member of the museum’s governing “Punk Collective.” (You get the chips on the side.) Or you might choose a Double Fatty, honoring Fat Mike himself: a double shot of Tito’s vodka, served with lime-flavored Liquid Death sparkling water and also a shot of Jameson. Fat Mike, as he told me within five minutes of his arrival, was a first-round investor in Liquid Death.

headline: Memorial Celebrates Rosalynn Carter’s Life, a ‘Public Love Story’
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter emerged from hospice care to join a cast of political heavyweights paying tribute to Mrs. Carter, who died at 96 last week at her home in Plains, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Her journey took her from the smallest of small towns in rural Georgia to the majesty of the White House, from the campaign trails of Iowa and New Hampshire to refugee camps in Asia and impoverished villages in Africa.

headline: A Convertible Apartment in Geneva
abstract: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the home can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the home can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”

headline: A Swiss Home So Well Designed It Needs Just One Door
abstract: Thanks to a series of pivoting panels, the Geneva apartment can be reconfigured for remote work or parties: “We only have one door, and that’s our front door.”
lead_paragraph: As their careers took them to various cities in Europe, the United States and Asia, Stef Claes and Michiel De Meulemeester, who are both Belgian, were used to leasing whatever lackluster apartments they could find. But when Mr. Claes, an architect, and Mr. De Meulemeester, a business executive who manages Mr. Claes’s firm, settled down in Geneva, they began thinking about creating a more appealing home.

headline: A Cartier Ring Inspired by the Work of a 20th-Century Style Icon
abstract: The piece evokes a 1938 interlocking gold cuff designed by the house’s then creative director, Jeanne Toussaint.
lead_paragraph: In 1847, Louis-François Cartier opened a modest jewelry workshop in Paris where he sold crystal bracelets, strands of pearls and brooches with floral motifs. Over the decades, his three grandsons, particularly the eldest, Louis Cartier, became known for mixing Old World craftsmanship and new techniques, as in the 1904 Santos pilot’s watch, named for a pioneering Brazilian aviator and decorated with tiny screws resembling airplane rivets; or the so-called mystery clock, a timepiece popularized by the brand in 1912 with jeweled hands that appeared to float (its rack-and-pinion gear system was hidden in the base).

headline: Fearful, Humiliated and Desperate: Gazans Heading South Face Horrors
abstract: Tens of thousands of Gazans are making the most difficult of choices, leaving their homes behind to survive.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Mellon Foundation Doubles Funding for U.S. Monuments, Pledging a Total $500 Million
abstract: The philanthropy will add to its ongoing initiative to tell diverse stories with new monuments in public spaces over the next five years.
lead_paragraph: Since 2020, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has spent nearly $173 million on 80 completed or ongoing monument projects across 37 states, supporting a broader and more diverse range of stories in the nation’s public spaces. On Tuesday, the arts and humanities philanthropy announced it would double its original commitment of $250 million over the next five years, pledging a total of $500 million for its Monuments Project.

headline: After More Than 2 Weeks, Rescue Arrives for Workers Trapped in Indian Tunnel
abstract: After repeated mechanical setbacks, the operation turned to trained miners using manual tools to clear the final stretch of debris.
lead_paragraph: After a 17-day effort to free dozens of Indian construction workers trapped inside a Himalayan road tunnel, rescuers finally cleared a path through debris on Tuesday and pulled the men out, ending an excruciating wait for the workers and their families.

headline: Russian Court Extends Detention of American Reporter
abstract: The decision means that the journalist, Evan Gershkovich, who has denied the espionage charge against him, will remain in custody until Jan. 30.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow court on Tuesday extended the pretrial detention of Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who has been held in Russia for nearly eight months on an espionage charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government vehemently reject.

headline: Israel-Hamas Truce Appears to Enter Another Day, and More
abstract: Plus, how money is flowing out of China and scientists are one step closer to a drug extending the lives of dogs.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: C.I.A. Director Arrives in Qatar for Talks on Hostage Releases
abstract: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. head, and David Barnea, who leads the Mossad, Israel’s spy service, are scheduled to meet with officials in Qatar, which has been mediating talks between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, arrived in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday for a new round of negotiations aimed at freeing more hostages held in Gaza, according to U.S. officials.

headline: Israel and Hamas’s Fragile Cease-Fire
abstract: How a grass-roots campaign for the return of hostages managed to pause the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Hostages are at the heart of the fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, now in its fifth day. As of Monday night, 50 Israeli hostages had been released, as had 150 Palestinian prisoners. More releases were expected on Tuesday, under what Qatari mediators said was a deal to extend the cease-fire by two days.

headline: Rob Reiner Teases Details of ‘Spinal Tap’ Sequel
abstract: Speaking on a podcast this week, the director said Paul McCartney and Elton John will appear in the film, among other real musical stars.
lead_paragraph: The director Rob Reiner has said that an upcoming sequel to his 1984 documentary parody “This Is Spinal Tap” is scheduled to begin shooting in late February and will feature Paul McCartney, Elton John and Garth Brooks, among other stars.

headline: A Strategic Dilemma
abstract: Israel’s leaders have big reasons to extend the temporary cease-fire — and big reasons to resume fighting.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas have extended their truce for two days — through tomorrow — which will bring the pause in fighting to six days. The deal is a sign that both sides have benefited from it.

headline: Germany to Override Debt Limit, Again, to Resolve Budget Crisis
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz pledged financial support for economic modernization and Ukraine, but will need backing for new borrowing to fill a spending gap.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz urged lawmakers on Tuesday to override Germany’s borrowing limits for a fourth consecutive year, allowing his government to take on billions of euros in fresh debt to modernize his country’s economy despite a budget crisis triggered by a constitutional court ruling.

headline: Shein’s Big I.P.O. Test
abstract: The fast-fashion giant is betting it can break the logjam of underperforming new listings, even as it continues to draw scrutiny from Washington.
lead_paragraph: In filing confidentially for an initial public offering, Shein, the ultrafast-fashion retailer, is showing ambition on two fronts.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Cease Fire, Sam Altman, C.T.E.
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 11 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 11 questions you can get right.

headline: The 10 Best California Books of 2023
abstract: These new works of fiction and nonfiction vividly render the state’s past and present.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, the end of 2023 is approaching.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2023
abstract: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s standout fiction and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: Every year, starting in the spring, we spend months debating the most exceptional books that pass across our desks: the families we grow to love, the narrative nonfiction that carries us away, the fictional universes we can’t forget. It’s all toward one goal — deciding the best books of the year.

headline: Inside Our List
abstract: Three New York Times Book Review editors share books from the “Best Books of 2023” list.
lead_paragraph: Three New York Times Book Review editors share books from the “Best Books of 2023” list.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A photo with an article on Monday about congressional retirements was published in error. The image of Carl Wilson, a former member of the Oregon House of Representatives, was included where an image of Representative Earl Blumenauer should have appeared.

headline: Koch Network Endorses Nikki Haley in Bid to Push G.O.P. Past Trump
abstract: The support will give Ms. Haley more organizational strength in the field as she battles Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for the No. 2 spot in the Republican presidential race.
lead_paragraph: The political network founded by the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch has endorsed Nikki Haley in the Republican presidential nominating contest, giving her organizational muscle and financial heft as she battles Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida to be the top rival to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Robert Battle Had a Wide Vision of What Alvin Ailey Could Be
abstract: Battle, the artistic director who brought Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater into a new century, resigned just before the company’s new City Center season.
lead_paragraph: When Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opens its annual season at New York City Center on Wednesday, it will be missing an important person: Robert Battle, the company’s jovial artistic director.

headline: Everybody’s Ejected After an N.H.L. Fight
abstract: All 10 skaters on the ice got a game misconduct in the Senators-Panthers game on Monday night in Ottawa.
lead_paragraph: Hockey is one of the most physical sports, and referees try to keep it in line by assessing penalties when a push or a trip goes too far. But on Monday night in Ottawa, the officials had enough.

headline: Wife of Ukraine’s Spy Chief Was Poisoned, Officials Say
abstract: Marianna Budanova, whose husband is the director of military intelligence, is recovering in a hospital, the officials said. Her husband has long accused Russia of trying to kill him.
lead_paragraph: The wife of Ukraine’s military intelligence chief has been poisoned and is recovering in a hospital, Ukrainian intelligence officials said on Tuesday, an incident that has led to widespread speculation that Russia was stepping up efforts to target Ukraine’s senior leadership.

headline: Hunter Biden Offers to Testify in House Inquiry, but Only in Public
abstract: The Republican chairman of the Oversight Committee quickly rejected the offer, saying the president’s son must first provide testimony behind closed doors.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, who is the subject of an investigation by House Republicans into his family, told Congress on Tuesday that he was willing to testify — but only publicly so that Republicans cannot twist or selectively leak what he says.

headline: NATO Leaders Try to Pin Down U.S. on Ukraine Aid as Republicans Waver
abstract: Continued American funding for Ukraine was a key concern for leaders in the military alliance, who met as the current allocation was running down and a Ukrainian counteroffensive appeared stalled.
lead_paragraph: With Republicans in Congress stalling on granting Ukraine more military aid, NATO’s top diplomat warned on Tuesday that it would be “dangerous” to curtail support to the war, as member countries tried to pin down the United States on its commitments to Kyiv and as the conflict in Gaza sapped Washington’s attention.

headline: Trump Seeks to Use Trial to Challenge Findings That 2020 Election Was Fair
abstract: The former president’s lawyers in his federal trial on charges of trying to overturn the election are asking to collect a wide range of evidence — including on unrelated issues like Hunter Biden.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said in court papers that they planned to question the findings of several government agencies that the 2020 election was conducted fairly as part of their efforts to defend Mr. Trump against federal charges that he sought to overturn the results of the race.

headline: Files Suggest Climate Summit’s Leader Is Using Event to Promote Fossil Fuels
abstract: A leaked document has talking points for the president of the United Nations climate conference, who is an oil executive in the United Arab Emirates, to advance oil and gas deals.
lead_paragraph: As the host of global climate talks that begin this week, the United Arab Emirates is expected to play a central role in forging an agreement to move the world more rapidly away from coal, oil and gas.

headline: Talking About the 10 Best Books of 2023
abstract: They’re here!
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year: After months of reading, arguing and (sometimes) happily agreeing, the Book Review’s editors have come up with their picks for the 10 Best Books of 2023. On this week’s podcast, Gilbert Cruz reveals the chosen titles — five fiction, five nonfiction — and talks with some of the editors who participated in the process.

headline: In Canada, a Judge Sentences an Incel Killer as a Terrorist
abstract: A Toronto teenager who killed a woman in a massage business was sentenced on Tuesday to life in prison. The case was the first time gender-based violence in the country was labeled terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The teenager was lying next to his bloodied sword when the police captured him outside a Toronto massage business where one woman had been stabbed to death and another seriously injured.

headline: Did That $4 Thrift Shop Painting Really Sell for $191,000? Nope.
abstract: A New Hampshire couple was quite happy when a rare N.C. Wyeth work they stumbled upon sold for so much at auction. But when the buyer reneged, the sale and their vacation dreams were undone.
lead_paragraph: To Tracy Donahue, the whole thing had felt like winning the lottery. And in a sense, she and her husband, Tom, had.

headline: Bold Flavors in Fast Dishes
abstract: Soba noodles in ginger broth and jerk chicken meatballs are satisfying swerves from the creamy casseroles and slow bakes of Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Hello, fellow home cooks. Genevieve here, filling in for Emily in the post-Thanksgiving, pre-holidays quiet.

headline: Gavin Newsom Wants Fox News Viewers to Hear Him Out
abstract: After sparring twice with Sean Hannity, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California will jump into the ring this week with Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. The stakes are high for both men.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Newsom has a scant history of tough debates over his two decades as governor and lieutenant governor of California and mayor of San Francisco.

headline: For Her Next Round, Toni Tipton-Martin Orders Up a Book of Cocktails
abstract: The author of “The Jemima Code” has distilled 200 years of African American drinking know-how into her new “Juke Joints, Jazz Clubs and Juice.”
lead_paragraph: While many in the world of cocktails are familiar with Tom Bullock, renowned for his juleps and long considered the first African American bartender to publish a cocktail manual, fewer know the work of Atholene Peyton, a home economics teacher whose 1906 “Peytonia Cook Book” predated Bullock’s by a decade.

headline: How to Watch the DeSantis-Newsom Debate
abstract: The unusual event, between a Republican presidential candidate and a high-profile Democratic governor who has been a surrogate for the Biden administration, will be moderated by Sean Hannity.
lead_paragraph: Fox News will host a 90-minute debate between Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday.

headline: How Mortadella Went From Cold Cut to Hot Item
abstract: Helped by its millennial-pink hue and the rise of the charcuterie board, the Italian specialty is winning a new fan base of American chefs and consumers.
lead_paragraph: By the standards of Bologna, Simona Scapin is a mortadella upstart. That’s not only because she’s young and the sole local producer of certified organic mortadella. Nor is it just because her family has been making mortadella for a mere four decades in the city where the recipe was ordained by papal authority in 1661.

headline: Italy Searches for Museum Leaders, With Nationalism in the Air
abstract: Last time the top jobs at some of the country’s most prestigious art institutions came up, many went to foreign candidates. This time, that’s unlikely.
lead_paragraph: For the past several weeks, dozens of candidates have been facing a five-person committee in a dark, book-lined room at Italy’s Culture Ministry, hoping to convince the panel that they should be selected to direct some of Italy’s top museums, including the Uffizi in Florence, the Capodimonte in Naples, the Brera in Milan and seven others.

headline: Helping Homeless People Who Are Mentally Ill
abstract: Responses to a Page 1 investigation. Also: An Oct. 7 observation; President Biden and the Israel-Gaza war; father, son and Jan. 6; planet Earth’s survival.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Stage Is Ours
abstract: Nearly 50 Jewish actors, playwrights and directors gathered at Broadway’s Lyceum Theater in September for T’s group portrait and reflected on what Jewish theater means to them.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 Jewish actors, playwrights and directors gathered at Broadway’s Lyceum Theater in September for T’s group portrait and reflected on what Jewish theater means to them.

headline: Amazon Introduces Q, an A.I. Chatbot for Companies
abstract: Amazon has been racing to shake off the perception that it is lagging in the push to take advantage of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI has ChatGPT. Google has the Bard chatbot. Microsoft has its Copilots. On Tuesday, Amazon joined the chatbot race and announced an artificial intelligence assistant of its own: Amazon Q.

headline: A Celebrated Street Food Market Will Return, in a Diminished State
abstract: After a city crackdown this summer, the vendors of Corona Plaza in Queens will return with far fewer stalls and hopes to expand.
lead_paragraph: Four months after New York City disbanded a celebrated but largely illegal street market in Queens that had exploded in popularity during the pandemic, the vendors are expected to return this week with far fewer stalls and, for now, none of the food that brought them acclaim.

headline: ‘Amid Falling Walls’ Review: Songs of Resilience From the Holocaust Era
abstract: A new musical from National Yiddish Theater Folksbiene stitches together music written and performed in Eastern Europe in the 1930s and ’40s.
lead_paragraph: With the war between Israel and Hamas keeping much of the world on tenterhooks, and the tide of antisemitism evidently rising, now is either a perfect time, or far too painful a time, for “Amid Falling Walls,” a new Yiddish-language musical set during the Holocaust.

headline: How to Watch the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree Lighting
abstract: The 91st annual celebration will take place on Wednesday and feature performances by Cher, Barry Manilow, Keke Palmer and others.
lead_paragraph: The Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center will be illuminated by more than 50,000 multicolored lights on Wednesday, kicking off a Midtown Manhattan holiday tradition that dates back to the 1930s.

headline: Finland to Close the Last Border Crossing With Russia for Two Weeks
abstract: Relations have deteriorated markedly since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the Finns accuse Moscow of orchestrating a flow of migrants in retaliation for Finland joining NATO.
lead_paragraph: Finland said Tuesday it was temporarily closing its only remaining open border crossing with Russia to stem an influx of asylum seekers that it accuses Moscow of orchestrating in retaliation for Finland’s decision to join NATO.

headline: Sierra Leone Announces Arrest of 13 Military Officials in ‘Attempted Coup’
abstract: The West African nation has not identified the military officials and one civilian it arrested after attacks in the capital on Sunday that left 20 people dead and more than 2,000 prisoners on the loose.
lead_paragraph: The small West African nation of Sierra Leone announced on Tuesday that it had arrested 13 military officials and one civilian in connection with a thwarted coup attempt on Sunday, when 20 people were killed and more than 2,000 prisoners were let loose.

headline: Hamburger America, From a Burger Documentarian, Opens in the Village
abstract: Partridge brings holiday cheer to the Standard, East Village, bars pop up for the holiday and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if, after publishing her flagship tomes, Julia Child had opened a French restaurant. George Motz has done something along those lines. The genial, whiskered filmmaker, a Long Island native, has spent decades chronicling the hamburger on TV, in guidebooks and cookbooks. He can now be seen pressing and seasoning onion-thatched portions of ground beef on the griddle at his first Hamburger America, a sunny restaurant with counter seats, booths and takeout, in SoHo. The restaurant’s name is that of his 2004 documentary film, a project that took him around the country researching hamburgers, and subsequent guidebook. In partnership with the owners of the Schnipper’s casual American restaurants, he serves a flattened fried onion burger with American cheese, and a classic smashburger with optional cheese and condiments, $7.25 for a single on a toasted, buttered potato roll, or $11.50 for a double. The meat is prime chuck, 75 percent lean. As for why the smashed burgers, they go back to what he says were the original hamburgers sold in the United States for more than 100 years. “I like history,” he said. There are fries, a few sandwiches, flavored milks including a chocolate egg cream, and Miller High Life, as well. Early next year he will invite guest hamburger makers from around the country on a monthly basis to serve their specialties. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Three Jewish Stage Luminaries Tell T a Joke
abstract: The comedian Alex Edelman, the playwright Paula Vogel and the actor and writer Harvey Fierstein share their favorite jokes.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Alex Edelman, the playwright Paula Vogel and the actor and writer Harvey Fierstein share their favorite jokes.

headline: Make Sure Your Google Accounts Are Active, or They Might Be Deleted
abstract: The company says it will start purging accounts, including services like Gmail and YouTube, that have been idle for two years or more.
lead_paragraph: If you have not used one of your Google accounts for a long time, you might want to this week. Inactive accounts will start vanishing on Dec. 1.

headline: Fed Officials Hint That Rate Increases Are Over, and Investors Celebrate
abstract: Stocks and bonds were buoyed after even inflation-focused Federal Reserve officials suggested that rates may stay steady.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials appear to be dialing back the chances of future interest rate increases, after months in which they have carefully kept the possibility of further policy changes alive for fear that inflation would prove stubborn.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Sailor Mother
abstract: A family struggles to pull their mom away from the call of the sea.
lead_paragraph: Sarah writes: My mother sails every weekend and often throughout the week. It’s not uncommon to try to plan a family event, only for her to ask that it be rescheduled to a time she wouldn’t prefer to be sailing, like nighttime or during a storm. Such events include my brother’s 40th birthday, baby showers and even my wedding. Please ask her to stop this.

headline: Poem: Settlement
abstract: The poem’s repetitions evoke the grim repetitions of history.
lead_paragraph: In Divya Victor’s “Settlement,” the poem’s repetitions evoke the grim repetitions of history. Even the poem’s prepositions are heavy and hard to bear. The string of “overs” that begin the poem are the “overs” of domination. The “we” of the poem are the “settled” who have become willfully insensate to history. They are left with the stark culmination of the Thanksgiving feast: a broken bone with no meat.

headline: Dolly Parton (Really) Rocks
abstract: “Rockstar,” the country icon’s new double album of rock songs, is now the highest charting LP of her career. But her history with the genre runs deep.
lead_paragraph: At age 77, and with nearly 50 (!) solo studio releases to her name, Dolly Parton just scored the highest charting album of her career, the mammoth double LP “Rockstar,” which debuted on this week’s Billboard 200 at No. 3. (Darn those young whippersnappers Drake and Taylor Swift for standing in the way of Parton’s first No. 1!)

headline: A Tragedy, a Symphony, a Love Story
abstract: This month, writer Suleika Jaouad revisits her second bone marrow transplant in the documentary “American Symphony.”
lead_paragraph: In the months following Suleika Jaouad’s second bone marrow transplant, her TikTok algorithm started serving her videos of bearded dragons shedding their skin. For a writer whose work deals in ambiguities, that metaphor was tidier than she’d have preferred.

headline: Rescuers Free 41 Workers Trapped in a Collapsed Indian Tunnel
abstract: The workers were trapped for more than two weeks after a landslide caused part of the tunnel they were building to collapse.
lead_paragraph: The workers were trapped for more than two weeks after a landslide caused part of the tunnel they were building to collapse.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Bringing Wine to a Party
abstract: Some hosts do not appreciate the gesture.
lead_paragraph: Adam writes: When we entertain, I tell people to bring nothing. What are we going to do with a bottle of wine? I don’t drink, and my husband prefers cocktails. When guests come proudly clutching some stupid gift, I berate them and force them to leave it in the car. My husband thinks this is severe.

headline: France to Ban Smoking in Forests, on Beaches and Near Schools
abstract: A government anti-smoking plan also includes costlier cigarettes and a ban on disposable vapes. Smoking is the leading cause of avoidable deaths in France.
lead_paragraph: France will ban smoking on beaches, near public buildings like schools and in public parks and forests next year, the French government said on Tuesday, as it unveiled plans to curb the habit by making it slightly more expensive and far less attractive, especially to younger people.

headline: Saudi Arabia to Host World Expo 2030, in Victory for Crown Prince
abstract: Winning the rights to host the major global event is a coup for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s efforts to remake the kingdom’s international image.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia won the bid to host the World Expo 2030 in a landslide on Tuesday, delivering a triumph to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, as he seeks to reshape the authoritarian country’s international image — and his own.

headline: Biden Navigates Divisions Over Gaza Inside the White House and Beyond
abstract: President Biden is facing deep anger over his solidarity with Israel among supporters and even from some staff members who have said they feel disenchanted with the president.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Democrats Pressure Republicans to Vote This Week to Expel Santos
abstract: A Democratic resolution to expel Representative George Santos aims to prevent Republican leadership from delaying action on the embattled congressman.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats on Tuesday moved to force a vote this week on whether to expel Representative George Santos of New York from office, a strategic effort to prevent Republican leadership from slow-rolling any bid to push one of their own out of office.

headline: Corporate America Has Dodged the Damage of High Rates. For Now.
abstract: Small businesses and risky borrowers face rising costs from the Federal Reserve’s moves, but the biggest companies have avoided taking a hit.
lead_paragraph: The prediction was straightforward: A rapid rise in interest rates orchestrated by the Federal Reserve would confine consumer spending and corporate profits, sharply reducing hiring and cooling a red-hot economy.

headline: Jean Knight, Who Struck Platinum With ‘Mr. Big Stuff,’ Dies at 80
abstract: Her anthem of female strength topped the Billboard R&B chart and reached No. 2 on the pop chart in 1971. Its appeal has endured.
lead_paragraph: Jean Knight, a soul singer whose memorable single “Mr. Big Stuff,” a brassy anthem of female strength, rose to No. 1 on Billboard’s rhythm and blues chart in 1971, died on Wednesday in Tampa, Fla. She was 80.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We’d Lost the American Dream’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: When we lost our apartment, my job and your nest egg in the 2008 recession, you suggested we move into your van and drive south to stretch the paycheck you earned online. It was just you, me and our dog. Then I got pregnant in Peru, and we continued on with our baby in tow to Patagonia. We’d lost the American dream, but through life’s twists, we found a different one, on the road. After 14 years, 23 countries and four continents, we ditched the van but are still chasing new horizons, redefining what it means to be “better-off.” — Stevie Trujillo

headline: Relatives describe the trauma of child hostages freed by Hamas.
abstract: Eitan Yahalomi, 12, was beaten and forced to watch videos from the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel, his aunt, Deborah Cohen, says.
lead_paragraph: Eitan Yahalomi, 12, was beaten and forced to watch videos from the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel, his aunt, Deborah Cohen, says.

headline: Eric Adams’s Top Fund-Raiser Is Out Amid F.B.I. Scrutiny and Raid
abstract: The mayor had previously suggested that he had no intention of replacing the fund-raiser, Brianna Suggs.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York said on Tuesday that the 25-year-old woman he had chosen to manage his political fund-raising was no longer working in that role, weeks after a search of her home by the F.B.I. revealed a federal investigation into his campaign and plunged his administration into turmoil.

headline: The Left Is Dooming Any Hope for a Palestinian State
abstract: A growing fraction of the progressive left is making common cause with some of the worst people on earth.
lead_paragraph: Do the people chanting “Free Palestine” and “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” have any idea of the irreparable harm they’re doing to any hope of Palestinian sovereignty?

headline: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Tuesday
abstract: The group of 12 hostages, most of them Israelis, is the first to be released under the extended cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released a group of 12 hostages on Tuesday, most of them Israelis or dual nationals but also including two Thai nationals, all of whom had been kidnapped during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 terrorist attacks in Israel.

headline: Wisconsin Judge Dismisses Felony Charge in ‘Ballot Selfie’ Case
abstract: The debate over a candidate’s photo reflects concerns among states over selfies of ballots and of people showing how they vote.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin judge on Monday dismissed a felony charge against a  school board candidate who had posted a photograph on Facebook of a ballot with his name filled in.

headline: Bidenomics and the Guys in the Bar
abstract: Yes, workers are better off than they were a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: Ten finance guys are drinking in a bar. Nine of them are Masters of the Universe — wheeler-dealers who make many millions of dollars every year. The tenth is what Gordon Gekko, in the movie “Wall Street,” called a “$400,000-a-year working Wall Street stiff.”

headline: A Gaza Truce Aids Both Sides. Until the Calculus Changes.
abstract: Both Israel and Hamas are reaping benefits from the cease-fire, but as the hostage-for-prisoner exchanges continue, Israeli leaders may feel growing pressure to resume the war.
lead_paragraph: The decision by Israel and Hamas to extend their brief truce has created short-term benefits for both sides but amplified uncertainty about how, when and whether Israel will continue its invasion of the Gaza Strip.

headline: Knowing When ‘They’ Means One
abstract: Saying “they wants” instead of “they want” could make our new usage of “they” easier to handle.
lead_paragraph: I have a proposal about our new usage of “they” to refer to individual people, as in, “Irene? Oh, they left an hour ago” or “Bernard cut themselves by accident.”

headline: What Makes a Vacuum Cleaner Sexy?
abstract: How Dyson’s cordless stick became a status symbol, a trophy of domesticity and a generational must-have.
lead_paragraph: When you imagine a life of luxury, what comes to mind? A mansion filled with walk-in closets the size of bedrooms? Garages housing sleek vehicles with German and Italian names?

headline: Wednesday Briefing: What to Watch at the U.N. Climate Talks
abstract: Plus how New Zealand’s Maori Wardens keep the peace.
lead_paragraph: Two facts loom over the COP28 U.N. climate talks, which begin tomorrow in Dubai: Earth is careening toward climate disaster, and governments are acting too slowly to avert it.

headline: For Sports Illustrated, Report About Fake Authors Is Latest Stumble
abstract: The venerable magazine has experienced management upheaval and staff complaints in recent years. Now there’s a question over who wrote product reviews on its site.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, journalists at Sports Illustrated were worried that the venerable magazine’s new owners and operators were drastically lowering its standards. They noted reports of plagiarism, and worried about substandard writing and the use of freelance reporters with little due diligence. The journalists also wanted better pay, greater transparency during the hiring process and a guarantee that all work published on the Sports Illustrated website would be edited.

headline: Pope Francis Cancels Trip to U.N. Climate Summit on Doctor’s Orders
abstract: Days after the pontiff was forced to slow down because of a flu, his doctors advised him to not travel to Dubai for COP28. Francis has made climate activism a hallmark of his papacy.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, following his doctor’s orders, will not attend the United Nations climate summit in Dubai later this week, the Vatican said Tuesday.

headline: Charles T. Munger, Much More Than Warren Buffett’s No. 2, Dies at 99
